“威廉·M·埃克斯 (William M. Akers) 打破了那句老话：不会教书的人，无所不能。他既是一位伟大的作家，也是一位伟大的老师——在我看来，这种结合就像摇马一样罕见。《你的剧本糟透了！》用清晰的语言阐述了大多数编剧从艰难的经历中学到但又不想让你知道的所有东西，因为你为什么要轻松呢？这本书是一部一生都在电影行业中学习的课程，由一个有智慧去观察、有天赋去理解、有慷慨去分享的人讲述——以天生的讲故事者的迷人和欺骗性的轻松方式展开。如果马克·吐温写剧本，这就是他写的建议书。”

“William M. Akers defies the old adage that those who can’t, teach. He’s both a great writer and a great teacher — in my experience a combination as rare as rocking-horse doo doo. Your Screenplay Sucks! lays out in crystal-clear language all the things that most screenwriters have learned the hard way but don’t want you to know, because why should you have it easy? This book is a lifetime of lessons in the screen trade recounted by someone with the intelligence to see, the talent to understand, and the generosity to share — laid out with the engaging and deceptive ease of a natural-born storyteller. If Mark Twain wrote screenplays, this is the advice book he’d write.”

— 乔恩·阿米尔（Jon Amiel），《歌舞神探》、《偷天陷阱》导演

— Jon Amiel, director, The Singing Detective, Entrapment

“如果你想要一本鼓励自己、让人感觉良好的写作书籍，请阅读《作家心灵鸡汤》。如果你想要了解好莱坞编剧的令人难以接受的、赤裸裸的真相，请阅读《你的剧本糟透了！》。

“If you want a pat-you-on-the-back, feel-good book on writing, read Chicken Soup for the Writer’s Soul. If you want the sucker-punch-you-in-the-throat, down-and-dirty truth about screenwriting for Hollywood, read Your Screenplay Sucks!”.

— 琳达·麦卡洛 (Linda McCullough)，芝加哥哥伦比亚学院

— Linda McCullough, Columbia College, Chicago

“这是一本关于编剧的书，读起来就像是一部优秀的剧本。书中充满了精彩的故事、例子和建议，让我爱不释手。”

“A book about screenwriting that reads like a good screenplay. It is so full of great stories, examples, and advice that I couldn’t put it down.”

— 汤姆·舒尔曼 (Tom Schulman)，奥斯卡获奖编剧，作品有《死亡诗社》、《亲爱的，我把孩子缩小了》、《鲍勃怎么样？》

— Tom Schulman, Academy Award–winning screenwriter for Dead Poets Society, Honey I Shrunk the Kids, What About Bob?

“这是一份深思熟虑的指南，可以帮助你走出困扰形式的众多创意死胡同。”

“A thoughtful guide to finding your way out of the many creative culde-sacs that bedevil the form.”

— John Requa， 《坏圣诞老人》、《坏消息熊》联合编剧

— John Requa, co-writer, Bad Santa, Bad News Bears

“这是一份精心编写的指南，可以帮助避免年轻或缺乏经验的编剧经常犯的错误……它是一本光明的指南，而光明正是我们所追求的。”

“A well-written recipe for avoiding the mistakes which young or inexperienced screenwriters often make... It is a luminous guide and light is, after all, what we are after.”

— 本尼迪克特·菲茨杰拉德，《智血》、《耶稣受难记》作者

— Benedict Fitzgerald, writer, Wise Blood, The Passion of the Christ

“不要太在意；你的剧本确实很烂。几乎所有的剧本都很烂，除非你把它们打磨好。威廉·M·埃克斯的书是一本很好的指南，可以帮助你避免初次写剧本的人遇到的陷阱和容易犯的错误。他的建议诚实而简单。只要你愿意努力，他会让你的剧本不那么烂。”

“Don’t take it personal; your screenplay does suck. Almost all screenplays suck until you beat them into shape. William M. Akers’s book is an excellent guide through the pitfalls and easy mistakes that first-time screenwriters face. His advice is honest and simple. He will make your screenplay suck less — as long as you’re willing to do the work.”

— 拉里·卡拉谢夫斯基 (Larry Karaszewski)，作家，曾参与创作《艾德·伍德：美国警探：人民公敌》和《月球上的人类》

— Larry Karaszewski, writer, Ed Wood, The People vs. Larry Flynt, Man on the Moon

“埃克斯在编写和修改剧本的过程中采取了直截了当、实事求是的方法。他直击问题的核心，直指问题所在，并简单地告诉你如何修复它。这本书太棒了。”

“Akers takes a straightforward, no-nonsense approach to the process of writing and fixing your screenplay. He cuts through the crap and gets right to the heart of what is wrong and simply tells you how to fix it. Fantastic book.”

— Matthew Terry，编剧、教师、 www.hollywoodlitsales.com专栏作家

— Matthew Terry, screenwriter, teacher, columnist for www.hollywoodlitsales.com

“在众多关于编剧的书籍中，威廉·M·埃克斯的《你的剧本糟透了！100 种让剧本更精彩的方法》无疑是其中的佼佼者。他所列举的 100 种方法从鼓舞人心到程序化再到实用性，但都非常有用。无论你还拥有哪些关于编剧技巧的书籍，这本书都应列在其中。”

“Among the many books on screenwriting, William M. Akers’ Your Screenplay Sucks! 100 Ways to Make It Great is a clear standout. His hundred ways range from the inspirational to the procedural to the minutely practical, but they are all inordinately useful. Whatever other books you own on the craft of screenwriting, this one needs to be among them.”

— 罗伯特·奥伦·巴特勒 (Robert Olen Butler)，普利策奖获奖作品《从你梦想的地方》的作者

— Robert Olen Butler, Pulitzer Prize–winning author of From Where You Dream

“我发现您反复说出了我一直对我认识的作家说的话。这也为我自己的工作提供了许多有用的提醒，这些提醒我都知道，但有时会忘记练习。您的方式直接清晰，您的例子有力且合乎逻辑。赞。”

“I repeatedly found you saying things that I’ve been saying to writers I know. It also provided me with many useful reminders for my own work, that I knew, but sometimes forget to practice. Your manner is direct and clear and your examples are strong and logical. Kudos.”

— Greg Beeman， 《超人前传》系列剧《英雄》执行制片人

— Greg Beeman, Executive Producer, Heroes, Smallville

“威尔的书是新手编剧的必读书籍。它不仅能帮助他们写出更好的剧本，还能写出更好、更商业化的剧本，从而增加电影制作人（以及阅读剧本的人）对剧本的兴趣。即使是经验丰富的编剧也可以从这本有趣且有教育意义的书中获取有用的建议。”

“Will’s book is a must for the novice screenwriter. Not only will it help them write a better script, they will write a better, more commercial script, increasing the odds that it will interest the people who make movies (and the people who read their scripts for them). Even experienced screenwriters can pick up helpful tips from this entertaining and edifying book.”

— 彼得·海勒 (Peter Heller)，洛约拉马利蒙特大学

— Peter Heller, Loyola Marymount University

“这是一本很棒的作家旅行指南，它敏锐地指出了‘应该避开哪些街区’。”

“It’s a terrific travel guide for the writer’s journey with a sharp eye on ‘which neighborhoods to avoid.’”

— Kevin Wade， 《上班女郎》和《遇见乔·布莱克》作家

— Kevin Wade, writer, Working Girl and Meet Joe Black

“伟大的编剧书籍以威廉·M·埃克斯的《你的剧本糟透了！》开始和结束！它不仅充满了关于编剧的精彩信息，而且读起来也非常不错。我在阅读过程中时而学习，时而大笑。对于严肃的编剧来说，这是一本必备书籍。”

“Great screenwriting books begin and end with William M. Akers’ Your Screenplay Sucks! Not only is it jammed full of terrific information on screenwriting, but it’s a damn good read as well. I was alternating between learning and laughing all the way through. A must have for the serious screenwriter.”

— 凯利·贝克， 《愤怒的电影制作人生存指南》作者

— Kelley Baker, author of The Angry Filmmaker Survival Guide

“威廉·M·埃克斯是电影界的文艺复兴者，他既是大制片厂的编剧，又是独立作家/导演，还是一位富有爱心、富有洞察力的老师。在修改剧本方面，他也知道书中的每一个技巧。这就是他想要的书！对于任何面临‘剧本暗夜’的作家来说，这都是必读之书。”

“William M. Akers is a renaissance man of film who is at once a big studio screenwriter, independent writer/director, and caring, insightful teacher. He also knows every trick in the book when it comes to fixing a script. And this is that book! A must for any writer facing the ‘dark night of the script.’”

— Blake Snyder，《救猫咪！》、《救猫咪！去电影院》作者

— Blake Snyder, author, Save the Cat!, Save the Cat! Goes to the Movies

你的剧本

太烂了！

Your Screenplay

Sucks!

 

100 种让生活更美好的方法

100 ways to make it great

作者：

威廉·M·埃克斯

by

William M. Akers

迈克尔·维斯制作公司

MICHAEL WIESE PRODUCTIONS

你的剧本太烂了！：让剧本变得精彩的 100 种方法 / 作者：威廉·M.埃克斯（William M. Akers）。

献给

我的老师

Bob Baldwin、Jim Boyle、Ken Robinson、John Truby

和

我的学生，

从他们身上我学到了很多。

没有你们，这本书就不会存在。

Dedicated

to my teachers

Bob Baldwin, Jim Boyle, Ken Robinson, John Truby

and

my students,

from whom I learned even more.

Without you, this book would not exist.

目录

Table of Contents

 

致谢

Acknowledgments

介绍

Introduction

第一幕：讲故事

Act I: Storytelling

 

主意

Idea

1. 您还没有写一些您关心的内容！

1. You have not written something you care about!

2. 你的想法缺乏创意！

2. Your idea isn’t vibrating with originality!

3. 您选错了类型！

3. You picked the wrong genre!

4. 你的故事只有你自己才感兴趣！

4. Your story is only interesting to you!

5. 你的故事讲的是悲惨的人，他们一生都很悲惨，最后结局也很悲惨！或者更糟！！

5. Your story is about miserable people who are miserable the whole time and end miserably! Or worse!!

6. 您没有花足够的时间来构思一个精彩的标题！

6. You haven’t spent enough time thinking up a fantastic title!

特点

Character

7.你选错了主角！

7. You picked the wrong main character!

8. 你还没有正确塑造你的主角！

8. You haven’t constructed your main character correctly!

9. 创建角色时，您并不需要具体指定所有事项！

9. You are not specific about EVERYTHING when you create a character!

10. 你还没有将“地点”塑造为你的故事中的一个角色！

10.   You haven’t made “place” a character in your story!

11. 我们对你的英雄不感兴趣！

11.   We have no rooting interest in your hero!

12.你的对手不是人！

12.   Your opponent is not a human being!

13. 你的坏人并不好！

13.   Your Bad Guy isn’t great!

14.对手不是英雄变革的推动者！

14.   The opponent is not the hero’s agent of change!

15. 坏人并不觉得自己是自己电影里的英雄！

15.   The Bad Guy doesn’t feel he’s the hero of his own movie!

16. 不要对坏人说坏人演说！

16.   You don’t give your bad guy a Bad Guy Speech!

17. 你的角色会做一些蠢事来推动故事的发展，也就是说，他们做这些事是因为你让他们这么做！

17.   Your characters do stupid things to move the story forward, a.k.a.   they do stuff because you make them!

18. 你的次要角色没有个性！

18.   Your minor characters don’t have character!

结构

Structure

19. 当你构思故事时，你担心故事的结构！

19.   You worried about structure when you came up with your story!

20.你的张力不够！

20.   You don’t have enough tension!

21. 你没有时间压力！

21.   You have no time pressure!

22.你没有给予读者足够的情感！

22.   You don’t give the reader enough emotion!

23. 你的故事结构很糟糕！

23.   You bungled your story structure!

24. 你还没有做，然后重做，再重做，一行提纲！

24.   You have not done, and then redone, and REDONE, a one-line outline!

25.你还没有做过《随想录》提纲！

25.   You have not done a “random thoughts” outline!

26. 你没有运用凯里斯·哈丁戏剧规则！

26.   You have not used the Kerith Harding Rule of Drama!

27. 你的 B 故事不会影响你的 A 故事！

27.   Your B story does not affect your A story!

28. 您没有充分利用“设置和还清”政策来为自己谋利！

28.   You don’t use Set Up and Pay Off to your advantage!

29. 你还没有像吉米·霍法那样埋没真相！

29.   You haven’t buried exposition like Jimmy Hoffa!

30. 您不会将惊喜保留到最晚！

30.   You don’t withhold surprises until as late as possible!

场景

Scenes

31. 你对每个场景的把握还不够！

31.   You haven’t pounded each scene enough!

32. 你的场景没有引起动作！

32.   Your scenes don’t turn the action!

33. 你的逆转还不够多！

33.   You don’t have enough reversals!

34. 你没有在每个场景前都大喊“我怎样才能激化冲突？！”

34.   You have not shouted at each scene, “How can I jack up the conflict?!”

35. 你还没有充分利用押韵场景的惊人力量！

35.   You have not used the incredible power of rhyming scenes to your advantage!

36. 你还没有从尽可能多的场景中删掉第一句和最后一句台词！

36.   You haven’t cut the first and last lines from as many scenes as possible!

37. 当你的角色可以和某人说话时，她会进行研究！

37.   Your character does research when she could be talking to somebody!

38. 你笔下的人物打电话太多了！

38.   Your characters talk on the phone too much!

39. 你并没有让每一个场景都令人难忘！

39.   You have not made every scene memorable!

对话

Dialogue

40. 你没有记录偷听到的对话！

40.   You don’t keep a log of overheard dialogue!

41. 你还没有分离人物的声音！

41.   You haven’t separated the characters’ voices!

42. 你的对话还不够深入！

42.   You haven’t worked your dialogue hard enough!

43. 你没有对对话进行 AB 处理！

43.   You didn’t A-B the dialogue!

44. 您有问答对话！

44.   You have Q & A dialogue!

45. 你笔下的人物只说正文，不说潜台词！

45.   You have characters speaking text but not subtext!

46. 你做了太多研究！

46.   You did too much research!

47. 你没有做足够的研究！

47.   You didn’t do enough research!

第二幕：物理写作

Act II: Physical Writing

 

欢迎来到写作

Welcome to Writing

48. 你没有接受过有关你选择的讲故事媒介的教育！

48.   You aren’t educated in your chosen storytelling medium!

49. 你使用了错误的书写工具！

49.   You’re using the wrong writing instrument!

50. 你的散文不够清晰！

50.   Your prose is not CRYSTAL CLEAR!

格式

Format

51. 你不懂剧本格式！

51.   You don’t understand screenplay format!

52. 你的 slugline 是裸露的，或者根本没有 slugline！

52.   You have naked sluglines or no sluglines at all!

53. 你对演员的指导过多了！

53.   You over-direct your actors!

54. 您使用括号错了！

54.   You use parentheticals wrong!

人物

Characters

55. 你给我们改了角色名！

55.   You change character names on us!

56. 你的角色中有太多名字了！

56.   Too many of your characters have names!

57. 角色名字以同一个字母开头！或者更糟的是，它们押韵！

57.   Character names begin with the same letter! Or WORSE, they RHYME!

58. 你没有用简洁、生动、两句左右的句子来描述主角！

58.   You do not describe main characters with a concise, telling, two (or so) sentence character description!

场景描述

Scene Description

59. 你的语言很新颖！

59.   You use novelistic language!

60. 你在场景描述中毒害了“是”！

60.   You poisoned your scene description with “to be”!

61. 你还没有尽可能地删去“thes”和“thats”！

61.   You haven’t cut as many “thes” and “thats” as possible!

62. 你没有把最重要的词放在句子的末尾！

62.   You don’t put the most important word at the end of the sentence!

63. 你在场景描述中描述对话！

63.   You describe dialogue in scene description!

64. 你在场景描述中没有注意图像顺序！

64.   You have not paid attention to image order in scene description!

65. 你还没有将场景描述删减到最精简的部分！

65.   You haven’t cut scene description to the bone!

重写

Rewriting

66.永远不要重复任何事！

66.   Don’t repeat! Anything! Ever!

67. 一边写一边重写！

67.   You rewrite while you write!

68. 一次性阅读整个剧本并进行重写！

68.   You do a rewrite by reading the whole script at once!

69. 你的第一页不够吸引人！

69.   You don’t have a killer first page!

70. 你把前十页都写烂了！啊啊啊啊啊！

70.   You blew your first ten pages! ARGGGGGHHHH!

71. 你还没有撕掉前二十页！

71.   You haven’t ripped out the first twenty pages!

72. 你还没有删掉所有多余的动作！

72.   You haven’t cut every bit of extraneous action!

73. 你认为你的第一稿（或第九稿）已经完美了！

73.   You think your first (or ninth) draft is perfect!

挑剔，挑剔，挑剔

Picky, Picky, Picky

74. 你不知道剧本里每个字的意思！

74.   You don’t know the meaning of every word in your script!

75. 你用数字代替文字！

75.   You use numbers instead of words!

76. 你发号施令！

76.   You call shots!

77. 你会点特定的歌曲！

77.   You call specific songs!

78. 你没有运行拼写检查，你这个白痴！

78.   You didn’t run your spellcheck, you moron!

79. 你相信你的拼写检查！啊哈哈哈哈哈哈！

79.   You trust your spellcheck! Ah haa ha haaa ha ha!

80. 你认为越长越好！

80.   You think longer is better!

81. 你没有大声读出你的剧本！

81.   You didn’t read your script out loud!

82. 你用的打印机太差了！

82.   You used a crummy printer!

第三幕：现在怎么办？

Act III: What Now?

 

不要做傻瓜，要专业

Don’t Be a Jackass, Be Professional

83. 你想出名远胜于你想写作！

83.   You want to be famous more than you want to write!

84. 你认为你的剧本很特别，规则不适用！

84.   You think your script is special and rules don’t apply!

85. 您在标题页上放了错误的内容！

85.   You put the wrong stuff on your title page!

86. 你还没有读过剧本！

86.   You haven’t done a table read!

87. 你还没真正准备好就急着把剧本发出去！

87.   You’re dying to send the script out before you’re really, really ready!

行业

The Industry

88. 你根本不知道这个行业是怎样运作的！

88.   You haven’t the first clue how the business works!

89. 你不知道好莱坞的人什么时候吃午饭！

89.   You don’t know what time they eat lunch in Hollywood!

90. 你的权利意识太强了！又名“不要与笔记作对！”

90.   Your sense of entitlement is in overdrive! a.k.a.   “Don’t fight the notes!”

91. 你不知道什么是一封像样的询问信！

91.   You don’t know what a decent query letter is!

92. 您在询问信中提出了愚蠢的要求！

92.   You made boneheaded demands in your query letter!

93. 你不想签署释放他们的协议！

93.   You don’t want to sign their release!

焦虑症

Angst-O-Rama

94. 你认为好莱坞会窃取你的创意！

94.   You think Hollywood will steal your idea!

95.你不懂汉隆剃刀原理！

95.   You don’t understand Hanlon’s Razor!

96. 你不知道 Natalie Merchant 和 Patti Smith 之间的区别！

96.   You don’t know the difference between Natalie Merchant and Patti Smith!

97. 你不知道你可以通过写作摆脱困境！

97.   You don’t know you can write your way out of a hole!

98. 你不知道如何找经纪人！

98.   You don’t know how to get an agent!

99. 当他们说喜欢它时，你会很兴奋！

99.   You get excited when they say they like it!

100. 你把希望与否认混淆了！

100. You’re confusing hope with denial!

淡出

Fading Out

关于作者

About the Author

致谢

Acknowledgments

 

首先要感谢布莱克·斯奈德。从一开始，他就认为这个愚蠢的想法很棒。

Thank you, first and foremost, to Blake Snyder. From the beginning, he thought this foolishness was a swell idea.

第二位是弗朗西斯科·梅内德斯，他邀请我去内华达大学拉斯维加斯分校给他的班级做演讲。最终，这份 100 页的讲义成为了这本书。

Second, Fransisco Menendez, who invited me to speak to his class at UNLV. The resulting 100-page handout eventually became this book.

我的理解家人，Kate McCormick、Scott Pierce、Cathie Pelletier、Tom Schulman、Linda McCullough、Melissa Scrivner、Nick Morton、Alex Beattie、Jessica Stamen、Mark Kurasz、Richard Hull、Kelley Baker、Randy Feldman、Willard Carroll、Margaret Matheson、Coke Sams、Mark Cabus、Beth O'Neil、Jason Blum、John Cherry、Carol Caldwell、Dave Brown、Kerith Harding、Steve Bloom、Ryan Saul、Jenny Wood、Pam Casey、Chris Ruppenthal、Jon Amiel、Shian Brisbois、Rob Muraskin、Suzanne Kingsbury、Tony Cane、Max Wong 和 Miles Davis。

My understanding family, Kate McCormick, Scott Pierce, Cathie Pelletier, Tom Schulman, Linda McCullough, Melissa Scrivner, Nick Morton, Alex Beattie, Jessica Stamen, Mark Kurasz, Richard Hull, Kelley Baker, Randy Feldman, Willard Carroll, Margaret Matheson, Coke Sams, Mark Cabus, Beth O’Neil, Jason Blum, John Cherry, Carol Caldwell, Dave Brown, Kerith Harding, Steve Bloom, Ryan Saul, Jenny Wood, Pam Casey, Chris Ruppenthal, Jon Amiel, Shian Brisbois, Rob Muraskin, Suzanne Kingsbury, Tony Cane, Max Wong, and Miles Davis.

介绍

Introduction

 
 

“诚实的批评很难接受，尤其是来自亲戚、朋友、熟人或陌生人的批评。”

富兰克林·P·琼斯

“Honest criticism is hard to take, particularly from a relative, a friend, an acquaintance, or a stranger.”

Franklin P. Jones

《你的剧本很烂！》诞生于批评剧本时的一个想法。

Your Screenplay Sucks! grew from an idea born while critiquing screenplays.

我有三部剧本被拍成了故事片。我是编剧协会的终身会员。我写剧本已经二十年了。我一直在为朋友评论剧本，过去七年左右我一直靠评论剧本赚钱。更不用说我在编剧课上指导过的数百部剧本了。

I’ve had three scripts made into feature films. I’m a Lifetime member of the Writers Guild. I’ve written screenplays for twenty years. I’ve critiqued scripts for friends the whole time, and have been paid to critique the past seven years or so. Not to mention the hundreds of scripts I have shepherded through my screenwriting classes.

通过阅读和评论，我发现初学写作的人总是会犯同样的错误。在好莱坞，这些错误可能会导致读者……（喘息！）停止阅读……

Through my reading and critiquing, I discovered that beginning writers consistently make the same mistakes. Mistakes which, in Hollywood, can cause the reader to… (gasp!) stop stop reading…

你知道，他们可以做到这一点。

They can do that, you know.

我发现自己一遍又一遍地告诉作家同样的事情：“不要让角色的名字押韵。”“每个角色的声音听起来都一样。”“你的英雄没有明确的目标。”重复到令人厌烦。我决定创建一个简单的清单，这样，在将剧本发给我之前，作家可以重写一下，清理这些基本内容，然后我们可以讨论情节、人物和结构，而不是把时间浪费在“运行该死的拼写检查”等通用的东西上。那个简短的清单变成了这本书。

I found myself telling writers the same things over and over: “Don’t have character names that rhyme.” “Every character’s voice sounds just like every other character.” “Your hero doesn’t have a clear goal.” Repeat ad nauseam. I decided to create a simple checklist so, before sending me their screenplay, writers could do a rewrite, cleaning up this nuts and bolts stuff, and then we could discuss plot and character and structure, instead of wasting time on generic stuff like, “run your damn spellcheck.” That short checklist turned into this book.

 

“我读到了第一个错别字。”

好莱坞经纪人

“I read to the first typo.”

Hollywood agent

欢迎来到好莱坞。

Welcome to Hollywood.

 

“如果这很容易，那么每个人都会这么做。”

洛杉矶的每一位制片人

“If it were easy, everyone would do it.”

Every producer in Los Angeles

理论上，读者必须读完整本书。有些人读了，有些人则不然。制片人不受这些礼节的约束。虽然他们确实希望找到下一部《夺宝奇兵》，但他们也在寻找任何借口，在读到第十页时就放弃。所以别给他们借口，好吗！这就是这本书的意义所在，从你的剧本中移除地雷，以免读者把它扔进垃圾桶。

In theory, readers have to read the whole thing. Some do. Some don’t. Producers are not bound by such niceties. While they do hope to find the next Raiders of the Lost Ark, they’re also looking for any excuse to put it down by page ten. So don’t give them one, okay! That’s the point of this book, removing land mines from your screenplay that will cause the reader to pitch it into the trash.

相信我，他们就是这么做的。

And believe me, that is what they do.

99% 的阅读剧本的人没有能力说“是”，但每个人都可以说“不”。他们只是渴望使用这种权力。

Ninety-nine percent of people who will read your script do not have the ability to say “Yes,” but every single one can say “No.” They are just itching to use that power.

 

“与权力斗争！”《为所应为》

中的罗西·佩雷兹

“Fight the power!”

Rosie Perez in Do the Right Thing

一个阳光明媚的洛杉矶下午，我坐在助理的办公室里，等待制片人，她的门关着。她可能在她那间充满俗气的办公室里打板球。我永远不知道。不管怎样，为了打发时间，我看了看助理的桌子上方，有两个架子上堆满了剧本。它们围绕着房间的三面墙壁。为了锻炼脑力，我估计了一下有多少剧本。1,400。一千四百部剧本，它们都有经纪人。

One fine sunny Los Angeles afternoon, I was sitting in an assistant’s office, waiting for the producer, and her door was closed. Probably inside her kitsch-packed office playing paddle ball. I’ll never know. Anyway, killing time, I looked above the assistant’s desk, and there were two shelves overflowing with screenplays. They ran around three walls of the room. For mental gymnastics, I estimated how many scripts there were. 1,400. One thousand four hundred screenplays, and they all had agents.

对于局外人来说，对于在洛杉矶以外的城市，远离经纪人办公桌或制片人办公室，在打字机或电脑前工作的人来说，这几乎是不可想象的……无法想象这个系统必须处理的素材数量之巨。每周从每个制片人、经纪人或高管的气窗上喷涌而出的剧本数量令人难以置信。你是一个坐在房间里、公园里或咖啡馆里写剧本的作家。在我们这片伟大的土地上，有成千上万的人坐在公园里，也在写剧本。所以，你写的东西必须非常出色。

It is nearly inconceivable to an outsider, to someone at a typewriter or a computer in a city other than Los Angeles, far from the agent’s desk, or the producer’s office… it is impossible to conceive of the staggering volume of material the system has to contend with. The number of scripts that gushes over the transom of every producer, or agent, or executive, every week, boggles the mind. You’re one writer sitting in your room, or at a park, or coffee shop, writing your screenplay. There are thousands of people sitting in parks all across this great land of ours, writing screenplays too. So, what you’re writing has to be really good.

虽然你面临的竞争非常激烈，但竞争也不是铁板一块。盔甲上总有裂缝和裂痕，而一份写得很好的剧本可以勉强通过。但剧本必须写得非常好。如果你的剧本不完美，或者不尽完美，那么它就没有机会通过。如果你认为几周内匆匆写出的东西，不重写，就是在浪费时间，那就太傲慢了。

While the competition you face is gigantic, it is not monolithic. There are chinks and cracks in the armor, and a well-written script can wriggle through. But it has to be extremely well written. If your script isn’t perfect, or as close to perfect as you can get it, then it doesn’t stand a chance. It is supremely arrogant to think that something you dash off in a couple of weeks, and don’t rewrite, is anything more than a waste of your time.

当你在制片人的办公室时，看看剧本的马特洪峰。每个剧本都是由和你一样的人写的。显然，编剧不是胆小鬼能干的。

When you’re in a producer’s office, take a gander at the Matterhorn of scripts. Each was written by somebody just like you. Obviously, screenwriting is not for the faint of heart.

写一个投机剧本（根据“猜测”写作，希望卖出去）完全是为了读者，不是你的妈妈，也不是批评你的材料的朋友，而是为了那些拿钱来阅读你作品的人。你知道，读者每个周末要读 15 个剧本。如果你不是这个行业的人，你根本不知道找到一个“真正的”人来阅读你的材料有多么困难。如果你有机会，你不会想把事情搞砸的。

Writing a spec screenplay [writing on “speculation,” hoping to sell it] is all about the reader, not your mom, or a friend who critiques your material, but someone who is paid to read your stuff. You know, a reader with fifteen scripts to plow through each weekend. If you’re not actually in the business, you have no idea how monumentally difficult it is to find someone “real” to read your material. If you ever get that chance, you don’t want to mess it up.

虽然读者确实非常希望找到一部精彩的剧本，并怀着不可压抑的希望打开每部剧本，但他也渴望停止阅读，这样他就可以躺在泳池边，喝一杯令人愉悦的清凉饮料。因此，如果你给他任何借口扔掉你的剧本，他就会接受。然后，噗！，你所有的努力都白费了。浪费了你六个月的生命。或者一年。或者七年，就像我认识的一个人一样。

While it’s true a reader really, really wants to unearth a fantastic screenplay, and opens each one with that uncrushable hope in mind, he is also dying to quit reading so he can flop by the pool with a delightfully refreshing umbrella drink. Therefore, if you give him any excuse to toss your script, he’ll take it. And poof!, all your effort will be for naught. A big fat waste of six months of your life. Or a year. Or seven years, like one guy I know.

对于你们中的某些人来说，这可能是一个令人心碎的消息：唯一想读你作品的人可能是你的父母，还有你的男朋友或女朋友，这取决于你们的关系有多新。还记得那瓶雨伞饮料吗？读者想要读起来像闪电一样的东西。留白很多的东西。他们不必费力去弄清楚你想说什么。

For some of you, this may come as heartbreaking news: the only people who want to read your work are your parents, maybe, and your boyfriend or girlfriend, depending on how new the relationship is. Remember the umbrella drinks? Readers want something that reads like lightning. Something with plenty of white space. Something where they don’t have to fight to figure out what you’re trying to say.

你要求为这项工作支付 100,000 美元以上的费用。你要求某人花费 100,000 到 1 亿美元来制作你刚刚编造的东西。你需要把这些事情做好。你需要有动听的场景描述。你需要有生动的配角。你需要运行拼写检查。就像这样。我告诉你的这些都很容易做到。这与才华、神话故事结构或圆形人物无关。我不是在告诉你“如何写出精彩的剧本”。有很多好书可以教你如何写出精彩的剧本。我给你的是一些指导方针，确保读者继续阅读。

You are asking upwards of $100,000 for said work. You’re asking someone to spend from $100,000 to $100,000,000 to produce something you just made up. You need to get this stuff right. You need scene description that sings. You need to have lively minor characters. You need to run your spellcheck. Like that. What I’m telling you is simple to execute. It has nothing to do with talent or mythic story structure or round characters. I’m not telling you “how to write a great script.” There are plenty of good books for that. What I am giving you are guidelines to make sure the reader keeps reading.

有一次，我在飞机上坐在一位制片人旁边，看着她读了六页剧本就放下了。那位作家花了好几个月的时间写剧本，但不知何故，在第六页就错失了机会。原因可能有很多。

I once sat next to a producer on a plane and watched her read six pages and put a script down. That writer spent months and months on his script but, for some reason, blew his chance by page six. Probably for a long list of reasons.

我将帮你从导致抑郁的清单中找出一百个原因！

I’m going to help you check a hundred reasons off that depression-inducing list!

 

“如果故事让人困惑，那么作者就失败了。”

约翰尼·科克伦（并非如此）

“If the story confuses, it’s the writer who loses.”

Johnny Cochran (not really)

对于读者来说，阅读剧本就像在黑暗的沼泽中奔跑，穿过漂浮着一百码的睡莲，同时遭到野蛮人的射击。最后一页是读者拼命想要到达的海岸线。如果有什么东西打断了她的注意力，哪怕只是一点点，她都可能跌倒，失去平衡，掉进食人鱼群中。尽你所能让她留在睡莲上！

For the reader, reading a screenplay is like sprinting through a dark swamp across a hundred yards of floating lily pads while getting shot at by savages. The last page is the shoreline the reader is desperately trying to reach. If something breaks her concentration, even slightly, she may stumble, lose her balance and fall into the piranhas. Do everything you can to keep her on the lily pads!

正如《爵士春秋》（由罗伯特·艾伦·奥瑟和鲍勃·福斯创作）中乔·吉迪恩的角色所说：

As the Joe Gideon character says in All That Jazz (written by Robert Alan Aurthur and Bob Fosse):

 

“听着。我不能让你成为一名伟大的舞者。我甚至不知道我是否能让你成为一名优秀的舞者。但是，如果你继续努力并且不放弃，我知道我可以让你成为一名更好的舞者。”

“Listen. I can’t make you a great dancer.I don’t even know if I can make you a good dancer. But, if you keep trying and don’t quit, I know I can make you a better dancer.”

如果你遵循《你的剧本糟透了！》清单，那么当你读完这本书时，你就会成为一名更好的作家。没问题。

If you follow the Your Screenplay Sucks! checklist, by the time you finish this book, you’ll be a better writer. No problem.

我希望您发现这本书非常有用。

I hope you find the book incredibly useful.

威廉·M·埃克斯 (William M. Akers)

在西瓦塔内霍的海滩上*

2008 年 8 月

William M. Akers

on the beach in Zihuatanejo*

August 2008

*不是真的，但听起来不是很棒吗！也许如果我卖几本书的话……

* Not really, but doesn’t it just sound great! Maybe if I sell a few books.…

第一幕：

ACT I:

 

评书

Storytelling

这是你赚钱的地方。

剩下的都是技巧。

This is where you earn the money.

The rest is mechanics.

 

 

 

“如果一个人能用二十五个字或更少的字告诉我（一部电影的）想法

，那么这部电影就相当不错了。

我喜欢那些可以

拿在手里的想法，尤其是电影想法。”

史蒂文·斯皮尔伯格

“If a person can tell me the idea [of a film] in twenty-five

words or less, it’s going to make a pretty good movie.

I like ideas, especially movie ideas, that you can

hold in your hand.”

Steven Spielberg

“作家是那些

比其他人写作更困难的人。”

托马斯·曼

“A writer is someone for whom writing is more difficult

than it is for other people.”

Thomas Mann

“作家的任务是让你听到，让你感受到

——最重要的是，让你看到。仅此而已，

这就是一切。”

约瑟夫·康拉德

“The task of the writer is to make you hear, to make you feel

— it is, before all, to make you see. That — and no more,

and it is everything.”

Joseph Conrad

“写下你害怕的东西。”

唐纳德·巴塞尔姆

“Write about what you’re afraid of.”

Donald Barthelme

 

 

淡入：

FADE IN:

“所有严肃的勇敢都

始于内心。”

尤多拉·韦尔蒂

“All serious daring

starts within.”

Eudora Welty

 

以下是本书中最重要的一课，也许是整个剧本创作中最重要的一课。我实际上听到了：

Here follows the most important lesson in this book, and maybe the most important single lesson in all of screenwriting. Actually overheard by me:

两个人排队买《寻找福雷斯特》的门票。

Two guys in line to buy tickets for Finding Forrester.

第一个人问：“这部电影是关于什么的？”他的朋友说：“肖恩·康纳利。”

First guy says, “What’s this movie about?” And his buddy says, “Sean Connery.”

永远不要忘记它。

Don’t you ever forget it.

与你可能认为的相反，你并不是想写一个伟大的故事。你不是在写蓝图以便制片厂可以制作你的电影。你不是在写可以治愈癌症或赢得诺贝尔奖的东西。你写的是吸引演员的诱饵。

Contrary to what you may believe, you’re not trying to write a great story. You’re not writing a blueprint so a studio can make your movie. You’re not writing something that’s going to cure cancer or win a Nobel Prize. What you’re writing is actor bait.

电影业刚起步时，演员的名字不会出现在银幕上。即便如此，制片人也不傻。很快，观众就找到了他们喜欢的演员。他们开始给“传记女孩”写粉丝信。收到粉丝信的女演员告诉传记电影公司，她希望在下一份合同中，她的名字出现在银幕上。制片人被迫让步。那位女演员名叫玛丽·毕克馥。剩下的就是历史了。

When the movie business first started, actors’ names weren’t on screen. Even then, producers weren’t stupid. Very quickly, the public found actors who caught their fancy. They started writing fan letters to “The Biograph Girl.” The actress getting the fan mail told Biograph Pictures that in her next contract, she wanted her name on screen. The producers were forced to relent. That actress was named Mary Pickford. The rest is history.

这些制片人知道，公众只对电影明星感兴趣，而不是故事、导演，甚至编剧。他们只对演员感兴趣。当有人说“我们要把这个剧本发给有才华的人”时，这里的“有才华的人”就是演员。

What those producers knew is that the public is only interested in movie stars, not story, not directors, not, for God’s sake, writers. Just actors. When someone says, “We’re sending this script out to talent,” the “talent” is actors.

如果你的创意不能激起演员的兴趣，如果他们不认为角色和对话能为他们赢得奥斯卡奖、让他们看起来很酷、让人们哭泣或让他们上床，那么你的电影就无法制作。为了激起演员的兴趣，你必须激起制片人的兴趣，而为了激起制片人的兴趣，你首先必须激起开发主管的兴趣，而为了激起开发主管的兴趣，你必须激起读者的兴趣。

If your idea doesn’t excite an actor, if they don’t think that character and dialogue is going to win them an Oscar, make them look cool, make people cry, or get them laid, then your movie won’t get made. In order to excite an actor, you have to excite a producer, and in order to excite a producer, you first have to excite the development executive, and, to excite a development exec, you must excite a reader.

并且，如果读者想向他的老板推荐你的剧本，他/她就必须读完整个剧本。

And, for a reader to recommend your script to his boss, she has to read the damn thing. All of it.

因此，你需要确保尽一切努力让每个人都读完剧本的最后一页。如果你的剧本很糟糕，他们就会停止阅读。

Therefore, you need to make sure you do everything to get everyone to read to the last page of your screenplay. If your screenplay sucks, they’ll stop reading.

所以，让我们撸起袖子，找出你的剧本烂透的原因。好消息是，大多数剧本都可以重写和修改。今天烂透的东西不一定总是烂透的。

So, let’s roll up our sleeves and find out why your screenplay sucks. The good news is that most screenplays can be rewritten and repaired. Something that sucks today doesn’t have to always suck.

除非你有什么坏主意。那你就死定了。

Unless you’ve got a bad idea. Then you’re dead.

一旦你选定了主意，你就必须全身心投入。就像早餐里的猪一样。

Once you’ve chosen your idea, you’re committed. Like a pig at breakfast.

 

“‘参与’和‘承诺’有什么区别？早餐时，鸡参与。猪承诺。”

匿名

“What’s the difference between ‘involved’ and ‘committed’? At breakfast, the chicken is involved. The pig is committed.”

Anonymous

牢记这一点，以下是 100 个导致你的剧本烂透了的原因。以及许多修复方法！

With that firmly in mind, here are 100 reasons your screenplay sucks. And a bunch of ways to fix it!

主意

Idea

 

1. 您还没有写一些您关心的内容！

1. You have not written something you care about!

 

写一些让你着迷的事情，让你热血沸腾的事情，让你半夜起床的事情，让你在鸡尾酒会上争论的事情，让你失去一位老朋友的事情。

Write about something that fascinates you, that boils your blood, that gets you out of bed in the middle of the night, that you argue about at cocktail parties, that might cost you an old friend.

 

“写一个能改变你生活的剧本。即使你卖不出去，至少你也改变了你的生活。”

约翰·特鲁比

“Write a screenplay that will change your life. If you don’t sell it, at least you will have changed your life.”

John Truby

向好莱坞传奇编剧老师特鲁比先生学习一下。你写的是一些你非常感兴趣的东西，因此也可能引起其他人的浓厚兴趣吗？尽管它可能被埋藏在表面下十七层，但你写的是一个“关于某事”的故事吗？

Take a cue from Mr. Truby, one of Hollywood’s legendary screenwriting teachers. Are you writing about something that is of deep interest to you and therefore might be of deep interest to other people? Though it may be buried seventeen layers below the surface, are you writing a story that is “about something”?

如果你有话要说，那么你的剧本就值得一读。即使你写的是一部全裸的银行抢劫音乐剧，投入其中也会有所帮助。

If you have something to “say,” then your script will be worth reading. Even if you’re writing an all-nude bank heist musical, it helps to be invested in it.

写作不是懦夫的活儿。它需要巨大的精神能量。这是一项艰苦的工作。写的时间长了，你就会得痔疮和背痛。如果你只是想赚钱，你永远也熬不过写作过程中的艰苦。所以，看在上帝的份上，说点什么吧。

Writing is not for wimps. It takes colossal mental and spiritual energy. It’s hard work. Do it long enough, you’ll have hemorrhoids and a bad back. If you’re only trying to make money, you’ll never survive the bone-grinding difficulty of the process. So, for God’s sake, have something to say.

你为什么想写作？你为什么充满激情？什么对你来说重要！？你能写什么？你关心什么？人们会感兴趣阅读什么？你知道什么？你比其他作家更有资格讲述什么故事？

Why do you want to write? Why are you passionate? What matters to you!? What can you write, that you care about, that people will be interested in reading, that you know about? What story do you have the right to tell, more than any other writer out there?

如果你只是因为前七部冲浪恐怖片大获成功而开始写一部冲浪恐怖片，那么你写这部电影的理由是错误的，读者会觉得它像坏疽一样难闻。你可以写出世界上最搞笑的电影——如果里面有什么东西能吸引你的注意——你就有机会写出一部精彩的电影。

If you’re just writing a surfer horror movie because the last seven surfer horror movies made a mint, you’re in it for the wrong reasons and the reader will smell it like gangrene. You can write the goofiest movie in the world — and if there is something in there that’s got its hooks in your guts — you’ve got a chance at writing something wonderful.

想想《婚礼傲客》。乍一看，这似乎很愚蠢。两个男人偷偷溜进婚礼上床。真希望我单身的时候能想到这一点。真希望上次坐下来集思广益写剧本时能想到这一点！但是，当你看这个故事时，你会发现它是关于一些东西的。一些深刻的东西：两个朋友之间的关系。这是一段兄弟情，两个男人之间的爱情故事，就像《墓碑镇》或《超级坏蛋》。而且，从本质上讲，《婚礼傲客》是真实而感人的。这不是一部愚蠢的喜剧。这是一个可爱、温馨的故事。

Consider Wedding Crashers. At first blush, it seems pretty silly. Two guys sneak into weddings to get laid. Wish I’d thought that up when I was single. Really wish I’d thought of it last time I sat down to brainstorm a screenplay! But, when you look at the story, it’s about something. Something profound: the relationship between two friends. It’s a bromance, a love story between two guys, like Tombstone or Superbad. And, at its core, Wedding Crashers is real and touching. It’s not a stupid comedy. It’s a lovely, heartwarming story.

 

“没有哪个混蛋知道接下来会发生什么。”

雷·查尔斯

“Ain’t no son of a bitch alive knows what’s gonna hit.”

Ray Charles

你不可能知道什么会畅销。不可能。没人知道。另一个原因是你应该写你关心的东西，因为你甚至不知道别人想读什么样的剧本。制片人可以告诉你他认为自己想要什么，但他实际上并不知道。他会表现得像他知道一样，他的理由可能很有说服力，但请记住，他也相信他的孩子不会偷他的酒，所以为什么要听他的？经纪人、演员或地球上任何活着的人都是如此。

You can’t know what’s going to sell. No way. No one does. Another reason to write what you care about, because you can’t even know the kind of script someone wants to read. A producer can tell you what he thinks he wants, but he doesn’t actually know. He will act like he knows, and his reasoning may be convincing, but remember, he also believes his kids aren’t stealing his liquor, so why listen to him? The same is true for agents, actors, or anybody alive on the planet.

你必须写下对你来说重要的事情，因为：

You must write what matters to you, because:

 

“不管他们说什么，那都不是他们想要的。”

贝尔菲尔德定律

“No matter what they say, that ain’t what they want.”

Barefield’s Law

回溯到 1976 年：如果你在街上问某人想看什么类型的电影，他们会说：“哇哦，老兄。这问题问得真好。我想看像《大白鲨》这样的电影。那只鲨鱼太酷了，哥们。”

Going back to 1976: if you asked someone on the street what kind of movie they wanted to see, they’d say, “Whoa, dude. What a question. I wanna see something like Jaws. That shark was cool, man.”

但是，他只是认为他想看像《大白鲨》这样的电影，因为他喜欢它。他真正想看的是一些令人惊叹、精彩和新颖的、与《大白鲨》完全不同的电影，但他无法表达这一点，因为——他不知道他想看什么，因为他还没有看过。观众真正想看的是 1977 年上映的电影，名为《星球大战》。

But, he only thinks he wants to see something like Jaws, because he liked it. What he really wants to see is something amazing and wonderful and new and nothing like Jaws, but he can’t articulate that because — he doesn’t know what he wants to see because he hasn’t seen it yet. What audiences actually wanted to see hit theaters in 1977, and it was called Star Wars.

对于生产者来说也是如此。当你给他们东西时，他们就会知道自己想要什么。所以就给他们吧！

Same is true for producers. They will know what they want when you give it to them. So give it to them!

他们会把精力投入到他们认为最有可能卖出去的东西上——所以写一些你认为有人能卖出去的东西。但是，既然它可能卖不出去，至少写一些你非常非常想写的东西！

They will put their efforts into what they believe is going to have the best shot at selling — so write something you think someone is going to be able to sell. But, since it probably won’t sell, at least write something you really, really want to write!

唐纳德·戴维斯的《讲述你自己的故事》这本书或许能帮你找到自己的故事。强烈推荐。

A book that may help you find your story is Telling Your Own Stories by Donald Davis. Highly recommended.

选择要写什么的一种方法是，如果一个想法不断浮出水面，说“听着，伙计。我就是你要讲的故事！”你对某个特定主题感兴趣很久了吗？也许有办法把这种迷恋变成一部电影。如果它已经在你的内心深处徘徊了好久，那就抓紧这个痒吧！如果你写一些你渴望写的东西，那就容易多了。读者会感受到你的热情。

One way to choose what to write is if an idea keeps bobbing to the surface, saying “Listen up, Bud. I’m the story you have to tell!” Have you been interested in a particular subject for a long, long time? Maybe there’s a way to turn that fascination into a movie. If it’s been digging at your innards for eons, scratch that itch! It’s so much easier if you write something you are dying to write. The reader will sense your enthusiasm.

处理主题的方法有很多。你可以写一些你想到的东西。一个原创的想法。你在这里有完全的自由。你可以创造世界、人物、事件，甚至你的世界的历史。你做主。尽情发挥。玩得开心！或者，你可以剽窃历史，写《特洛伊》或《300勇士》 。你可以拿一本公共领域的小说，比如简·奥斯汀的《爱玛》，把它颠倒过来，瞧！你就有了《独领风骚》。你可以花钱买一个短篇故事、某人的生命权、一本书或一篇杂志文章。没关系。

There are lots of ways to approach subject matter. You can write something you think up. An original idea. You have total freedom here. You can create the world, the characters, the events, even the history of your world. You’re in charge. Go wild. Have fun! Or, you can plunder history and write Troy or 300. You can take a public domain novel, like Emma by Jane Austen, turn it on its head and, presto! you’ve got Clueless. You can spend money and option a short story, someone’s life rights, a book, or a magazine article. Doesn’t matter.

无论你选择写什么，一定要确保你创造的角色能引起我们的注意。好的写作是关于人类状况的。电影越是陷入情节、动作、特殊效果和不揭示人物性格的东西越多，他们就越容易误入歧途。看看《虎胆龙威》。你会担心麦克莱恩和他的妻子，还有外面的警察，甚至担心车库里豪华轿车里的孩子。如果我们不关心你的人，那就完了。如果我们与角色产生共鸣，你就自由了。

Whatever you choose to write, make sure you create characters who get our attention. Good writing is about the human condition. The more movies get bogged down in plot, action, special effects and things that are not revelatory of character, the more they go astray. Look at Die Hard. You worry about McClane and his wife and the cop outside and even the kid in the limo in the garage. If we don’t care about your people, it’s over. If we connect with the characters, you’re home free.

您是您的想法的第一批受众，因此它一定会引起您的兴趣。

You’re the first audience for your idea, and it must interest you.

你是否能在写作过程中保持这种兴趣？你不想失去灵感，陷入歧路的花园。你的想法为什么如此伟大、令人兴奋、引人注目？你如何才能让读者坚持到最后？你认为你能卖出它吗？你的方法有什么新颖之处？

Can you sustain that interest over the years it may take you to write it? You don’t want to lose sight of the spark and go down into the garden of forking paths. How is your idea so great, exciting, and compelling? How can you pull the reader through to the end? Do you think you can sell it? What is new about your approach?

制片人会愿意赤脚走过碎玻璃来拍摄你的电影吗？

Will a producer want to walk barefoot across broken glass to make your movie?

2. 你的想法缺乏创意！

2. Your idea isn’t vibrating with originality!

 

去看电影！看看都拍了些什么。看看那些有趣又新颖的电影，比如《美丽心灵的永恒阳光》或《三个国王》，它们一开始只是一个简单的战争故事，但最后却变成了更引人入胜的故事！

Go to the movies! See what gets made. Look at movies that are interesting and original like Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind or Three Kings, which starts as a simple little war story but turns into something way more fascinating!

 

“人类最古老、最强烈的情感是恐惧，而最古老、最强烈的恐惧是对未知的恐惧。”

HP洛夫克拉夫特

“The oldest and strongest emotion of mankind is fear, and the oldest and strongest kind of fear is fear of the unknown.”

H. P. Lovecraft

带我们去一个我们从未去过的世界，给我们一次意想不到的旅程。《奇幻人生》是一部独特而令人愉悦的电影。 《2001：太空漫游》上映时，完​​全是新鲜的。哎呀，它现在仍然如此！《春天不是读书天》。《上帝之城》。《成为约翰·马尔科维奇》。《我的狗生》。

Take us to a world we’ve never been to, and give us a ride we never expected. Stranger than Fiction is a uniquely delightful movie. When it came out, 2001: A Space Odyssey was wholly fresh. Heck, it still is! Ferris Bueller’s Day Off. City of God. Being John Malkovich. My Life as a Dog.

每本书都极具原创性。如果你没有带读者去一个他从未去过的地方，为什么要让他读完第一页呢？

Each was wonderfully original. If you’re not taking your reader to a place he’s never been, why ask him to read past page one?

给你。这是我送给你的礼物。一个你在电影里从未见过的世界，一次也没有！这是一个距离你居住地几英里的世界。

Here. My gift to you. A world you’ve never seen in a movie, not once! It’s a world that exists a few miles from where you live.

然而，从来没有人把电影设定在这个领域。问自己一个难题：“你怎样才能带我们踏上一段在某种程度上既新颖又迷人的旅程？ ”约翰·巴里的《涨潮》是一部令人惊叹的非虚构作品。19 世纪中叶，一名戴着临时潜水钟的工程师在密西西比河的河底行走：

Yet no one has ever set a movie in this arena. Ask yourself the hard question: “How can you take us on a journey that, on some level, is this new and fascinating?” Rising Tide by John Barry is a stunning piece of non-fiction. In the mid-19th century, an engineer in a makeshift diving bell is walking on the bottom of the Mississippi River:

 

没有光线，埃兹看不见河水。但他能感觉到它。水底吸着他，而水流在黑暗和寂静中将他包围。水流也冲击着、鞭打着、威胁着、拉扯着他。潜水员必须靠在水流上，推着它。与风不同，水流从不停歇。他后来写道：“我曾有机会在湍急的水流中下潜到水底，以至于需要非常手段才能将钟沉入水中。……沙子像密集的暴风雪一样在底部飘浮……在水面以下六十五英尺处，我发现河床至少有三英尺深，是一个移动的物体，非常不稳定，当我试图在钟下找到立足点时，我的脚穿过了它，直到我能感觉到，虽然站得笔直，沙子从我的手边冲过，被一股似乎和水面上一样湍急的水流推动着。我发现沙子在水底至少两英尺处在运动，并且移动速度随着深度的增加而减小。”

Without light, Eads could not see the river. He felt it. The bottom sucked at him while the current embraced him in darkness and silence. The current also buffeted, whipped, bullied, pulled. A diver had to lean against it, push against it. Unlike the wind, it never let up. He later wrote: “I had occasion to descend to the bottom in a current so swift as to require extraordinary means to sink the bell. …The sand was drifting like a dense snowstorm at the bottom… At sixty-five feet below the surface I found the bed of the river, for at least three feet in depth, a moving mass and so unstable that, in endeavoring to find a footing on it beneath my bell, my feet penetrated through it until I could feel, although standing erect, the sand rushing past my hands, driven by a current apparently as rapid as that on the surface. I could discover the sand in motion at least two feet below the surface of the bottom, and moving with a velocity diminishing in proportion to its depth.”

哇哦。多么神奇的世界啊。如果你把电影背景设在那里，那将是我们从未去过的地方。不过话说回来，希瑟斯的韦斯特伯格高中也不是我们曾经去过的世界。

Whoa. What an amazing world. And were you to set a movie there, it would be a place none of us had ever been. But, then again, Westerberg High School in Heathers is not a world we’d ever been to either.

仅仅因为你认为一个想法非常聪明，并不意味着你应该写下来。你想出的东西并非都是天才之作。

Just because you think an idea is wildly clever doesn’t mean it’s something you should write. Not everything you come up with is genius.

花时间反复琢磨，将其翻来覆去，使其更有趣。问问题。我能做些什么来让它变得更好？这像我看过的另一部电影吗？这里有我们从未见过的东西吗？为什么有人会关心这个故事？这是人们会急于告诉朋友的事情吗？它会引发强烈的情感反应吗？我们以前看过吗？我如何颠覆了这种类型？我能做些什么让它变得更酷、更漂亮、更时髦？我只是在重复别人的电影，还是这里有我的灵魂？我怎样才能把这个想法变成一件令人惊叹的事情？

Spend time bouncing it on its head, turning it inside out, twisting it around to make it more interesting. Ask questions. What can I do to make this better? Is this like another movie I saw? Is there something here we’ve never seen? Why will anyone care about this story? Is this something people will be busting to tell their friends? Will it force a strong emotional reaction? Have we seen it before? How have I turned the genre on its head? What can I do to make it cooler, niftier, groovier? Am I just rehashing somebody else’s movie, or is there a piece of my soul here? How can I take this idea and explode into something amazing?

 

“竞争太激烈了。”

理查德·西尔伯特，《唐人街》和《迪克·特雷西》

的制作设计师

“The competition is grotesque.”

Richard Sylbert, production designer

on Chinatown and Dick Tracy

你最好相信这一点。如果你正在为一部精彩的故事片筹集资金，你最好有一个非常出色的剧本。令人惊讶的是，人们可以为一个糟糕的剧本筹集资金。他们可以根据糟糕的剧本制作电影。然而，这并不意味着他们应该根据糟糕的剧本制作电影。在无聊、平庸的材料上浪费的时间和金钱是惊人的。经验表明，牙医几乎愿意投资任何东西，但你为什么要浪费他们的钱、他们的时间、场务员的时间、灯光师的时间、演员、编辑的时间，以及你自己的宝贵时间（你实际上没有那么多时间）在一件并不好的事情上？再打十遍草稿；确保你的剧本是原创的、绝对的、钛合金的和坚不可摧的。如果人们读了它却不问你能做些什么来帮助你制作它，那么你就没有写出一部新鲜的作品。就这么简单。

You better believe it. If you’re out there raising money for your fabulous feature film, you better have a very sharp script. Amazingly enough, people can raise money for a bad screenplay. They can make a movie based on a bad screenplay. However, this does not mean they should make a movie based on a bad screenplay. The amount of time and money wasted on boring, mediocre material is staggering. Experience shows that dentists will invest in damn near anything, but why should you want to waste their money, their time, the grip’s time, the gaffer’s, the actor’s, the editor’s, and your own precious time, of which you don’t actually have that much, on something that wasn’t GREAT? Do another ten drafts; make sure your script is original as hell, absolute, titanium-clad and bulletproof. If people read it and don’t ask you what they can do to help you get it made, then you haven’t written a fresh piece of work. It is as simple as that.

仅仅因为你拍了一部电影，并把它展示给你的朋友、叔叔或满屋子兴奋的投资者，并不意味着你拍了一部成功的电影。如果有人购买了你的电影，并且它进入了 iPod、手机，或者我敢说，进入了电影院，那么它就是成功的。记住那句古老的广告格言：“没有销量，就没有创意。”

Just because you make a movie and show it to your buddies, your uncle, or a room full of giddy investors, does not mean you made a successful film. If someone buys your film and it goes to iPods, cell phones, or, dare I say, movie theaters, then it is successful. Remember the old advertising adage: “It’s not creative unless it sells.”

现在你只需要担心如何写剧本。你还需要担心别人如何销售它，因为毕竟这是电影行业。

Right now, you’re only worried about writing it. You also need to be worried about how someone is going to sell it, because, after all, this is the movie business.

想想看，当你坐下来思考电影创意时，“哪些部分会让这部电影卖座？”你有什么可以拿给发行商并让他们兴奋起来的？是否有爆炸或激情浪漫的场面可以展示预告片中有什么动作？对我来说，戏剧是最有趣的叙事形式，也是最难推销的，因为没有“可利用的元素”。你只能看到人们在交谈，有时还会大喊大叫。除非他们扔家具，否则预告片中不会有太多动作。恐怖片有“可利用的元素”，即粘液和血腥。但你的电影呢？你的剧本会有令人惊叹的时刻，让你的电影卖座吗？

Consider, when you’re sitting down to think of your idea for a movie, “What parts are going to make it sell?” What have you got in there someone can take to a distributor and get them revved up about? Are there explosions or steamy romance they can show in the trailer? Drama, to me the most interesting storytelling form, is also the hardest to sell, because there are no “exploitable elements.” You only have people talking to, or sometimes yelling at, each other. Unless they’re throwing furniture, you don’t have much action for a trailer. A horror film has “exploitable elements,” in that there is goo and gore. But what about your movie? Is your script going to have WOW moments that will get your film sold?

问问自己，你还记得电影中的哪些开创性场景——然后创造一些对你的故事有重大影响的场景。以下是一些对我有用的场景。

Ask yourself which ground-breaking scenes you remember from movies — and then create some that work that strongly for your story. Here are some that work for me.

在《情到深处》中，约翰·库萨克将音箱举过头顶，为心爱的女孩播放歌曲，浪漫而难忘。在《动物屋》中的食物大战。在《天堂电影院》中，阿尔弗雷多移动放映机的玻璃，影像在放映室的墙壁上滑过。在《小鹿斑比》的妈妈去世时。在《低俗小说》中，塞缪尔·杰克逊背诵圣经经文杀死毒贩时。在《杀死一只知更鸟》中，布·拉德利从杰姆卧室门后走出来时。在《阿拉伯的劳伦斯》中，劳伦斯必须杀死他在沙漠中救下的加西姆时。在《34街的奇迹》中，克里斯·克林格用荷兰语和小女孩说话时。

In Say Anything when John Cusack holds the boom box above his head and plays the song for the girl he loves: it’s romantic and unforgettable. The food fight in Animal House. In Cinema Paradiso, when Alfredo moves the glass on the movie projector and the image slides across the walls of the projection booth. When Bambi’s mother dies. In Pulp Fiction, when Samuel L. Jackson recites the Bible verse and kills the drug dealers. In To Kill a Mockingbird when Boo Radley comes out from behind Jem’s bedroom door. In Lawrence of Arabia, when Lawrence has to kill Gasim, the man he saved in the desert. In Miracle on 34th Street, when Kris Kringle speaks to the little girl in Dutch.

在《光猪六壮士》的高潮部分，加兹承认自己太害怕上台了，他一直在宣传整部电影的脱衣舞表演，然后他的儿子鼓励了他。在电影院看那一幕，我笑着哭着。

At the climax of The Full Monty, Gaz, who’s been promoting the strip show for the entire movie, admits he’s too afraid to go onstage, and then is encouraged by his son. Watching that scene in a theater, I laughed and cried at the same time.

您正在考虑的想法可以实现到那个水平吗？

With the idea you’re considering, can you deliver to that level?

3. 您选错了类型！

3. You picked the wrong genre!

 

体裁是一个很大的话题。很多书都是关于体裁的。它值得深入研究。

Genre is a huge topic. Books are written about genre. It’s worth some major study.

你需要知道你的故事属于什么类型，并且需要清楚、迅速、尽早地向观众传达这一点。如果你对某个类型一无所知，那么写作就会困难得多。

You need to know what your story’s genre is and you need to communicate it to the audience clearly, quickly, and early. If you’re writing a genre you don’t know backwards and forwards, it’s going to be much more difficult.

它是否是一种清晰、成熟、简单易懂的类型？它是西部片、犯罪片、爱情故事、剧情片、恶心片、科幻片、恐怖片、成长故事……它是什么？如果你不确定，而且我们在第十页还不清楚你是否确定，那你就完蛋了。读者必须马上知道她身处什么样的故事中。

Is it one clear, established, simple to understand genre? Is it a western, caper film, love story, drama, gross out movie, sci fi, horror, coming of age story… what is it? If you’re not sure, and we aren’t clear by page ten that you are sure, then you’re toast. The reader has to know, right quick, what kind of story she’s in.

你写的是你喜欢的类型吗？你写的是自己擅长的类型吗？如果你只看警匪片，却在写一部以 18 世纪英格兰荒野为背景的浪漫爱情故事，那么你可能在损害自己的才华。如果你发现你在 Netflix 上租的西部片比其他类型的电影都多，那就好好考虑写一部西部片吧。

Are you writing a genre you like? Are you writing a genre you’re good at? If all you ever watch are cop movies, but you’re writing a romantic love story set on the heaths of England in the 1700s, perhaps you are doing your talent a disservice. If you find you rent more westerns on Netflix than any other genre, give a long thought to writing a western.

您是否因为这个月电影院里流行某种类型的电影而选择它？《死亡饼干》？

Did you seize on a genre because that’s what’s popular in theaters this month? Death on a cracker.

你需要六个月到一年的时间来写剧本，如果幸运的话，还需要一年的时间才能让别人愿意购买。到那时，那种流行的类型就会逐渐消失，所以你就浪费了时间。你能写的剧本数量有限，所以要谨慎选择要花在哪些剧本上。

It will take you six months to a year to write the script, another year to get somebody to want to buy it, if you’re lucky. By then, that flavor du jour genre will have petered out and died, so you will have wasted your time. There are only so many screenplays you’ll be able to write, so pick carefully what you choose to spend irreplaceable time on.

有时，你可能只是运气不好。有一次，我的同学鲍勃·罗达特决定写一部黑帮电影。他写了这部电影。不幸的是，在三部黑帮电影上映并遭遇惨败的同一周，他把剧本交给了经纪人。他的经纪人把他的剧本扔了。但他没有放弃。不久之后，他写了《拯救大兵瑞恩》。

Sometimes you can just be a victim of bad luck. Once upon a time my school chum, Bob Rodat, decided to write a gangster movie. He wrote it. He had the massive misfortune to send it to his agent the same week three gangster movies opened and bombed. His agent threw his script away. He didn’t give up. Soon thereafter, he wrote Saving Private Ryan.

不要只因为某个类型现在很流行就选择它。不要只因为某个类型能让你赚钱就选择它。选择你觉得舒服的类型，选择你喜欢的类型。但要知道，外面可能有人在做和你很相似的事情……

Try not to pick a genre just because it’s popular right now. Try not to pick a genre just because it’s something you could make money with. Pick a genre you are comfortable with, pick a genre you love. But know that someone out there may be doing something a lot like yours…

4. 你的故事只有你自己才感兴趣！

4. Your story is only interesting to you!

 

不要让读者感到无聊。

Don’t bore the reader.

不要让读者感到无聊。

Don’t bore the reader.

不要让读者感到无聊。

Don’t bore the reader.

 

“当你走进电影院时，你应该感觉自己好像被火箭射中了屁股一样。”

加里·奥德曼

“When you go to a cinema, you should come out like having a rocket up your ass.”

Gary Oldman

这本书的很多内容，你可以持保留态度。如果你愿意，可以不同意我的观点。如果你认为我说的话很愚蠢，可以诽谤我的人格。但是，无论你做什么，都不要无聊。这是唯一不可侵犯的规则。如果一个场景、你的想法或主角无聊，请停止写作，直到你找到一种不无聊的方法。

A lot of this book, you’re welcome to take with a grain of salt. Disagree with me if you like. Cast aspersions on my character if I say something you think is moronic. But, whatever you do, don’t be boring. That’s the only inviolable rule. If a scene, or your idea, or the main character is ever boring, stop writing until you figure out a way to un-boring it.

这很难，特别是如果你的故事是自传的话。

This is tough, especially if your tale is autobiographical.

告诉人们“哟，当这件事发生在我身上时，我感到很激动”，但很遗憾，这还不够。仅仅因为你经历过这件事时很激动，并不意味着它对读者有用。仅仅因为你在小狗死后哭了，并不意味着读者也会哭。尤其是当 Fido 被保险箱砸中而死去时。

Telling people, “Yo, when it happened to me, it was so intense” is, sadly, not enough. Just because it was exciting when you lived through it, doesn’t mean it’s going to work for the reader. Just ’cause you cried when your doggie died doesn’t mean the reader will. Especially if Fido croaked when a safe fell on him.

您的生活可能不适合拍成电影，因此在改编成戏剧时要小心；但是，请深入挖掘您的生活，寻找情感。您可以拍一部关于您感受的精彩电影，因为强烈的情感具有普遍性，会像流沙一样吸引读者。

Your life is probably not a good subject for a movie, so beware adapting it into drama; however, do dig deep into your life for emotion. You can make a fantastic movie about how you felt, as a strong emotion will be universal and will suck the reader in like quicksand.

我们可能不在乎你九岁时做了什么，但我们肯定关心你的感受。我的剧本是关于西贡沦陷的灵感来自我小时候看的《音乐之声》，当时我为家人在被纳粹抓捕前逃离祖国而感到恐惧。我利用自己内心深处的恐惧来创作剧本。结果，其他人也对此感同身受，剧本卖得很好。

We probably don’t care what you did when you were nine, but we sure do care how you felt. My script about the fall of Saigon came from my watching The Sound of Music as a child and being terrified for the family trying to get out of the country before the Nazis captured them. I tapped into my own deep fear to write the screenplay. Turns out, other people related to it too, and the script sold.

曾几何时，比利·鲍勃·桑顿是一名演员，他受到虐待，生活悲惨。在一个悲惨的精神世界里，他躲在自己的拖车里，对着镜子做鬼脸，开始自言自语，诉说自己的感受。从他破碎的灵魂和灼热的镜子长篇大论中，他塑造了《弹簧刀》中令人惊叹的卡尔这个角色。卡尔不是比利·鲍勃，但他们有着相同的情感联系。他因挖掘了自己的悲伤而获得了一座闪亮的奥斯卡奖。

Once upon a time, Billy Bob Thornton, working as an actor, was mistreated and miserable. In a wretched spiritual place, he hid out in his trailer, made faces in the mirror and started talking to himself about how he felt. From his shattered soul and searing mirror-diatribes, he squeezed the amazing character, Carl, in Sling Blade. Carl is not Billy Bob, but they share the same emotional connective tissue. Landed himself a nice, shiny Academy Award for tapping into his sadness.

你为什么关心竞技交际舞？什么都不在乎，对吧？观看《舞国英雄》的前十分钟，制片人会让你相信竞技交际舞是世界上最重要的事情！

What do you care about competitive ballroom dance? Nothing, right? Watch the first ten minutes of Strictly Ballroom and the filmmakers will convince you that competitive ballroom dance is the most important thing in the world!

 

“没有人理解你，并不意味着你就是艺术家。”

汽车保险杠贴纸

“The fact that no one understands you does not make you an artist.”

bumper sticker

仅仅因为你喜欢它，并不意味着其他人会关心它。仅仅因为你认为这是一个好主意，并不意味着它就是一个好主意。如果你的主意不妙，你就是在浪费时间。我的意思是一个好主意。在《X档案》中，编剧有时会每天工作十个小时，持续六个月，想出一个可以成为一集的主意。这很难做到。

Just because you dig it, doesn’t mean anyone else is going to care. Just because you think it’s a great idea doesn’t mean it is a great idea. If your idea isn’t great, you’re wasting your time. And I mean a GREAT idea. On X-Files, a writer would sometimes work ten hours a day for six months to come up with one idea that would become an episode. It’s that difficult to do.

好消息是，在这个阶段，你浪费的只是时间。好吧，如果你出去砌砖拿工资，而不是坐在咖啡店里根据只有你才会关心的想法写剧本，你本可以赚到钱。

The good news, at this stage: it’s only your time you’re wasting. Well, that and money you could have made had you been out getting paid to lay bricks instead of sitting in a coffee shop writing a screenplay based on an idea only you will care about.

只是因为你花时间写了它，有人会想读它吗？或者看这部电影吗？真的吗？别浪费你的时间。或者别人的时间。

Just because you take the time to write it, is anyone going to want to read it? Or see the movie? Really and truly? Don’t waste your time. Or anyone else’s.

 

“写你所知道的。”

每个创意写作老师

“Write what you know.”

every creative writing teacher

 

“他写他所知道的东西。没花多长时间。”

霍华德·内梅罗夫

“He wrote what he knew. It didn’t take long.”

Howard Nemerov

内梅洛夫是美国桂冠诗人。他对写作颇有心得！从某些方面来说，如果你是一个真正的作家，你不能只写你知道的东西。你必须站在跳水板的末端，蒙上眼睛……伸手，伸手……当然，你可以在写作中运用你所知道的东西，但你可以走出自己的舒适区。你认为创作《越狱》系列剧的人坐过牢吗？《黑道家族》的创作者既不是治疗师，也不是黑手党头目。马里奥·普佐是意大利人，所以他了解意大利面、家庭、荣誉，也知道意大利裔美国人意味着什么。他弥补了其余的一切，并创作了《教父》。

Nemerov was poet laureate of the United States. He knew a thing or two about writing! In some respects, if you’re a real writer, you can’t write just what you know. You have to be out there on the end of the diving board, blindfolded… reaching, reaching…. You can use what you know in your writing, sure, but you are allowed to move outside your comfort zone. Do you think the guy who created the series Prison Break served time? The Sopranos creator is neither a therapist nor a mafia don. Mario Puzo was Italian, so he knew about pasta and family and honor and what it meant to be Italian-American. He made up the rest and it became The Godfather.

“写你所知道的”最有用的意思是：把你内心翻腾的东西用在你的写作中。这并不意味着，如果你是一名二年级的老师，你就只能写二年级的老师。但是如果你是一名二年级的老师，而你正在写一位二年级的老师，那么一定要确保她正处于一个能深深吸引每个人的情感故事之中。

“Write what you know” at its most useful means: take something churning inside you and use it in your writing. It doesn’t mean that, if you’re a second grade teacher, you can only write about second grade teachers. But if you are a second grade teacher, and you’re writing about a second grade teacher, make certain she is in the middle of an emotional story that is going to hook everybody, deep.

5. 你的故事讲的是悲惨的人，他们一生都很悲惨，最后结局也很悲惨！或者更糟！！

5. Your story is about miserable people who are miserable the whole time and end miserably! Or worse!!

 

我的工作不是告诉你该写什么。你必须写一些能让你早上起床的东西，或者让你熬夜的东西，或者让你在车里口述的东西，或者让你坐在公园里写作的东西，而不是呆在家里被你的配偶大吼大叫，因为你没有照顾好你的孩子。

It is not my job to tell you what to write. You have to write something that will get you up in the morning, or get you to stay up late at night, or get you to dictate in your car, or sit in a park and write instead of being at home getting yelled at by your spouse because you’re not looking after your children.

写你想写的。不过，对于主题，我不建议写痛苦，尤其是无休止的痛苦。这可能是你的生活，但我们想要一个故事。

Write what you wanna write. However, for a topic, I don’t suggest misery, especially relentless, unending misery. It may be your life, but we want a story.

拍一部电影非常非常困难。如果你的电影讲的是无尽的残酷恐怖，那么难度就要增加四倍或五倍。如果结尾没有精神上的升华，读者就会把剧本扔进壁炉里，看着它燃烧，咯咯笑个不停。为什么观众要和角色一起受苦，而这一切都是徒劳的？

It’s very, very, very hard to get a movie made. Quadruple or quintuple that degree of difficulty when your movie is about endless grim horribleness. If there is no spiritual uplift at the end, the reader is going to heave the script into their fireplace and cackle as it burns. Why should the audience suffer along with the character only for it to have been in vain?

帕特里克·马伯将佐伊·海勒的小说《她在想什么》改编成剧本《丑闻笔记》。在书中所有角色经历了磨难之后，他们最终陷入了低谷、黑暗、可怕的境地，没有救赎的希望。自杀区。这不是你想要的电影结局。聪明的小伙子马伯重新设计了结局，让我们对主角抱有希望。虽然没有太多希望，但足以让观众认为，“哦，她经历了这整个悲惨的经历，至少她学到了一些东西，也许可以挽救她的婚姻！”呼。

Patrick Marber adapted the Zoe Heller novel What Was She Thinking into the screenplay Notes on a Scandal. After all the characters’ trials and tribulations, the book ends with them in a low, dark, awful place, with zero hope for redemption. The suicide zone. NOT how you want to end a movie. Marber, clever lad, reworked the finale to give us hope for the main character. Not a lot, but enough for the audience to think, “Oh, she’s gone through this whole wretched experience and at least she’s learned something, and maybe can save her marriage!” Whew.

让读者在希望或救赎的氛围中结束这部影片。保罗·哈吉斯的《百万美元宝贝》结局悲惨，但随后主角终于做了他一直想做的事情。我们带着一丝兴奋离开影院。虽然我们感到悲伤，但我们为男主角感到高兴，因为他在悲伤中找到了一些快乐。好主意，作家先生！

Let the reader end on a note of hope or redemption. Million Dollar Baby, by Paul Haggis, has a grim ending which is then followed by the lead character’s at last doing what he’d always wanted to do. We leave the theater with a smidgen of an uplift. Though we’re sad, we feel good for the hero, as he’s managed to find something happy in the midst of his sadness. Good plan, Mr. Writer!

要么有一个美好的结局，要么想办法给读者一些希望！

Either have a happy ending or figure out a way to give the reader some hope!

6. 您没有花足够的时间来构思一个精彩的标题！

6. You haven’t spent enough time thinking up a fantastic title!

 

你的标题是好标题还是愚蠢的标题？它是否没有暗示你的故事？它是否是一个没有人会理解的标题，没有人会理解你会关心什么？它是否太奇怪以至于让人反感？它是主角的名字吗？它发音或拼写困难吗？

Is your title a good title or a stupid title? Does it give no hint about your story? Is it a title no one will understand and no one will care about? Is it so weird that it’s going to be off-putting? Is it the main character’s name? Is it hard to pronounce or spell?

如果您的标题不够出色，请更改它。

If you have a less-than-stellar title, change it.

如果片名能让你微笑、大笑或产生温暖、迷茫的感觉，那就保留它。如果它告诉读者这部电影是关于什么的，那就保留它。片名是人们了解你的剧本的第一件事。如果你的片名很蠢，他们会认为这将是一个愚蠢的剧本。我再怎么强调也不为过。

If the title makes you smile or laugh or get a warm and fuzzy feeling, keep it. If it tells the reader what the movie’s about, keep it. The title is the first thing people learn about your script. If you have a dumb title, they’ll think it’s going to be a stupid screenplay. I cannot emphasize this enough.

我当时正在和我以前的一个学生通电话，他是洛杉矶的一名经纪人助理，他有两个剧本可以选择。他选了那个名字很酷的。他认为如果有人能想出一个好名字，那么剧本可能也会很好。我不时想知道那个剧本是否被人看过。

I was on the phone with one of my former students, an agent’s assistant in Los Angeles, and he had a choice of two screenplays to read. He picked the one with the cool title. He figured that if someone could think up a good title, maybe the script would be good too. From time to time, I wonder if that other screenplay ever got read.

我最喜欢的片名是《银翼杀手》。它很酷很吸引人，让我想读剧本或看电影。我很乐意把我写的每一部电影都命名为：《银翼杀手》。是的！

My favorite title is Blade Runner. It’s cool and compelling and makes me want to read the script or see the movie. I’d be happy naming every movie I write: Blade Runner. Yeah!

这些都不错：《异形》、《富人和名人》、《乱世佳人》、《天堂的烦恼》、《角斗士》、《美丽心灵》、《地动天惊》、《二手车商》、《金龟车》、《疯狂的乔治王》、《生死时速》、《最年长的南方邦联寡妇吐露一切》、《机械战警》、《女友星期五》、《厄内斯特拯救圣诞节》、《热天午后》。

These are good: Alien, Rich and Famous, Gone with the Wind, Trouble in Paradise, Gladiator, A Beautiful Mind, Tremors, Used Cars, Herbie: Fully Loaded, The Madness of King George, Speed, Oldest Living Confederate Widow Tells All, Robocop, His Girl Friday, Ernest Saves Christmas, Dog Day Afternoon.

这些，嗯，不太好，因为你不知道电影是关于什么的：The Island、K-Pax、SwimFan、She's the Man、The Man、Monster、Signs、Tomorrow Never Dies、Go、The Grudge、Fur、The Neverending Story、Music and Lyrics、Freddy Got Fingered、Gigli、Manos: The Hands of Fate、Jeeper's Creepers、August Rush。

These are, um, less good because you have no idea what the movie is about: The Island, K-Pax, SwimFan, She’s the Man, The Man, Monster, Signs, Tomorrow Never Dies, Go, The Grudge, Fur, The Neverending Story, Music and Lyrics, Freddy Got Fingered, Gigli, Manos: The Hands of Fate, Jeeper’s Creepers, August Rush.

《婚礼傲客》、《四十岁的老处男》和《一夜大肚》怎么样？这些片名太棒了——令人愉悦又引人入胜，而且它们告诉你这部电影讲的是什么！可惜，这些片名已经被占用了。

How about Wedding Crashers, The 40-Year-Old Virgin, and Knocked Up? What GREAT titles — delightfully intriguing, and they tell you what the movie’s about! Unfortunately, they’re taken.

你能想出的最佳片名是你的吗？试着为你的电影想出至少 50 个片名。给你的朋友发邮件，让他们推荐标题。请他们从您最喜欢的十部电影中挑选一部。去音乐商店看看歌曲标题。去 imdb.com 上偷取一部 1934 年的电影的标题。努力找到最好的标题。

Is yours the best you can come up with? Try to think of at least 50 titles for your film. Email your friends and ask them to suggest titles. Ask them to choose between your top ten. Visit a music store and look at song titles. Go to imdb.com and steal a title from a film made in 1934. Make the effort to find the best title you possibly can.

这会带来影响。

It will make a difference.

特点

Character

 

7.你选错了主角！

7. You picked the wrong main character!

 

你会惊讶地发现，人们写完一整部剧本后，才发现他们把错误的人当成了英雄。这很难做到，而且发现自己犯了错误会让人沮丧。但是，在这个阶段，最好把剧本扔掉，围绕合适的人重写，而不是把它交给一个真实的人，浪费他们给你的唯一一次阅读机会。

You’d be surprised how often people write an entire screenplay only to find they’ve written it with the wrong person as their hero. This is a tough one to get right, and is demoralizing to discover you’ve goofed. But, it’s better at this stage to throw the script out and rewrite it around the right person than give it to someone real and squander the only read they’ll ever give you.

什么告诉你已经找到了正确的主角？

What tells you you’ve got the right main character?

英雄试金石

Hero Litmus Test

 

1）你的英雄必须活跃。

1) Your hero must be active.

他必须掌控行动、问题或命运，并不断奋斗，直到战胜坏人。不积极的英雄永远不会吸引观众或读者。逃亡者理查德·金博尔博士从不放弃。无论遇到什么问题，他都会不断努力寻找解决方案并继续奋斗。

He must seize control of the action, his problem, or his destiny and struggle without quitting until he has triumphed over the bad guy. A hero who is not active will never engage the audience or the reader. Dr. Richard Kimball, the Fugitive, never gives up. No matter what problems are thrown at him, he fights and fights to find a solution and continues the struggle.

 

 

她会主动采取行动还是让别人去想接下来发生的事情？是的，你可以写一个剧本，讲述一个坐着不动、不采取行动、不做决定、始终保持沉默和被动的角色，但娜塔莉·波特曼不会扮演她。

Does she initiate action or allow other people to think up the stuff that happens? Yes, you can write a screenplay about a character who sits still and takes no action and makes no decisions and is quiet and passive the entire time, but Natalie Portman won’t play her.

 

 

被动的主角是前往 Palookaville 的单程票。

A passive main character is a one-way ticket to Palookaville.

 

 

2）你的英雄必须有一个明确的问题。

2) Your hero must have a well-defined problem.

一个问题。它必须简单。它必须让读者清楚，并且读者需要首先了解这个问题十页。不能有多个问题。只能有一个主要问题，即电影的主题。电影更接近短篇故事，而不是小说。保持简单。

One problem. It must be simple. It must be clear to the reader, and that reader needs to know about that problem in the first ten pages. There can’t be several problems. There can only be one main problem, which is what the movie is about. A movie is closer to a short story than a novel. Keep it simple.

 

 

一个问题。

One problem.

 

 

3）主人公的问题必须引起观众的兴趣。

3) The hero’s problem must be interesting to an audience.

仅仅因为你觉得它很有趣，我可能不这么认为。你必须让我们参与进来。问题必须足够强大，才能让我们读完 110 页。不要想得太小，要想得更大。

Just because you think it’s fascinating, I may not. You have to engage us. The problem must be strong enough to drag us all the way through 110 pages. Don’t think tiny, think huge.

 

 

英雄的问题越大，读者就越感兴趣。这并不意味着每部电影都必须讲述一个人炸毁一颗流氓小行星，以阻止它撞向地球并消灭我们所知的生命。问题必须是你的角色所要面对的最困难的问题。在《突破》中，英雄努力弄清自己是骑自行车的人还是石匠。在《太坏了》中，他想喝点酒，这样他就可以和美丽的女孩出去了。

The bigger the hero’s problem, the more engaging it will be for the reader. This does not mean every movie has to be about a guy blowing up a rogue asteroid to stop it from crashing into earth and wiping out life as we know it. The problem has to be the most difficult problem your character would ever have to deal with. In Breaking Away, the hero struggles to find out if he’s a bike rider or a stone cutter. In Superbad, he wants to get some liquor so he can go out with the beautiful girl.

 

 

对于整个宇宙来说，这可能不是什么大问题，但对于电影中的人们来说，这一定是个大问题。

It may not be a big problem to the Universe At Large, but it had better be HUGE for the people in the movie.

 

 

4）英雄必须解决他/她自己的问题。

4) Hero must solve his/her own problem.

关键时刻没人能救他。他必须靠自己坚持到底。他可以有盟友，但在最后的战斗中，你的英雄必须靠自己打败邪恶势力（如果你是英国人：邪恶）。

No one can save him in the big moment. He must gut it through on his own. He can have allies, but in the final battle, your hero has to down the forces of evil (if you’re British: eeevil) on his own.

 

 

她最后是想出了一个好主意，拯救了自己，还是其他人拯救了她？那个人可能是主角的不错人选！

Does she come up with a great idea and save herself at the end, or does someone else do the saving? That someone else might be a good candidate for Main Character!

 

 

在《埃及王子》中，以色列人逃离埃及人，却不幸撞上了红海。他们不可能不被抓住——百分百是炮灰。突然，一道火柱突然出现，阻挡了坏人，摩西有足够的时间想办法分开红海，把大家带到安全地带。摩西没能解决自己的问题。这是天降神兵的典型例子，我查了一下《圣经》看看是否真的发生过，因为只有这样，迪士尼的优秀人才才会允许这种糟糕的剧本。好吧，火柱确实在《圣经》中出现过，但剧本写得非常差劲。

In Prince of Egypt, the Israelites are running away from the Egyptians and come smack up against the Red Sea. There’s no way they aren’t going to get caught — guaranteed 100% cannon fodder. Suddenly, out of the blue, comes a pillar of fire that stops the bad guys juuuust long enough for Moses to figure out how to part the Red Sea and hustle everybody to safety. Moses doesn’t solve his own problem. It’s such an egregious example of deus ex machina that I looked in the Bible to see if had actually happened, because that would have been the only way the fine folks at Disney would have allowed such crummy writing. Okay, so the pillar of fire happened in the Bible, but it’s incredibly poor screenwriting.

 

 

在《木偶奇遇记》中，每当木偶奇遇记陷入困境时，蓝仙女就会飞下来给他一个他自己无法找到的线索。天降神兵是推动故事发展的低级方式。避免使用它。

In Pinocchio, every time Pinocchio gets in a jam, the Blue Fairy swoops down and gives him a clue he’s been unable to find on his own. Deus ex machina is a low level way to move a story forward. Avoid it.

如果您对上述四条准则有疑问，请认真重新考虑您的主角。

If you have trouble with the above four guidelines, give your main character a serious re-think.

问问自己：你的女主角是不是总是处于困境之中？她是不是总是遇到越来越大、越来越快的问题？

Ask yourself: Is your heroine in the crusher all the time? Is she the one having larger and larger problems thrown at her, faster and faster?

她的情感是否足够丰富，足以支撑整个故事？

Are her emotions big enough to hang a whole story on?

她的问题让你着迷吗？还是她那位在厨房里制造战斗机、把你的裙子炸掉的姨妈让你着迷？这个故事真的是“关于”她吗？也许这个故事实际上是“关于”别人的，比如主角的弟弟。这就是为什么你会把你的草稿交给朋友阅读，并问他：“你认为贝蒂是主角，还是维罗妮卡是主角？”

Is her problem one you’re fascinated by, or is it really her aunt, who’s building a fighter plane in her kitchen, who blows your dress up? Is the story really and truly “about” her? Perhaps the story is really “about” someone else, say the lead character’s little brother. This is why you give your rough draft to a friend to read and ask, “Do you think Betty is the lead, or is it Veronica?”

她大部分时间都出现在屏幕上吗？

Is she on screen most of the time?

她是不是那个在烈火中奋力拼搏，最终蜕变的女演员？那个做出改变的女演员往往就是获得奥斯卡奖的那个人。

Is she the one who fights her way through a fiery furnace to be transformed at the end? The actress who does the changing is often the one with the Oscar.

如果你选错了主角，那就高兴吧！你已经做了很多出色的工作，这些工作将为你的新故事增色不少。你可以继续前进，因为你知道你终于走上了正确的道路。最棒的是，你没有把剧本寄出去。否则，你大量的出色工作就浪费了时间。

If you’ve chosen the wrong main character, rejoice! You’ve done heaps of good work which will serve your new story. You can sail forward knowing that at last, you’re on the right path. Best of all, you didn’t send your script out. Then your heaps of good work would have been a waste of time.

你应该庆幸自己现在才发现，而不是在获得 CAA 的报道后才发现。

Be glad you found out now, instead of when you got hold of CAA’s coverage.

8. 你还没有正确塑造你的主角！

8. You haven’t constructed your main character correctly!

 

不要忘记《寻找福雷斯特》中最重要的一课。你正在写一个演员诱饵。

Don’t forget the all-important Finding Forrester lesson. You’re writing actor bait.

演员会喜欢你的剧本，因为他们想扮演你塑造的角色。好好塑造他们吧！

Actors will attach to your script because they want to play the characters you construct. Construct them well!

情节源自人物。事情的发生取决于人物性格。在《夺宝奇兵》的开篇，我们了解到哈里森·福特非常害怕蛇。这是他性格的一部分。所以，在高潮部分，蛇一定是他的敌人！在《阿拉伯的劳伦斯》中，他热衷于避免流血；后来，他改变了，开始享受杀戮。在《卡萨布兰卡》中，里克坚定地不会为任何人冒险，最后，他确实这么做了。

Plot comes from character. Things happen because of who they are. Early in Raiders of the Lost Ark, we learn Harrison Ford is terrified of snakes. It’s part of his character. So, at the climax, it has to be snakes! In Lawrence of Arabia, he has a passion to avoid bloodshed; later, he changes and enjoys killing. In Casablanca, Rick steadfastly won’t stick his neck out for anyone, and finally, that’s exactly what he does.

让我们谈谈角色变化。角色的“弧线”。他们在开始时是谁，在结束时是谁。演员有时会查看前十页和后十页，看看是否有重大变化。如果角色没有变化，他们就会放下剧本。正如罗克中士所说，“啊，啊！”

Let’s talk about character change. The character’s “arc.” Who they are at the beginning versus who they are at the end. Actors sometimes look at the first ten pages and the last ten pages to see if there is a big change. If the character doesn’t change, they put down the script. As Sergeant Rock would say, “ARGGGGGHHHH!”

角色转变很重要。这种转变在生活中很少发生：我们希望善良和正义取得胜利，但我们也希望角色能够找到自我，成为他们最初不是的样子。

Character transformation is important. It happens so seldom in life: we want goodness and justice to triumph, but we also want the characters to figure something out about themselves, becoming something that they weren’t at the beginning.

还记得《圣诞怪杰》吗？故事开始时，令人讨厌的格林奇心肠太小。到最后，他的心肠长大了，他面带微笑，对 Whoville 的人们很友善。巨大的变化。在《关于亨利》中，哈里森·福特是个混蛋。他被枪击后，重新发现了自己的生活，并最终成为了一个更好的人。在《绿野仙踪》中，多萝西讨厌堪萨斯，但最终很高兴能回家。在《窈窕淑女》中，丽莎·杜立特一开始是个下流货色，最后却成了淑女。在《面具》中，斯坦利·伊普基斯是一个卑躬屈膝的失败者，而面具释放了他的内心。天哪，他淡出后完全变了一个人！

Remember How the Grinch Stole Christmas? When the story starts, the terribly unpleasant Grinch’s heart is too small. By the end, it grows two sizes and he smiles and is nice to folks in Whoville. Massive change. In Regarding Henry, Harrison Ford is a jerk. He gets shot, rediscovers his life, and ends a better person. In The Wizard of Oz, Dorothy hates Kansas and ends up thrilled to come home. In My Fair Lady, Liza Doolittle starts as gutter trash and finishes a lady. In The Mask, Stanley Ipkiss is a sniveling obsequious loser, and the Mask releases his inner self. Boy, is he different at fade out!

主角并不总是需要改变。 《荒野大镖客》中的无名之辈有角色弧吗？不不不。

The main character doesn’t always have to change. Does the Man With No Name in A Fistful of Dollars have a character arc? Naaaaaaaaaah.

在比利·怀尔德 (Billy Wilder) 和 IAL Diamond 执导的《公寓春光》中，杰克·莱蒙 (Jack Lemmon) 是一个书呆子(他的邻居也称他为书呆子！)，他学着成为一个正人君子(他这样称呼自己)。

In Billy Wilder and I.A.L. Diamond’s The Apartment, Jack Lemmon is a nebbish (and his neighbor calls him one!) who learns to be a mensch (which he calls himself).

一开始：

At the start:

 

杰克一心想在保险公司里升职，为此，他用自己的公寓给副总裁们买零食和酒，招待他们的情妇。他很孤独，吃冷冻食品。他在别人的聚会后洗碗。他是个野心勃勃的软弱之人。

Jack is desperate to work his way up in the insurance company, and to that end, buys snacks and liquor for the VPs using his apartment to um, entertain their mistresses. He’s lonely and eats frozen food. He washes dishes after someone else’s party. He’s a doormat with ambition.

 

当他被说服冒雨离开公寓，以便他的一位老板可以和某个傻妞鬼混时，他很生气，但保持沉默。很明显，如果他不让他们使用公寓，他的工作就岌岌可危了。

When he allows himself to be convinced to leave his apartment in the rain so one of his bosses can screw some ditzy babe, he’s angry, but keeps his yap shut. It’s clear his job is on the line if he doesn’t let them use the apartment.

稍后：

Later on:

 

他把公寓钥匙交给了弗莱德·麦克莫里，后者去那里与电梯女郎发生性关系，而电梯女郎正是杰克·莱蒙爱上的女孩！但是，他却得到了他梦寐以求的升职。

He gives the apartment key to Fred MacMurray, who goes there to have sex with the elevator girl, the girl Jack Lemmon has fallen in love with! But, he does get that big promotion he’d wanted.

然后，再往前走：

Then, way further down the road:

 

杰克再也无法忍受这种安排，他告诉弗雷德他不能再使用这间公寓了。杰克决定成为一个男人，一个正常人，于是辞去了工作。他的一切都不同了。甚至他的语气也变了。而且，一旦他变了，他终于让可爱的雪莉·麦克雷恩和他一起打牌。瞧。

Jack no longer can tolerate this arrangement and tells Fred he can’t use the apartment any more. Jack gives up his job, after deciding to become a mensch, a human being. Everything about him is different. Even his tone of voice has changed. And, once he’s transformed, he finally gets adorable Shirley MacLaine to play cards with him. Voilà.

杰克变了。变化很大。你的主角也应该如此。

Jack changes. A lot. Your main character should too.

当你弄清楚为什么你的角色是这样的时，请按照以下顺序构建层蛋糕：

When you’re figuring out why your characters are the way they are, build the layer cake in this order:

 

他们到底是谁？他是艺术品窃贼还是牧师？她来自芝加哥，是一名水下焊工。他是古罗马的角斗士。他是一个手上拿着剪刀的怪孩子。她是一个会飞的修女。他是一个有赌博问题的商人。

Who are they, basically? Is he an art thief or a priest? She’s from Chicago and is an underwater welder. He’s a gladiator in Ancient Rome. He’s a weird kid with scissors for hands. She’s a nun who can fly. He’s a businessman with a gambling problem.

 

她们内心有冲突吗？萨莉既软弱又坚强吗？她内心既善良又邪恶吗？一边是恶魔，另一边是天使？萨莉想成为好女孩返校节女王，但她也想杀死她的竞争对手。

Are they in conflict inside themselves? Is Sally weak and strong at the same time? Is there good and evil inside her, a demon on one shoulder, an angel on the other? Sally wants to be the good girl homecoming queen, but she also wants to murder her competition.

 

他们性格的具体特征？个性特征。文化影响。经济背景。历史时期。职业。所有这些都影响着他们的言行举止。他们的信仰是什么？道德观是什么？他们对父母、孩子或同事有什么感觉？她容易激动吗？他讨厌撒谎的人吗？他是撒谎者吗？他是不是在一万年前被冻在一块冰里，所以铅笔是个奇迹？她是不是园艺狂热者？等等。

Specific characteristics of their character? Personality traits. Cultural influence. Financial background. Historical period. Occupation. All this influences how they talk, move and act. What are their beliefs? Morals? How do they feel about their parents or their children or their coworkers? Is she excitable? Does he hate liars? Is he a liar? Was he frozen in a lump of ice ten thousand years ago, so a pencil is a miracle? Is she a gardening fanatic? and on and on.

 

读者喜欢细节。演员也一样。你的男人在亲吻妻子的脖子时喜欢说法语吗？他的口袋里是否装着圣克里斯托弗奖章？左撇子对她有什么影响？她是否把拔下来的眉毛排列在水槽边缘？当她说“爸爸”时，她会结巴吗？

Readers love details. So do actors. Does your guy love to speak French when he kisses his wife on her neck? Does he carry a St. Christopher medal in his pocket? How does being left-handed affect her? Does she line up her plucked eyebrow hair on the edge of the sink? Does she stutter when she has to say, “Father.”

 

最后，这些特征是否贯穿整个故事？不要因为需要而制造意外惊喜。一旦你定义了他的核心性格，他所做的一切都必须符合这个角色。他不能是素食主义者，然后突然开始吃培根。

Finally, are they consistent throughout the story? No wild card surprises just because you need one. Once you’ve defined his core personality, everything he does must fit that character. He can’t be a vegan and suddenly start eating bacon.

每个角色一定非常渴望得到一些东西。但是，他们需要的东西与他们想要的东西不同，他们最终必须得到那个。（当我就结构发表高谈阔论时，会对此进行更多讨论。）

Each character must want something, very badly. But, what they need is different from what they want, and they must get that by the end. (More about this when I pontificate about structure.)

这种渴望必须强烈到足以推动整部电影。它还必须简单。在《丰饶之旅》中，老妇人想回家。 《为黛西小姐开车》中的老妇人想要独立，但她的儿子不让她开车，并强迫她雇司机。

That desire must be strong enough to drive the whole movie. It also has to be simple. In The Trip to Bountiful, the old woman wants to go home. The old woman in Driving Miss Daisy wants independence but her son wants her not to drive, and forces her to hire a chauffeur.

角色们必须避免面临简单的决定，例如“我是要嫁给返校节女王还是进监狱？”让他们做出令人心碎的道德决定：1）我爱我的丈夫，但我想和我的学生住在一起。2）好人杀了坏人。你会绞死他吗？3）如果我告诉我的客户真相，他们会庭外和解。如果我对他们撒谎，我可能会在法庭上大获全胜。

Characters must not be faced with an easy decision, like “Do I marry the homecoming queen or do I go to jail?” Give them a bone-crushing moral decision: 1) I love my husband but I want to move in with my student. 2) A good man kills a bad one. Do you hang him? 3) If I tell my clients the truth, they’ll settle out of court. If I lie to them, I might be able to win big in court.

鬼魂（就像在《哈姆雷特》中一样！）是指向英雄背后的矛头，驱使他不断前进。在《唐人街》中，过去，吉蒂斯想要保护一位女性，但她最终却受了伤。他极度不希望这种事情再次发生。在《紫苑花》中，英雄摔下了他的婴儿并因此死去。那个孩子的鬼魂正在活活地吞噬他。在《日落黄沙》中，罗伯特·瑞安背叛了他的挚友威廉·霍尔登，将其交给了法律。在《卡萨布兰卡》中，瑞克的鬼魂就是在巴黎发生的一切；他拥有过爱情，然后失去了它。这驱使他想要在下次有机会时紧紧抓住爱情。在《普通人》中，在电影开场之前，一个儿子死了，另一个试图自杀。死去的、更受爱戴的儿子的鬼魂将所有人物推向了边缘。

The ghost (like in Hamlet!) is the spear point at your hero’s back, driving him forward. In Chinatown, in the past, Gittes wanted to protect a woman, but she ended up getting hurt. He desperately doesn’t want that to happen again. In Ironweed, the hero dropped his baby and it died. The ghost of that child is eating him alive. In The Wild Bunch, Robert Ryan betrayed his best friend, William Holden, to the law. In Casablanca, Rick’s ghost is what happened in Paris; he had love and lost it. That drives him to want to hold onto love the next time he gets a chance. In Ordinary People, before the movie opened, one son died and the other tried to kill himself. The ghost of the dead, better-loved son pushes all the characters toward the brink.

背景故事不同于幽灵。背景故事解释了他们为什么会变成现在这个样子，因为过去发生了一些特定事件。背景故事可以是十件事，也可以是六件事，也可以是两件事。背景故事不是幽灵（英雄鞋子里的石头），而是他在新泽西长大，养过鸽子，出生在一个码头工人家庭，是一名拳击手，为了钱而摔跤，并且本可以成为一名竞争者。

Backstory is different from ghost. Backstory explains why they are the way they are because of specific events from the past. It can be ten things or six or two. It’s not the ghost (the stone in the hero’s shoe) but it’s that he grew up in New Jersey, raised pigeons, came from a family of longshoremen, was a boxer, took falls for short end money, and could have been a contender.

鬼魂是更大背景故事的一部分。不要花太多时间谈论鬼魂和背景故事。我们看到的是冰山一角，但你知道水面下的一切。

Ghost is part of a larger backstory. Don’t spend a lot of time talking about ghost and backstory. We see the tip of the iceberg, but you know everything that’s below the surface.

在《雨人》中，汤姆·克鲁斯是个很棒的孩子。有一次，他考了全优，向父亲要他珍爱的别克车的钥匙。老爸拒绝了。汤姆还是和朋友们一起把车开出去了，他父亲声称车被盗了。他们都进了监狱。其他男孩的父亲来接他们。但不是汤姆的父亲。他离开了他两天。一个男人试图强奸他，并用刀捅了他。出狱后，汤姆离家出走，再也没有回去。

In Rain Man, Tom Cruise was a great kid. One time he got all As and asked his father for the keys to the treasured Buick. The Old Man said no. Tom took it out with his friends anyway, and his father called the car in as stolen. They all went to jail. The other boys’ fathers came and got them. Not Tom’s. He left him for two days. A guy tried to rape him and knifed him. When he got out of jail, Tom left home and never went back.

汤姆对过去发生的事情的感受影响着他现在的一举一动。

How Tom feels about what happened in the past affects his every move in the present.

关于角色的最后想法：

Last thoughts on character:

你的英雄是 100% 优秀的吗？没有人应该如此。确保他们有一两个缺点。

Is your hero 100% good? No one should be. Make sure they’ve got a flaw or two.

是否存在您不需要的字符，或者您可以将两三个字符组合成一个字符？

Are there any characters you don’t need, or two or three you could combine into one character?

确保主角不会消失太久。

Make sure none of your main characters disappear for too long.

我们是通过人物的行为而不是对话来了解他们的吗？一个男人殴打他的妻子，哭着说他很抱歉，但还是继续殴打她。人物必须清晰可见，而且声音必须关闭。看着一个男人在把蔬菜罐头放进食品柜之前先清洗一下，这比他说“我是个洁癖狂”要好得多。

Do we learn about your characters by what they do — not through dialogue? A man beats his wife, cries and says he’s sorry, but keeps on beating her. Character must be visible with the sound turned off. Watching a guy wash his cans of vegetables before putting them in the pantry trumps his saying, “I’m a neat freak.”

如果场景中有两个人，请让他们完全不同。如果他们的性格截然不同，写作就会变得容易得多。一个崇拜克林顿。另一个在她的隔间里贴满了布什的贴纸。想象一下他们共进午餐！想象一下他们共进午餐，喝酒！

If you have two people in a scene, make them WILDLY different from one another. It becomes much easier to write if they have contrasting personalities. One worships Clinton. The other has Bush stickers all over her cubicle. Imagine them at lunch! Imagine them at lunch, drinking!

您是否给了角色尽可能多的时间去采取行动？在小说《迷人的四月》中，威尔金斯夫人在教堂认识了阿博思诺特夫人，并邀请她和自己一起在意大利租一栋别墅。在剧本中，威尔金斯夫人在报纸上登出一则广告，寻找可以合租别墅的人，这要冒更大的风险，而她就是这样认识阿博思诺特夫人的。这是作者更有趣的角色选择。

Have you given your character as many moments as possible to take action? In the novel, The Enchanted April, Mrs. Wilkins knows Mrs. Arbothnot from church and asks her to rent a villa in Italy with her.
