In the screenplay, Mrs. Wilkins places an ad in the paper searching for people to share rent the villa, a much greater risk, and that is how she meets Mrs. Arbothnot. It’s a more interesting character choice from the writer.

再次问，但这不是最后一次：你的角色会改变吗？改变越大，写起来就越容易。在 114 页的剧本中，如果托比从 A 一直变成 Z，想象一下你可以写多少步骤。但是，如果他只是从 A 变成 F，那就没什么变化了。很难写。

Again, and not for the last time: does your character change? The bigger the change, the easier it will be to write. In a 114-page script, if Toby changes from A all the way to Z, imagine how many steps along the way you can write about. But, if he only goes from A to F, that’s not much of a change. Tough to write.

很难变成演员诱饵！

Tough to turn into actor bait!

9. 创建角色时，您并不需要具体指定所有事项！

9. You are not specific about EVERYTHING when you create a character!

 

这是我和一位学生的对话。她饰演的角色琳达是医院的一名病人。罗宾是她的护士。

Here’s a conversation I had with a student. Her character, Linda, is a patient in a hospital. Robin is her nurse.

 

“那么，跟我说说琳达。”

“她病了。”

“她是怎么病的？”

“感染了。”

“什么样的感染？”

“她身体侧面插着一根管子，它被感染了。”

“她为什么要插管子？”

“她得了癌症。”

“什么样的癌症？”

“这重要吗？”

“嗯，是的。什么样的癌症会影响她的外表、感觉以及我们对她的看法。如果她得了乳腺癌，你就会有粉红丝带和许多政治议程，而这些不会伴随胰腺癌。”

“真的吗？”

“如果她得了胰腺癌，她肯定会死，虽然死得很快，但不会太痛苦。”

“So, tell me about Linda.”

“She’s sick.”

“How is she sick?”

“From an infection.”

“What kind of infection?”

“She has a tube in her side and it got infected.”

“Why has she got a tube?”

“She’s got cancer.”

“What kind of cancer?”

“Does it matter?”

“Well, yes. What kind of cancer affects how she appears, how she feels, and how we feel about her. If she’s got breast cancer, you’ve got pink ribbons and a lot of political agenda that doesn’t come with, say, pancreatic cancer.”

“Really?”

“And if she’s got pancreatic cancer, she’s for sure going to die, and it will be fast but it won’t be too painful.”

长时间的停顿。

Long pause.

 

我说：“所以你看，如果她病了，你一定要确切地知道她为什么病，因为这会影响一切。”

“是的，当然。现在我知道了。”

“现在，告诉我关于护士罗宾的事。”

“她对自己的生活状况非常不满。”

“我们怎么看这件事？”

“她偷药。”

“什么样的药？”

“我不知道。就药片。”

“兴奋剂？”

“也许吧。那可能有用。”

“那镇静剂呢？偷兴奋剂的人会和偷巴比妥类药物的人有非常不同的个人问题和性格特征。她吃止痛药吗？为什么？她性格中的哪一部分引导她偷奥施康定，还是吗啡？她的故事会非常不同，这取决于她偷的是哪种药。”“哦，是的，很酷。”

I said, “So you see how it really matters that, if she’s sick, that you know exactly why she’s sick, because it will affect everything.”

“Yeah, sure. Now I do.”

“Now, tell me about Robin, the nurse.”

“She’s very upset with where she is in her life.”

“How do we see this?”

“She steals pills.”

“What kind of pills?”

“I don’t know. Just pills.”

“Uppers?”

“Maybe. That might work.”

“What about downers? A person who steals uppers is going to have very different personal problems and a different character makeup than someone who steals barbiturates. Does she take pain killers? Why? What part of her personality directs her to steal Oxycontin, or morphine? Her story will be very different, depending on what kind of pills she steals.” “Oh, yeah, cool.”

就这样继续下去。谈话结束时，她对自己需要做的事情有了更好的了解，并且她明白了我说“你说得不具体”的意思。

And it went on from there. At the end of the conversation, she had a much better idea of what she needed to do, and she understood what I meant when I said, “You’re not being specific.”

你需要问自己同样的问题。如果你对一个角色说了些什么，比如“他很伤心”，这还不够。他是“伤心”还是“有自杀倾向”，当然，你必须知道原因。

You need to ask yourself these same questions. If you say something about a character, like “He’s sad,” that’s not enough. Is he “sad” or “suicidal,” and then, of course, you have to know why.

如果你发现自己在故事中说了什么，那就想办法让它具体化。不要说“他毕业于一所知名大学。”告诉我们是哪所学校！

If you find yourself saying anything in a story, figure out a way to make it specific. Don’t say, “He graduated from a well-known university.” Tell us what school!

演员会想知道这些事情。读者也会想知道。要具体。要非常具体。

The actor will want to know these things. So will the reader. Be specific. Be very specific.

10. 你还没有将“地点”塑造为你的故事中的一个角色！

10. You haven’t made “place” a character in your story!

 

以下是一些糟糕的写作：

Here’s some lousy writing:

 

 

 

 

淡入：

FADE IN:

 

 

外部。 不起眼的道家日

EXT. NONDESCRIPT TRACT HOME    DAY

 

 

一座普通城市里的一栋漂亮房子。

A nice home in an average city.

尽你所能地帮助自己。这没有帮助。

Give yourself all the help you can. This isn’t helping.

不存在所谓的“普通小镇”。不存在所谓的“中等城市”。现实生活中可能不存在，电影中肯定不存在。如果你对地点的选择不够明确，无论是乡村、城市还是房子里的某个房间，你都无法写出好作品。

There is no such thing as an “average small town.” No such thing as “a medium-size city.” Probably not in real life and certainly not in a movie. If you are not incredibly specific with your choice of location, be it country, city, or particular room in a house, you will not write as well as you should.

地点感应该被视为一个独立的人物。你的故事是否发生在你想要表达的正确时间和地点？你把人物放在哪里至关重要。

A sense of place should be treated as a separate character. Does your story happen in the correct time and location for what you’re trying to get across? Where you put people is crucial.

当你为故事选择一个地方时，不要说“郊区”，而应该说密歇根州的哈姆特拉克。选择一个城市或城镇，并把它塑造成一个角色。住在底特律以外的人会以不同于住在基韦斯特以外的人的方式受到当地环境的影响。如果你想知道地点对故事有多重要，请阅读蒂姆·高特罗的小说。

When you pick a place for your story, don’t say “suburbs” when you should say Hamtramck, Michigan. Pick a city or a town and make it a character. People who live outside Detroit are going to be affected by their locale in a different way than, say, people who live outside Key West. Read the novels of Tim Gautreaux if you want to see how place really matters to a story.

 

“人们的行为因所处位置而异。想象一下，丈夫和妻子在前院发生争吵。现在，把争吵转移到后院。争吵的性质会有什么变化？当人们知道邻居没有注意时，他们会有不同的行为。”

琼·特尤克斯伯里，《纳什维尔》的作家

“People behave differently depending on where they are. Imagine an argument that takes place between a husband and wife in their front yard. Now, move it to the back yard. How does that change the nature of the argument? People behave differently when they know their neighbors are not watching.”

Joan Tewkesbury, writer of Nashville

我为《保送入学》的制片人写了一个剧本。剧本以他大学一年级时爱上的一个女孩为背景。他的女朋友在费城上学，她的父母住在纽约，而他曾在长岛当救生员。出于某种原因，这个故事不太成功。我们不断修改，最后我终于意识到（几个月后！）我们被现实生活中发生的事情所困扰。我把剧本改成了女孩和她的父母在纽约。他们住在那里，她在那里上学。这改变了一切，让故事变得精彩。只是因为我决定让她住在纽约。

I wrote a script for the producer of Risky Business. It was based on his first year of college and a girl he had been in love with. His girlfriend had gone to school in Philadelphia and her parents lived in New York, and he’d been a life guard on Long Island. For some reason, the story didn’t work. We worked on it and worked on it, and I finally realized (after months!) that we were stuck on what had happened in real life. I changed it so the girl and her parents were in New York. They lived there and she was in school there. It changed everything and made the story work. Just because I decided to have her live in New York.

你的故事是否发生在最好的年份？合适的季节？想象一下，如果你的故事发生在阿拉斯加州诺姆，在隆冬时节，积雪三英尺，或者在加利福尼亚的海滩上，故事会有什么不同。如果人们来自内布拉斯加州或阿拉巴马州塞尔玛，他们会对事件有何反应？

Does your story happen in the best possible year? The right season? Imagine how different your story will be if it takes place in Nome, Alaska in the dead of winter with three feet of snow, or perhaps on the beach in California. How will people react to an event if they are from Nebraska or from Selma, Alabama?

地点感不仅会影响整个故事，还会影响个别场景。

A sense of place will affect not only your entire story, but individual scenes.

虽然《洛奇》中的这个例子实际上并非出自剧本，但我们就假装它出自剧本吧。史泰龙的剧本要求洛奇和阿德里安最终约会。他约她出去，她拒绝了，但他终于说服了她。他们去了一家餐馆。他们进行了一次愉快的交谈。这是一次美妙的初次约会，对吧？

While this example from Rocky doesn’t actually spring from the writing, let’s pretend it does. Stallone’s script called for Rocky and Adrian to finally go on a date. He’s asked her out and she’s refused, but he’s at last worn her down. They go to a restaurant. They have a lovely conversation. It’s a wonderful first date, right?

好吧，当拍摄这个场景时，他们负担不起租餐厅和支付所有这些临时演员的费用。他们不得不找一个便宜的、不需要临时演员的掩护场景。他们用了什么？一个晚上关闭的空溜冰场。

Well, when it got around to shooting the scene, they couldn’t afford to rent a restaurant and pay for all those extras. They had to find a cover set that was cheap to rent, requiring no extras. What did they use? An empty ice rink that was closing for the night.

剩下的就是电影历史了。让阿德里安穿上摇摇晃晃的溜冰鞋，洛基走在她身边，一边甜蜜地交谈，一边在餐厅里说着同样的话，这是一个绝妙的选择。赞博尼送冰机的家伙说他们几分钟后就要离开了，这带来了一点冲突，这是我最喜欢的电影场景之一。所有这些都是通过改变场景发生的地点来实现的。

The rest is movie history. Putting Adrian on wobbly skates and Rocky walking beside her while they had their sweet, halting conversation — same dialogue they’d have used in a restaurant — was a sublime choice. A little conflict thrown in from the Zamboni guy saying they have to leave in a few minutes, and you have one of my favorite scenes in any movie. All by changing where the scene takes place.

逐个场景地检查你的剧本，看看你是否可以将一些无聊的地点变成神奇的地方。

Go through your script, scene by scene, and see if you can turn a few boring locations into something magical.

11. 我们对你的英雄不感兴趣！

11. We have no rooting interest in your hero!

 

这并不意味着我们希望她去挖松露。

This does not mean we want her to dig for truffles.

 

“吸引人群的最简单方法是让人们知道，在特定的时间和特定的地点，有人将尝试某件事，如果失败，将导致突然死亡。”

哈利·胡迪尼

“The easiest way to attract a crowd is to let it be known that at a given time and a given place someone is going to attempt something that in the event of failure will result in sudden death.”

Harry Houdini

我们需要迫切希望你的英雄获胜。这并不意味着“要有一个令人同情的主角”。你的英雄不必令人同情。他不必善良。仅仅因为开发人员或写作老师说你的主角必须讨人喜欢，并不意味着你必须听从。如果你所有的朋友都跳下悬崖，你会吗？

We need to desperately want your hero to win. This does not mean “have a sympathetic lead character.” Your hero does not have to be sympathetic. He doesn’t have to be nice. Just because development people or writing teachers say your main character has to be likeable, doesn’t mean you have to listen. If all your friends jumped off a cliff, would you?

看看《尽善尽美》中的杰克·尼科尔森。他有同情心吗？我们看到他做的第一件事就是把一只可爱的小狗扔进垃圾槽！这可不讨人喜欢。当他被赶出餐厅时，所有的顾客都会鼓掌，因为每个人都讨厌他。

Look at Jack Nicholson in As Good As It Gets. Is he sympathetic? First thing we see him do is drop an adorable little dog down a garbage chute! That’s not likeable. When he gets thrown out of a restaurant, all the patrons applaud because everybody hates him.

这就是故事的主人公吗？

And this is the story’s hero?

他并不同情。一点也不。但是。我们确实同情他的处境。我们理解他的感受。我们理解他的问题。我们非常希望他能克服它。

He’s not sympathetic. Not at all. But. We do feel empathy for his situation. We identify with his feelings. We understand his problem. And we very much want him to overcome it.

我们支持他。

We’re rooting for him.

虽然杰克·尼科尔森的角色一点也不讨人喜欢，但他确实很迷人。我们希望他最后能得到海伦·亨特。我们希望他获胜！

While the Jack Nicholson character is not sympathetic in the slightest, he sure is fascinating. We want him to get Helen Hunt at the end. We want him to win!

如果你的主角不能让读者着迷，那么除了哭泣之外，其他一切都结束了。她可能是宇宙中最大的混蛋，但如果她很有趣，我们就会被吸引。看看莎士比亚的理查三世。现在，有一个世界级的 24 克拉邪恶混蛋。一点也不讨人喜欢，但我们无法将目光从这个人身上移开。想想粉红色先生。他不给小费。或者金发先生。他割掉了好警察先生的耳朵。这些人并不“有同情心”。他们很可怕！你永远不会邀请他们来吃千层面，但你肯定想在电影里看到他们。

If your lead character is not mesmerizingly compelling to the reader, it’s all over but the crying. She can be the biggest jerk in the universe, but if she’s interesting, we’re hooked. Look at Shakespeare’s Richard III. Now, there’s a world-class, 24 karat evil bastard. Not remotely likeable, but we can’t take our eyes off the guy. Think about Mr. Pink. He doesn’t tip. Or Mr. Blonde. He cuts off Mr. Nice Policeman’s ear. Those guys aren’t “sympathetic.” They’re horrible! You’d never invite them over for lasagna, but, you sure want to watch them in a movie.

以《阳光小美女》中脾气暴躁的老头艾伦·阿金为例。他现在是个令人不快的老家伙。但他爱他的孙女，花了很多时间帮助她练习舞蹈，所以我们希望他能赢。

Take Alan Arkin, the incredibly grumpy old man in Little Miss Sunshine. Now there’s an unpleasant old geezer. But, he loves his granddaughter and spends a ton of time helping her with her dance routine, so we want him to win.

我们希望男孩在《突破》中赢得比赛。我们希望桑德拉·布洛克在《选美小姐》中抓住坏人。我们希望亨伯特·亨伯特抓住洛丽塔。我们希望汤姆·克鲁斯和达斯汀·霍夫曼在《雨人》中解决他们的问题。我们希望布鲁斯·威利斯在《虎胆龙威》中打败汉斯·格鲁伯团伙。我们希望汤姆·鲁宾逊被判无罪，我们希望斯考特免受尤厄尔先生的伤害。

We want the boy to win the race in Breaking Away. We want Sandra Bullock to catch the bad guy in Miss Congeniality. We want Humbert Humbert to nail Lolita. We want Tom Cruise and Dustin Hoffman to work out their problems in Rain Man. We want Bruce Willis to defeat the Hans Gruber Gang in Die Hard. We want Tom Robinson to be found innocent and we want Scout to be safe from Mr. Ewell.

你必须设定好角色，这样我们才能希望他得到他想要的东西。但是，我们不必“喜欢”他。这是我挑选的“我们最讨厌，但我们仍然希望他获胜的人！”

You must set up the character so we want him to get what he wants. But, we don’t have to “like” him. Here’s my pick for “guy we loathe the most, but who we still want to win!”

在托德·索伦兹的《幸福》中，迪伦·贝克饰演一位深藏不露的恋童癖者。在一场儿童睡衣派对上，他给孩子们的冰块上撒了糖安眠药膏。不太令人同情。他想做的事是非法和不道德的，我们永远不会赞成，但随着障碍阻碍他的愿望，他越是要努力得到他想要的东西，我们就越希望他得到它——尽管我们内心深处知道他想要的是错的！错的！错的！错的！然而，我们仍然希望他获胜。这太神奇了。

In Todd Solondz’ Happiness, Dylan Baker plays a deeply closeted pedophile. At a child’s slumber party, he laces the kids’ ice cream with sleeping pills. Not so sympathetic. What he wants to do is illegal and immoral and nothing we would ever applaud, but as obstacles get in the way of his desire and the more he has to struggle to get what he wants, the more we want him to get it — even though down in our guts we know what he wants is wrong! wrong! wrong! wrong! Yet, we still want him to win. It’s amazing.

我们必须全力支持你的人获胜，否则你的故事将无人关心。

We have to be pulling for your guy to win, or you’ve got no story anyone will care about.

12.你的对手不是人！

12. Your opponent is not a human being!

 

“邪恶的纽约”并不是一部电影中的坏人。“人与人之间的残忍”不是约翰·丹曼这位强硬而暴躁的俄克拉荷马城私家侦探的对手。“黑暗而压抑的存在”并不是《异形》中西格妮·韦弗的威胁。那是一个怪物。一个巨大、长着滴答作响的獠牙的生物——就像《开放的美国学府》中的汉德先生。斯皮科利必须与一个人战斗。

“Evil New York City” is not a good bad guy for a movie. “Man’s inhumanity to man” is not an opponent for John Denman, tough and crusty Oklahoma City private investigator. “A dark and oppressive presence” was not what threatened Sigourney Weaver in Alien. It was a monster. A big, drippy-fanged creature — just like Mr. Hand in Fast Times at Ridgemont High. Spicoli had to do battle with a person.

你的英雄也应如此。

And so should your hero.

你的坏人不应该是疾病、“体制”、内疚或天气。这些可能是英雄的问题的一部分，但他必须面对人类。人们可以制定计划，有复杂的欲望和需求，有一套与英雄截然相反的信念，并且可以在房间里对他大喊大叫！

Your bad guy shouldn’t be a disease or “the system” or guilt or the weather. These can be part of the hero’s problem, but he must face off with a human being. People can make plans, have complex wants and needs, have a set of beliefs in direct opposition to the hero’s, and can be in a room to yell at him!

您可能会争辩说《僵尸肖恩》的对手是僵尸，但我要反驳的是，在僵尸袭击酒吧之前，人类之间发生了许多冲突，将那一小群人撕成了碎片。

You can argue that Shaun of the Dead had zombies as an opponent, but I will counter that there was plenty of human conflict ripping that little group of people to pieces well before the undead attacked the pub.

如果你想让邪恶的存在成为“医疗行业”，那就创造一个医生或护士来体现大医药令人厌恶的企业违法行为。看看《飞越疯人院》中的护士拉契特。露易丝·弗莱彻与杰克·尼科尔森。当她确实对他和他的医院伙伴们下手时，观众会感到很恐怖，而当他终于打败她时，观众会感到非常满意。因为她是一个人。

If you want the evil being to be “the medical profession,” create a doctor or nurse to embody the loathsome corporate transgressions of Big Medicine. Look at Nurse Ratched in One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest. Louise Fletcher is in near-mortal conflict with Jack Nicholson. It’s horrible for the audience when she does mean things to him and his hospital buddies, and it’s terribly satisfying when he, at long last, defeats her. Because she’s a person.

你必须找到一个英雄可以与之对抗的人。如果没有，那就找一个。

You have to have a person for the hero to fight against. If you don’t have one, find one.

另外，你不可能为“黑暗、压抑的存在”写出漂亮的对话。演员们想说很酷的话。如果演员们不想出演，制片人就不会拍你的电影。

Plus, you can’t write nifty dialogue for a “dark, oppressive presence.” Actors want to say cool stuff. And producers won’t make your movie if actors don’t want to be in it.

13. 你的坏人并不好！

13. Your Bad Guy isn’t great!

 

你的英雄有多有趣，取决于与他同台竞技的那个家伙。

Your hero is only as interesting as the dude he’s in the ring with.

 

“在科幻电影中，怪物应该总是比女主角更大。”

罗杰·科曼

“In science-fiction films the monster should always be bigger than the leading lady.”

Roger Corman

这是我对《空中大灌篮》海报的记忆：迈克尔乔丹身边笼罩着一只巨大、可怕、长着獠牙的怪物。

This is my memory of the Space Jam poster: Michael Jordan with a big, scary, fanged monster looming over him.

 

看这里。男主角是一位英俊、干净的篮球运动员。他聪明、强壮、长相帅气。完美的电影英雄。他与谁有冲突？不是街上那个可以打倒的小家伙蒂米，而是一个巨大的、可怕的、长着獠牙的外星人，他拥有超强的力量和狡猾的手段。此外，他还有野蛮的跳投能力。一个值得尊敬的对手！

Lookee here. The hero is a nice, clean-cut basketball player. He’s smart, strong, and good looking. The perfect movie hero. Who is he in conflict with? Not little Timmy from down the street, a squirt he could mop the floor with, no, but a huge, ghoulish, fanged space alien who has super strength and devious ways. Plus, a savage jump shot. A worthy opponent!

对手、坏人或反派必须比好人更强大，否则你就没有电影可拍。如果在故事的开头，我们在面对对手时没有感到胆战心惊，那么你就需要重写剧本了。这并不意味着她必须有一把射线枪。她可以是《普通人》中的玛丽·泰勒·摩尔。那个妈妈是一个强大、无情、无情的对手。

The opponent, or bad guy, or antagonist has to be stronger than the good guy or you’ve got no movie. If, at the start of your story, we’re not quaking in our boots when faced with the opponent, you have some rewriting to do. This does not mean she has to have a ray gun. It can be Mary Tyler Moore in Ordinary People. That mom is one strong, implacable, relentless opponent.

你的坏人必须一直在行动。他总是在策划阴谋。策划、偷窃、杀害、伤害、贬低或刮掉披萨上的奶酪。如果坏人没有不断做出（越来越聪明的）举动，他就不算坏人。

Your bad guy must always be taking action. He’s always plotting. Planning, stealing, killing, wounding, belittling, or scraping cheese off your pizza. If the bad guy isn’t constantly making (more and more clever) moves, he’s not much of a bad guy.

你的坏人和好人是否尽可能多地待在同一个房间里？想办法让他们面对面。让他们挂断电话，一起上车。如果有办法让坏人和好人成为商业伙伴而不是跨城对手，那就这么做吧。

Are your bad guy and good guy in the room together as much as possible? Figure out ways for them to be face to face. Get them off the phone and into a car together. If there is a way for the bad guy and the good guy to be business partners instead of cross-town rivals, do it.

不要让他 100% 坏。就像你的英雄不是 100% 好人一样，你的对手也不应该是彻头彻尾的混蛋。如果他是恐怖分子，就让他像美酒一样。在《卡萨布兰卡》中，斯特拉瑟少校并不是一个流口水的恶棍；他有充分的理由做他所做的事情。教父的动机是对家人的爱。戈登·盖柯的动力是成功和野心。贾斯·A·胡克船长受苦是因为“没有小孩子爱我”。

Don’t make him 100% bad. Just like your hero isn’t 100% good, your opponent shouldn’t be a total jerk. If he’s a terrorist, let him like fine wine. In Casablanca, Major Strasser is not a drooling villain; he has good reasons for doing what he does. The Godfather is motivated by love for his family. Gordon Gekko is driven by success and ambition. Captain Jas. A. Hook suffers because “no little children love me.”

那你的坏人是不是专门为了激怒好人而设的呢？如果好人因为在名牌大学教书赚不了多少钱而感到难过，那么坏人就住在街对面，靠教书赚两倍的钱。

What about your bad guy is set up precisely to punch the good guy’s buttons? If the good guy feels horrible because he doesn’t make much money at his prestigious university teaching job, the bad guy lives across the street and makes twice that money, teaching.

没有好的对手，你的英雄就不能成为英雄。如果穆罕默德·阿里与摩西奶奶对决，谁会花钱去看？乔·弗雷泽让阿里成为今天的冠军。没有弗雷泽，就没有阿里。

Without a good opponent, your hero can’t be heroic. If Muhammad Ali had faced off with Grandma Moses, who’d have paid to see that? Joe Frazier made Ali the champion he is today. Without Frazier, there’d be no Ali.

14.对手不是英雄变革的推动者！

14. The opponent is not the hero’s agent of change!

 

如果没有对手，你的英雄就永远不会进化成他/她需要成为的人。

Without the opponent, your hero will never evolve to who he/she needs to be.

大多数主角都会发生改变。演员们知道，如果男主角没有表现出一些成长，他们就无法获得奥斯卡奖。那么，你的英雄如何达到那个被称为“角色变化”的耀眼目标呢？

Most main characters are transformed. Actors know they won’t win an Oscar if the guy doesn’t show some growth. So, how does your hero reach that dazzling Grail known as “character change?”

故事一开始，你的英雄生活不如意，待人粗暴，灵魂深处有个洞，你可以扔一辆马克卡车砸穿他的灵魂。电影结束时，他会更快乐，适应能力更强，他的余生也会变得轻松。

At the beginning of your tale, your hero is in a bad place in his life, treats other people shabbily, and has a hole in his soul you could drop a Mack truck through. At the end of the movie, he’ll be happier, better adjusted, and the rest of his life will be a snap.

一切都是因为对手。

All because of the opponent.

在《虎胆龙威》中，约翰·麦克莱恩的婚姻并不顺利。他对妻子并不好。他已经分居，即将离婚。这时，汉斯·格鲁伯出现了。

In Die Hard, John McClane is in a bad marriage. He’s not been treating his wife very well. He’s separated and on the slippery slope to divorce. Enter Hans Gruber.

格鲁伯绑架了麦克莱恩的妻子等所有人，并计划将他们全部杀死。麦克莱恩被迫挺身而出。为了从这个聪明的强盗手中救出妻子，麦克莱恩意识到自己有多爱她，故事的结尾，他们又复合了，他们的婚姻也得到了挽救。麦克莱恩成为了故事开始时他需要成为的那个人。汉斯·格鲁伯，婚姻顾问。

Gruber kidnaps everybody in sight, including McClane’s wife, and plans to kill them all. McClane is forced to step up to the plate. By having to save his wife from this clever robber, McClane realizes how much he loves her, and, at the end of the story, they are back together and their marriage has been saved. McClane becomes the man he needed to be at the start of the story. Hans Gruber, marriage counselor.

选择任意一部电影。

Pick any movie.

在《卡萨布兰卡》的开头，里克·布莱恩是个自私的混蛋。在结尾，他完全变了一个人，放弃了一个女人他会为了帮助战争而让他开心。这是一个巨大的人物弧线。因为这是一个爱情故事，对手是伊尔莎·伦德。如果不是她把他的生活彻底颠覆了，他会一直是个混蛋，死在卡萨布兰卡。

At the start of Casablanca, Rick Blaine is a selfish jerk. At the end, he’s a totally different guy, having given up the one woman who will make him happy in order to help the war effort. That’s a gigantic character arc. Because it’s a love story, the opponent is Ilsa Lund. Were it not for her turning his life inside out, he would remain a jerk and die in Casablanca.

在《撞车》中，特伦斯·霍华德很难应对种族主义和他在白人世界中的地位，更不用说他和妻子之间的许多“问题”。他被马特·狄龙激怒，在差点变成汉堡包之后，他从绞肉机里出来，成为一个更好、更强大的人。没有马特·狄龙，就没有幸福。

In Crash, Terrance Howard has trouble dealing with racism and his place in the white world, not to mention a lot of “issues” with his wife. He has his buttons pushed by Matt Dillon and, after nearly becoming hamburger, comes out of the meat grinder a better, stronger person. No Matt Dillon: no happiness.

在《售货女郎》中，克莱尔·丹妮丝对杰森·施瓦兹曼（她应该和他在一起的人）不感兴趣，直到史蒂夫·马丁让她饱受折磨——而她只是因为与他的关系而改变。直到那时，她才有了与杰森在一起所需的自信。

In Shopgirl, Claire Danes isn’t interested in Jason Schwartzman (the guy she should be with) until she is put through the wringer by Steve Martin — and she only changes because of her relationship with him. Then, and only then, does she have the self confidence she needs to end up with Jason.

因此，看看你的剧本，看看是什么导致了主角的改变。

So, look at your script and see what causes the main character to change.

最好是对手。

It had better be the opponent.

15. 坏人并不觉得自己是自己电影里的英雄！

15. The Bad Guy doesn’t feel he’s the hero of his own movie!

 

坏人做事总有充分的理由。

The bad guy has good reasons for what he’s doing.

在《极限措施》中，吉恩·哈克曼是休·格兰特不择手段的对手。但他绝不是连环杀手。他是一位年事已高的著名外科医生，正在寻找治疗瘫痪的方法。他知道，由于 FDA 批准他的治疗方案需要的时间比他活的时间还要长，因此他必须采用非传统方法来实现他坚信不疑的治疗方案。现在有一个崇高的目标！

In Extreme Measures, Gene Hackman is Hugh Grant’s unscrupulous opponent. But he’s far from a serial killer. He’s a renowned surgeon, getting on in years, searching for a cure for paralysis. He knows that, since FDA approval for his protocol will take longer than he has to live, he must resort to untraditional methods to bring about the cure he believes in so strongly. Now there’s a noble goal!

但——哎呀！——他通过对无家可归的人进行实验来做到这一点，其中一些人，嗯，死了。他认为这是合理的，因为治愈方法会很棒，而无家可归的人被遗忘，无论如何也没有活下去的理由。他做坏事，但出于可以理解（和同情）的理由。

Except — whoops! — he does it by experimenting on homeless people and some of them, um, die. He thinks it’s justifiable because a cure would be wonderful and the homeless guys are forgotten and have no reason to live anyway. He’s doing bad things but for an understandable (and sympathetic) reason.

坏人想要的东西应该有情感成分。

There should be an emotional component to what the bad guy wants.

在《肖申克的救赎》中，信奉《圣经》的典狱长希望监狱秩序井然。这绝对值得称赞。但有一个问题。他是个虐待狂。

In The Shawshank Redemption, the Bible-believing Warden wants order in the prison. Totally laudable. But there’s just one problem. He’s a sadist.

在《春天不是读书天》中，坏人想要学校恢复秩序——这是一种完全可以理解的、令人同情的愿望。“这次我必须抓住他。让这些孩子知道，他树立的榜样是通往虚无的头等舱机票。”鲁尼做的是对的。不幸的是，如果他成功了，他就会毁了费里斯的生活。

In Ferris Bueller’s Day Off, the bad guy wants order in the school — a totally sympathetic, understandable desire. “I have to catch him this time. To show these kids that the example he sets is a first class ticket to nowhere.” Rooney’s doing the right thing. Unfortunately, if he succeeds, he’s going to ruin Ferris’s life.

即使是西方的邪恶女巫也有生气的理由。如果有人把房子砸到你妹妹身上，偷走了你母亲遗产中你一直指望的魔法鞋，你会有什么感觉？所以，她也是她电影中的女主角。

Even the Wicked Witch of the West has a reason to be upset. How would you feel if someone dropped a house on your sister and stole the magic shoes that you had been counting on from your mother’s inheritance? So, she too is the heroine of her movie.

16. 不要对坏人说坏人演说！

16. You don’t give your bad guy a Bad Guy Speech!

 

我们就是这样知道他是他自己电影里的英雄的。令人惊讶的是，你经常看到这个坏人谈论他的感受以及他为什么要这么做。

This is how we learn he’s the hero of his own movie. It’s amazing how often you see the bad guy talk about how he feels and why he’s doing what he’s doing.

在迈克尔·曼和克里斯托弗·克罗创作的《最后的莫希干人》（根据詹姆斯·费尼莫尔·库珀的小说改编）中，马古阿是个十足的坏蛋！他聪明、丑陋、卑鄙，对门罗和他的女儿们恨之入骨。我们害怕马古阿。他只想把这些可爱的小女孩砍成碎片……但是，如果这是他唯一的特征，就像《大白鲨》中的鲨鱼一样，他就只是一个杀人机器。

In The Last of the Mohicans, written by Michael Mann and Christopher Crowe (and based on the novel by James Fenimore Cooper), Magua is a delicious bad guy! He’s smart, ugly, mean, and hates Munro and his daughters with an unquenchable purple passion. We’re scared to death of Magua. All he wants to do is hack these sweet little girls to bits… But, were that his sole characteristic, like the shark in Jaws, he would just be a killing machine.

Magua 一直保持着单一的性格，直到他有机会讲述他的故事。首先，他吓坏了我们。（顺便说一下，这是 DVD 的第 12 章——Magua 的仇恨。）当 Montcalm 问为什么 Magua玛古阿憎恨灰发，他说他想杀死灰发并吃掉他的心脏，但在他死前，玛古阿给他准备了一份特别的礼物。“玛古阿将把他的孩子置于刀下，这样灰发就会看到他的种子被永远消灭了。”

Magua remains one-dimensional until he gets a chance to tell his side of the story. First, he scares us. (It’s Chapter 12 — Magua’s Hate — of the DVD, btw.) When Montcalm asks why Magua hates the Grey Hair, he says he wants to kill the Grey Hair and eat his heart, but before he dies, Magua has a special treat for him. “Magua will put his children under the knife so the Grey Hair will see his seed is wiped out forever.”

这真是让人大跌眼镜。有趣的是，他没有回答蒙卡尔姆的问题：“为什么？”我们只知道他想杀死那两个小女孩，吃掉她们父亲的心脏。杰森和弗雷迪退后一步，一位大师已经进入了房间。

That’s a showstopper. Interestingly, he doesn’t answer Montcalm’s question, “Why?” We only know he wants to kill those two little girls and eat their father’s heart. Step back, Jason and Freddy, a master has entered the room.

这部《坏人演说》的妙处在于，迈克尔·曼和克里斯托弗·克罗把它分成了两个部分。第一部分过后，我们又看到了一些刺激、一些亲吻、一丝死亡和阴谋——我们也看到了玛古阿的坚强母亲——但我们仍然认为他只是一只嗜血的动物。

What’s great about this Bad Guy Speech is that Michael Mann and Christopher Crowe break it into two parts. After the first half, we get some more excitement, some kissing, a soupçon of death and intrigue — and we see what a tough mother Magua really is — but we still don’t view him as anything other than a bloodthirsty animal.

然后，在第 21 章“马古阿的痛苦”中，蒙卡尔姆和读者听到了马古阿内心的愤怒。很酷的是，他完全正确。

Then, in Chapter 21 — Magua’s Pain — Montcalm and the reader hear what’s boiling Magua’s guts. What’s cool, he’s in the right, 1,000%.

蒙卡尔姆看到马古阿背上有巨大的伤疤，便问是谁干的。马古阿慢慢地告诉他，他的村庄被毁了，他的孩子也被英国人杀害了。马古阿被为“灰发”而战的印第安人奴役，最后，最糟糕的是，马古阿的妻子以为他死了，嫁给了另一个男人。所有这一切都是因为马古阿的敌人“灰发”。

Montcalm sees huge scars on Magua’s back and asks who did it. Magua slowly tells him that his villages had been destroyed and that his children had been killed by the English. Magua was enslaved by Indians who fought for the Grey Hair, and finally, worst of all, Magua’s wife thought he was dead and married another man. All this, because of Magua’s enemy, the Grey Hair.

哇哦！难怪他想杀死他和他的可爱女儿。我们完全同情这个家伙。突然间，他变成了一个迷人的角色，他与英雄的冲突更加丰富和有意义。

Whoa! No wonder he wants to kill him and his sweet little girls. We totally sympathize with the guy. Suddenly, he becomes a fascinating character, and his conflict with the hero is all the more rich and rewarding.

坏人的演讲太震撼了！

Bad guy speeches rock!

17. 你的角色会做一些蠢事来推动故事的发展，也就是说，他们做这些事是因为你让他们这么做！

17. Your characters do stupid things to move the story forward, a.k.a. they do stuff because you make them!

 

如果你的角色做了一些在现实生活中永远不会做的事情，请重新考虑。

If your character does something that they’d never actually do it in real life, reconsider.

如果莉莉是你的英雄，而且她是个聪明、机智、有才华的女人，而肖恩让她怀孕了，而且他对此非常混蛋——她为什么会想要他？

If Lily is your heroine, and she’s a smart, with-it, on-her-game woman, and Sean gets her pregnant, and he’s a complete jerk about it — why would she want him?

 

肖恩

                （故意地）

莉莉，我站在这里愿意带你回去。

百合

肖恩，很抱歉我没有告诉你我怀孕的事，但是我——

肖恩

——我为你留下了一顿与参议员们共进的晚餐——

百合

——我保证你能分享我的孩子。而且——

肖恩

--我不想要共同监护权！我再给你一次机会。你不能独自完成这件事！

SEAN

                (deliberately)

Lily, I am standing here willing to take you back.

LILY

Sean, I’m sorry I didn’t tell you about my pregnancy, but I--

SEAN

--I left a God-damned dinner with Senators for you--

LILY

--I promise you can share my child. And--

SEAN

--I don’t want shared custody! I’m giving you another chance. You can’t do this alone!

如果他像对待垃圾一样对待她——而她也接受了这一点——读者会认为她是个白痴，并且不会再花时间阅读有关她的文章。

If he treats her like garbage — and she takes it — the reader will think she’s a moron and won’t invest any more time reading about her.

如果你遇到一个超级聪明的连环杀手，他非常聪明，能够接近、追踪和杀死受害者，但在每个人的抽屉里都留下了诱人的线索，方便侦探找到并破案，那么聪明人是不会这么做的。但是，你可以让它奏效。例如，如果他完全自负，认为警察侦探很蠢。

If you’ve got a super-intelligent serial killer who is diabolically clever in how he approaches, tracks, and kills his victims, but leaves a nice, juicy clue in each one’s dresser drawer for the detectives to conveniently find so they can solve the crime, that’s not something a smart guy would do. You can make it work, however. If he is, for instance, totally vain and thinks police detectives are stupid.

你是否已经封锁了你的角色可以走的所有道路，只留下他们自己可以走的那条路？

Have you sealed off every avenue for your character to take except the one they take?

如果小玛菲特小姐独自一人躺在黑暗的房间里，瑟瑟发抖，担心凶手会来给她的凝乳和乳清下毒——而且旁边还有一部电话——那你就有麻烦了。如果她在现实生活中会拨打 911，那么在电影中她也会拨打 911。让凶手切断电话线，或者让当地警察在三十英里外喝啤酒。你是个作家。发挥你的创造力吧。

If Little Miss Muffet shivers alone on her tuffet in a dark room afraid the killer is coming to poison her curds and whey — with a telephone next to her — you have a problem. If she’d call 911 in real life, she’d call 911 in the movie. Have the killer cut the phone line or make the local constable be thirty miles away knocking back a beer. You’re a writer. Be creative.

在《罪与错》中，伍迪·艾伦需要马丁·兰道杀死他的情妇。故事就围绕着这一点展开。因此，艾伦知道自己必须让英雄走上一条非常狭窄的道路，因此一路上关上了每一扇门。兰道无法告诉妻子真相。他无法报警。他无法说服女友，因为她比厕所里的老鼠还要疯狂。最后，唯一的选择就是谋杀。所以他杀了她，电影得以继续，他很高兴地知道观众完全相信这个好男人会谋杀那个可怕的女人。

In Crimes and Misdemeanors, Woody Allen needed Martin Landau to kill his mistress. The story hinged on it. So, knowing he had to march his hero down a very tight path, Allen closed every door along the way. Landau couldn’t tell his wife the truth. He couldn’t go to the police. He couldn’t reason with his girlfriend ’cause she was crazier than a shithouse rat. Finally, the only option was murder. So he kills her and the movie can proceed, happy in the knowledge that the viewer totally buys that the nice man would murder that awful woman.

在让-皮埃尔·梅尔维尔 (Jean-Pierre Melville) 的《独行杀手》 (Le Sa​​mourai ) 的开头，杀手阿兰·德龙 (Alan Delon) 走出公寓楼并偷走了一辆车。如此聪明的人为什么要偷一辆可能属于自己街区的车呢？当他回家并停好车时，即使他更换了车牌，真正的车主也可能会看到它。这真是愚蠢的行为；为什么不偷另一个街区的车呢？

At the beginning of Jean-Pierre Melville’s Le Samourai, Alan Delon, a hit man, walks out of his apartment building and steals a car. Why would a guy who’s that smart steal a car that could belong to someone in his own neighborhood? When he comes home and parks the car, even though he’s changed the license plate, the real owner might see it. It’s just such a boneheaded thing to do; why not steal the car in a different neighborhood?

在《委托人》中，那个孩子爬上一艘悬挂在船屋天花板上的小船。坏人闯入船屋，他可以偷听到他们邪恶的对话。在那里，他完全看不见。他吓得魂飞胆丧，他所要做的就是静静地躺着，没有人会发现他。那么他做了什么呢？他试图爬过一些天花板横梁！我想尖叫着逃离剧院。我还想让他们开枪打死他，因为他太蠢了。

In The Client, the kid climbs up in a rowboat hanging from a boathouse ceiling. Bad guys come into the boathouse and he can overhear their nefarious conversation. Up there, he’s totally unseen. Scared silly, all he has to do is lie still and no one will find him. So what does he do? He tries to crawl out across some ceiling beams! I wanted to run screaming from the theater. I also wanted them to shoot him because he was so dumb.

在《加勒比海盗 3》中，一个角色做的最愚蠢的事情是在众多高潮之一中，当贝克特勋爵的船两面夹击。他是个出色的坏人，而不是一个昏庸之辈，但当两艘好人的飞船开始爆炸时，他却僵住了，没有下令开火！他为什么要这么做？！他的飞船变成了飞来的牙签，而他却嘟囔着说这样“对生意有好处”。他像嗑药了一样盯着太空——什么也没做。他一直都是邪恶的快速决策者。突然间，他变成了服用了戊巴比妥的卡斯帕·米尔克托斯特。那个角色永远不会做这样的事情。永远不会。

In Pirates of the Caribbean 3, the dumbest thing a character does is during one of the many climaxes, when Lord Beckett’s ship is attacked from both sides. He is an excellent bad guy, not a dim bulb, but when the two good guy ships start blasting away, he freezes and doesn’t give the order to open fire! Why would he do that?! His ship is turned into flying toothpicks while he mumbles something about this being “good for business.” He stares into space like he’s stoned — and does NOTHING. He’s always been Mr. Evil Quick-Decision Maker. Suddenly, he’s Caspar Milquetoast on Nembutal. That character would never, ever do something like that. Never.

这至少应该让某些人感到愤怒。

It should have been infuriating to, at least, somebody.

访问这个网站：www.movi​​ecliches.com。了解陈词滥调并避免它们。例如：巴黎的任何公寓都能看到埃菲尔铁塔，如果主角在战争中死去，他家乡的爱人也会在同一时刻做噩梦。

Make a pilgrimage to this site: www.moviecliches.com. Learn the clichés and avoid them. For example: Any apartment in Paris will have a view of the Eiffel Tower, and, if a main character dies in a war, his sweetheart back home will have nightmare at that exact same moment.

另一个超级网站：如果我成为邪恶霸主（www.eviloverlord.com）。我特别喜欢的一句话是：“我的通风管道太小了，爬不过去。”呃。

Another super website: If I Ever Become An Evil Overlord (www.eviloverlord.com). My particular fave: “My ventilation ducts will be too small to crawl through.” Duhh.

《异形》中的角色们做蠢事的世界冠军祖父就是其中的一员。一个丑陋的怪物（顺便说一句，世界冠军祖父坏蛋！）正在以残酷、恶心的方式吞噬一艘宇宙飞船的船员。船员们约定“团结一致”，然后发生了什么？亚菲特·科托走进一个巨大的黑屋子寻找一只猫。独自一人！而且没有开灯。天哪，发生了什么？他被吃掉了。这是他应得的。

The world champ granddaddy of characters doing stupid things is in Alien. A hideous monster (world champ granddaddy bad guy, btw!) is gobbling up the crew of a spaceship in grim, icky ways. The crew makes a pact to “stick together” and then what happens? Yaphet Kotto goes off in a giant dark room looking for a cat. By himself! And doesn’t turn on the light. And gee, what happens? He gets eaten. Which he richly deserves.

当然，这只猫安然无恙。

The cat, of course, is fine.

18.你的次要角色没有个性！

18. Your minor characters don’t have character!

 

让所有角色，即使是小角色，都有特定的、迷人的、令人难忘的性格。这将大大提高你剧本的整体水平。

Make all characters, even in small roles, have specific, fascinating, memorable character. It will raise the overall level of your script an amazing amount.

以《体热》中的助理检察官泰德·丹森为例。劳伦斯·卡斯丹给他做了一些很棒的小动作：他假装自己是弗雷德·阿斯坦，总是在这里那里跳着小舞步，挥舞着手臂，在房间里滑行。这很奇怪，但很酷。这让他的角色比我们在电影中看到的 99% 的助理检察官更有趣。

Consider Ted Danson, assistant D.A. in Body Heat. Lawrence Kasdan gave him a great little bit: he pretends he’s Fred Astaire, always doing little dance steps here and there, throwing out his arms and gliding across the room. It’s weird, but cool. It makes his character more interesting than 99% of the assistant district attorneys we see in the movies.

观看最精彩的《潜望镜下》。了解 David Ward 如何快速、出色地塑造次要角色，让船长 Dodge 中尉对这些奇妙的傻瓜做出反应。这对作者来说是多么有趣！以下是一些：

Watch the most excellent Down Periscope. Get an understanding of how quickly, and how well David Ward establishes the secondary characters, giving Lt. Dodge, the captain, all these wonderful goofballs to react to. What fun for the writer! Here are a few:

 

执行官“马蒂”帕斯科——循规蹈矩的军人，爱管闲事，有愤怒管理问题。他是船员中个子最矮的人，他用恐吓来弥补。当道奇中尉给他下达命令时，马蒂会大声向船员重复命令。他要求调到另一艘船，因为船员们都是“一群白痴”。

Executive Officer “Marty” Pascoe — By-the-book military, officious, with anger-management issues. Shortest man on the crew, he uses intimidation to compensate. When Lt. Dodge gives him an order, Marty repeats it to the crew by yelling at the top of his lungs. He asks for a transfer to another ship because the crew is “a bunch of idiots.”

 

二级水兵 ET“声纳”洛瓦塞利——忠诚而粗鲁，但听觉惊人。他有一套鲸鱼声音的录音带。在战争游戏中遇到敌舰时，他会发出鲸鱼交配的声音来转移敌人的注意力。

Seaman 2nd Class E.T. “Sonar” Lovacelli — Loyal, and uncouth with an amazing sense of hearing. He has a collection of whale noises on tape. When confronted by an enemy ship in the war game, he makes the sounds of whales having sex to divert the attention of the enemy.

 

一等机械师斯泰潘纳克——好斗、粗鲁、懒惰、身上有纹身的硬汉。他讨厌海军，但因为他的父亲是海军上将而留下来。当道奇中尉问他为什么在他们被敌人追捕时不泄露他们的位置时，他说“那太不道德了。我只想操我自己，这样我就可以离开这里了。不想操其他人。”

Engineman 1st Class Stepanak — Belligerent, rude, lazy, tattooed tough-guy. He hates the Navy, but stays because his father is the Admiral. When asked by Lt. Dodge why he didn’t give away their position when they were being hunted by the enemy, he says “that would be unethical. I just want to fuck myself so I can get out of here. Not fuck everybody else.”

 

电工尼特罗——非常愚蠢，有点古怪，但工作效率很高。多年来，他似乎因为受到的冲击而失去了智力。道奇中尉与上级沟通时，Nitro 通过电击自己来建立联系。

Nitro, the electrician — Incredibly dumb, somewhat erratic, but efficient at his duties. He seems to have lost his intelligence because of all the shocks over the years. For Lt. Dodge to communicate with his superiors, Nitro makes the connection by shocking himself.

 

艾米丽·莱克中尉，潜水军官——班上最优秀、勤奋、果断。尽管缺乏实际经验，但过于自信。她非常有魅力，船员们都对她垂涎三尺。她向道奇中尉炫耀她在模拟中的成功，说她的成绩比他好。然而，当被要求在船上执行实际任务时，她却充满了焦虑和对失败的恐惧。

Lt. Emily Lake, diving officer — Top of her class, diligent, and determined. Overconfident despite lack of real-life experience. She’s so attractive that the crew drools over her. She flaunts her success in simulations by telling Lt. Dodge that she scored better than he did. Yet when asked to do real-life tasks on the ship, she’s overwhelmed with anxiety and fear of failure.

 

总工程师霍华德·埃尔德——经验丰富的水手。因此看起来有点古怪。他穿着一件脏兮兮的夏威夷衬衫，胡子刮得很乱。就好像他在珍珠港事件中受到了精神创伤，从此再也没有换过衣服。

Chief Engineer Howard Elder — Sailor with tons of experience. Seems slightly wacky because of it. He wears a dirty Hawaiian shirt and is poorly shaved. It is as if he was traumatized during Pearl Harbor and never changed clothes since.

所有配角都各具特色，很容易区分。

All supporting characters are distinctive and easy to separate one from the other.

完成初稿后，只删除次要角色的对话。继续努力。让他们成为真实、鲜活、有生命力的人，不要让他们仅仅具有“功能”。让他们引人注目。赋予他们态度和有趣的情节。

When you finish your first draft, pull out just the secondary character’s dialogue. Work on it. Make them real, living, breathing people, don’t let them just have a “function.” Make them compelling. Give them attitude and interesting business.

如果女服务员的一句台词是“这是你的咖啡”，至少让她端过来并抱怨“这是你的咖啡，怪胎。”如果你有一个水表读数员，给他一个滑稽的个性和精彩的对话。记住，即使这个角色很小，制片人也必须找到一个愿意扮演它的人。如果你在低预算国家，付不起演员的钱，这一点尤其重要。给他世界级的对话，他会付钱给你的！

If a Waitress’ one line is “Here’s your coffee,” at least have her bring it over and grumble “Here’s your damn coffee, freak.” If you have a Water Meter Reader, give him a zany personality and awesome dialogue. Remember, even if the role is tiny, the producers have to find someone who wants to play it. This is especially true if you are in Low-Budget Land and can’t pay the actor. Give him world-class dialogue, he’ll pay you!

结构

Structure

 

19. 当你构思故事时，你担心故事的结构！

19. You worried about structure when you came up with your story!

 

如果你这样做了，我很抱歉。你错过了写作中最快乐的时刻。人物和故事是最重要的。比任何事情都重要。当然比第一幕、第二幕和第三幕的废话都重要。

If you did, I’m sorry. You missed some of the most joyous moments in writing. Character and story come first. Before anything. Certainly before all that Act One, Two, and Three crapola.

当你在构思故事情节时，做大量的笔记。大声思考。对着录音机说话。做更多的笔记。写满 3x5 卡片的海洋。在黄色便笺簿上书写。在白色便笺簿上书写。在餐巾纸或啤酒杯垫上涂鸦。为角色写下一些很酷的事情，这些事情可能永远不会出现在电影中。做笔记，做更多的笔记，但不要为结构而烦恼。

When you’re teasing out your story, make lots of notes. Think out loud. Talk to a tape recorder. Make more notes. Fill up oceans of 3x5 cards. Write on yellow legal pads. Write on white legal pads. Scribble on napkins or beer coasters. Write down cool stuff for characters to do that may never find its way into the movie. Make notes and more notes and more notes, but do not trouble yourself with structure.

螺丝结构。玩得开心。

Screw structure. Have fun.

结构留到以后再说。现在，让你那令人难以置信的创意自由驰骋。记下人物、情节、故事、有趣的时刻和你想去的地方。为你的角色录下对话。给每个人配上不同的声音。你会惊讶于自己想出了什么！想想你的前男友，这个特技飞行员角色是如何让你想起唯一迷人的那个人。自由联想。记住你的祖母，当你的母亲不给你玉米片和七喜的时候，她会给你。想想你看到父亲在他最好的朋友的坟前哭泣的时候。编造一些东西。再编造更多的东西。从现实生活中窃取，让它成为你自己的。从别人的生活中窃取。听大声播放音乐，并运用音乐所暗示的内容。写下来。做笔记。带着录音机去散步，说出你脑子里想到的一切。多做笔记。享受这个过程！

Structure is for later. For now, just let your incredibly creative mind run free. Make notes about character and plot and story and funny moments and locations you’d like to visit. Tape record dialogue for your characters. Use different voices for each one. You’ll be astounded what you come up with! Think about old boyfriends and how this stunt pilot character reminds you of the sole charming one. Free associate. Remember your grandmother and how she used to serve you Fritos and 7-Up when your mother wouldn’t. Think about the time you saw your father cry at his best friend’s grave. Make stuff up. Make more stuff up. Steal from real life and make it your own. Steal from other people’s lives. Listen to music up loud and use what it suggests. Write it down. Make notes. Go for a long walk with a tape recorder and say whatever comes into you head. Make more notes. Enjoy this part of the process!

如果您不必担心是否合适，那么想出很酷的材料会更容易。

It’s easier to think up cool material if you don’t have to worry if it fits.

我最有创造力的时刻之一，是在下午时分，我躺在床上，胸前放着一台袖珍录音机。我一边写故事，一边听着音乐，慢慢进入梦乡。在真正入睡之前，有一段奇妙的时间，我仍然可以思考和说话，我的思绪与音乐相连，放松下来，变得无比自由。随着各种想法不由自主地涌现出来，我口述了一个又一个由音乐引发的想法。我强迫自己醒来，抓住那个不受正常思维束缚的区域，在半昏迷状态中对着录音机说话——最后我睡着了。

One of my most creative moments, ever, came in the middle of an afternoon when I lay on my bed with a pocket tape recorder on my chest. I was working on a story, and had music playing as I slowly drifted toward sleep. There’s an amazing space just before actual sleep where I could still think and talk, and my mind connected with the music, cut loose, and got incredibly free. With ideas tripping on themselves to get out, I dictated idea after idea triggered by the music. I’d force myself awake, holding onto that zone unfettered by normal thought, talking into the tape recorder as I drifted in semi-consciousness — and finally I fell asleep.

午睡醒来后，我把笔记抄了下来。有些是废话，但有些却非常有创意。这是一种想出故事点子的绝妙方法。

After I woke up from my nap, I transcribed the notes. Some were garbage, but some were amazingly inventive. It was an extraordinary way to come up with story ideas.

只要有用就行！

Whatever works, works!

如果你对正确的结构感到苦恼，你就不会有创造力。创造力才是卖点。担心规则和页数只会让你头脑混乱。

If you get all constipated agonizing about proper structure, you won’t be creative. Creativity sells. Worrying about rules and page numbers will only cloud your mind.

现在，玩得开心。

For now, have fun.

结构很重要，但并不好玩。话虽如此，我们该慢慢进入结构吗？

Structure is important, but it’s not fun. That said, shall we ease into structure?

20.你的张力不够！

20. You don’t have enough tension!

 

如果没有不断营造的紧张感，你就失去了读者。

If there is no constantly building tension, you’ve lost the reader.

读者喜欢担心。你把他们塞到角落里，让他们紧张，然后加大压力。这并不意味着汽车追逐和爆炸。那是动作，不是紧张。紧张是：一位父亲决定是否放下吊桥，防止客运列车撞入河中——或者把吊桥放下，以免儿子掉进机器里被压死。这就是短片《大多数》中的紧张，电影院里我旁边的那位女士情不自禁地抽泣着。

Readers love to worry. You jam them in a corner, make ’em nervous, and then turn up the heat. This does not mean car chases and explosions. That’s action, not tension. Tension is: a father deciding if he should lower a drawbridge and keep a passenger train from crashing into the river — or leave it up and not crush his son who’s fallen into the machinery. That was the tension in the short film Most and the woman beside me in the theater was sobbing uncontrollably.

作为一名作家，你需要的是张力。

What you want as a writer is tension.

也不一定要达到冷战那种按下按钮就能产生的紧张感。可以很小 — — 只要对角色来说不小即可。在《长日留痕》中，安东尼·霍普金斯（管家）正在他的小房间里看书。对他有点迷恋的艾玛·汤普森（女仆）带着一个问题来到他的房间。她一打开门，他就盖住了书名。砰！紧张气氛。她迫切想知道他在读什么，但他却迫切不想让她知道。他告诉她这只是一本书。他们都很礼貌，没有人说话超过安静程度，但紧张气氛真是让人窒息！

It doesn’t have to be Cold War finger-on-the-button level tension, either. It can be small — as long as it’s not small to the characters. In Remains of the Day, Anthony Hopkins (butler) is in his little room reading. Emma Thompson (maidservant), who has a wee crush on him, comes to his room with a question. The instant she opens the door, he covers his book’s title. SLAMMO! Tension City. She desperately wants to know what he’s reading, but he desperately doesn’t want her to know. He tells her it’s just a book. They’re all very polite and no one speaks above a hush, but the tension is killing!

紧张感会让读者忍不住继续翻阅。你能找到一种方法来在整个故事中保持并增强紧张感吗？

Tension will keep a reader turning pages. Can you find a way to maintain and then heighten tension all the way through your story?

另一种紧张感是赌注。不是像韦伯的那种过度烹饪，如果整个街区都站在那里等待，那可能会非常紧张，而是像“我的主角面临什么风险？”这样的赌注。

Another form of tension is stakes. Not like the ones you overcook on the Weber, which can be quite tense if the whole neighborhood is standing there, waiting, but stakes like “what’s at risk for my lead character?”

我写了一部 Ernest 电影。《波士顿环球报》评价说这是“系列中最好的” ！我从导演约翰·切里那里学到了很多东西。他告诉我，“如果这部电影不是关于统治世界的，那就什么都不是了。”你认为这意味着什么？为什么一部适合小孩子和保姆一起看的搞笑喜剧也适合你的巨作呢？

I wrote one of the Ernest movies. “Best of the series,” said the Boston Globe! I learned a lot from John Cherry, who directed it. He told me, “If it’s not about world domination, it’s not about anything at all.” What do you think that means? And why should something that applies to a goofy comedy created for little kids to watch with babysitters apply to your magnum opus?

在詹姆斯邦德电影中，统治世界就是这个意思。在《普通人》中，他们为控制一个家庭而战。这仍然是统治世界。

In a James Bond movie, world domination means just that. In Ordinary People, they’re fighting for control of a home. It’s still world domination.

如果你的角色没有为所有弹珠而努力，读者就会收拾行李回家。如果你的故事中赌注很小，那就加大赌注。之后，想办法让赌注进一步增加——因为你的故事必须随着情节的发展而变得更加紧张。

If your characters aren’t playing for all the marbles, the reader is going to pack up and go home. If the stakes in your story are small, ratchet them up. Later, find a way for them to increase even more — because your story has to get more intense as it goes along.

在《好人寥寥》的开头，汤姆·克鲁斯饰演的律师角色正在审理一个大案子。赌注很高——如果他输了，他的客户就会被关很长时间的监狱。然后，在审理过程中，赌注开始上升。如果他与杰克·尼科尔森对簿公堂，并且输了，他的海军法律生涯就结束了。对于一个父亲是美国司法部长的人来说，这些都是世界上所有的风险。

At the beginning of A Few Good Men, Tom Cruise’s attorney character is trying a big case. The stakes are high — if he loses, his clients go to jail for a long, long time. Then, partway through, the stakes go up. If he takes on Jack Nicholson, and loses, his Navy legal career is over. For a guy whose dad was U.S. Attorney General, those are all the marbles in the world.

你的故事里的主角也是这样吗？

Is that true for the main character in your story?

不要犯很多学生都会犯的错误，即一开始没有紧张感。赌注不会从低到高。赌注从一开始就很高，然后越来越高。一开始你的男主角已经在高空钢丝上，然后风开始吹，当他走到一半时，他的妻子在钢丝的另一端大喊她要离开他。当他走到四分之三时，他的医生扔给他一架纸飞机。那是一张纸条，上面写着他得了癌症。

Do not make the mistake a lot of my students make, which is no tension at the beginning. Stakes do not start low and get high. Stakes are high from the start and get way higher and then higher still. Start with your guy already on a high wire, and then have the wind start blowing and when he’s halfway across, his wife yells from the far end of the wire that she’s leaving him. When he’s three-fourths of the way across, his doctor throws him a paper airplane. It’s a note saying he’s got cancer.

无论你做什么，都不要让你的人物从还在地上开始。故事从一开始就必须紧张。

Whatever you do, don’t start with your guy still on the ground. The story must be tense from the beginning.

在《卡萨布兰卡》中，维克多·拉兹洛对盟军的战争努力至关重要，他必须逃离卡萨布兰卡，否则他将被送往集中营，或被送回德国占领的法国，或者更糟的是，在卡萨布兰卡被杀。里克知道这一点。他是一个爱国者，但爱上了拉兹洛的妻子。里克通过保住他唯一爱过的女人来面对个人幸福，或者通过帮助输掉战争来面对个人诅咒！

In Casablanca, Victor Lazlo, who is essential to the Allied war effort, must escape Casablanca or he will be sent to a concentration camp, or back to German occupied France, or, worse, be killed in Casablanca. Rick knows this. He’s a patriot, but is in love with Lazlo’s wife. Rick faces personal happiness by keeping the only woman he’s ever loved — or personal damnation by helping lose the war — some stakes!

在《鬣蜥之夜》中，理查德·伯顿失去了教堂会众，最终在墨西哥走投无路。他为布莱克旅行社工作，而“没有什么比布莱克旅行社更糟糕的了”。上个月，他因巡演不顺利而被缓刑。​​如果他如果他输掉本月的巡演，他就会被解雇。当他与那个想解雇他的拘谨女人斗争时，我们明白他面临什么风险。一切。

In Night of the Iguana, Richard Burton lost his church congregation and has ended up in Mexico at the end of his rope. He works for Blake’s Tours and there’s “nothing lower than Blake’s Tours.” Last month, he was on probation because he had a bad tour. If he loses this month’s tour, he’ll get sacked. When he’s doing battle with the prim woman who wants him fired, we understand what’s at risk. Everything.

如果你的英雄没有始终处于压力之下，压力越来越大，那么你写的故事将无人关心。

If your hero is not in the crusher, all the time, with the pressure getting worse and worse, you’re writing a story no one will care about.

要了解好莱坞编剧有多优秀，请阅读《燃眉追击》，然后再看 DVD。在书中，杰克·瑞恩甚至没有去南美洲。他从未遇到过危险！编剧做的第一件事就是让英雄处于危险之中，这让读者感到担忧。

To see how good Hollywood writers are, read Clear and Present Danger, then see the DVD. In the book, Jack Ryan doesn’t even go to South America. He’s never in danger! First thing the screenwriter did was put the hero in harm’s way, which makes the reader worry.

另一种思考紧张的方式是“危险”。你的英雄是否处于持续不断的、不断升级的危险之中？这当然适用于被外星人袭击，也适用于来访的祖母。如果你的外婆想让你吃你的烤奶酪三明治，但你不吃，因为她把它烧焦了，她问你，当你妈妈把烤奶酪三明治烧焦时，你会怎么做，而你说，“她没有烧焦我的烤奶酪三明治”，你就处于极大的危险之中。

Another way to think about tension is “jeopardy.” Is your hero in constant, escalating peril? This applies to being attacked by aliens, of course, but also visiting grandmother. If your bitch-on-wheels granny wants you to eat your grilled cheese sandwich, but you won’t because she burned it, and she asks you what your mother does when she burns the grilled cheese sandwich, and you say, “She doesn’t burn my grilled cheese sandwich,” you’re in jeopardy, big time.

让读者在每一步都感受到紧张感。听听《美国风情画》中鲍勃·法尔法的提示：“一旦我让这个傻瓜动起来，你就会忍不住求饶。”

Make your reader feel the tension, every step of the way. Take a tip from Bob Falfa in American Graffiti: “You’re gonna be hangin’ on for mercy once I get this sucker rollin’.”

21. 你没有时间压力！

21. You have no time pressure!

 

有一块滴答作响的钟总是有帮助的。

Always helps to have a ticking clock.

在《百万》中，这两个男孩只有有限的时间，否则他们发现的钱财将变得一文不值，因为所有货币都即将兑换成欧元。他们必须尽快解决问题，否则这箱钱就没用了。

In Millions, the two boys have only a limited amount of time before the fortune in cash they found is worthless, as all currency is about to be converted to Euros. They are forced to solve their problem before the suitcase of money is useless.

在《16 个街区》中，布鲁斯·威利斯必须在接下来的两个小时内把莫斯·德夫送到法院。任何能给角色施加时间压力的事情都会产生巨大的影响。有多少部电影可以你会想到他们要在接下来的48 小时内把白喉血清送到诺姆吗？一部名为《48 小时》的电影怎么样？

In 16 Blocks, Bruce Willis has to get Mos Def to the courthouse in the next two hours. Anything you can do to put time pressure on the characters, makes a huge difference. How many movies can you think about where they have to get the diphtheria serum to Nome in the next 48 hours? How about a movie titled 48 HRS?

《虎胆龙威》的故事发生在一夜之间！

Die Hard takes place in one night!

关键在于让事件在尽可能紧凑的空间内发生。如果你给角色六个月的时间来完成任务，看看如果给他一个月会发生什么。这会给你的故事带来什么改变？一周呢？

It’s all about making the events happen in as compressed a space as you can. If you’ve given the character six months to accomplish his task, see what happens if you give him a month. How does that change your story? What about a week?

你的时间压缩得越紧，写作就会越有成就感，因为你的角色的处境会变得更加艰难。

The tighter you can squeeze down your time period, the more satisfying it is to write because you make it more difficult for your character.

如果不是真的有滴答作响的钟表，你的故事发生的时间是否被尽可能地压缩了？霍顿·福特 (Horton Foote) 编剧的电影版《杀死一只知更鸟》耗时一年半。这本书的创作耗时三年。结果为观众带来了更强烈的体验。

If not an actual ticking clock, is the time over which your story happens screwed down as tightly as possible? The film version of To Kill a Mockingbird, written by Horton Foote, took a year and a half. The book took place over three years. The result is a more powerful experience for the audience.

你能做些什么来让你的故事在更短的时间内发生吗？

Is there anything you can do to make your story happen in less time?

22.你没有给予读者足够的情感！

22. You don’t give the reader enough emotion!

 

让读者产生情感体验，否则你就是在浪费时间。情感是什么并不重要，但一定要确保读者能感受到某种情感。情感越强烈越好。

Give the reader an emotional experience or you’re wasting your time. It doesn’t matter what that emotion is, but make damn sure he or she feels something. The stronger, the better.

你是否花了足够的篇幅来描述那些最能打动读者和观众的情感时刻？不要掩盖某些东西。不要错过任何情感时刻。确保你充分利用了它们，并在每一步中思考每个角色的反应，并问问这是否是正确且合适的反应。

Are you spending enough page length on the moments that are supposed to be the most emotionally affecting for the reader and audience? Don’t gloss over something. Don’t miss an emotional moment. Make sure you are milking them enough and, at each step of the way, think how each character reacts and ask if that is the correct and appropriate response.

也想想这个问题：如果你的英雄有情绪激动的时刻，他或她值得吗？

Think about this, too: If your hero has an emotional moment, has he or she earned it?

情感可以是任何东西。笑声。恐惧。同情。心痛。欲望。像这些场景一样给你的故事注入情感：

Emotion can be anything. Laughter. Fear. Compassion. Heartache. Lust. Give your story emotion like in these scenes:

在《后窗》中，格蕾丝·凯利带着她的马克·克罗斯旅行箱来到吉米·斯图尔特的家。她打开旅行箱，我们看到了她的睡衣。我们满怀期待地颤抖着，意识到她收拾好旅行箱，就知道她要和他一起睡觉了。

In Rear Window, Grace Kelly comes to Jimmy Stewart’s house with her Mark Cross overnight case. She opens it and we see her nightie. We shiver with anticipation, realizing she had packed that case knowing she was going to sleep with him.

在《印第安纳人》中，教练告诉队员们测量他们参加锦标赛的体育馆的大小。这个体育馆和他们家乡的旧体育馆一样大。

In Hoosiers, the coach tells the team to measure the size of the gym they have to play in for the championship. It’s the same size as their old gym back home.

老人想起了《公民凯恩》里的“白衣女孩” 。看过之后就再也忘不掉。这是电影中最感人的时刻。我经常想起那位老人。

The old man remembers the “girl in the white dress” in Citizen Kane. Once you’ve seen it, you’ll never forget it. It’s the most emotional moment in the film. I think about that old guy often.

我通过电子邮件征集了朋友们最喜欢的情感场景。我收到了一份令人惊叹的清单。

I sent out a call via email for my friends’ favorite emotional scenes. I got back an amazing list.

 

我最喜欢的场景是《午夜守门人》中的场景，夏洛特·兰普林把自己锁在浴室里，打碎了一块玻璃，迫使德克·博加德赤脚穿过玻璃来到她身边，从而扭转了他曾经扮演的折磨者/虐待狂的角色，颠覆了浪漫或正确爱情的观念。受虐狂变成了虐待狂，而虐待狂喜欢这样。

My favorite scene is in The Night Porter, when Charlotte Rampling locks herself in the bathroom and shatters a glass, forcing Dirk Bogarde to walk barefoot across the glass to get to her, thereby reversing the role he once played of torturer/sadist and turning ideas of romantic or correct love on its ear. The masochist becomes the sadist, and the sadist likes it.

 

《天堂可以等待》结尾处，朱莉·克里斯蒂在更衣室隧道里迷路了，她向沃伦·比蒂求助。（她的未婚夫沃伦已经去世，又以另一个人的身体复活了。沃伦知道自己将要死去，他告诉她，她可能会遇到一个人，从他的眼睛里看到一些东西，他甚至可能是四分卫。）在隧道里，他们交谈，他邀请她喝咖啡，因为他感觉到了什么，但她拒绝了。然后她看着他，说了这样的话：“你是四分卫。”这句话很简单，但却说明了一切。她有点知道，但她不知道是怎么知道的，他就是那个人。他们一起走了。

Near the end of Heaven Can Wait when Julie Christie is lost in the locker room tunnel and asks Warren Beatty for help. (Warren, her fiancé, has died and come back in someone else’s body. Knowing he was going to die, he told her that she might meet someone and see something in his eyes, and he might even be the quarterback.) In the tunnel, they talk, he invites her for coffee, because he feels something, but she declines. Then she looks at him and says something like “You’re the quarterback.” It is so simple, but it says it all. She knows kind of, but she doesn’t know how, that he is the guy. They go off together.

 

《码头风云》。 马龙白兰度在后座上与罗德斯泰格尔对峙，谈论这场打斗，当时他意识到自己的兄弟毁了他的一生。 “我本可以成为一个竞争者。我本可以成为一个重要人物。” 这句话如此有力、如此感人，让我心碎。

On the Waterfront. The scene in the backseat where Marlon Brando confronts Rod Steiger about the thrown fight, when he realizes his brother ruined his life. “I could have been a contender. I could have been somebody.” It is so powerful and poignant, and it breaks my heart.

 

每当我第一次看到艾略特和外星人在月球的映衬下起飞和飞行时，我仍然会起鸡皮疙瘩。这是意料之外的，也是神奇的。

I still get goosebumps every time I see Elliott and E.T. take off and fly for the first time, silhouetted against the moon. It is unexpected and magical.

 

在《四百击》中，当让·皮埃尔·利奥说他因为母亲去世而缺课时，他只是和朋友一起玩耍，然后父母就出现了。

In The 400 Blows, when Jean Pierre Léaud says he missed school because his mother died, but he was just playing with a friend, and then the parents appear.

 

在《奇迹工作者》中，当小女孩成功地将“水”这个词与水联系起来时。这是这个女孩真实生活的开始。这位女演员很棒。人们真的相信她实际上是残疾人，她在这场戏中的表情非常富有表现力。

In The Miracle Worker, when the little girl succeeds in associating the word “water” and the water. It is the beginning of the real life for this girl. The actress is great. One really believes she is actually handicapped, her face during this scene is so expressive.

 

《唤醒内德·迪瓦恩》中有一个葬礼场景，非常巧妙和感人。彩票中奖者内德·迪瓦恩死了，镇上的人密谋让迈克尔代替他，以便分割奖金。杰基正在为内德致悼词，这时彩票代表碰巧走进教堂寻找内德。这位在乡下患有花粉症的代表打了个喷嚏——现在每个人都知道他在房间里。这是一个紧张的场景。情节巧妙地衔接在一起，对于镇民来说，这一刻要么赢要么输；他们要么发财，要么入狱。杰基站在讲台上，所有人的目光都集中在他身上，他迅速思考，转而悼念坐在前排的老朋友迈克尔（彩票代表认为他是内德）。该剧讲述了一些关于友谊和生活的非常甜蜜和诗意的事情，这个场景很好地说明了喜剧如何突然转换节奏，让一个轻松的故事充满活力。

There is a funeral scene in Waking Ned Divine that is very clever and emotional. Ned Divine, the lottery winner, is dead, and the town has conspired to put Michael in his place in order to split the money. Jackie is giving Ned’s eulogy when the Lottery representative happens into the chapel, looking for Ned. The rep, who suffers hay fever in the country, sneezes — everyone now knows he is in the room. This is a tense scene. The plot converges marvelously, and, for the townsfolk, all is either won or lost in this moment; they will either be rich or jailed. Jackie, at the lectern, all eyes on him, thinks fast, and instead eulogizes his longtime friend Michael, who is sitting in the front row (whom the Lotto rep thinks is Ned). Some very sweet and poetic things are said about friendship and life, and the scene is a wonderful example of how a comedy can suddenly switch gears and give a light story a beating heart.

每次我讲给学生听的《把妈妈从火车上扔下去》中那个场景都会让我哭泣，该场景由斯图·西尔弗创作。比利·克里斯托是一名写作老师，他最烦人的学生是丹尼·德维托。丹尼邀请他共进晚餐。不仅比利不想去，我们也不希望他去，因为丹尼太烦人了。丹尼深爱的父亲已经去世，母亲又很可怕。女演员安妮·拉姆齐患癌症，部分舌头被切除，因此，除了长得丑陋之外，她的声音还迟缓而痛苦。“欧文，你没有朋友！”

The scene that makes me cry, every time I tell it to my students, is in Throw Momma From the Train, written by Stu Silver. Billy Crystal’s a writing teacher and his most annoying student is Danny DeVito. Danny invites him over for dinner. Not only does Billy not want to go, we don’t want him to go, ’cause Danny’s so damn aggravating. Danny’s beloved father is dead and his mother is horrible. The actress, Anne Ramsey, had had cancer and part of her tongue had been removed, so, on top of being fantastically ugly, she had a sluggishly painful voice. “Owen, you don’t have any friends!”

晚餐很糟糕。妈妈很糟糕，比利·克里斯托只想离开。他鄙视丹尼·德维托，我们也一样。妈妈刚回到她的巢穴，比利以为他已经出门了，丹尼问他是否想看看他的硬币收藏。

The dinner is awful. The mom is awful and all Billy Crystal wants to do is leave. He despises Danny DeVito and so do we. Just after mom has retired to her lair, and Billy thinks he’s out the door, Danny asks if he wants to see his coin collection.

比利别无选择，只好答应。他和丹尼坐在地板上。丹尼拉起地毯。他搬开一块地板。拿出一个生锈的烟草罐。

Billy has no choice but to say yes. He and Danny get on the floor. Danny pulls up the carpet. He removes a floorboard. Pulls out a rusty tobacco tin.

你必须明白观众此时有多么讨厌丹尼。到目前为止，他所做的一切都令人不快，我们再也不想见到他了。

You have to understand how much the viewer loathes Danny at this point. Up to now, he hasn’t done anything that’s not irritating, and we never want to see him again.

丹尼在地上扔了大约十枚硬币。几枚破烂的 25 美分硬币、10 美分硬币和一两枚 5 美分硬币。比利惊呆了。“就这些？”他想。我们也这么想。然后，在令人难以置信的惊人转折中，编剧让你爱上了丹尼·德维托。

Danny dumps about ten coins on the floor. A couple of ratty quarters, dimes, and a nickel or two. Billy is mortified. “That’s it?” he’s thinking. We’re thinking it too. And then, in a mindblowingly amazing turnabout, the writer makes you LOVE Danny DeVito.

丹尼捡起一枚硬币，拿给比利看——我边打出这句话边流泪——他说：“这枚是我爸爸带我去看彼得、保罗和玛丽时得到的零钱。这枚是我在马戏团买热狗时得到的零钱。我爸爸让我把零钱留着。他总是让我把零钱留着。”这真是太棒了。

Danny picks up a coin, shows it to Billy — I’m tearing up as I type this — and he says, “This one here, I got in change, when my dad took me to see Peter, Paul, and Mary. And this one, I got in change when I bought a hot dog at the circus. My daddy let me keep the change. He always let me keep the change.” It’s wonderful.

电影的其余部分，丹尼·德维托的表现都很不错！我们崇拜他。他仍然很烦人，但我们爱他。我坐在这里，写这本书，因为二十年前看过的一部电影中的一个场景，我眼含热泪。

For the rest of the movie, Danny DeVito can do no wrong! We adore him. He’s still annoying, but we love him. I’m sitting here, working on this book, and I have tears in my eyes because of a scene in a movie I saw twenty years ago.

这就是情感。就这么做吧。

That’s emotion. Do that.

23. 你的故事结构很糟糕！

23. You bungled your story structure!

 

糟糕的结构=永恒的地狱。

Bad structure = hell for eternity.

情节构建相当简单。其实也没那么简单，因为如果每个人都能做到，那么每个作家都会住在一栋付费的大房子里。

Plot construction is fairly simple. Well, not that simple, because if everyone could do it, every writer would live in a big house that’s paid for.

你的故事需要“关于”某件事。这就是你的主题。把它贴到你的显示器上，然后一直看着它。无论你的主题是什么，主人公最终都需要处理它。他的角色成长必须与该主题紧密相关。这是故事结构的基础。

Your story needs to be “about” something. This is your theme. Tape it to your monitor and keep looking at it. Whatever your theme is, the hero needs to deal with it at the end. His character growth has to be tied into that theme. That’s the foundation of story structure.

这是我最喜欢的故事描述，出自斯科特·梅雷迪斯的《写作以销售》：

Here’s my favorite description of story, from Writing to Sell by Scott Meredith:

 

“一个富有同情心（或令人着迷！）的主角发现自己陷入了某种困境，并积极努力摆脱困境。然而，每一次努力都只会让他陷入更深的困境，他路上的每一个新障碍都比上一个更大。最后，当事情看起来最糟糕，主角似乎已经完蛋了，他设法通过自己的努力、智慧或独创性摆脱困境。”

“A sympathetic [or fascinating!] lead character finds himself in trouble of some kind and makes active efforts to get himself out of it. Each effort, however, merely gets him deeper into his trouble, and each new obstacle in his path is larger than the last. Finally, when things look blackest and it seems certain the lead character is finished, he manages to get out of his trouble through his own efforts, intelligence, or ingenuity.”

这太有用了。让我们来分析一下。

This is so useful. Let’s break it down.

 

“一个令人同情的主角... ”

“A sympathetic lead character…”

我在其他地方也谈过这个问题，但读者对主角感兴趣很重要。我建议的“引人入胜”也行得通，因为我们对他的同情并不重要。我们必须理解他的问题，我们必须以某种方式同情他。你的读者必须与你的主角建立情感联系。她不必喜欢他。她不必认为他很可爱，也不必想带他回家吃晚饭，但她必须希望他获胜。

I talk about this elsewhere to a degree, but it’s important for the reader to be interested in the main character. My suggestion of “fascinating” works too, because it’s not crucial that we find him sympathetic. We do have to understand his problem, and we somehow have to empathize with him. Your reader must make an emotional connection with your main character. She doesn’t have to like him. She doesn’t have to think he’s cute and may not want to take him home for supper, but she has to want him to win.

这就是布莱克·斯奈德所说的“拯救猫咪”时刻。让它们做一些好事、有趣或搞笑的事情，这样我们就可以把我们的情感寄托在它们身上。

This is what Blake Snyder calls the “Save the Cat” moment. Make them do something nice, or interesting, or funny, so we can hitch our emotional wagon to them.

因为读者从打开剧本的那一刻起就迫切地想要抓住某个人，所以一般来说，你希望我们先认识主角。如果你愿意，我们可以先认识反派，但你最好在前五页就找到一个重要的人来抓住我们。

Because the reader is desperate to attach to somebody from the moment she opens your screenplay, as a general rule of thumb you want us to meet the main character first. We can meet the villain first if you want, but you better find us somebody important to latch onto in the first five pages.

我刚刚把一本磁带书带回了图书馆。我听了第一盘磁带的 A 面，然后就放弃了。角色们在伦敦的某个男士俱乐部里闲逛，进行着各种愚蠢的、没有冲突的对话，故事从未真正开始。我的小天线四处挥舞着，试图找到一个我可以锁定的人，但我失败了。就在我把盒子塞进图书馆的插槽时，我读了简介。令我惊讶的是，带着黑心的我很高兴，我注意到这本书是关于一个名叫伊丽莎白的女人，我以前甚至还没有见过这个角色！

I just took a book-on-tape back to the library. I listened to side A of the first tape and gave up. Characters were wandering around some men’s club in London having all sorts of silly conflict-free dialogue, and the story never quite got started. My little antennae were out waving around trying to find somebody I could lock onto, and I failed. Just as I was shoving the box into the library slot, I read the synopsis. To my surprise, with black-hearted delight, I noticed the book was about a woman named Elizabeth, a character I had not even met yet!

 

“…发现自己陷入了某种麻烦…”

“…finds himself in trouble of some kind…”

麻烦需要像主角一样有趣。而且不只是对你来说有趣！它必须是一个大而困难的问题，如此严重，以至于如果她不解决它，她的余生就会一团糟。

The trouble needs to be like the main character, interesting. And not just interesting to you! It must be a large and difficult problem, so intense that, if she doesn’t solve it, the rest of her life will be wreckage.

麻烦一定随时会毁掉她的整个世界。就是这样。如果对她来说这不是一个大问题，那我们为什么要读它呢？请注意，它不一定是一个可以从太空看到的问题，但它必须威胁要把英雄撕成碎片。你可以拍一部关于冬天舔金属旗杆的孩子的短片。这对他来说是个大问题，因此对你的读者来说也是如此。

The trouble must be poised to destroy her entire world. Period. If it’s not a BIG problem, to her, then why are we reading about it? It doesn’t have to be a problem that can be seen from space, mind you, but it has to threaten to rip the hero to bits. You can make a short film about a kid in wintertime who licks a metal flagpole. That’s a BIG problem to him, and therefore, to your reader.

 

“……并积极努力使自己摆脱困境。”

“…and makes active efforts to get himself out of it.”

这里的关键词是什么？主动！达赖喇嘛不会成为一个很好的电影英雄，因为他坐在金色宝座上挥手，其他人出去为他解决问题。当你为你的人物想办法摆脱你给他造成的困境时，他必须不停地挣扎，试图自己解决问题。一旦你让另一个人物介入并试图为他解决问题，读者就会停止翻页。

What’s the key word here? Active! The Dalai Lama would not make a very good movie hero because he sits on a golden throne and waves his hand, and other people go out to solve his problems for him. When you think of things for your character to do to get out from under the rock you’ve dropped on him, he must never stop squirming and trying to fix it himself. The minute you have another character step in and try to solve his problem for him, the reader will stop turning the pages.

 

“每一次努力……”

“Each effort…”

这很重要，因为它让你想到了重复。你的女孩尝试了 A 计划，但失败了。然后她又开始实施 B 计划，这比 A 计划更大。它失败了，更糟糕。然后是 C 计划，等等。自胶片出现以来，这一直是电影叙事的结构。哈尔·罗奇刚开始拍电影时就知道了这一点，因为这是大多数单卷喜剧的结构。

This is important because it gives you the idea of repetition. Your girl tries Plan A, which fails. Then she revs up Plan B, which is bigger than Plan A. It fails, worse. Then Plan C, etc. This has been the structure of motion picture storytelling since the dawn of celluloid. Hal Roach knew about it when he first started making movies, as it is the structure for most one-reel comedies.

永不言败！这是你的英雄的座右铭。

Never say die! That’s your hero’s mantra.

 

“然而，每一次努力都只会让他的麻烦越来越大……”

“Each effort, however, merely gets him deeper into his trouble…”

你看过《明星伙伴》吗？看看那群有趣的傻瓜！当他们想出一个计划时，它能奏效吗？不仅不，绝对不行！这行不通，否则故事就到此为止了。当出现问题时，他们试图解决该问题，结果却陷入了更深的流沙之中。

Do you ever watch Entourage? Look at that band of interesting idiots! When they come up with a plan, does it work? Not only no, but hell no! It can’t work, or the story stops right there. When something goes wrong, and they try to solve that problem, they just sink deeper into quicksand.

故事的这个部分是事情变得更糟的地方，比之前更糟，而且速度更快。你的英雄从山上摔下来，一路跌跌撞撞，身上沾满了雪、树枝、泥巴，还有被高山滑雪者压扁的雪，山坡越来越陡，很快他就自由落体了，速度达到每秒 32 英尺。

This part of your tale is where things get worse, a whole lot worse, and a whole lot faster. Your hero’s falling down a mountain, tumbling along, gathering snow, sticks, mud, and squished alpine skiers, and the slope gets steeper and steeper, and soon he is in free fall, accelerating at 32 feet per second per second.

 

“……他路上遇到的每一个新障碍都比上一个更大。”

“…and each new obstacle in his path is larger than the last.”

障碍必须越来越大，否则，随着角色的挣扎，变得更聪明、更强大，他将能够打败反派。此外，还有一个更中肯的原因是，如果障碍不越来越大，读者会感到无聊。

The obstacles have to get bigger, otherwise, as the character struggles along, getting smarter and stronger, he will be able to defeat the villain. Also, and a more pertinent reason, if the obstacles don’t get bigger, the reader will get bored.

《杀死一只知更鸟》的结尾，主人公面对的是谁？随着障碍越来越大，她面对的不是疯狗，也不是埃维尔先生（他试图杀死她，但没有成功），而是布·拉德利。斯考特一生都害怕布。

Who does the hero face at the end of To Kill a Mockingbird? Since the obstacles get bigger, she faces, not the rabid dog, or Mr. Ewell (who tried to kill her and failed), but Boo Radley. Her entire life, Scout has been afraid of Boo.

莳萝

DILL

我想知道他在里面做什么？我想知道他长什么样？

I wonder what he does in there? I wonder what he looks like?

正义运动

JEM

嗯，从他的足迹判断，他大约有六英尺半高。他吃生松鼠和他能抓到的所有猫。他的脸上有一道长长的锯齿状伤疤。他的牙齿发黄，已经腐烂。他的眼睛突出。他大部分时间都在流口水。

Well, judgin’ from his tracks, he’s about six and a half feet tall. He eats raw squirrels and all the cats he can catch. There’s a long, jagged scar that runs all the way across his face. His teeth are yella and rotten. His eyes are popped. And he drools most of the time.

我们也害怕他。

We are terrified of him too.

影片结尾，杰姆躺在床上，手臂被尤厄尔先生打断，画面感人至深。他的父亲阿迪克斯和妹妹斯考特也躺在床上。

At the end of the film, in an incredibly emotional reveal, Jem is in bed with the broken arm he got from Mr. Ewell. His father, Atticus, is there with Scout, his sister.

斯考特不知道是谁拦住了尤厄尔先生。她父亲告诉她尤厄尔先生就在门后。门被推开，布·拉德利出现在她面前。她害怕的对象。他们中最大的障碍。

Scout doesn’t know who stopped Mr. Ewell. Her father tells her he’s right there, behind the door. The door is swung open and reveals Boo Radley. The object of her fear. The biggest obstacle of them all.

 

“最后，当一切看起来最黑暗，主角似乎已经完蛋了……”

“Finally, when things look blackest and it seems certain the lead character is finished…”

当你编写一部剑与魔法电影时，这部分很容易，因为主角进入了永恒黑暗之坑之下，末日洞穴，并失去了他的荣耀与光明之剑——就像邪恶的莫德雷德带着全能双节棍出现一样……

This part is easy when you’re writing a sword and sorcery movie because the main character goes underneath the Pit of Eternal Darkness, into the Cave of Doom, and loses his Sword of Glory and Light — just as Mordred the Wicked steps up with the Nunchucks of All Power….

如果你在写一部法庭剧，这一步会更难，但也不是那么难。如果你在写一部浪漫喜剧，这一步就很难了。一定会有那么一个时刻，低谷，我们认为男主角已经失去了一切。整部电影中他想要的一切都毁了。更糟糕的是（但对读者来说更好！），这一切都是因为他犯了一个错误而被毁掉的。例如，她发现他和前女友上床，然后把他甩了。现在，你，作为作家（哈哈哈！），必须找出一个他和前女友上床的令人同情的原因，但这不是我的问题。

This step is harder if you’re doing a courtroom drama, but not that hard. It’s a really difficult step when you’re writing a romantic comedy. There’s got to be a moment, the Low Point, where we think the hero has lost it all. Everything he’s wanted the entire movie is destroyed. What’s worse (but better for the reader!) is that it gets destroyed because of a mistake he made. For instance, she catches him in bed with his old girlfriend, and dumps him flat. Now, you, as the writer (ha ha ha!), have to figure out a sympathetic reason he was bopping his old girlfriend, but that’s not my problem.

不管怎样，无论你怎么把他送到那里，他肯定已经奄奄一息，躺在地上，四分五裂。

In any event, however you get him there, he’s got to be near death and in pieces on the ground.

 

“他通过自己的努力、智慧或巧计摆脱了困境。”

“He manages to get out of his trouble through his own effort, intelligence, or ingenuity.”

我可以告诉你：如果他不能摆脱困境，你就写了一部法国电影，你最好放弃把它卖给好莱坞。如果他不能通过自救摆脱困境，你最好放弃把你的剧本卖给牙医，因为你找不到发行商。

I can tell you this: If he doesn’t manage to get out of trouble, you’ve written a French movie, and you may as well give up trying to sell it to Hollywood. If he doesn’t get out of trouble by saving himself, you should probably give up trying to sell your script to dentists, because you won’t get a distributor.

好的，现在再多谈一下结构。

Okay, now, a bit more on structure.

阅读布莱克·斯奈德的《拯救猫咪》、克里斯托弗·沃格勒的《作家之旅》和约翰·特鲁比的《故事的解剖》。从这些书中获取你需要的内容并继续阅读。

Read Blake Snyder’s Save the Cat, Christopher Vogler’s The Writer’s Journey, and John Truby’s The Anatomy of Story. Take what you need from those books and press on.

当你阅读编剧书籍时，最好在脑子里先想好一个故事。阅读时，你会突然灵光一闪！你会记下各种关于你的故事的笔记。我有一个学生不会在不打开《拯救猫咪》的情况下写剧本。我还有其他学生对沃格勒的书深信不疑。希望你也会对我的书有同样的感受！

When you’re reading a screenwriting book, it helps to have a story in mind already. As you read, little light bulbs will go off! You’ll make all kinds of notes about your story. I have one student who will not write a screenplay without Save the Cat open beside her. I have other students who swear by the Vogler book. Hopefully you will feel the same way about mine!

因为每个读过你的剧本的人都已经接受了三幕故事结构，就像溺水的人抓住任何被拉向他的东西一样，所以理解它至关重要。你必须先理解他们的邪恶计划，然后才能用它来对付他们。

Because everyone who reads your script has bought into Three Act Story Structure like a drowning man clutching whatever gets heaved at him, it’s crucial to understand it. You must comprehend their eeevil plan before you can use it against them.

你必须知道从哪里开始塑造这个角色。你必须知道她最后会变成什么样子。这就是她的弧线。她的转变。她的改变。有时你可以先想想结局：“当这一切结束时，她会变成什么样子——坚强、善良、活着？”然后倒推——“她一开始会变成什么样子：软弱、烦人、处于危险之中？”

You have to know where you’re starting with this character. You have to know where she’s going to be at the end. That’s her arc. Her transformation. Her change. Sometimes you can think about the end first: “Who is she going to be when all this is over — strong, kind, alive?” and work backwards — “Who will she be at the start: weak, irritating, in danger?”

你以《从前》作为开场，主角陷入困境，情况并不好。他正处于一个严重的问题之中，你马上就确定了这一点。如果他没有问题，你为什么要讲他的故事？给他一个沉重、困难、有趣的问题。

You open, Once Upon a Time, with your hero stuck in his difficult spot, which is not going well. He’s in the middle of a serious problem, which you establish right away. If he hasn’t got a problem, why are you telling his story? Give him a weighty, difficult, interesting problem.

他是如何与社会格格不入的？她是如何在这个世界上迷失的？他是如何对别人刻薄的？她灵魂上的空洞是什么？一旦你迅速而恰当地确定了这个问题，你的目标就是让剧本的其余部分找到这个唯一迫切问题的答案。如果你要花 110 页来处理一个问题，那么这个问题最好是一个大问题。他想要解决的就是这个问题。

How is he off-kilter with society? How is she adrift in the world? How is he being mean to other people? What is the hole in her soul? Once you establish this problem, well and swiftly, it will be your goal, for the rest of the screenplay to find the answer to this one single burning question. For you to spend 110 pages dealing with one problem, it had better be a helluva problem. It’s this problem he wants to solve.

确定了“想要”之后，就该看看“需要”了——故事结尾时，人物迫切需要成为什么，而在故事开始时，他最好不要意识到这一点。米克和基思说得最好——“你不可能总是得到你想要的东西”，但如果你努力尝试（非常努力！），“你就会得到你需要的东西。”

“Want” established, it’s time to look at “Need” — what the character desperately needs to become at the end of the story, which, at the beginning, he had better not be aware of. Mick and Keith put it best — “You can’t always get what you want” but if you try (real hard!), “you get what you need.”

迈克尔·柯里昂希望与凯结婚并远离家族事务，但他需要成为新的教父。

Michael Corleone wants to marry Kay and stay out of the family business, but he needs to become the new Godfather.

开发人员必须有一个“激励事件”。它会发生在第 5 页到第 15 页之间，这就是故事的开始。一旦我们认识了英雄，并对他所处的世界有了大致的了解，就会发生一些事情来震撼这个世界。陀思妥耶夫斯基曾说过，文学作品中只有两个故事，“一个人踏上旅程，一个陌生人来到小镇。”激励事件是当男人开始他的旅程或陌生人来到小镇的时候。

Development people gotta have an “Inciting Incident.” It will happen someplace between pages 5 and 15, and it’s what gets the story going. Once we meet the hero and have a decent handle on the world he’s struggling in, something happens that jars that world. Dostoyevsky supposedly said there are only two stories in all of literature, “A man goes on a journey and a stranger comes to town.” The Inciting Incident is when the man starts his journey or the stranger comes to town.

 

英雄发现他的老板在偷东西！

一位神秘的客户敲开了私家侦探的门！

一个小女孩接到一个电话，说她有机会参加选美比赛！

阿提克斯·芬奇被雇来为汤姆·鲁宾逊辩护。

The hero discovers his boss is stealing!

The private detective has a mysterious client knock at her door!

A little girl gets a phone call telling her she has a slot in the beauty contest!

Atticus Finch is hired to defend Tom Robinson.

我们要开始比赛了。

And we’re off to the races.

我们需要知道英雄的问题，她将如何解决它，对手将如何打击她。问自己这两个问题：你多快能告诉我们好人想要什么？我们多快能知道坏人想要什么？

We need to know the hero’s problem and how she is going to try to solve it and how the opponent is going to try to clobber her. Ask yourself these two questions: How quickly do you tell us what the good guy wants? How quickly do we know what the bad guy wants?

第一幕结束时，一定要发生一些大事。第二幕结束时，一定要发生一些惊天动地的大事。此外，这些事件必须非常非常明显。不仅对你来说，对盲人来说也一样清楚。我都数不清有多少次和编剧讨论他们的幕间休息，他们告诉我，在一些不起眼的场景中，发生了一些小事——我甚至都没有注意到。仅仅因为你认为这是一个幕间休息，并不意味着读者会明白。角色的世界必须在第一幕结束时被彻底颠覆，在第二幕结束时被彻底扭曲！让它变得明显！让读者说：“啊哈！这是第一个幕间休息！这位作家肯定知道他的结构！也许我可以让我的老板给他开张支票！”

You gotta have something big happen at the end of Act One. You gotta have something enormous happen at the end of Act Two. Plus, these events have to be really, really obvious. Clear, not just to you, but to a blind man. I can’t tell you how many times I’ve talked to writers about their act breaks and got told about some dinky scene where a little tiny thing happened — that I hadn’t even noticed. Just because you think it’s an act break doesn’t mean the reader is going to catch on. The character’s world must be turned upside down at the end of Act One and twisted inside out at the end of Act Two! Make it obvious! Allow the reader to go, “Aha! Here’s the first act break! This writer sure knows his structure! Maybe I can get my boss to write him a check!”

绘制故事中重大步骤的另一种方法是查看角色做出的决定。第一幕是她在压力越来越大的情况下，不得不做出重大决定的时刻。决定。这个决定是错误的决定。如果这是正确的决定，那电影就结束了！第二幕是英雄的一长串决定：在挣扎、麻烦、挣扎、麻烦、挣扎、麻烦中，决定越来越大。第二幕的结尾是她做出的一个重大决定，将她推向结局。

Another way to chart the big steps in your story is by looking at decisions the character makes. The First Act is her moving under increasing pressure to a moment where she has to make a big decision. This decision will be the wrong decision. If it were the correct decision, heck, the movie’d be over! The second act is a long string of your hero’s decisions: bigger and bigger ones in the midst of struggle, trouble, struggle, trouble, struggle, trouble. End of Act Two is a huge decision she makes that pushes her into the finale.

在《判决》的开场，律师保罗·纽曼决定在殡仪馆分发名片。救护车追逐者！醉鬼！失败者！他的第一个重大决定是不诚实的，当他决定在未咨询客户的情况下拒绝教区的和解提议时。他可能会被吊销律师执照！电影的其余部分都源于这个可怕的选择。

In the opening scene of The Verdict, attorney Paul Newman decides to give business cards out at funeral homes. An ambulance chaser! A drunk! A loser! His first BIG decision, which is dishonest, comes when he decides to turn down the diocese’s settlement offer without consulting his client. He could be disbarred! And the rest of the movie proceeds from that horrible choice.

在《体热》中，内德·拉辛的第一个重大决定是将一把椅子扔进马蒂·沃克的窗户，然后，嗯，在她家前厅的地板上与她发生性关系。内德，这是一个错误的决定！这让他陷入了麻烦之中。

In Body Heat, Ned Racine’s first big decision is to heave a chair through Matty Walker’s window and, um, engage in sexual congress with her on her front hall floor. Bad call, Ned! It gets him in a world of trouble.

所以，你已经在良好的状态中完成了剧本的第一部分。这不是很容易吗？事情正在发生。我们正在发现新的信息。第一幕快结束了。

So, you’ve got the first part of your screenplay under a good head of steam. Wasn’t that easy? Things are happening. We’re finding out new information. Time for the end of Act One.

在《唐人街》中，第一幕的结尾是杰克·吉蒂斯发现他一直在调查的通奸案是一场骗局，而雇佣他的女人只是假扮穆尔雷太太。他在第 23 页艰难地了解到了这一点，真正的穆尔雷太太带着她的律师出现，并冷静地宣布他将对吉蒂斯采取强硬措施。

In Chinatown, the end of Act One comes when Jake Gittes finds out that the adultery case he has been pursuing is a set-up, and the woman who hired him was only pretending to be Mrs. Mulwray. He learns this the hard way on page 23 when the real Mrs. Mulwray shows up with her attorney and coolly announces that he is going to get tough with Gittes.

《虎胆龙威》第一幕的结尾是麦克莱恩将一具尸体扔出窗外，落在一辆警车上。在此之前，《虎胆龙威》一直是麦克莱恩和格鲁伯在大楼内的战斗。当我们进入第二幕的未知领域时，麦克莱恩打开了世界，扩大了问题，引入了更多参与者，并使自己的情况变得更糟。

The end of Act One in Die Hard is when McClane throws a body out the window and it lands on a cop car. Until then, Die Hard has been a battle inside the building between McClane and Gruber. As we enter the uncharted waters of Act Two, McClane opens the world up, enlarges the problem, brings in more players, and makes things worse for himself.

在《末路狂花》中，第一幕的结尾是路易丝枪杀了强奸犯，而她们短暂的假期旅行突然变成了两个女人的逃亡之旅。

In Thelma and Louise, the end of Act One is when Louise shoots the rapist and their little vacation trip suddenly becomes two women on the lam.

电影《卡萨布兰卡》开播 25 分钟后，伊尔莎走进了里克的酒吧。砰！

Twenty-five minutes into Casablanca, Ilsa walks into Rick’s bar. Pow!

在我的剧本《105 度和上升》中，第一幕的结尾是男主角发现美国人可能不会带走他们的主要越南工人，而他们已经承诺了二十年不会留下这些工人。男主角的世界被彻底震撼了，他进入了被称为第二幕的黑暗虚空。

In my screenplay 105 Degrees and Rising, the end of Act One is when the hero discovers that the Americans might not take out their key Vietnamese workers, who they have promised for twenty years not to leave behind. The hero’s world is bowled over, and he enters into the murky void known as Act Two.

对第二幕最好的描述是“情况变得更糟”。在结构良好的第二幕中，你的第二幕，情况会变得越来越糟，而且越来越快。到第二幕结束时，整个事情对英雄来说必须变得非常糟糕，非常快，以至于他正在走向地狱。看看《在魔鬼知道你死前》的中间部分。“情况变得更糟”的惊人例子。

The best description of Act Two is “things get worse.” In a well-structured second act, YOUR second act, things get much, much worse, and faster and faster. By the end of Act Two, the whole thing needs to be going so wrong for the hero, so fast, that he’s on his way to hell in a handbasket. Check out the middle of Before the Devil Knows You’re Dead. Staggering example of “Things Get Worse.”

时不时地，必须发生一些有趣的事情。它必须让角色和读者感到惊讶。你可以称它们为情节点、逆转、情节转折、启示，我不管是什么，但你最好至少每十五页或更短的时间内出现一个新的。

Every so often, something interesting has to happen. It must be surprising to the character and the reader. You can call them plot points, reversals, plot twists, revelations, I don’t care what, but you better have a new one every fifteen pages or less, at least.

就像《辛普森一家》一样。如果你不喜欢一个笑话，那就等五秒钟，因为接下来会有一个笑话。如果没有足够的揭露，你的剧本就会一团糟。尽量多揭露一些。超过十二个怎么样！

It’s like The Simpsons. If you don’t like a joke, wait five seconds because here comes another one. Not enough reveals, your script is burnt toast. Try to have a lot of them. How about more than twelve!

第二幕中，男主角深陷其中，无法自拔。陷入了痴迷。

Act Two is where the hero gets deeply involved. No way to get out. Obsessed.

吉蒂斯

（现在离她只有几英寸）

GITTES

(now inches from her)

——我差点儿失去了我的鼻子！而且我

--I goddamn near lost my nose! And I

我喜欢它。我喜欢通过它呼吸。而且

like it. I like breathing through it. And

我仍觉得你隐藏了一些事情。

I still think you’re hiding something.

你没听出杰克·尼科尔森说过这句话吗？在罗伯特·汤恩的《唐人街》中，一旦对手的攻击变得人身攻击，吉蒂斯就绝不会放过他。即使穆尔雷夫人试图让他放弃这个案子。

Can’t you hear Jack Nicholson saying that? In Chinatown, by Robert Towne, once the opponent’s attacks get personal, there’s no way Gittes is going to turn this one loose. Even when Mrs. Mulwray tries to get him to drop the case.

我相信您知道，第一幕应该在第 25 页和第 35 页之间结束。第二幕应该在第 80 页或第 90 页左右结束。同样，这些事情发生在哪里并不重要，只要有足够的内容，让第 80 页的怪人抓住您的一个启示并说：“他真是个聪明的小伙子！第二幕在正确的位置结束！我会继续读下去！”

Act One, as I’m sure you know, needs to end somewhere between pages 25 and 35. Act Two needs to end somewhere around 80 or 90.
