One last example. You can also trim the middle!

格雷厄姆的七幅画作

INT. GRAHAM’S SEVEN PAINTINGS

巨大的、近乎抽象的画布上画着血淋淋、死去、被开膛剖肚的动物。路毙的动物被一层潦草的笔迹覆盖。格雷厄姆与玛格达合影，更多照片。

Huge, nearly abstract canvases of bloody, dead, eviscerated animals. Road kill under a layer of sloppy handwriting. Graham poses with Magda, more photos.

玛格达离开。卡米拉走近。

Magda departs. Camilla approaches.

卡米拉

CAMILLA

我是卡米拉·沃伦。晚安。

I’m Camilla Warren. Nice night.

他们慢慢地摇晃着。她很有魅力。

They shake, slowly. She is very appealing.

格雷厄姆

GRAHAM

买，还是看？

Buying, or watching?

卡米拉

CAMILLA

正在观看。

Watching.

她检查他。

She inspects him.

卡米拉

CAMILLA

卖啥了？

Sold anything?

格雷厄姆

GRAHAM

我会。

I will.

卡米拉

CAMILLA

当你这么做的时候，来找我。

When you do, find me.

她已经走了。

And she’s gone.

以下是同一场景，已标记剪切：

Here’s the same scene, with the cut marked:

格雷厄姆的七幅画作

INT. GRAHAM’S SEVEN PAINTINGS

巨大的、近乎抽象的画布上画着血淋淋、死去、被开膛剖肚的动物。路毙的动物被一层潦草的笔迹覆盖。格雷厄姆与玛格达合影，更多照片。

Huge, nearly abstract canvases of bloody, dead, eviscerated animals. Road kill under a layer of sloppy handwriting. Graham poses with Magda, more photos.

玛格达离开。卡米拉走近。

Magda departs. Camilla approaches.

卡米拉

我是卡米拉·沃伦。晚安。

CAMILLA

I’m Camilla Warren. Nice night.

他们慢慢地摇晃着。她很有魅力。

They shake, slowly. She is very appealing.

格雷厄姆。

GRAHAM.

买，还是看？

Buying, or watching?

卡米拉

CAMILLA

正在观看。

Watching.

她打量着他。

She inspects him.

 

 

卡米拉

CAMILLA

卖啥了？

Sold anything?

格雷厄姆

GRAHAM

我会。

I will.

卡米拉

CAMILLA

当你这么做的时候，来找我。

When you do, find me.

现在她已经走了。

Now she’s gone.

现在最终产品：

Now the final product:

格雷厄姆的七幅画作

INT. GRAHAM’S SEVEN PAINTINGS

巨大的、近乎抽象的画布上画着血淋淋、死去、被开膛剖肚的动物。路毙的动物被一层潦草的笔迹覆盖。格雷厄姆与玛格达合影，更多照片。

Huge, nearly abstract canvases of bloody, dead, evisceratedanimals. Road kill under a layer of sloppy handwriting. Graham poses with Magda, more photos.

玛格达离开。卡米拉走近。

Magda departs. Camilla approaches.

卡米拉

CAMILLA

卖啥了？

Sold anything?

格雷厄姆

GRAHAM

我会。

I will.

卡米拉

CAMILLA

当你这么做的时候，来找我。

When you do, find me.

她已经走了。

And she’s gone.

削减物质。让剩下的物质更加坚固。

Cut stuff. Make what’s left, stronger.

37. 当你的角色可以和某人说话时，她会进行研究！

37. Your character does research when she could be talking to somebody!

 

您知道这个场景。我们已经看过一百遍了（无论如何这应该是一个提示！）。这位勇敢的女主角需要了解过去发生的事情，所以她去了当地的图书馆，快速浏览缩微胶卷上的旧报纸，直到她发现……一些……重要的东西……

You know the scene. We’ve seen it a hundred times (which should be a tip off anyway!). The intrepid heroine needs to find out about what happened in the past, so she goes to her local library and zips through old newspapers on microfilm, until she discovers… something… important….

这真是太无聊了。

And it’s soooo boring.

消除旧报纸、尘封的档案、文件、图书馆和计算机记录，转而关注真实人物之间的对话。让她找到镇上年老、脾气暴躁的历史学家，了解导致她父母丧生的飞机失事事件。如果你的角色必须去图书馆，至少你的女主角和店员可以争论、发生冲突、互相反应。

Eliminate old bound newspapers, dusty archives, files, libraries, and computer records in favor of conversations between actual people. Have her track down the town’s old, crotchety historian to find out about the plane crash that killed her parents. If your character must go to a library, at least your heroine and the clerk can argue, have conflict, react to each other.

写一个令人难忘的场景！微缩胶片阅读器没有什么令人难忘的，除非它落在她身上。还记得在唐人街杰克·尼科尔森必须应付一个油嘴滑舌、爱管闲事的店员吗？

Write a scene that is memorable! There’s nothing memorable about a microfilm reader, unless it falls on her. Remember in Chinatown where Jack Nicholson has to deal with a smarmy, officious clerk?

 

 

 

店员

    （安静地流鼻涕）

先生，这不是借阅图书馆，而是档案馆。

吉蒂斯

那么——用尺子怎么样？

店员

尺子？干什么用的？

吉蒂斯

印刷得相当好。我忘了带眼镜。我希望能够看清。

CLERK

    (quietly snotty)

Sir, this is not a lending library, it’s the Hall of Records.

GITTES

Well, then -- how about a ruler?

CLERK

A ruler? What for?

GITTES

The print’s pretty fine. I forgot my glasses. I’d like to be able to read across.

多么棒的场景！因为英雄和某人说话了！

What a great scene! Because the hero talks to somebody!

如果没有别的办法，你可以为扮演老态龙钟、古怪古怪的历史学家的演员提供就业机会。他会得到他的健康保险。给他工作会让你感觉很好，而制片人也可以省下租用微缩胶片机的钱。

If nothing else, you can provide employment for the actor who will play the doddering, oddball, strange historian. He’ll get his health insurance. You’ll feel good about giving him work and the producers will save money not renting a microfilm machine.

与有趣的人面对面的冲突比积满灰尘的旧报纸有趣得多。

Face to face conflict with an interesting person is way more fun than dusty old newspapers.

38. 你笔下的人物打电话太多了！

38. Your characters talk on the phone too much!

 

这就像“反微缩胶片”规则。

This is like the “anti-microfilm” rule.

如果角色可以面对面交谈，就不要让他们打电话。当然，这对演员更好，而且当角色在同一个房间里时，读者也会更感兴趣。面对面的人物比打电话的人物更引人注目。

Don’t have characters talk on the phone when they could be face to face. It’s better for the actors, certainly, and it’s also more interesting for the reader when characters are in the same room. Characters face to face are more compelling than characters on the phone.

这确实会让你放松下来，不再纠结于角色之间的冲突和可能发生的情况，因为当你把他们放在一个房间里时，有趣的事情就会发生。他们可以互相扔煎锅，注意对方脸上表情的细微差别，一起做饭，或者一起用手指画画——如果他们只打电话，这些都不可能发生。

It will really loosen you up in terms of conflict and what can take place between the characters, because, when you stick them in a room together, interesting stuff can happen. They can throw skillets at each other, notice nuances of expression on each others’ faces, cook a meal, or finger-paint together — none of which can happen if they’re only on the phone.

39. 你并没有让每一个场景都令人难忘！

39. You have not made every scene memorable!

 

尝试让每个场景都以某种方式引人注目。问问自己，“这个场景中有什么我可以做的更好吗？”即使你的初稿是一幅无聊的城市天际线全景图，也并不意味着你不能重写它。采用贾斯珀·琼斯 (Jasper Johns) 的方法。

Try to make every scene remarkable in some way. Ask yourself, “Is there anything about this scene that I can make — better?” Just because your first draft is a boring pan across a city skyline doesn’t mean you can’t rewrite it. Take the Jasper Johns approach.

 

“拿一个物体。对它做点什么。对它做点别的事。对它做点别的事。”

贾斯珀·琼斯

“Take an object. Do something to it. Do something else to it. Do something else to it.”

Jasper Johns

有史以来最好的写作课之一。

One of the finest writing lessons of all time.

这就是神奇的“如果”。如果她现在不走怎么办？如果她直接说了怎么办？有时这真的会有帮助。坚持问“如果”会让你收获颇丰。

It’s the magic “what if.” What if she doesn’t leave now? What if she walks out on that line? Sometimes that will really help. Persistently asking “what if” will get you a piece of gold.

另一种思考方式是赋予每个场景第二层，以使其更有趣。

Another way to think about this is to give each scene a second layer, to make it more interesting.

《死亡诗社》和《鲍勃呢？》的编剧汤姆·舒尔曼试图在每个场景中都做到这一点。他写了一个开场“让我们见见鲍勃”的场景。最后，它没有出现在电影中，但你会明白我在说什么。

Tom Schulman, who wrote Dead Poets Society and What About Bob?, tries to do that in every scene. He wrote an opening “let’s meet Bob” scene. In the end, it didn’t make it into the film, but you’ll see what I’m talking about.

第一稿：鲍勃站在浴室里刷牙。好的。很好。很好。我们看到了鲍勃。我们看到了他的浴室。我们会从他移动的方式或对着镜子微笑的方式了解他。但这没什么好写的。然后舒尔曼开始思考他能做些什么来让这个场景变得非凡。

First draft: Bob is standing in his bathroom brushing his teeth. Okay. That’s fine. Nice. We see Bob. We see his bathroom. We’ll learn about him from the way he moves or smiles at himself in the mirror. But it’s nothing to write home about. Then Schulman started wondering what he could do to make the scene remarkable.

舒尔曼说：“我知道我们必须领先观众一步，让观众了解鲍勃这个人，所以在重写剧本时，我在浴室场景前加了一张字幕。字幕上写着：‘有记录显示，有 2,567 人吞下牙刷……世界纪录保持者是俄罗斯精神病院的一名患者。他一生中从胃里取出了 121 把牙刷。’现在，镜头切换到鲍勃刷牙的场景……”

Schulman said, “I knew we had to be ahead of the audience about this guy Bob, so in the rewrite, I put in a title card before the bathroom scene. The card read: ‘There have been 2,567 recorded cases of people swallowing their toothbrushes… The world record holder was a patient in a Russian insane asylum. In his lifetime, he had 121 toothbrushes removed from his stomach.’ Now, you cut to Bob brushing his teeth…”

现在，您对这个场景有什么看法？

Now what do you think about the scene?

观众的感受完全不同，只是因为添加了片头字幕。鲍勃的镜头是一样的，但实际上不是，因为我们在期待——某事。然后他吞下了他的牙刷！他惊慌失措，深吸一口气，设法让自己平静下来，打开橱柜，里面还有20 把刷子。他又拿了一把，刷完了牙。

The audience feels totally different just because the title card was added. The shot of Bob is the same, but not really, because we’re anticipating — something. Then he swallows his toothbrush! He’s panicked and takes a deep breath, manages to calm himself, opens his cabinet and inside — there are 20 more brushes. He gets another one and finishes brushing his teeth.

那是角色介绍！那是一个令人难忘的场景。它之所以出现，是因为作者利用了一个现有的场景并对其进行了一些改动。

THAT is a character introduction! That is a memorable scene. And it only appeared because the writer took an existing scene and did something to it.

你可能会问，为什么这么精彩的场景没有出现在电影中？比尔·莫里无法吞下糖果牙刷，否则会呕吐。

Why wasn’t such a fantastic scene in the movie, you ask? Bill Murray couldn’t swallow the candy toothbrush without throwing up.

让我们来看看弗朗西斯·科波拉的惊艳之作《现代启示录》。在“克林先生之死”的场景中，想象一下编剧正在写初稿。他们正在沿着侬河逆流而上，兰斯正在玩紫色烟雾弹，突然间，曳光弹从丛林中射出，发生了一场激烈的交火，克林死了。厨师因好友的死而心碎，场景以他痛苦地抱着死去的船友的尸体结束。

Let’s pay a visit to Francis Coppola’s stunning Apocalypse Now. In the “Mr. Clean’s Death” scene, imagine the writer doing the first draft. They’re chugging up the Nung river, Lance having fun with a purple haze smoke bomb and all of a sudden, tracer bullets stream out of the jungle, there’s a vicious firefight, and Clean is dead. Chef is torn apart by his buddy’s death and the scene ends with him in agony, hold his dead shipmate’s body.

这是一个不错的场景，但作为作家，你必须时刻想着再来一次。你能做些什么让观众对这个场景更加难忘？你如何让这个已经令人痛苦的场景变得更糟？你如何让读者/观众更加担心？

It’s a good scene, but as the writer, you must always think about going back for a second dip. What can you do to make the scene more memorable for the audience? How can you make the already harrowing scene even worse? How can you make the reader/viewer worry more?

对于第二层，我们得到每个人都从家里收到邮件的元素。

For the second layer, we get the element of everybody getting mail from home.

大厨站在船头，读着 13,000 英里外女友写来的“分手信”，而克莱恩则站在船尾，听着母亲的磁带“信”。当兰斯在玩烟雾弹时，克莱恩的妈妈告诉他，家人打算给他买一辆车，但他必须保守这个秘密。然后，枪战爆发，克莱恩被杀。现在，这一次，第二层情节已经展开，当大厨抱着克莱恩的尸体时，作者扭曲了我们的情感，母亲的磁带播放器的声音在背景中继续充满爱意地播放，“把你的屁股完好无损地带回家，因为我们非常爱你。爱你的，妈妈。”

Chef is up front, reading a “Dear John” letter from his girlfriend, 13,000 miles away and Clean is in the stern, listening to a cassette tape “letter” from his mother. While Lance is playing with the smoke bomb, Clean’s mom tells him the family is going to buy him a car, but that he has to keep it their secret. Then, the firefight breaks out and Clean is killed. Now, this time, with the second layer in place, when Chef holds Clean’s dead body, the writer twists us on the emotional gaff as the mother’s cassette player voice continues lovingly in the background, “bring your hiney home all in one piece, cause we love you very much. Love, Mom.”

我不知道作者是否这样计划过或者将其添加为第二层，但这令人痛心。

I have no idea if the writers planned it that way or added it as a second layer, but it’s gut-wrenching.

对话

Dialogue

 

40. 你没有记录偷听到的对话！

40. You don’t keep a log of overheard dialogue!

 

你必须学会​​写出精彩的台词。演员们想说一些很酷的话。你写这部电影是为了让演员们投入其中。没有什么比知道一个真正有才华的人喜欢你的台词并想在大屏幕上说出来更令人兴奋的了。但这需要大量的时间、工作和努力——血汗。

You’ve got to learn to write great dialogue. Actors want to say cool stuff. You’re writing this movie so actors will attach themselves to it. There’s nothing more exciting than knowing somebody really talented loves your dialogue and wants to say it on the big screen. But that takes a lot of time, work, effort — blood, tears, and sweat.

提高的方法之一是写下你听到的对话。

One way to improve is to write down dialogue you hear.

记录无意中听到的对话是成为更好的作家过程中的关键一步，也是你在写作生涯中应该保持的习惯。

Keeping a log of overheard dialogue is a crucial step in the process of becoming a better writer, and it’s a habit you should maintain for the rest of your writing life.

在公交车上、电影院排队时、市场里或任何地方，听听人们说些什么——并在口袋里放一本笔记本。或者把它写在笔记本电脑上。或者黑莓手机上。或者写在手上。可惜我们不再有纸袖口和衣领了。想想它们会成为多么棒的便笺纸！

Listen to what people say on buses, in line at movies, at the market, anywhere — and keep a notebook in your pocket. Or write it in your laptop. Or BlackBerry. Or on your hand. It’s a pity we no longer have paper cuffs and collars. Think what great notepaper they’d make!

首先，偷听很有趣。

First of all, it’s fun to eavesdrop.

其次，这对你的耳朵来说是一次极好的训练。你听和记下的真实对话越多，你就越能理解人们是如何说话的。他们互相打断。他们互相干扰对方的话。他们不会说完整的句子。根据他们来自哪里，他们有特定的语序、节奏、句法和词汇。读读马梅特的对话，你就会明白我的意思。

Second, it’s delicious training for your ear. The more real dialogue you listen to and copy down, the more you’re going to understand how people talk. They interrupt each other. They step on each other’s words. They don’t speak in complete sentences. Depending where they’re from, they have specific word order, rhythm, syntax, and vocabulary. Read Mamet’s dialogue, you’ll see what I mean.

请访问www.overheardinnewyork.com查看一些精彩示例。

Check out www.overheardinnewyork.com for some swell examples.

如果你把无意中听到的对话写下来，并不断地从笔记本中获取信息，那么你的人物就会比不写下听到的对话更加真实。此外，你听到的内容也会让你大吃一惊。

If you write down overheard dialogue and ceaselessly plunder your notebooks, your characters will have a deeper level of reality than if you don’t write down what you hear people say. Plus, it’s mind blowing what you’ll hear.

最好听这句！我在一家餐馆里听到的。一个男人对他的女朋友说：“我不在乎你的医生说什么。我告诉你，你没有得癌症，贱人！”

Top this one! I heard it in a restaurant. Man to his girlfriend: “I don’t care what your doctor says. I’m telling you, you don’t have cancer, bitch!”

你好！你可以根据这个写出整个剧本。

Hello! You could write a whole screenplay based on that.

41. 你还没有分离角色的声音！

41. You haven’t separated the character’s voices!

 

你认识乔治·康斯坦萨，对吧？他是宋飞的霸道朋友？很好。我一会儿再回复他。

You know George Costanza, right? Seinfeld’s overbearing buddy? Good. I’ll get back to him in a minute.

几年前，我正要去好莱坞开会。当时我正走在喷泉街上，在拉布雷亚的红绿灯前。我向窗外望去，看到一个女人走在人行道上。她又高又瘦。她穿着九英寸厚底鞋和一套粉蓝色双面针织长裤套装。喇叭裤笔挺而僵硬。她故意把一只脚放在另一只脚前面，就像走在钢丝上一样，几乎像个机器人。她面朝前方，僵硬地盯着地平线。她的黑发被狠狠地往后梳。头发从头顶卷成一个狭窄的锥形，高达一英尺，就像一只独角兽。她很奇怪。

Some years ago, I was on my way to a meeting in Hollywood. I was on Fountain, at the light at La Brea. I looked out my window and saw a woman walking up the sidewalk. She was tall and thin. She had on nine-inch platform shoes and a powder blue double-knit pants suit. Bellbottoms that were starched and rigid. She was deliberately putting one foot straight in front of the other, like she was walking on a wire, almost like a robot. Facing straight ahead, she stared stiffly at the horizon. Her dark hair was pulled straight back, severely. It wound up, off the top of her head, in a narrow cone that went up to a foot-high point, like a unicorn. She was odd.

灯变了，我开车走了。我到了会议室，进行了这样两句话的对话。仔细想想，这是一次令人惊讶的对话。

The light changed and I drove off. I got to my meeting and had this two-sentence conversation. When you think about it, an astonishing conversation.

我：“我刚刚见到了我在洛杉矶见过的最奇怪的人。”

卡尔：“我知道他是谁。”

Me: “I just saw the strangest person I’ve ever seen in Los Angeles.”

Karl: “I know who it is.”

哇哦。然后卡尔说：“我知道她住在哪里。”哇哦。会议结束后，我沿着底特律街往南走，就在梅尔罗斯街的下面。在一个角落里，是她的房子。它不可能属于别人。它是黑色的。整个房子、屋顶、烟囱、排水沟、窗户、墙壁和水泥院子里的大石头都被漆成了黑色。好像整栋房子都浸在一桶巨大的油漆里。

Whoa. Then Karl said, “And I know where she lives.” Double whoa. After the meeting, I went south on Detroit, just below Melrose. On a corner, was her house. It couldn’t have belonged to anybody else. It was black. The whole house, roof, chimney, gutters, windows, walls and big rocks in the concrete yard were painted black. It was as if the entire house had been dipped in a giant bucket of paint.

她的名字叫 Neptunia，我对她还有一件事要说。我的朋友 Max 对她和她的房子很着迷。有一天，愿上帝保佑她，Max 敲开了黑色的前门，要求借用她的电话，因为她丢了她的狗。Neptunia 让她进来了，这就是 Max 看到的景象。“房子里的一切，我的意思是一切，都铺着长毛地毯。地板、墙壁、家具。地毯一直铺到沙发，越过沙发，然后又铺回地板。”Max 不容易被吹走，但这次却被彻底吹走了。

Her name was Neptunia and I know one more thing about her. My friend Max was fascinated by her and her house. One fine day, bless her little heart, Max knocked on the black front door and asked to use her phone, as she’d lost her dog. Neptunia let her in, and here is what Max saw. “Everything in the house, and I mean everything, was covered in shag carpeting. The floor, the walls, the furniture. The carpet came up to the sofa, ran over the sofa and then back down across the floor.” Max, who does not blow away easily, was properly blown away.

春假期间，我接到过一些学生打来的电话，他们兴高采烈地对着手机大喊：“我来到了她家门口，一切都和你说的一样！”然而，很遗憾，在你收拾行装前往梅尔罗斯南部的底特律之前，海王星的房子已经翻修一新了。那座黑房子已经不复存在了。

I’ve had students call from spring break screaming joyfully into their cell phones, “I’m in front of her house AND IT’S JUST LIKE YOU SAID!” However, sorry to say, before you pack up and pay a visit to Detroit south of Melrose, Neptunia’s house has been remodeled. The black house is no more.

好的，以上就是如何分离人物声音的介绍。

Okay, all that by way of introduction to separating out character’s voices.

你能想象海王星会怎么说话，对吧？你可以在脑海中听到她的声音。如果她给附近的商店打电话叫人送货上门，或者她正在给牙医打电话，或者和马克斯谈论一只名叫克洛伊的走失的狗，她那奇怪的、尖细的声音和她不同寻常但绝妙的措辞都会铭刻在你的脑海里，并流入键盘，所以她的对话听起来就像海王星而不是其他人。

You can imagine how Neptunia would speak, right? You can hear her voice in your head. If she’s calling the neighborhood store to have her groceries delivered, or if she’s on the phone to the dentist, or talking to Max about a lost dog named Chloe, her strange, little high voice and her unusual but brilliant word choice is etched in your mind and flows into the keyboard so her dialogue sounds like Neptunia and no one else.

还记得乔治·康斯坦扎吗？你知道乔治是怎样说话的。每个人都知道乔治是怎样说话的：如果你把乔治丢在荒岛上，他游荡过来向猎头借一杯糖，你就知道乔治会怎样说话了。对吧？

Remember George Costanza? You know how George talks. EVERYBODY knows how George talks: If you drop George on a desert island and he wanders over to borrow a cup of sugar from a headhunter, you know what George’s use of language will be. Right?

现在，想象一下乔治住在海王星隔壁，他的篮球刚落在她家的院子里，但她却不肯还给他。你为那两只争吵的鸟写了精彩的对话。如果你把名字遮住，读者绝对会知道是乔治在说话还是海王星在说话。

Now, imagine George lives next door to Neptunia and his basketball just landed in her yard, but she won’t give it back. You write dazzling dialogue for those two birds arguing. If you cover up the names, the reader will absolutely know if it’s George or Neptunia speaking.

你把人物的声音区分开来了。你太棒了。

You separated the characters’ voices. You’re a champ.

这一点至关重要。如果你不这样做，读者就会猛烈抨击你。

This of tantamount importance. Readers pounce when you don’t do it.

逐个检查角色的对话，以确保：

Character by character, check their dialogue to make sure:

1) 自始至终，他们听起来都和他们自己一模一样。

1) All the way through, they always sound just like themselves.

他们的“声音”是否一致，是否与他们的出身、道德、经济阶层、成长方式以及与他们的性格有关的一切相符？

Is their “voice” consistent and in keeping with where they’re from and their morality and economic stratum and how they were raised, and everything else having to do with their character?

他们说话的速度。他们语言的节奏。词语的选择。他们经常、很少、从不使用缩略词吗？他们经常骂人吗？他们使用大词，但不知道这些词的意思吗？他们来自北达科他州吗？他们的对话中是否表现出来？他们在军队服役过吗？他们害羞吗？

The speed at which they talk. The rhythm of their language. Choice of words. Do they use contractions a lot, seldom, never? Do they cuss a lot? Do they use big words, but don’t know what they mean? Are they from North Dakota and does it show in their dialogue? Were they in the military? Are they shy?

仅通过他们个人的语言使用方式，你能告诉我们多少关于每个人的信息？

How much can you teach us about each person, just by their personal use of language?

2) 他们的对话听起来与其他角色的对话都不一样。

2) Their dialogue doesn’t sound like any other character’s.

3) 他们听起来不像你！

3) They don’t sound like you!

把配音分开对于次要角色来说是正确的，因为你是在写演员诱饵。当然，你有兴趣让超级明星来扮演男主角，但你也必须选出披萨送货员。如果你写出有趣、具体的披萨送货员对话，你就会找到一个很棒的演员来扮演披萨送货员。

Separating out the voices holds true for minor characters because you’re writing actor bait. Sure, you’re interested in getting Mr. Mega Star to attach to play the male lead, but you also have to cast Pizza Delivery Dude. You write interesting, specific Pizza Delivery Dude dialogue, you’re going to get a great actor to play Pizza Delivery Dude.

这是我改编的苏珊娜·金斯伯里 (Suzanne Kingsbury) 作品《弗莱彻·格里尔爱我的夏天》中的部分对话。

Here’s some dialogue from my adaptation of The Summer Fletcher Greel Loved Me by Suzanne Kingsbury.

汽水机旁的男人

MAN ON SODA MACHINE

      （拍卖师快速）

      (auctioneer fast)

我很好。安妮·梅今天早上打来电话，她的儿子沃尔特和那个小男孩彼得森到处乱跑。彼得森一家人都快崩溃了。那个男孩的父亲大詹姆斯·厄尔·彼得森上个月开枪打穿了自己的嘴巴。就在上周六，那个小男孩也做了同样的事情，用 .22 口径手枪对着自己的舌头，然后扣动了扳机。沃尔特死了，不得不看着这一切。他十岁了。

I’m doing good. Annie May’s on the phone this mornin, her son Walter he run around with that little Peterson boy. The Petersons, they can’t hold theyselves together. Big James Earl Peterson, that boy’s daddy, he gone shot himself through the mouth last month. Just last Sat’day, that little un done the same thing, .22 on his tongue, and pulled the trigger. Walter gone and have to watch it. He ten years old.

莱利

RILEY

王八蛋。

Son of a bitch.

汽水机旁的男人

MAN ON SODA MACHINE

那男孩也胖得跟猪一样。这么热的天气，后门廊上躺着一个死胖子，简直就是个混蛋。

That boy’s fat as a hog, too. Dead fat kid on a back porch in this heat’s a Goddamn buttache.

你认为苏打机上的男子来自哪里？温哥华？我不这么认为。他的声音一点也不像这位因美国向南越撒谎而感到厌恶的职业外交官：

Where do you think Man On Soda Machine is from? Vancouver? I don’t think so. His voice is not remotely like this career diplomat who’s disgusted with America for lying to the South Vietnamese:

麦基洛普

MCKILLOP

我已经来这里五年了……

I’ve been here five years...

      （看着艾伦）

      (looks at Ellen)

这是我的家……而现在我们就快要跑出去了……

This is my home... And now we’re just running out...

      （这让他丧命）

      (this kills him)

没人叫我们来这里。我们告诉这些人，我们会把他们从恶魔手中救出来。他们信任我们……现在一切都结束了……一切都支离破碎。我们来到这里时，带着“我们穿着外套和领带，我们知道自己在这里做什么”的态度，而……我们没有……而现在……而现在，我们像夜贼一样离开……把他们留在一片混乱中……而，而，而……我感到非常羞愧和抱歉……

Nobody asked us to come here. We told these people we’d save them from the boogie man. And they trusted us... And now it’s over... Just shot to pieces. We came in here with our “we wear coats and ties, we know what we’re doing here folks” attitude, and... wedidn’t... And now... and now, we’re going like a thief in the night...leaving them... in such a mess...and, and, and... I’m so ashamed and so sorry....

特鲁迪·米德 (Trudy Mead) 听起来既不像麦基洛普 (McKillop)，也不像苏打机上的男子 (Man On Soda Machine)。

Trudy Mead doesn’t sound like either McKillop or Man On Soda Machine.

我和 Dub Cornett 一起创作了这首歌。

I wrote this with Dub Cornett.

特鲁迪

TRUDY

我是特鲁迪·米德。叫我特鲁迪就行。亲爱的，你将成为第一位从马术项目毕业的女性。我不在乎这会要了你的命，我们都会帮助你度过难关，亲爱的。

I’m Trudy Mead. Call me Trudy. And you, my dear, are going to be the first woman to graduate from the Equine program. I don’t care if it kills you and me both, we’re going to get you through, darling.

芭芭拉

BARBARA

谢谢。

Thanks.

特鲁迪

TRUDY

我想成为一名马兽医。二十年前，奥本大学的兽医专业根本没有多少女孩，大型动物诊所就更不用说了。所以我一直忙着给贵宾犬的屁股切脓肿，希望你能来让我的生活更有价值。所以别让我失望，孩子！

I wanted to be an Equine vet. Twenty years ago, there weren’t even many girls in the vet program at all, at Auburn, much less in the large animal practice. So I been stuck lancing boils on poodles’s asses hoping you’d come along and make my life a little more worth while. So don’t let me down, kiddo!

想象一个场景，这些角色都在同一页上。你永远不需要读他们的名字就能知道谁在说话。这就是你的目标。每个角色的声音都如此独特，读者读起来如风般顺畅，不必浪费时间读角色的名字就能知道谁在说话。对话必须这样进行，否则他们不会把你的剧本交给他们的老板。

Imagine a scene with these characters all on the same page. You would never need to read their names to know who’s speaking. That is your goal. Every character’s voice so distinctive that the reader, reading like the wind, won’t have to waste time reading the character’s name to know who’s talking. Dialogue has to work like that, or they won’t give your script to their boss.

42. 你的对话还不够深入！

42. You haven’t worked your dialogue hard enough!

 

对话很难，但也有办法。

Dialogue is tough, but there are ways into it.

一个选择是为你认识的人写对话，这样你的角色听起来就像你的朋友。为自己写，写你在那个年龄时的样子，但不要自传——表达你的感受。永远记住每个角色的年龄和经历。

One option is to write dialogue for someone you know so your character sounds like your friend. Write for yourself, how you used to be at that age, but don’t be autobiographical — channel your feelings. Always keep in mind each character’s age and experience.

你可以为一个你熟悉其声音的演员写剧本，但他可能永远不会出现在电影中，尤其是如果他们已经去世了。我曾经写过一个角色，用的是杰克·尼科尔森的声音、说话方式和节奏。他从来没有读过剧本，而且年纪太大了，不适合这个角色，但它给了我一个声音。当你读到对话听起来像某人。没有人会说，“嘿，这听起来就像杰克·尼科尔森，你这个没有天赋的笨蛋”，但这听起来确实像一个读者可以抓住的角色。

You can write for an actor whose voice you know well, but who might never end up in the movie, especially if they’re dead. I once wrote a character and used Jack Nicholson’s voice and speech pattern and rhythm. He never read the script and was too old for the part anyway, but it gave me a voice in my head. When you read the dialogue it sounds like somebody. No one ever said, “Hey, that sounds just like Jack Nicholson, you talentless clod,” but it does sound like a character a reader can grab hold of.

在每个角色中找到情感核心，即使这种经历不是每个人都会拥有或能够拥有的，但让它具有人性化总是会鼓励读者参与其中。

Find the emotional core in every character, even if the experience isn’t something that everyone will have, or could have, but making it human always encourages the reader to become involved.

对着录音机说话，直到你完全掌握角色的声音。尽量不要让你配偶的父母看到这一幕。

Talk into a tape recorder until you get a solid handle on the character’s voice. Try not to let your spouse’s parents witness this.

问问自己：每句对话是否都尽可能地精彩、有趣、简洁、有趣和写得好？看看每句对话，想想你可以如何改进它、消除它，或者你可以如何利用它以更好更有趣的方式推动故事的发展。

Ask yourself: Is every smidgen of dialogue as good or funny or terse or interesting and as well-written as possible? Look at every line of dialogue and think how you could improve it, eliminate it, or how you could use it to move the story forward in a better more interesting way.

只是因为你写了它，并不意味着你不能重写它！或者删掉它！！

Just ’cause you wrote it doesn’t mean you can’t rewrite it! Or cut it!!

参加表演课。

Take acting classes.

制定自己的规则：比如，主角家里的每个人都可以用英国语法说话，即使他们都是美国人。

Make up your own rules: say, everyone in the lead character’s family can speak with British syntax, even if they’re all American.

为每个角色编写一段对话。按 Ctrl F 或 Apple F 查找，将其设置为“匹配大小写”，然后以大写字母输入角色的名字。逐个角色地检查剧本，只检查他们的对话，确保听起来总是像他们而不是其他人。即使是披萨送货员。

Do a dialogue pass for each character. Type Ctrl F or Apple F, for FIND, set it for “match case” and then, in uppercase letters, a CHARACTER’S NAME. Go through the script one character at a time checking only their dialogue, making sure it always sounds like them and no one else. Even for Pizza Delivery Dude.

您是否添加了逗号，以便按照您想要的节奏阅读？是否在应该有句号的地方加了句号？是否在应该有逗号的地方没有标点符号，等等？

Have you put commas so it reads with the rhythm you intend? Are there periods where there should be periods? Is there no punctuation where there should be a comma, and so on and so on?

去买一本儿童读物《吃、射、离开》，作者是 Lynne Truss。读给你的孩子听，然后偷偷地把它带到你的写作角落，狼吞虎咽地读下去。这本书讲的是逗号的重要性。它很有教育意义，也很搞笑。举个例子：一只熊猫抢劫了一家银行，但先吃了点零食：他吃了，射了，然后离开了。或者在动物园里，熊猫为了食物会做什么：他吃嫩芽和树叶。意思有点不同，是吧？逗号很棒。

Go buy the children’s book Eats, Shoots and Leaves by Lynne Truss. Read it to your kids and then sneak it over to your writing nook and gobble it up. It’s about how commas matter. It’s instructive, and hilarious. One example: a panda bear robs a bank, but has a snack first: he eats, shoots and leaves. OR at the zoo, what does a panda do for food: he eats shoots and leaves. Slightly different meaning, eh? Commas rock.

吉蒂斯

GITTES

我能告诉你什么呢孩子？你是对的。当你是对的时候你就是对的，你是对的。

What can I tell you kid? You’re right. When you’re right you’re right, and you’re right.

在对话中，当你真正想说“你是”时，你会说“你是”吗？确保在应该使用缩写的地方使用缩写。如果不使用缩写，人们往往会听起来受教育过度。这就是你的观点吗？

In dialogue do you say “you are” when you actually mean “you’re?” Make sure you have contractions where there should be contractions. People have a tendency to sound highly over-educated if they don’t use contractions. Is that your point?

请记住，人们会互相打断，并且不会讲完整的句子。

Remember, people interrupt each other and don’t speak in complete sentences.

有时，为了进行正确的对话，您必须进行研究。

Sometimes, to get dialogue right, you have to do research.

如果您正在编写警察调度员对话，请找一位真正的警察调度员来帮助您。电视记者说话不像挖井人。花点时间把事情做好。但是，如果您正在寻找一位俄罗斯大公爵夫人来帮助您进行对话研究，那么您可能不得不自己想办法。

If you’re writing police dispatcher dialogue, find a real police dispatcher to help you. Television reporters don’t talk like well-diggers. Take time to get it right. However, if you’re looking for a Russian Grand Duchess to help you with dialogue research, you’re probably going to have to make it up.

了解你的角色使用的语言。如果你写的是乡村音乐，你知道“girm”是什么意思吗？如果你的角色是妓女，那么“blue steel”是什么意思呢？骗子用“Lapping”，洞穴探险者用“rocksoluble”，山地自行车手用“crayon”，漫画迷用“chibi”，政客用“bafflegab”。做好功课。

Know what language your character uses. If you’re writing about Country music do you know what “girm” means? What about “blue steel” if your character is a prostitute? “Lapping” for con men, “rock solvent” for cavers, “crayon” for mountain bikers, “chibi” for a manga fan, and “bafflegab” for politicians. Do your homework.

《希德姐妹帮》的编剧丹尼尔·沃特斯知道，如果他使用现在的高中方言，青少年的每句对话很快就会过时，所以他自己编造了。而且，他编造的东西成为了语言的一部分：

Daniel Waters, who wrote Heathers, knew if he used current high school patois, that every single bit of teenage dialogue would soon be dated, so he made up his own. And, the stuff he made up became part of the language:

维罗妮卡·索耶

VERONICA SAWYER

你损失了多少钱，希瑟？

What is your damage, Heather?

还有这个经典...

And this classic...

希瑟·钱德勒

HEATHER CHANDLER

好吧，用电锯轻轻地操我。我看起来像特蕾莎修女吗？

Well, fuck me gently with a chainsaw. Do I look like Mother Theresa?

就像《墓碑镇》中的“I'll be your huckleberry”（我会成为你的哈克贝利） 、 《大人物拿破仑》中的“Gosh!”（天哪！）和《太坏了》中的“I am McLovin”（我是麦克拉文）——如果你在台词上下足功夫，它可能会成为时代精神。

Like “I’ll be your huckleberry,” from Tombstone, “Gosh!” from Napoleon Dynamite, and “I am McLovin,” from Superbad — if you work your dialogue hard enough, it might enter the zeitgeist.

黛西·富特是我这一代最出色的剧作家之一，她会用最酷的方式让台词准确无误。如果她写的是一部关于某个来自新斯科舍省的人的戏剧，她会给她的朋友打电话，找一个认识住在新斯科舍省并愿意提供帮助的人，给他们寄一台录音机和一堆磁带，让他们录下他们一家人吃晚饭的场景。她不在乎他们谈论什么，但她对他们的语言使用、他们说话的节奏以及他们说话的方式很感兴趣。结果非常准确。黛西写出了一些我听过的最精彩的台词。

Daisy Foote, one of the finest playwrights of my generation, does the coolest thing to get her dialogue right. If she’s writing a play about someone from, say, Nova Scotia, she calls around to her friends, finds someone who knows someone who lives in Nova Scotia who’s willing to help, mails them a tape recorder and a bunch of tapes, and asks them to record their family having dinner. She doesn’t care what they talk about, but she’s interested in their use of language, the rhythm of their speech, and how they say what they say. The results are spot-on accurate. Daisy writes some of the finest dialogue I’ve ever heard.

你也可以。

You can too.

43. 你没有对对话进行 AB 处理！

43. You didn’t A-B the dialogue!

 

吉姆·博伊尔教会了我这项高超的技术。

Jim Boyle taught me this superb technique.

在写场景时，很难将两个角色的声音区分开来。这也很重要。为了确保场景中的人物有自己独特的声音，请 A - B 对话。

It’s difficult to keep two character’s voices separate when you’re writing a scene. It’s also crucial. To insure the people in a scene have their own distinct voices, A - B the dialogue.

首先写出角色 A 的对话。只写他们的对话。而不是其他人的。如果他来自布鲁克林（而你不是），你需要花一些时间才能理解他的声音。他使用的语言、说话的节奏、词序——所有让布鲁克林店主听起来像布鲁克林店主的东西。

Write character A’s dialogue first. Just their dialogue. Not the other guy’s. If he’s from Brooklyn (and you’re not), it’s going to take you a while to get into his voice. The language he uses, rhythm of speech, word order — everything that makes a shop keeper from Brooklyn sound like he’s a shop keeper from Brooklyn.

你已经对场景中要做什么有了大致的想法，所以写一半的对话其实并不难。你有一个目标，场景的发展方向，然后你按照这个方向写作。

You already have a general idea of what you want to do in the scene, so writing half the dialogue isn’t that difficult, actually. You have a goal, where the scene is headed, and you write in that direction.

你只需要写写写——只写角色 A 的对话。你还不需要写其他人的对话，所以不用担心。只要做一个来自布鲁克林的人，尽情发挥就行了。

And you write and write and write — only Character A’s dialogue. You don’t have to write the other person’s dialogue yet, so don’t worry about it. Just be a guy from Brooklyn, and let ‘er rip.

很快，你就会听到他的声音，对话就会流淌出来。听起来就像是来自布鲁克林中心的杂货店老板。最后，你会穷尽《布鲁克林先生》中那个场景的所有对话可能性，现在是时候开始塑造角色 B 了，一个来自阿拉巴马州的老太太。

Pretty soon, you’re going to hear his voice in your head, and the dialogue will flow. And it will sound like a grocer from the heart of Brooklyn. Finally, you will exhaust all the possibilities of dialogue for that scene from Mr. Brooklyn, and now it’s time to work on Character B, a little old lady from Alabama.

于是，你开始写角色 B 的对话，只写了她一半的场景，瞧，当你开始写的时候，听起来很像你的老太太来自布鲁克林。不过，过了一会儿，你就会摆脱布鲁克林的束缚，进入到桌布、红粘土和贝尔·布莱恩特的世界。你将能够专注于她的世界、她的问题、她的措辞、她的说话方式——一直到场景的底部。

So, you start to write Character B’s dialogue, just her half of the same scene, and lo and behold, when you start, it sounds a lot like your little old lady is from — Brooklyn. After a while, though, you’ll shed the trappings of Brooklyn, and will enter into the world of doilies, red clay, and Bear Bryant. You’ll be able to concentrate on her world, her problems, her diction, her speech patterns — all the way to the bottom of the scene.

完成后，打印出来。

When you’re done, print it.

拿一支荧光笔，标记布鲁克林先生说的所有精彩对话，以及阿拉巴马夫人说的所有精彩内容，在它们之间反复切换，直到你得到一段真正的对话。剪切和粘贴，你就会得到一段听起来完全不一样的两个人之间的对话！

Get a highlighter and mark all the swell dialogue that Mr. Brooklyn said, and all the good stuff that Mrs. Alabama said, bouncing back and forth between them until you have a real conversation. Cut and paste and you have a conversation between two people who sound nothing like each other!

太棒了。用最少的努力就解决了编剧的最大难题。

Bingo. Screenwriting’s biggest problem solved with a minimum of effort.

不客气。

You’re welcome.

44. 您有问答对话！

44. You have Q & A dialogue!

 

地球上最糟糕、最可怕的对话出现在家乡电视上为家具店拍摄的广告中。

The worst, most godawful dialogue on the planet is in hometown television spots for furniture stores.

 

莎莉：鲍勃，这是什么华丽的家具？！

鲍勃：嘿，谢谢你，莎莉。这真是一件华丽的家具，不是吗？！

莎莉：当然是了，鲍勃。你能告诉我一些关于它的事情吗？！

鲍勃：好吧，萨尔，我当然可以告诉你一点！这是布罗希尔实心桃花心木五斗橱，配有黄铜配件和燕尾榫结构！

莎莉：哇，鲍勃！燕尾榫结构？看起来真贵！我怎么可能买得起布罗希尔实心桃花心木五斗橱，配有黄铜配件和燕尾榫结构？！

鲍勃：看起来确实很贵，莎莉，但是，嘿，它出奇地便宜！

Sally: Say, Bob, what’s this gorgeous piece of furniture?!

Bob: Hey, thank you Sally. It is a gorgeous piece of furniture, isn’t it?!

Sally: Sure is, Bob. Can you tell me a little bit about it?!

Bob: Well, Sal, I certainly can tell you a little bit about it! It’s a solid mahogany Broyhill chest of drawers with brass fittings and dovetail construction!

Sally: Wow, Bob! Dovetail construction? It sure looks expensive! How can I possibly afford a solid mahogany Broyhill chest of drawers with brass fittings and dovetail construction?!

Bob: It does look expensive, Sally, but, hey, it’s surprisingly affordable!

ARRGGGGGGGGHHHHHHHH！我再也受不了打出这些垃圾字了！

ARRGGGGGGGGHHHHHHHH! I can’t stand to type one more word of that garbage!

她问了一个问题。问。

She asks a question. Q.

他回答了。A.

He answers it. A.

呕吐。

Barf.

问题：

Question:

山姆

SAM

你在跟我开玩笑。

You’re kidding me.

回答：

Answer:

安吉洛

ANGELO

我没有跟你开玩笑。我不会拿钱开玩笑。

I’m not kidding you. I don’t joke about money.

问答对话就像流沙。它会阻止一切前进的动力。然后它会淹没你。如果你有问答对话，请振作起来。这只是初稿。你还没有把你的剧本发给经纪人。我希望如此。

Q & A dialogue is like quicksand. It stops all forward motion. Then it drowns you. If you’ve got Q & A dialogue, take heart. It’s just a first draft. You haven’t sent your script to an agent yet. I hope.

好的对话回答了问题，但跳过了显而易见的答案，给了我们新的信息——同时仍然回答了问题。以下是《魔鬼的自己》中的一段话：

Good dialogue answers the question, but leapfrogs OVER the obvious answer and gives us new information — while still answering the question. This from The Devil’s Own:

哈里森·福特

HARRISON FORD

他们抓到那帮混蛋了吗？

Did they catch the fuckers?

布拉德·皮特

BRAD PITT

他们才是混蛋。

They were the fuckers.

始终推动我们前进：

Always move us forward:

黛安娜

DIANE

她最近在喝酒吗？

She boozing these days?

富兰克林

FRANKLIN

仍在戒酒。

Still on the wagon.

黛安娜

DIANE

你要去参加聚会吗？

Are you going to the party?

富兰克林

FRANKLIN

我宁愿死。

I’d rather die.

黛安娜

DIANE

为什么不呢？

Why not?

富兰克林

FRANKLIN

你见过 Nan 了。

You’ve met Nan.

租借安吉丽娜·朱莉的《Playing By Heart》。对话精彩。然后看看 1935 年兰道夫·斯科特版的《她》。有史以来最糟糕的问答对话！

Rent Playing By Heart with Angelina Jolie. Amazing dialogue. Then check out the 1935 Randolph Scott version of She. Some of the worst Q&A dialogue, ever!

45. 你笔下的人物只说正文，不说潜台词！

45. You have characters speaking text but not subtext!

 

潜台词是没有说出口的文字。潜台词是他们想表达的意思，但是没有说出来。

Subtext is unspoken text. It’s what they mean, but don’t say.

如果两个五十多岁的男人在周六晚上聊天，其中一个说：“你今晚要做什么？”而他的朋友回答：“没什么。你打算做什么？”你就知道作者想让你知道什么，不用两个人说出来：“我的生活很悲惨，因为我没有女朋友。”

If two fifty-year-old men are talking to each other on a Saturday night, and one says, “What are you going to do tonight?” and his buddy answers, “Nothing. What are you going to do?” you know what the writer wants you to know without either guy saying it: “my life is so miserable because I don’t have a girlfriend.”

未说出口的文字就是潜台词。

The unspoken text is subtext.

在《赤色分子》中，约翰·里德（沃伦·比蒂饰）和露易丝·布莱恩特（黛安·基顿饰）曾结过婚，但两人关系疏远。他们在俄罗斯，一起工作、生活，但不能睡在一起。虽然这不是他想要的安排，但这是他能得到的最好的结果，而且总有希望。到目前为止，每次他对她的作品提出批评时，她总是会生气并拒绝，而她总是要求批评。这一次（押韵得真好！）他告诉她她的作品有什么问题，她听了！她说他是对的。这对她的性格来说是一个巨大的转变。他惊呆了。

At one point in Reds, John Reed (Warren Beatty) and Louise Bryant (Diane Keaton) are married, but estranged. They’re in Russia, working and living together, but not sleeping together. While it’s not the arrangement he wants, it’s the best he can get and there’s always hope. Up to now, every single time he’s ever given her criticism on her writing, which she has always asked for, she’s gotten angry and rejected it. This time (nice rhyming!) he tells her what’s wrong with her piece, and she listens! She tells him he’s right. This is a sea change for her character. He’s stunned.

我们也是。然后她在上床睡觉时说道：“你对其他事情也说对了。”

So are we. Then she says, as she’s getting into bed, “You’ve been right about something else, too.”

现在潜台词来了。镜头对准了他。他看着她，我们知道他希望她改变主意，想要发生性关系。我们知道。我们不需要被告知。虽然对话中没有，但我们明白。

Now comes the subtext. Camera is on him. He’s looking at her and we know he’s hoping that she’s changed her mind, and wants to have sex. We KNOW it. We don’t have to be told. It’s not in dialogue, but we get it.

然后她说：“布尔什维克将带领俄罗斯退出战争。”他说：“晚安。”他没有说：“哎呀，亲爱的，我还以为你想让我和你一起上床。”他可能在第一稿或第九稿中说过这句话，但他没有在他们拍摄的那一稿中说这句话。他们抓住了角色的想法，也就是潜台词，然后把它埋了起来。

Then she says, “The Bolsheviks will take Russia out of the war.” And he says, “Good-night.” He doesn’t say, “Gee, honey, I thought you wanted me to come to bed with you.” He may have said that in the first draft, or the ninth, but he doesn’t say it in the one they shot. They take what the character is thinking, the subtext, and they bury it.

以下是一些相当直白的文字：

Here’s some rather on-the-nose text:

米里亚姆

MYRIAM

你对我太刻薄了。我们在一起的生活简直是一场骗局。你太可恶了。你不理解我，也不了解我的需求，我们的婚姻肯定岌岌可危。如果你再一次对我不好，我发誓，我会离开你和你那些可怜的包装工队球迷酒友。明白了吗？

You are so mean to me. Our life together has been such a sham. You are so hateful. You don’t understand me or my needs and our marriage is definitely on the rocks. If you treat me badly just one more time, I swear, I’m leaving you and your sorry Packers fan drinking buddies. Is that clear?

        （片刻）

        (a moment)

你到底在听没？

Are you even listening?

这是我最喜欢的潜台词例子。这是Harley Peyton 创作的《Bandits》中的一段。

Here’s my favorite example of subtext. This is from Bandits, written by Harley Peyton.

红发的凯特·布兰切特一边做晚饭，一边唱着《我需要一个英雄》。她几乎在跳脱衣舞，因为她太喜欢这首歌了。当她用喷雾器软管当麦克风、敲打滤锅、切菜、搅拌面粉等时，你能感受到她火热的个性。然后，镜头切换到令人惊叹的厨房，远处是一条令人惊叹的河流，你会意识到这一切都是幻想。她想象自己在唱歌跳舞。现在，她站在那里，做了一顿美味的饭，她的丈夫走进来：

Redheaded Cate Blanchett sings along with “I Need A Hero” while she cooks dinner. She nearly does a striptease, she’s so into the song. You get a huge sense of her fiery personality as she uses the sprayer hose as a microphone, drumming on a colander, chopping vegetables, tossing flour around, etc. Then, they cut to wide in the stunning kitchen, with an incredible view of a distant river, and you realize the whole thing was a fantasy. She imagined herself singing and dancing. Now, she’s standing there, having cooked an amazing meal and her husband walks in:

丈夫

HUSBAND

        （觉得很棒）

        (thinks it’s great)

那是什么味道？

What is that smell?

她详细讲述了她做的这顿美餐。她也说得很性感。然后他告诉她他今晚要和客户一起吃晚饭。她掩饰了自己的伤心，说她做这顿饭只是为了好玩。

She goes into great detail telling about this stellar meal she cooked. She’s quite sexy about it, too. Then he tells her he’s got dinner tonight, with clients. She covers the hurt by saying that she cooked the meal just for fun.

那一刻，你知道他们的婚姻岌岌可危。他根本不知道她是谁。她费尽心机，他却浑然不知。当她说“这只是为了好玩”时，你知道她不是这个意思。于是他离开了。她独自站在那里，惊魂未定，然后他回来了。

Right there, you know their marriage is on the rocks. He doesn’t have a clue who she is. She’s taken all this trouble and he doesn’t notice. When she says, “It’s just for fun,” you know that’s not what she means. So he leaves. She’s standing there alone, shell shocked, and then he comes back.

丈夫

HUSBAND

亲爱的？

Sweetheart?

妻子

WIFE

        （激动）

        (thrilled)

是的！？

Yeah!?

丈夫

HUSBAND

你为什么不去看电影呢？

Why don’t you go see a movie?

他走了。她怒不可遏。她接下来做的事就是冲出家门，丢下他。

He goes. She’s enraged. The next thing she does is slam out of the house, leaving him.

当她说“是啊！？”时，我们知道她想让他说：“亲爱的，你为什么不和我一起去吃晚饭呢？”或者，“我取消和客户的晚餐，我们可以一起在这里吃饭。”我们从一个对话词中了解到她所有的希望和愿望，所有的潜台词。

When she says, “Yeah!?” we know she wants him to say, “Sweetheart, why don’t you come with me and have dinner.” Or, “I’ll cancel dinner with the clients and we can eat here together.” We get all her hope and desire, all that subtext, from one single word of dialogue.

他的下一条短信是：“你为什么不去看电影呢？”潜台词是“我们的婚姻很糟糕，我对你没有一点尊重。”

His next text is, “Why don’t you go see a movie.” The subtext is “our marriage stinks and I have no respect for you.”

但编剧没有这样写。他让你自己去想。

But the screenwriter doesn’t write that. He lets you figure it out.

46. 你做了太多研究！

46. You did too much research!

 

威廉·M·埃克斯的研究第一定律：不要做太多！

William M. Akers’ First Law of Research: Don’t do much!

但相反地……

But, conversely…

47. 你没有做足够的研究！

47. You didn’t do enough research!

 

哎呀，真令人困惑啊！

Gee, how confusing!

 

“我要和她断绝关系吗？我要娶她吗？你们俩选哪一个？”理查德·康登和珍妮特·罗奇

在《普里兹家族的荣耀》中引用了查理·帕坦娜的一段话

“Do I ice her? Do I marry her? Which of dese?”

Charley Partanna in Prizzi’s Honor

by Richard Condon and Janet Roach

研究可能会毁掉你的故事，所以要小心。当心。快逃！另一方面，研究可以拯救你的故事，所以要深入挖掘！

Research can kill your story, so watch out. Beware. Run away! On the other hand, research can save your story, so dig in deep!

这是我关于研究的理论。只做写剧本所需的研究，不要做太多。特别是在前期，在你写草稿之前。找到你的故事，然后做研究。

Here’s my theory on research. Do only as much as you need to write your script, and no more. Especially at the front end, before you have a draft. Find your story, then do the research.

我写的关于西贡沦陷的剧本目前正由一家好莱坞制片厂选择，所以它可能不算烂。当我第一次坐下来时，我对我想讲述的故事只有一个模糊的想法，但我足够聪明，知道研究就像一条盘绕着准备咬人的响尾蛇。

My script about the fall of Saigon is currently under option to a Hollywood studio, so it’s probably not crap. When I first sat down, I had only the vaguest idea of the story I wanted to tell, but I was wise enough to know that research is like a rattlesnake coiled to bite.

在写初稿之前，我读了一本关于西贡沦陷的书。我采访了一位去过那里的中情局人员，并阅读了《纽约时报》一个月来关于西贡沦陷最后一天的文章。就这样。花了几天时间。但我知道的足够多了，可以开始了。我确定了人物和故事。我写了剧本。写完后，人物还行，故事还行，我有很多事实是错的。没什么大不了的。我回到了我在中情局的人、一些越南人和一名空军飞行员那里，读了一些书。因为我有一份完整的草稿，所以我知道我需要哪些帮助。

Before I wrote the first draft, I read one book about the fall of Saigon. I interviewed a CIA guy who had been there, and I read a month of New York Times articles leading up to the last day of the collapse. That was it. It took a few days. But I knew enough to get started. I figured out my characters and story. I wrote my script. When I got done, the characters were okay, the story was okay, and I had lots of facts wrong. No biggie. I went back to my man from the CIA, some Vietnamese people, an Air Force pilot, and I read some more books. Because I had a completed draft, I knew where I needed help.

慢慢地，但很肯定地，我的错误被改正了。剧本完成后，非常准确，以至于当我去开会时，人们以为我参加了越南战争。

Slowly, but surely, my mistakes were corrected. When finished, the script was so accurate that when I’d go into meetings, people thought I’d been in the Vietnam war.

完成第一遍后，我所做的任何研究都是有针对性的、直接的，并且只适用于我的故事。我没有浪费时间在迷失的森林里徘徊。

After I had that first pass, any research I did was pointed, direct, and only applied to my story. I wasted no time wandering in the woods lost.

研究可能会毁掉你的故事。

Research can destroy your story.

面对现实吧，研究往往比写作更有趣。与酷人交谈和阅读引人入胜的书籍总是比坐在电脑前试图弄清楚为什么你的故事和你的生活会付诸东流更有趣。

Face it, research is often more fun than writing. It’s always more interesting to talk to cool people and read fascinating books than it is to sit there in front of your computer trying to figure out why your story and your life are going down the drain.

研究中最危险的部分是“厨房水槽”的泥潭。你发现了一些有趣的东西，然后说：“哦，太棒了！我可以把它放进去！”而就在那一刻，你已经毁掉了你的故事，甚至都不知道。只有当你锁定并融入你的故事和人物后，你才能进行安全而充实的研究，这样你就不会“扔进”那些在你了解到时似乎很吸引人的无关垃圾，但这些垃圾只会削弱你的故事。

The most dangerous part of research is the “kitchen sink” morass. You find out something juicy and you say, “Oh, cool! I can put this in!” And, in that one moment, you have torpedoed your story and don’t even know it. Only when you have your story and characters locked down and tucked in, can you go do research, safe and content that you won’t “throw in” extraneous garbage that seemed fascinating when you learned it, but only weakens your story.

你可能知道太多事实。你的核心故事可能会被埋没在一堆“重要内容”之下，直到永远消失。

You can know too many facts. Your core story can be buried under mounds of “great stuff” until it is lost forever.

我每次上课都会对学生说“小心研究的邪恶”，一天晚上下课后，一位女士眼含泪花地说：“我真希望在我坐下来写作之前听到你这么说，否则我就浪费了三年时间研究，然后就没法讲述我的故事了。”这太可悲了。所以，即使你没有学到任何东西，这本书也物有所值。

I say “beware the evils of research” to every class I teach, and one night after class a woman came up with tears in her eyes, saying, “I wish I’d heard you say this before I wasted three years researching before I sat down to write, and then I couldn’t tell my story.” It was so sad. So, even if you learn nothing else, this book just paid for itself.

 

威廉·M·埃克斯的第二研究定律：充分利用你所拥有的一切！

William M. Akers’ Second Law of Research: What you have, get right!

如果你写的是一些你一无所知的东西，那么很容易找到愿意分享知识的专家来纠正你的写作。无论你做什么，都不要发送有错误的东西，因为你的读者会找出错误并讨厌你。

If you’re writing about something you know nothing about, it is easy to find experts willing to share their knowledge to get your writing correct. Whatever you do, don’t send something out with mistakes, because your reader will ferret them out and loathe you.

在一次作家会议上，我曾听一位作家朗读一篇关于鹌鹑狩猎的短篇小说。他提到，故事中人物的猎枪有瞄准镜。猎枪没有瞄准镜。我立刻意识到他在胡说八道，并驳斥了他的整个故事。不要让这种事情发生在你身上。做对事情。

At a writers conference, I once heard an author read a short story about quail hunting. He mentioned that the character’s shotgun had a telescopic sight. Shotguns don’t have telescopic sights. I knew instantly he was full of bull and dismissed his entire story. Don’t let this happen to you. Get it right.

一件小事。在这本书的后面，我提到了我在洛杉矶农贸市场无意中听到的一句话。我一开始把它写成了“农贸市场”，然后意识到我不确定拼写。我上网找到了它，并改正了错误。

A small thing. A little later in this book, I mention a quote I overheard at the Los Angeles Farmers Market. I first wrote it “Farmer’s Market,” then realized I wasn’t sure of the spelling. I went on line, found it, and corrected the mistake.

淡入：

FADE IN:

系列照片——洛杉矶地标

SERIES OF SHOTS -- L.A. LANDMARKS

洛杉矶天际线。好莱坞标志。电影海报。棕榈树。罗迪欧大道。一切都阳光灿烂、幸福美满。

L.A. skyline. Hollywood sign. Movie posters. Palm trees. Rodeo Drive. Everything and everyone sunny and happy.

上面的场景描述是我的一个学生写的。她从未去过洛杉矶。她对洛杉矶的地标还算了解，但对这座城市却一无所知。我给她加了一点颜色。

The above scene description was written by one of my students. She’s never been to Los Angeles. Her L.A. landmarks are okay, but show no knowledge of the city. I gave her a smidgen of color.

淡入：

FADE IN:

系列照片——洛杉矶地标

SERIES OF SHOTS -- L.A. LANDMARKS

洛杉矶天际线。Angelyne 广告牌。棕榈树。罗迪欧大道。一切都阳光灿烂、幸福快乐。

L.A. skyline. Angelyne billboard. Palm trees. Rodeo Drive. Everything and everyone sunny and happy.

如果你在洛杉矶待过一段时间，你就会知道 Angelyne 是谁。她为场景描述增添了一点活力。读者会说，“嘿，这位作家很懂行。”

If you’ve done time in L.A., you know who Angelyne is. She gives the scene description a little pizzazz. The reader will say, “Hey, this writer knows her stuff.”

然而，明显的研究会让你看起来像个小丑。就像你的衬裙露出来一样。不要只因为你知道某样东西就把它放进去，尤其是如果它是炫耀的话。在我最后一次重写西贡剧本的时候，我已经知道了很多关于西贡沦陷、直升机的种类、警察穿的狩猎夹克和无数其他东西的信息。我发现自己在看剧本时删除了一些对讲述故事没有帮助的很酷的研究。仅仅因为我发现大使的狗叫 Nitnoy，并不意味着我必须让大使用名字来称呼他的贵宾犬！

However, obvious research makes you look like a clown. The same as if your petticoat shows. Don’t put something in just because you know it, especially if it’s show-offy. By the last rewrite of my Saigon screenplay, I knew so much stuff about the fall of Saigon and the kinds of helicopters and the safari jackets the cops wore and a zillion other things. I found myself going through the script and taking out cool research that didn’t help tell the story. Just because I found out the Ambassador’s dog was named Nitnoy, didn’t mean I had to have the Ambassador call his poodle by name!

 

威廉·M·埃克斯的研究第一定律——矛盾：正确的研究可以让你获得奥斯卡奖提名。

William M. Akers’ First Law of Research — Contradiction: The right research can get you an Academy Award nomination.

《死囚之舞》的联合编剧威尔·罗科斯 (Will Rokos)也来上我的课，他是个可爱的家伙。他曾想写一个关于死囚的剧本。通过研究，他了解到狱警的工作通常是家族式的。如果你看过这部电影（你应该看，因为它真的很好，而且第一幕的结局让人惊叹），你就会意识到，如果没有他在研究中发现的关键信息，他就不可能写出这样的剧本。

Will Rokos, co-writer of Monster’s Ball, and a lovely guy, came to my class. He had had a screenplay idea about a guy who worked on death row. From his research, he learned prison guard jobs often run in families. If you’ve seen the film (and you should, because it’s really good and has a “wow” first act ending), you’ll realize that, without that key piece of information found during his research, he’d never have written the script he did.

 

关于讲故事就说到这里。让我们继续讨论第二幕，以及没人谈论的写作部分。

Enough about storytelling. Let’s move on to Act II and the part of writing no one talks about.

斯蒂芬·金曾与谭恩美有过一次对话。在作家演讲后的问答环节，那些想要成为作家的人总会问：“你的想法是从哪里来的”、“我怎样才能找到经纪人”、“你能看看我的作品，然后告诉我你认为我是否应该辞职吗？”金先生问了谭恩美一个她从未被问过的问题。她说：“从来没有人问过语言问题。”

Stephen King once had a conversation with Amy Tan. At Q&As after writer’s talks, wannabe authors always ask “Where do you get your ideas,” and “How can I get an agent,” and “Would you take a look at my work and tell me if you think I should quit?” Mr. King asked Ms. Tan what question she is never asked. She said, “No one ever asks about the language.”

写作才是作家真正热爱的事情，但没人提到这一点。当然，没人教过我如何把文字写到纸上。

It’s what writers really love — the writing — and no one mentions it. For sure, no one ever taught me anything about how to put words on a page.

淡出。

FADE OUT.

 

第二幕：

ACT II:

 

物理写作

Physical Writing

仅仅因为你写了它，

并不意味着你必须保留它。

Just because you wrote it,

doesn’t mean you have to keep it.

 

 

 

 

西西莉

CECELIE

你无法写出一个字，因为那个字必须非常完美。但你不知道那个非常完美的字是什么，因为你还没有把你的心血倾注到纸上，也没有从中筛选出那些精彩的片段。

You can’t write one word because that word has to be oh so perfect. But you have no idea what the oh so perfect word is, because you haven’t barfed your heart out onto the page and sorted through to find the chunks of brilliance.

梅丽莎·斯克里夫纳 (Melissa Scrivner) 谈及写作瓶颈

Melissa Scrivner, on writer’s block

“一本书的所有需求中，最重要的

就是它的可读性。”

安东尼·特罗洛普

“Of the needs a book has, the chief need

is that it be readable.”

Anthony Trollope

“我省去了人们会跳过的部分。”

埃尔莫·伦纳德 (Elmore Leonard)

“I leave out the parts that people skip.”

Elmore Leonard

“富有想象力的作品应该用

非常通俗易懂的语言来写；想象力越纯粹，

就越需要通俗易懂。”

塞缪尔·泰勒·柯尔律治

“Works of imagination should be written in

very plain language; the more purely imaginative

they are the more necessary it is to be plain.”

Samuel Taylor Coleridge

“只有擦除的手才能写出真实的东西。”

迈斯特·艾克哈特

“Only the hand that erases can write the true thing.”

Meister Eckhart

 

 

淡入：

FADE IN:

“写出初稿的最后一页是写作中最愉快的时刻。这是人生中最愉快的时刻之一。”

尼古拉斯·斯帕克斯

“Writing the last page of the first draft is the most enjoyable moment in writing. It’s one of the most enjoyable moments in life, period.”

Nicholas Sparks

 

“所有东西的初稿都是垃圾。”

欧内斯特·海明威

“The first draft of everything is shit.”

Ernest Hemingway

当你完成初稿时，恭喜你，你已经完成了十分之一！真正的写作，也就是重写，现在就开始了。

When you get to the bottom of your first draft, congratulations, you’re about 1/10th of the way done! The real writing, which is rewriting, will now commence.

海明威一如既往地迷人，他说得完全正确。每个人的初稿都是烂透了。即使是他的。你的也一样！你必须反复重写，直到写对为止。然后你就停下来。好消息是，你可以修复几乎任何东西。只需要付出努力和时间。

Hemingway, charming as ever, was totally correct. Everybody’s first draft is shit. Even his. Yours too! You have to rewrite and rewrite and rewrite until you get it right. Then you stop. The good news is, you can fix just about anything. It only takes elbow grease and time.

你必须有一个精彩的故事，这是真的。但你也必须把它传达给别人——在纸上。如果他们无法从你的纸上理解它，你的故事就毫无价值。纸上的文字必须向读者解释你脑海中的电影。这比你想象的要复杂得多。

You have to have a great story, true. But you must also communicate it to someone else — on paper. If they can’t get it off your page, your story is worthless. The words on the page must explain to the reader the movie in your head. It’s way more complex than you might think.

 

“他们只读对话。”

洛杉矶农贸市场传来消息

“All they read is the dialogue.”

Overheard at the Farmers Market, Los Angeles

不对。相信这个后果自负。如果说这话的人是个在职作家，他会在环球影城的办公室里，而不是在下午在农贸市场喝咖啡。

Untrue. Believe this at your peril. If the guy who said that were a working writer, he’d be in an office on the Universal lot instead of sucking down coffee at the Farmers Market in the middle of the afternoon.

好的写作很重要。虽然不是对每个人都很重要，但对足够多的读者、制片人、演员和导演来说，这值得你花时间去关注。欣赏好写作的读者会注意到你的场景描述。如果写得马虎，他们就会走向门口。读完第一页，他们不知道你是否知道什么是反转，但他们肯定会知道你是否能写出一个像样的句子。

Good writing matters. Not to everyone, but to enough readers, producers, actors, and directors to make it worth your while to pay attention. Readers who appreciate good writing will notice your scene description. If it’s sloppy, they’re going to head toward the door. By the end of the first page, they can’t tell if you know what a reversal is, but they will certainly know if you can write a decent sentence.

实体写作。没人谈论过这个东西。

Physical writing. Nobody ever talks about this stuff.

嗯，斯蒂芬·金是的。

Well, Stephen King does.

这是我花了很多时间与学生一起研究的。我费尽心思自己想出来的很多东西都收录在金的《论写作》一书中。我希望在我开始写作时这本书就已经存在了。

This is something I spend a lot of time on with my students. Much of what I laboriously figured out on my own is included in King’s superb book, On Writing. I wish it had existed when I started.

欢迎

来到写作

Welcome

to Writing

 

48. 你没有接受过有关你选择的讲故事媒介的教育！

48. You aren’t educated in your chosen storytelling medium!

 

如果你不读过很多很多剧本，你怎么能搞清楚这种最奇怪的写作形式呢？你疯了吗？

How are you going to figure out this most bizarre of writing forms if you’re not reading lots and lots and lots of screenplays? Are you nuts?

你去看电影吗？

Do you go to movies?

你们租电影吗？

Do you rent movies?

你读过剧本吗？你读过吗？

Do you read screenplays? Do you read?

噢，来吧！

Aw, come on!

你肯定上过写作课。或者更花哨一点：创意写作。从三年级开始，你就知道如何写短篇故事。或者写小说、商业信函或令人眼花缭乱的电子邮件。但是，如果你买了这本书，你并不是一个大牌编剧，你最好一直在阅读各种剧本。

You have no doubt taken writing classes. Or more fancypants: Creative Writing. You know, by now, having done it since the third grade, how to write a short story. Or a novel, or a business letter, or a dazzlingly wicked Email. But, if you’ve bought this book, you are not a big time screenwriter, and you had better be reading all kinds of screenplays, all the time.

成功的作家若不经常阅读，就无法取得如今的成就。如果你将一半的写作时间用于阅读，另一半用于写作，那么你的进步速度就会比只专注于自己作品的作家更快。

No successful writer got where they are without reading all the time. If you spend half your writing time reading and half writing, you’re moving forward faster than the writer who only works on her own stuff.

你会学到更多。你会摆脱困境。你会看到其他人在面对同样的问题时做了什么。

You learn more. You get out of your head. You see what other people have done when faced with the same problems.

当我开始写作时，我能找到的唯一一本看起来像剧本的书是普雷斯顿的《五部剧本》

When I started to write, the only book I could find with pages that looked like screenplay pages was Five Screenplays by Preston

斯特吉斯。它仍然在我的书架上，触手可及。它们是在 1950 年之前写的，但这并没有影响格式。它仍然是一样的。

Sturges. It’s still on my bookshelf, right in arm’s reach. The fact that they were written before 1950 didn’t affect the format. It’s still the same.

我打开神奇的www.script-o-rama.com。去那里尽情享受吧！每天读一个剧本。假装你是一个开发人员。每天读三个剧本！假装你是约翰尼·德普。只读附有报价的剧本。

I invoke the amazing www.script-o-rama.com. Go there and rejoice! Read a script every day. Pretend you’re a development person. Read three scripts a day! Pretend you’re Johnny Depp. Only read scripts with offers attached.

但要读剧本。书店和图书馆都有。我非常喜欢图书馆，因为它们是免费的。而且，如果它们是免费的，你会读更多的剧本。你读得越多，你就会成为更好的作家。

But read scripts. Bookstores and libraries have them. I’m a big fan of libraries because they are free. And, if they’re free, you’ll read more screenplays. The more you read, the better a writer you will be.

阅读，阅读，阅读。

Read, read, read.

但是，如果你只读剧本，你的剧本很有可能会很糟糕！千万别说：“老兄，我是个编剧。我对写小说不感兴趣。”

However, there’s a good chance your screenplay will suck — if all you read is screenplays! Don’t you dare say, “I’m a screenwriter, dude. I’m not interested in writing a novel.”

全部读完。读你能拿到的所有东西。剧本。戏剧。博客。新闻。短篇小说。连环画。漫画书。小说。非小说。回忆录。麦片盒背面。那些不是用英语写作的人写的书。《花花公子》上的文章，哈哈哈。死去男人写的书。死去女人写的书。任何好东西。任何东西。它会给你带来难以置信的帮助。

Read it all. Read EVERYTHING you can get your hands on. Scripts. Plays. Blogs. Journalism. Short stories. Comic strips. Comic books. Fiction. Non fiction. Memoirs. Backs of cereal boxes. Books by guys who didn’t write in English. The articles in Playboy, ha ha ha. Books by dead men. Books by dead women. Anything that’s good. Anything. It will help you like you won’t believe.

如果你读过托马斯·麦瓜恩的作品，那会帮助你了解自己的写作风格……即使你写的不是蒙大拿州的牧场主。狄更斯可以教你很多关于喜剧的东西。莎士比亚的作品也很棒。

If you read Thomas McGuane, it will help you understand something about your own writing… even if you’re not writing about a rancher in Montana. Dickens can teach you a ton about comedy. Shakespeare’s good.

以下作家也同样值得关注：苏珊·金斯伯里、特里·凯、大卫·麦卡洛、纳丁·戈迪默、乔伊斯·卡罗尔·奥茨、詹姆斯·琼斯、乔治·V·希金斯、布鲁斯·费勒、欧内斯特·海明威、欧文·肖、扎迪·史密斯、卡米尔·帕格里亚、居伊·德·莫泊桑、简·奥斯汀、安东·契诃夫、埃德加·爱伦·坡、托拜厄斯·沃尔夫、安妮·泰勒、李·史密斯、罗尔德·达尔、杰克·伦敦、A·S·拜厄特、杰西·希尔·福特、卡尔文·特里林、唐纳德·巴泰勒米、吉姆·汤普森、弗兰纳里·奥康纳、埃尔莫·伦纳德、伊莎贝尔·阿连德、卡尔·海森、派翠西亚·海史密斯、牙买加·金凯德、杰伊·麦克伊纳尼、理查德·福特、杰弗里·伦特、蒂姆·高特罗等等……

So are these writers: Suzanne Kingsbury, Terry Kay, David McCullough, Nadine Gordimer, Joyce Carol Oates, James Jones, George V. Higgins, Bruce Feiler, Ernest Hemingway, Irwin Shaw, Zadie Smith, Camille Paglia, Guy de Maupassant, Jane Austen, Anton Chekov, Edgar Allan Poe, Tobias Wolff, Anne Tyler, Lee Smith, Roald Dahl, Jack London, A.S. Byatt, Jesse Hill Ford, Calvin Trillin, Donald Bartheleme, Jim Thompson, Flannery O’Connor, Elmore Leonard, Isabel Allende, Carl Hiaasen, Patricia Highsmith, Jamaica Kinkaid, Jay McInerney, Richard Ford, Jeffrey Lent, Tim Gautreaux, and on and on…

让你的朋友告诉你他们读过的最棒的作家的名字。问问你的父母。问问你父母的朋友！也许有人会推荐理查德·布劳提根。他是我上大学时最喜欢的作家，但我的学生中只有一个听说过他。读读他那本具有里程碑意义的小说《堕胎》。它确实很有感染力。《麦田里的守望者》也是如此。读完这本书，然后一本正经地告诉我，一个作家必须听起来像其他作家一样。

Ask your friends to tell you names of the best writers they’ve ever read. Ask your parents. Ask your parents’ friends! Perhaps one will suggest Richard Brautigan. He was my favorite writer when I was in college and only one of my students has ever heard of him. Read his watershed novel, The Abortion. It sure has a voice. So does The Catcher In The Rye. Read that and tell me with a straight face that a writer has to sound like every other writer.

你的剧本很烂，因为你没有读过你出生前写的剧本。如果你不能用谈论查理·考夫曼时那种气喘吁吁的语气谈论普雷斯顿·斯特吉斯、萨姆森·拉斐尔森和乔·曼凯维奇，那你还有许多要学的。

Your screenplay sucks because you don’t read scripts written before you were born. If you can’t talk about Preston Sturges, Samson Raphaelson and Joe Mankiewicz in the same breathless tone you ooh and ahh about Charlie Kaufman, you still have some learning to do.

最后，因为你不看电影，所以你的剧本很烂！

And finally, your screenplay sucks because you don’t watch movies!

每次上课，我都会问学生那周看了哪些电影。有时答案是零。每周我都会在电影院看至少一部电影，在 DVD 上看三部或更多。一年下来，这可是很不少的电影了。而且我已经知道如何写剧本了！你一年看了多少部电影？

Every class, I ask my students what movies they’ve seen that week. Sometimes the answer is zero. Every single week I see at least one movie in a theater and watch three or more on DVD. In a year, that’s a lot of movies. And I already know how to write a screenplay! How many movies do you see in a year?

你知道 Netflix ( www.netflix.com ) 吗？他们会邮寄 DVD 给你。据最新统计，他们有大约 85,000 个节目。

Do you know about Netflix (www.netflix.com)? They mail DVDs to you. At last count, they had around 85,000 titles.

不管你如何做，都要学会这种奇妙的讲故事方式。从长远来看，你会得到回报的。

However you do it, educate yourself in this wonderful storytelling medium. It will pay off in the long run.

49. 你使用了错误的书写工具！

49. You’re using the wrong writing instrument!

 

让我们从基础开始：纸、铅笔、钢笔、电脑、打字机、不同品牌的钢笔。

Let’s start with basics: paper, pencil, pen, computer, typewriter, different brand of pen.

如何在纸上书写文字会影响你的写作。你喜欢有线条的纸张吗？如果你从铅笔转到电脑，你的风格就会改变。海明威除了对话外都是手写的，对话是用打字机写的。

How you get the words on the page will affect your writing. Do you like paper with lines? Your style will change if you move from pencil to computer. Hemingway wrote longhand, except for dialogue, which he did on a typewriter.

这也适用于你写作的地方。你的床（伍迪·艾伦用手写的地方）、办公室、汽车的前排乘客座位、游乐场的野餐桌、厨房、咖啡店，或者任何地方。

This also applies to where you write. Your bed (where Woody Allen writes, in longhand), an office, the front passenger seat of your car, a picnic table at a playground, your kitchen, a coffee shop, or wherever.

书写工具和地点的每种组合都会影响您的写作。您必须找到最有效的组合。

Each combination of writing instrument and locale will affect your writing. You have to find the cocktail that works.

如果你很难表达自己的想法，那就改变你在纸上写下文字的方式。有些人先口述，然后再打字。当我必须做一些重要的事情时，我会用铅笔写。当我用铅笔时，我的大脑与纸张的连接更直接。铅笔的好处是它比电脑慢，而且我倾向于尽可能多地省略单词——这很好地缩短了写作时间。

If you’re having trouble getting your thoughts out, change the method by which you put words on the page. Some people dictate and then type it later. When I have to do something crucial, I write in pencil. My brain connects to the page more directly when I use a pencil. The great thing about a pencil is that it’s slower than a computer, and I have a tendency to leave out as many words as possible — which tightens up the writing nicely.

无论如何，只要你能把它写在纸上：编剧兼导演《Playing By Heart》的威拉德·卡罗尔告诉我的班上，他是一个非常没有纪律的作家。他花了几个月的时间散步，思考他的角色和他们的故事。一旦他在脑子里想好了，他就写了剧本——只用了八天时间。

Any way you can get it on the page: Willard Carroll, who wrote and directed Playing By Heart, told my class he is a very undisciplined writer. He spent months taking walks, thinking about his characters and their stories. Once he’d finished working it out in his head, then he wrote his script — in eight days.

您认为这个演员阵容的制作预算是多少？

What do you think the production budget was for this cast?

娜斯塔西娅·金斯基、丹尼斯·奎德、帕特丽夏·克拉克森、吉娜·罗兰兹、肖恩·康纳利、吉莲·安德森、玛德琳·斯托、安东尼·爱德华兹、艾伦·伯斯汀、杰·摩尔、乔恩·斯图尔特、瑞恩·菲利普、阿曼达·皮特和安吉丽娜·朱莉！！

Nastassja Kinski, Dennis Quaid, Patricia Clarkson, Gena Rowlands, Sean Connery, Gillian Anderson, Madeleine Stowe, Anthony Edwards, Ellen Burstyn, Jay Mohr, Jon Stewart, Ryan Phillippe, Amanda Peet, and Angelina Jolie!!

他找到了那个演员阵容，花了 500 万美元拍了这部电影。因为他写了演员诱饵。

He got THAT cast and made the movie for five million dollars. Because he writes actor bait.

创作了传奇电视剧《印第安纳州的恐怖》的卡尔·谢弗 (Karl Schaefer ) 在电脑上撰写了他的第一稿，然后在硬拷贝上进行修改，然后将整个草稿重新输入到电脑。重新输入整个脚本非常麻烦，以至于他立即省略了不需要输入的内容。同样，写作更加紧凑，自动完成。

Karl Schaefer, who created the legendary television series, Eerie, Indiana, writes his first draft on a computer, then makes corrections on a hard copy, and then retypes the entire draft into the computer. Retyping the whole script is such a pain that he instantly leaves out anything he doesn’t have to type. Again, tighter writing, automatically.

请记住，读者并不想阅读你的脚本，因此删除不必要的内容是个好主意。因此，即使你拥有一台电脑，也并不意味着你必须使用它！

Keeping in mind that the reader doesn’t want to read your script, leaving out unnecessary crud is a superb idea. So, just because you own a computer, doesn’t mean you have to use it!

50. 你的散文不够清晰！

50. Your prose is not CRYSTAL CLEAR!

 

确保您的读者了解您希望他们做什么。

Make sure your reader understand what you hope they do.

遗憾的是，从你头脑中的图像到读者大脑的路径并不是一条硬连线的主电路。每句话的含义并不是从你裹着锡纸的头脑传到读者的大脑的。

The path from the image in your head to the reader’s brain is, sadly, not a hard-wired main circuit line. The meaning of each sentence isn’t beamed from your tinfoil-wrapped head to the reader’s.

 

你所写的内容从你的头脑，通过你的手指，到纸上，然后才到达读者的大脑。在这段危险的旅程中，有巨大的空间可以让人感到困惑（此时播放着恐怖的音乐！） 。

What you write goes from your mind, through your fingers, to the page, and only then up to the reader’s tiny pea-brain. Along that treacherous journey, there’s enormous room for (scary music here!) confusion.

当你写一个句子时，你是在要求某人进入你混乱的小脑袋里，而他们从纸上得到的东西可能不是你想象的那样。可悲的是，不公平的是，但事实上，如果你的写作被误解了，那不是读者的错。领带不会落到跑步者的头上。

When you write a sentence, you are asking someone to take a trip inside your scrambled little head, and what they get from the page may not be what you imagine to be on the page. Woefully, unfairly, but truthfully, if your writing is misunderstood, it’s not the reader’s fault. Tie does not go to the runner.

一旦你有了草稿，你就有责任剔除任何潜在的“传达错误”。你必须不断问自己：“我在这里所想的意思，实际上是他们读到它时会理解的意思吗？”这是一个很难的问题。

Once you’ve got a draft, it is incumbent on you to weed through any potential “errors in transmission.” You must continually ask, “Is what I think I mean here, actually what they are going to understand when they read it?” Difficult question.

当我还是个小剃须刀手时，我上了我的第一堂电影制作课，拍了一部浪漫的电影，背景设在意大利（如果你相信的话），我用了西纳特拉的《夜色中的陌生人》作为配乐。在我一生的配乐中，它是最重要的歌曲之一。它很有力量。它能让我心软。我把它放在我的 8 毫米自传电影的配乐中。当我为全班播放它时，当那个场景出现时，我哽咽了。你猜怎么着？

When I was a little shaver in my first filmmaking class, I made a romantic film, set in Italy (if you can believe it) and I used Sinatra’s “Strangers In The Night” on the soundtrack. On the soundtrack of my life, it was one of the most important songs, ever. It was powerful. It could reduce me to jelly. I put it in the soundtrack of my 8mm autobiographical film. When I played it for the class, when that scene came on, I was all choked up. And guess what?

全班同学都笑了。

The class laughed.

对于 Yours Truly 来说，这是一次令人心碎的凄凉时刻，但也是电影制作中一次难忘的教训。屏幕上的图像与 Sinatra 的歌曲并列，对观众来说意义完全不同！我坐在那里，满眼泪水，怀念着我认识的某个女孩，而他们则对我愚蠢的音乐选择大喊大叫。

It was a slit-your-wrists bleak moment for Yours Truly, but a hell of a lesson in filmmaking. The on screen image juxtaposed with the Sinatra song did not remotely mean the same thing to the audience as it did to me! I was sitting there, all teary-eyed with nostalgia for some girl I’d known, and they were howling at my idiotic choice of music.

请从我过去灾难性的筛选和痛苦经历中吸取教训。确保您认为读者会感受到的正是他们真正会感受到的。

Take a caution from my disastrous screening and agonizing pain of bygone years. Be sure that what you think the reader is going to feel, is what he is really going to feel.

从宏观上看，对于你的整个故事来说都是如此；从微观上看，对于每个时刻来说，也是如此。

This is true in the macro, for your whole story, and in the micro, for each moment.

例如，不要让角色抱起他们最好的朋友并称之为“尸体”，除非这个朋友已经死了，因为这就是我们会想到的。

For instance, don’t have a character pick up their best friend and have you call it a “body” unless the friend is dead, because that’s what we’re going to think.

 

 

鲍勃捡起尸体。

Bob picks up the body.

还有这个例子：暴徒们是在侧翼进攻艾尔牧师还是进攻入口？

And this example: are the goons flanking Pastor Al or the entrance?

 

 

外景，酒厂大门，夜晚

EXT. WINERY GATES - NIGHT

 

 

艾尔牧师从他的豪华轿车里走出来，在他的暴徒的护送下走向入口。

Pastor Al climbs out of his limo and approaches the entrance flanked by his goons.

在这里，我们感觉到 Tindel 警官已经服刑过度。您的读者可能没有意识到您只是想让 Tindel 睡觉。

Here, we get the impression that Officer Tindel has been over-served. Your reader may not realize you only meant for Tindel to be sleeping.

 

 

外景，酒厂大门，夜晚

EXT. WINERY GATES - NIGHT

 

 

富兰克林从警车里挤出来，从酒瓶里喝了一口，然后用胖乎乎的手掌擦了擦嘴，向派对走去。

Franklin squeezes out of the police cruiser and takes a pull from his flask before wiping his mouth with a chubby paw and heading for the party.

 

 

巡洋舰内部，廷德尔昏倒了。

Inside the cruiser Tindel is passed out.

以下是我写的一些蹩脚的文字，或者至少是有点模糊的文字：

Here’s some crummy writing, or at least a tad vague, from, er, me:

 

 

外部停车场日

EXT. PARKING LOT      DAY

 

 

Loose Wrap 发现 Nervous Man 正准备登上直升机。

Loose Wrap spots the Nervous Man about to board a chopper.

宽松包装

LOOSE WRAP

是他嗎？

That him?

女朋友

GIRLFRIEND

这是我的行李箱。我想要把它找回来。

It’s my suitcase. I want it back.

宽松包装

LOOSE WRAP

和你哥哥一起等待。

Wait with your brother.

 

 

他冲过去，夺走了手提箱。

He sprints over, wrests the suitcase away.

宽松包装

LOOSE WRAP

你输了，混蛋。

You lose, motherfucker.

 

 

愤怒的男人从敞开的门外怒视着 Loose Wrap。 Chinook 直升机起飞。

The angry man glares at Loose Wrap from the open door. The Chinook LIFTS OFF.

这很挑剔，但很重要。在第一段场景描述中，紧张的人“即将登上”直升机。这意味着他还没有上。他可能在排队，离直升机还有五个人。下次我们听到他的时候，他正从敞开的门口怒视着 Loose Wrap，直升机飞走了。我们脑海中的画面很模糊。那个人是站在门边还是在直升机里？有点混乱。请原谅我用了一个脏话。

This is picky, but it matters. In the first piece of scene description, the Nervous Man is “about to board” the chopper. That means he’s not on it yet. He could be in line, five people away from the chopper. Next time we hear about him, he’s glaring at Loose Wrap from the open door, and the helicopter flies away. The picture in our mind is murky. Was the guy standing near the door or was he in the helicopter? A tad confusing. And, please, pardon my use of a dirty word.

这是改写的版本。“即将登机”变成了“登机”。

Here’s the rewritten version. “About to board” has become “boarding.”

 

 

外部停车场日

EXT. PARKING LOT DAY

 

 

Loose Wrap 发现 Nervous Man 登上了直升机。

Loose Wrap spots the Nervous Man boarding a chopper.

宽松包装

LOOSE WRAP

是他嗎？

That him?

女朋友

GIRLFRIEND

这是我的行李箱。我想要把它找回来。

It’s my suitcase. I want it back.

宽松包装

LOOSE WRAP

和你哥哥一起等待。

Wait with your brother.

 

 

他冲过去，夺走了手提箱。

He sprints over, wrests the suitcase away.

宽松包装

LOOSE WRAP

你输了，混蛋。

You lose, motherfucker.

 

 

愤怒的男人从敞开的门里怒视着 Loose Wrap。CH-53 升空。

The angry man glares at Loose Wrap from the open door. The CH-53 LIFTS OFF.

通过这一细微的改变，我们更好地了解了角色的地理位置。我们创造了这样一个形象：紧张的人不是在等着别人告诉他去哪里，而是真正踏上了直升机。所以，当直升机飞走时，我们知道紧张的人在里面。

With that slight change, we get a better picture of the characters’ geography. We create the image that the Nervous Man is not waiting around to be told where to go, but is actually stepping onto the helicopter. So, when the chopper flies away, we know the Nervous Man is in it.

经过更多研究后，我还将其从“Chinook”更改为 CH-53。

After more research, I also changed it from “Chinook” to CH-53.

要清楚。看在上帝的份上，记住那个可怜的读者，在那些睡莲上跑来跑去，试图在她脑海里形成一个形象，试图弄清楚你到底想让她明白发生了什么。如果她不明白，那是你的错。

Be clear. For God’s sake remember the poor reader, running across those lily pads, trying to make an image in her mind, trying to figure out what the heck it is you want her to understand is going on. If she doesn’t get it, it’s your fault.

要清楚。不要写“弗兰克穿着好看的衣服”，因为我们可能会认为他正在穿衣服。相反，要写“弗兰克穿着好看的衣服”，这样我们就知道他是个时尚达人。确保我们明白你正在向我们的大脑传达的画面。

Be clear. Don’t write, “Frank dresses in nice-looking clothes,” because we might think he’s getting dressed. Instead, write “Frank wears nice-looking clothes,” so we understand that he’s a fashion plate. Make sure we understand the picture you’re beaming into our brain.

以下是场景描述，最终版本：

Here is scene description, the final version:

 

 

他拿出手机拨号。电话响了，但没有人接听。他又拨了另一个号码。

He takes out his phone and dials. It RINGS without picking up. He calls a different number.

很明显，这个人接连给不同的人打了两个电话。现在，来看看原话。记住：混乱=撕扯头发和咬牙切齿。

Obvious that the guy makes two phone calls, one after the other, to different people. Now, the original. Remember: Confusing = Tearing of hair and gnashing of teeth.

 

 

他拿出手机拨号。电话铃响了，但没有人接听。他再次拨打。

He takes out his phone and dials. It RINGS without picking up. He calls again.

我们以为他打了同一个号码两次。但事实并非如此，我们感到很困惑。

We think he calls the same number twice. Because he doesn’t, we’re confused.

要清楚。立即检查场景描述的每一部分！毕竟，这是一份清单。检查一些内容！

Be clear. Check every chunk of your scene description RIGHT NOW! This is a checklist, after all. Check some stuff off!

看看这个。哎呀，我是个挑剔的人！现在我对一个棉花采摘词很恼火！小石头掉进池塘时不会做什么？

Look at this one. Yipes, I am one picky dude! Now I’m irritated about one cotton picking word! What do small rocks NOT do when they hit a pond?

 

 

外景池塘之夜

EXT. POND NIGHT

 

 

卡拉和特拉维斯在宁静的湖边，在星空下依偎在一起。锯草在风中沙沙作响。特拉维斯的手臂环抱着卡拉，她把小石头和小木棍扔进池塘，打破了夜晚的寂静。

Kara and Travis cuddle under the stars next to a quiet lake. The saw grass rustles in the wind. Travis’s arms are wrapped around Kara as she tosses small rocks and sticks into the pond, shattering the night silence.

它们不会“打破”夜晚的寂静！一辆从高速公路桥上翻滚而下的拖车，撞倒在特拉维斯的池塘里，会“打破夜晚的寂静”，但看在上帝的份上，这不是一块“小石头”。砰！从睡莲上掉下来！

They don’t “shatter” the night silence! A tractor trailer truck that end-over-ends from the freeway bridge, crashing down in Travis’s pond, will “shatter the night silence,” but for Pete’s sake, not a “small rock.” Boink! Off the lily pads!

皮特被救护车撞了多少次？

How many times does Petey get hit by the ambulance?

 

 

当马克在人行道上停下时，时间变慢了。

TIME SLOWS DOWN as Mark stops on the sidewalk.

 

 

露西和特雷在塔霍湖内观看。

Lucy and Trey watch from inside the Tahoe.

 

 

皮特跑到街上。被救护车撞倒了。

Petey runs into the street. Is hit by the ambulance.

 

 

太浩湖国际

INT. TAHOE

 

 

孩子们把脸贴在窗户上。

The kids press their faces against the windows.

露西

LUCY

哦不！皮蒂！

OH NO! PETEY!

特雷

TREY

妈的。

Oh shit.

 

 

内部救护车

INT. AMBULANCE

 

 

听到“砰”的一声，救护车停了下来。司机从救护车里爬出来

A THUD is heard and the ambulance stops. The DRIVER scrambles out of the ambulance

丹妮丝

DENISE

那到底是什么？

What the hell was that?

紧急医疗救护

EMT

妈的。

Oh shit.

 

 

皮蒂的妈妈咳嗽得更厉害了。

Petey’s mom begins to cough even harder.

 

 

 

 

外部街道

EXT. STREET

 

 

皮特跑到街上。警笛一响，救护车就向前猛冲。车头撞到皮特，皮特失去平衡，头撞到人行道上，救护车随即停了下来。

Petey runs into the street. The ambulance lurches forward as the siren begins to sound. It immediately stops as the front bumps Petey, knocking him off balance and his head hits the pavement.

本文作者让 Petey 被击中三次，但他只想让他被击中一次。

This writer has Petey get hit three different times, when he only meant for him to be hit once.

这段对话看起来没什么问题，但如果你多读几遍的话：

This dialogue seems fine until you read it a couple of times:

预言家

他受到幽灵的保护。

SOOTHSAYER

He has protection from a spirit.

这是否意味着鬼魂保护他免受那些试图杀死他的人的伤害，或者这是否意味着他有一个护身符，可以保护他免受试图伤害他的鬼魂的伤害？一句话。完全相反的可能含义。

Does this mean the spirit protects him from those trying to kill him, or does it mean he has an amulet that gives him protection from a spirit trying to do him harm? One sentence. Totally opposite possible meanings.

副警长：

我听到她从克莱斯勒车里进来。

DEPUTY SHERIFF

I heard her come in the Chrysler.

作者想要表达什么意思？

Which meaning did that writer intend?

格式

Format

 

51. 你不懂剧本格式！

51. You don’t understand screenplay format!

 

这看上去很容易。但不知为何，事实并非如此。

This seems so easy. For some reason, it’s not.

按照好莱坞认可的剧本格式来写。就这样。不要因为你太“有创意”而做不同而有趣的事情。他们会拿起你的剧本并注意到你的格式。如果它看起来和其他人不一样，他们会用它来包鱼。

Write in Hollywood approved screenplay format. Period. Don’t do different and fun things because you’re so “creative.” They will pick up your script and notice your format. If it doesn’t look like everyone else’s, they’ll use it to wrap fish.

如果你购买 Final Draft 编剧软件，那么写起来会容易一些，但你还是会犯错。所以，听好了。大约 95% 的格式问题都在接下来的几页中得到解答。这肯定足以让读者继续阅读下去。

If you buy Final Draft screenwriting software, it will be easier, but you can still make mistakes. So, listen up. About 95% of format questions are answered in the next few pages. Certainly enough to keep the reader reading.

 

 

在 Final Draft 中，使用华纳兄弟风格。

In Final Draft, use Warner Bros. style.

剧本之所以看起来如此，是有原因的。你首先看到的是 slugline，然后是场景描述。除了INT . 和EXT . 之外，slugline 中没有句号。

Screenplays look the way they do for a reason. The first thing you see is a slugline, followed by scene description. Other than INT. and EXT., no periods in a slugline.

 

 

鬼屋之夜

INT. HAUNTED HOUSE      NIGHT

 

 

神秘、咆哮、恐怖、可怕的风穿透了腐烂的深黄色摇摇欲坠的百叶窗，把约翰尼的 LL Bean 亮绿色橡胶套鞋吓得魂不守舍。

The mysterious, howling, terrifying, awful wind tears through the rotten dark yellow rickety shutters and scares Johnny clean out of his L.L. Bean bright green rubber galoshes.

标题行告诉您拍摄时摄制组站在哪里。它位于页面的最左侧（加上三孔打孔纸的一点额外空白），下面是场景描述，因为这是您首先看到的。视觉效果。动作。他们做什么。这就是电影的意义所在。发生了什么。而不是他们说什么。在戏剧中，对话空白位于最左侧，因为戏剧是关于文字的，而不是动作的。电影不是这样。

The slugline tells you where the camera crew is standing when shooting. It’s at the far left of the page (plus a little extra margin for three hole punched paper) with scene description underneath, because it’s what you see first. The visuals. The action. What they do. That’s what movies are about. What happens. Not what they say. In plays, the dialogue margin is at the far left because plays are about words, not action. Not in movies.

不要将 slugline 放在页面底部，除非其中至少有一行场景描述。切勿在任何地方放置 slugline 而只提供描述。

Do not put a slugline at the bottom of a page unless there is at least one line of scene description with it. Never have a slugline anywhere without some description.

几乎从不呼叫摄影角度。如果摄影机移动至关重要，你可以指出来。直升机镜头。快速移动摄影机。

Almost never call camera angles. If the camera movement is critical, you can indicate it. HELICOPTER SHOT. RAPID DOLLY.

这是观点的引文。事物没有观点。只有人。

Here’s a slugline for point of view. Things do not have points of view. Only people.

 

 

艾伦的观点——手枪

ELLEN’S POV - THE PISTOL

发生在两个地方的场景。比如一辆汽车在街上行驶。在门廊上。透过窗户。

Scene that takes place in two places. Like a car riding down a street. On a porch. Through a window.

 

 

外部/内部门廊/客厅

EXT./INT. PORCH/LIVING ROOM

仅在 slugline 中，您才单独使用一个连字符。在其他地方，请使用两个连字符。

Only in a slugline, do you use one hyphen alone. Everywhere else, use two.

以下是我表示闪回的方法：

Here’s how I indicate a flashback:

 

 

闪回- 外景：悬崖边

FLASHBACK - EXT. EDGE OF CLIFF DAY

确保标题一致。不要说：

Make sure sluglines are consistent. Don’t say:

吉米的办公室内景

INT. JIMMY’S OFFICE a few times and then

办公大楼内部，最后

INT. OFFICE COMPLEX and finally

 

 

立方体农场

INT. THE CUBE FARM

选择一种并坚持下去。如果你使用 Final Draft 来分解你的剧本，如果 slugline 不一致，它就无法准确地做到这一点。另外，回到我通常的抱怨，它会让你的读者感到困惑。

Pick one and keep with it. If you use Final Draft to break your script down, it can’t do it accurately if the sluglines are not consistent. Also, back to my usual rant, it confuses your reader.

角色每次说话时，其名字都以大写字母显示。角色名字的缩进比对话多。角色名字不在页面上居中。所有角色名字（无论短还是长）的左边距都相同。

A character’s name is in CAPITAL LETTERS every time he or she speaks. The character name is indented more than the dialogue. The character name is not centered on the page. All character names, short or long, have the same left margin.

約翰尼

JOHNNY

是你吗，妈妈？

Is that you mommy?

 

 

他什么也听不见，只有风声。他四处寻找他最喜欢的套鞋。它们已经成为历史了。

He hears nothing but the wind. He looks around for his favorite galoshes. They’re history.

解散为：

DISSOLVE TO:

 

 

 

外景，墓地之夜

EXT. GRAVEYARD      NIGHT

 

 

神秘、咆哮、恐怖、可怕的风在腐烂、破碎、坑坑洼洼的大理石墓碑间呼啸而过。欧内斯特和阿布纳蹲在美丽的拉斐尔前派纪念碑上。

The mysterious, howling, terrifying, awful wind rips between the rotten, crumbling pitted marble headstones. ERNEST and ABNER crouch on lovely pre-Raphaelite monuments.

因为我们是第一次见到 Ernest 和 Abner，所以他们的名字是大写的。在场景描述中，他们的名字再也不会大写。如果你是英国人，出于某种原因，每次在场景描述中出现角色名称时，你都会将其大写。如果你不是英国人，第一次之后就不要这样做了。场景描述中的音效、镜头移动和光学效果也大写。

Because we are meeting Ernest and Abner for the first time, their names are capitalized. They will never be capitalized again in scene description. If you’re English, for some reason, you capitalize the CHARACTER NAME every time it appears in scene description. If you’re not English, don’t do it after the first time. SOUND EFFECTS and CAMERA MOVES and OPTICAL EFFECTS are also in caps in scene description.

 

 

汽车爆炸。电话铃响了。哈利和莎莉大声亲吻。

The car EXPLODES. The phone RINGS. Harry and Sally KISS loudly.

 

 

我们看到了凶手。镜头回到弗兰克身边。揭开桌子上的配方。

We SEE the killer. DOLLY BACK with Frank. REVEAL the formula on the table.

 

 

校舍破旧不堪。叠加标题：五年前。

The schoolhouse is old and rotting. SUPERIMPOSE TITLE: FIVE YEARS AGO.

欧内斯特

ERNEST

我只是喜欢吃来墓地野餐的高中生。

I just love to eat little high school kids that come up to the cemetery on a picnic.

艾伯纳

ABNER

对我来说这听起来像是一种度过夜晚的美妙方式。

Sounds like a swell way to spend an evening to me.

 

 

欧内斯特用奶油派砸向阿布纳的脸。

Ernest hits Abner in the face with a cream pie.

请注意，Ernest 的名字和 Abner 的名字位于对话的最上方。角色名称和对话之间没有空格。

Notice that Ernest’s name and Abner’s name sit right down on top of their dialogue. There is no space between the character name and the dialogue.

如果您的简介由两部分组成，请在一般部分（汽车经销商）和具体部分之间添加连字符。始终在 INT. 和地点之间保留相同数量的空格。始终在地点结尾和 DAY或NIGHT之间保留相同数量的空格。

If you have a two-part slugline, put a hyphen between the general part (the car dealership) and the specific. Always keep the same number of spaces between INT. and the location. Always maintain the same number of spaces between the end of your location and the DAY or NIGHT.

汽车经销商内部 - 展厅日

INT. CAR DEALERSHIP - SHOWROOM DAY

 

 

奶油派还在从阿布纳的鼻子上滴下来，他买了一辆奔驰车。

Cream pie still dripping from his nose, Abner buys a Mercedes.

艾伯纳

ABNER

        （讽刺地）

        (wryly)

我要这个。

I’ll take this one.

 

 

这位油嘴滑舌的推销员舔了舔嘴唇，想着他的假期。

The SMARMY SALESMAN licks his lips, thinks of his vacation.

（讽刺）被称为括号或讽刺语。它给读者或演员一个提示，让他们知道你想让他们如何说这段对话。它位于对话之上，角色名称也位于对话之上。它们之间不能有任何空格。它总是位于对话之前，而不是之后，尽管它可以分隔两段对话。

The (wryly) is called a parenthetical or a wrylie. It gives the reader or actor a hint on how you want them to say the dialogue. It sits on the dialogue, and the character name sits on it. Never any spaces between them. It always goes before the dialogue, never after, though it can separate two bits of dialogue.

油嘴滑舌的推销员

SMARMY SALESMAN

非常好的选择，先生。

An excellent choice, sir.

        （假笑）

        (smirks)

餐巾？

Napkin?

仅当对话的含义可能不清楚时，即仅当读者可能会误解时，才使用括号。

Use parentheticals only when the dialogue’s meaning might be unclear, i.e., only when the reader might misunderstand.

乔

JOE

        （真讨厌她）

        (hates her guts)

亲爱的，我爱你胜过生命。我甚至连一小时都不能忍受离开你。

Darling, I love you more than life itself. I can’t bear to be away from you for even an hour.

一定要用现在时态写作。你描述的是读者眼前发生的事件。它就发生在这一刻！不是这样的：

Always write in present tense. You’re describing events that unfold before the reader’s eyes. It’s happening right this second! Not like this:

 

 

凯特难以置信地看着艾斯曼。他刚刚把自己对这起犯罪的理解讲给凯特和警长听。

Kate stares incredulously at Eisman. He just finished relating his understanding of the crime to Kate and the Chief.

使用三个点来表示言语中的停顿，并在动作将言语分开时连接言语以表示连续的对话。

Use three dots to show pause in speech and to connect speeches when action separates them to indicate continual dialogue.

南

NAN

发生什么事了？这个地方……

What is going on? This place...

艾伯纳

ABNER

我知道我的袜子在这里。

I know my socks were here.

南

NAN

...就像一个三环马戏团。

... is like a three ring circus.

使用两个破折号表示中断。一个角色的讲话结束时，下一个角色的讲话开始。

Use two dashes to indicate interruption. At end of one character’s speech, start of next character’s speech.

艾伯纳

ABNER

你看见过……我的袜子吗？它——

Have you seen... my socks? It’s--

南

NAN

——我看上去像是在乎吗？

--Do I look like I care?

使用 (更多) 继续下一页的对话，然后使用下一页角色名称旁边的(继续)。

Use (MORE) for dialogue continued on next page, then use (CONT’D) on next page beside character name.

芭芭拉

BARBARA

我在这里感觉很棒！生活就是

I’m feeling just great here! Life is just

就像它应该的那样

like it was supposed to be

（更多的）

(MORE)
