_____________________________ 分页符

_____________________________ page break

芭芭拉（继续）

BARBARA (CONT’D)

小艾迪将于周二接受手术。真棒。

and little Eddie is going to have his operation Tuesday. How nifty.

如果“(MORE)”占用的空间与在一页上完成演讲所需的空间相同，请不要使用“(MORE)”。尽可能避免使用“(MORE)”。

Don’t use (MORE) if it takes up the same space as it would to complete the speech on one page. Avoid (MORE) whenever possible.

出于某种原因，对于初学写作的人来说，打电话是一件难事。我经常看到这样的事情：

For some reason, phone calls are a toughie for beginning writers. I see this a lot:

缺口

NICK

（电话里）

(on the phone)

你想要什么？

What do you want?

莎莉

SALLY

（电话里）

(on the phone)

我希望你别再这么爱管闲事了。

I want you to stop being so nosey.

缺口

NICK

（电话里）

(on the phone)

你就是那个翻我垃圾的人！

You’re the one going through my garbage!

莎莉

SALLY

（电话里）

(on the phone)

只因你把我的情书扔掉了！

Only because you threw away my love letters!

要让某人通过电话交谈，请设置第一个人的位置，然后他们就可以与另一个人交谈：

To have someone talk on a phone, set up the first person’s location and then they talk to the other person:

 

 

海滨别墅日

INT. BEACH HOUSE DAY

 

 

莎拉拿起电话。拨号。

Sarah picks up the phone. Dials.

莎拉

SARAH

史密斯先生？是你吗？

Mister Smith? Is that you?

史密斯先生（OS）

MR. SMITH (O.S.)

你到底付不付钱给我？

Are you going to pay me or not?

在第一个位置确定了第一个角色后，转到：

Once you’ve established the first character in the first location, go to:

 

 

外部施工现场日

EXT. CONSTRUCTION SITE DAY

并在该场景描述中说：交叉剪辑电话对话或交叉剪辑场景。之后，只需像他们站在那里互相交谈一样进行对话。

and in that scene description say: INTERCUT TELEPHONE CONVERSATION or INTERCUT SCENES. After that, just run the dialogue as though they were standing there talking to each other.

 

 

外部施工现场日

EXT. CONSTRUCTION SITE DAY

 

 

史密斯先生非常恼火。镜头切换。

Mr. Smith is darn irritated. INTERCUT SCENES.

史密斯先生

MR. SMITH

你欠我钱，姑娘。

You owe me money, girly girl.

莎拉

SARAH

骗子，骗子，裤子着火了！

Liar, liar, pants on fire!

 

 

（VO）是画外音。它要么是旁白，要么是电影另一部分的对话，覆盖在我们正在观看的场景上。

(V.O.) is voice over. It is either a narrator or dialogue from another part of the movie that is laid over the scene we are watching.

 

 

（OS）不在画面中。当我们听到角色说话时，他们在另一个房间或镜头外。

(O.S.) is off screen. A character is in the other room or off camera when we hear them speak.

本笃（OS）

BENEDICT (O.S.)

亲爱的，你看到我的袜子了吗？

Honey, have you seen my socks?

旁白（画外音）

NARRATOR (V.O.)

他注定永远找不到它们。

He was destined never to find them.

永远不要在对话行的末尾用连字符连接单词，除非该单词中间有连字符。

Never hyphenate a word at the end of a line of dialogue unless the word has a hyphen in it anyway.

在场景描述中划出关键词（很少），以便读者能够看到它们。

Underline key words in scene description (rarely) so the reader will be sure to see them.

 

 

奥斯瓦尔德拿起了这支大威力步枪。

Oswald picks up the high powered rifle.

不要使用大写字母。

Don’t do it with CAPS.

 

 

疲惫不堪的加里和艾德审视着重生的球场。他们俩看起来都像是找到了失散已久的挚爱。球道左侧是一堵高高的岩壁。

Worn out, Gary and Ed survey the reborn course. They both look like they’ve found a long lost love. A high ROCK WALL’s left of the fairway.

不要使用斜体。它们太难看见了。

Don’t use italics. They’re too hard to see.

切丽

CHERRIE

我爱的是你。对我来说，不会再有别人。永远。

It’s you that I love. For me there can be no other. Ever.

这些人的阅读速度很快，你需要尽你所能帮助他们。在对话中，在需要强调的单词下划线。而且不要经常这样做。

The speed at which these people read, you need to give them all the help you can. In dialogue, underline words that need emphasis. And don’t do it a lot, either.

切丽

CHERRIE

我爱的是你。对我来说，不会再有别人。永远。

It’s you that I love. For me there can be no other. Ever.

点。三个点之前没有空格。点之后有一个空格。

Dots. No space before three dots. One space after.

达斯

DARTH

卢克……我……是……你的父亲。

Luke... I... am... your father.

为了熟悉格式，你可以将你欣赏的剧本的十页逐字逐句地输入到电脑中。首先，你会真正掌握格式，其次，你会看到剧本一页上实际上只有很少的字。你会对写作产生一种感觉，这种感觉会延续到你自己的作品中。亨特·S·汤普森在学习写作时，一页又一页地打印了 F·斯科特·菲茨杰拉德的作品。这对你来说似乎也是一个好主意。

To familiarize yourself with format, copy ten pages of a screenplay you admire by typing it into your computer — every single word. First, you’ll really nail down the format, and second, you will see how few words actually go on a page of screenplay. You’ll get a feel for writing that will carry over into your own work. Hunter S. Thompson typed up page after page of F. Scott Fitzgerald when he was learning to write. Seems like a swell idea for you, too.

每分钟一页，速度由页面的视觉效果决定。字数越少，读者的视线向下移动的速度就越快。充满场景描述的页面会更加宏伟，或充满长镜头。

At one page per minute, more or less, pace is controlled by the visual look of your page. The fewer words, the faster the reader’s eye moves down the page. A page filled with solid scene description will be more majestic or filled with long takes.

这是《人类之子》的一页。它有很宽的对话空白，我不建议这样做。不过，有很多空白。注意场景描述，一行，一个空格，然后是两行。快，直奔主题，打破对话。你很少看到一页纸上只有对话。最长的对话是四行。大多数对话要少得多。

Here is a page from Children of Men. It has wide dialogue margins, which I counsel against. Lots of white space, though. Notice the scene description, one line, a space and then two lines. Quick, to the point, breaking up the dialogue. Rarely do you see just dialogue on a page. Longest piece of dialogue is four lines. Most is far less.

 

这是《四十岁的老处男》中的一段对话。页边距越窄，阅读速度越快。一段对话有八行，但这是一部对话繁多的剧本。只有一行场景描述。

Th is is solid dialogue from The 40-Year-Old Virgin. Narrower margins speed up the read. One piece of dialogue is eight lines, but it’s a dialogue heavy script. One line of scene description only.

 

还有外星人。

And Alien.

 

对话很短，断断续续，节奏很快。大多数对话只有一行。场景描述简洁。其中一段只有一个词！

That dialogue is short, staccato, and moves quickly. Most dialogue is one-line only. Terse scene description. One paragraph of which is only one word!

返回《人类之子》。本页结合了对话和场景描述。每段描述不超过三行。无括号。最长的对话是四行。

Back to Children of Men. This page combines dialogue and scene description. No paragraph of description is more than three lines. No parentheticals. Longest piece of dialogue is four lines.

 

《四十岁的老处男》对话/动作页面有更多的对话，但场景描述段落仍然很短。不超过两行！

The 40-Year-Old Virgin dialogue / action page has more dialogue, but still the scene description paragraphs are short. No more than two lines!

 

《异形》的页面与前两页完全不同。我用双线标记了 slugline，以便您能看清。场景描述非常简短。只有一段对话有两行长。其余的都是一行。想象一下，那一页读起来有多快！

The Alien page looks totally different from the first two. I marked sluglines with double lines so you can see them. VERY short bursts of scene description. Only one bit of dialogue is two lines long. The rest are one. Imagine how quickly that page will read!

 

现在，这是《人类之子》的一页动作。一些对话将其打断，但并不多。这一页是完整的场景描述，但没有一个段落超过四行。短段落确保读者会在每段话上停下来，吸收简短的信息，然后继续阅读。

Now, a page of action from Children of Men. Some dialogue breaks it up, but not much. The page is solid scene description, but no paragraph is longer than four lines. Short paragraphs insure the reader will pause at each one, take in the brief amount of information, and continue.

 

《四十岁的老处男》中的动作场面看起来与众不同。留白更多。不再强调描述，而是加快速度。完全没有对话。一页上有六条台词、六个场景。他们正在向前推进！

Action in The 40-Year-Old Virgin looks different. More white space. Less emphasis on the description, more speed. No dialogue at all. Six sluglines, six scenes on one page. They are moving on along!

 

用一页《异形》中的动作来结束。七条引文。段落不超过一行。这是一本光速阅读的书。但足以表达要点。

Wrapping up with a page of action from Alien. Seven sluglines. No paragraph longer than one line. This is a speed-of-light read. Still, enough to get the point across.

 

 

 

读者更愿意读哪一页？嗯？

Which page would a reader rather read!? Hmmm?

如果您想了解有关格式的更多信息，请阅读Rick Reichman 的《Formatting Your Screenplay》或Chris Riley 的《The Hollywood Standard 》。

If you want to know more about format, get Formatting Your Screenplay by Rick Reichman or The Hollywood Standard by Chris Riley.

您不必在 Final Draft 中写作。您可以使用 Microsoft Word。Word 提供了很多发展机会。谁需要它？

You don’t have to write in Final Draft. You can use Microsoft Word. Word offers lots of opportunity for growth. Who needs it?

在 Word 中，使用 Courier Regular 字体，而不是 Courier New。

In Word, use Courier Regular font, not Courier New.

Final Draft 知道您何时需要写角色名称，并会帮您对齐对话边距。您可以在 Word 中执行此操作，但这很麻烦。操作方法如下：访问田纳西州编剧​​协会的网站www.tennscreen.com，点击“写作技巧”，然后点击“剧本格式：Word 作为编剧处理器”。它将引导您完成这些步骤。

Final Draft knows when you want to write a character name, and it lines up the dialogue margins for you. You can do that in Word, but it’s a pain. Here’s how: go to www.tennscreen.com, the Tennessee Screenwriting Association’s website, and click on “Writing Tips” and then “Screenplay Formatting: Word as a Screenwriting Processor.” It will take you through the steps.

如果您能买得起 Final Draft，就使用 Final Draft。

If you can afford Final Draft, use Final Draft.

52. 你的 slugline 是裸露的，或者根本没有 slugline！

52. You have naked sluglines or no sluglines at all!

 

Final Draft 称其为场景标题。其他人都称其为 slugline。它告诉工作人员站在哪里。它还告诉你脚在哪里。我把没有场景描述的 slugline 称为“裸 slugline”——你不应该这样做。

Final Draft calls it a Scene Heading. Everybody else calls it a slugline. It tells the crew where to stand. It tells you where your feet are, too. I call a slugline with no scene description with it a “naked slugline” — and you shouldn’t do it.

 

 

外景，北麓之夜

EXT. NORTHERN FOOTHILLS NIGHT

鲍勃

BOB

小心伙计们！这是五十

Look out fellas! It’s the fifty

脚女士！

foot lady!

始终包含场景描述——它告诉我们发生了什么：

Always include scene description — it tells us what’s going on:

 

 

外景，北麓之夜

EXT. NORTHERN FOOTHILLS NIGHT

 

 

在广阔的体育世界中，这到底是什么？！

What in the wide, wide world of sports is that?!

鲍勃

BOB

小心伙计们！这是五十

Look out fellas! It’s the fifty

脚女士！

foot lady!

请给我们描述一下LA SORBONNE DORMITORY 之后的场景：

Give us a bit o’ the ole scene description after LA SORBONNE DORMITORY:

 

 

系列照片——黎明

SERIES OF SHOTS - DAWN

 

 

太阳升起。巴黎。埃菲尔铁塔。歌剧院。

Sun rises. Paris. Eiffel tower. Opera house.

 

 

富凯咖啡馆。人行道上，一个 GRUBBY BUM 用橡皮老鼠吓唬人们。

Fouquet’s café. On the sidewalk, a GRUBBY BUM scares people with a rubber rat.

 

 

外景，索邦大学宿舍，白天

EXT. LA SORBONNE DORMITORY - DAY

 

 

内景，让·米歇尔的宿舍，白天

INT. JEAN MICHEL’S DORM ROOM - DAY

 

 

Jean Michel 醒来，煮了咖啡。真是个酷小伙子！

Jean Michel wakes up, makes coffee. What a cool guy!

不要在不该有空格的地方留空格。读者知道你没有校对，你看起来像个傻瓜。看看“在里面！”双重傻瓜。

Don’t have spaces where there shouldn’t be spaces. The reader knows you didn’t proofread and you look like a doofus. Check out “in the along!” Double doofus.

 

 

外景，罗莎巴尔的遭遇 - 夜晚

EXT. ROSABAL’S ENCOUNTER - NIGHT

 

 

 

 

罗萨巴尔和维加沿着回家的路走着，这时乡村警卫开着一辆吉普车迎面而来。

Rosabal is walking with Vega in the along the road home as he is encountered by the rural guard who approach in a jeep.

这里空格太多，校对也很差：

Too many spaces and poor proofreading here, too:

司机

DRIVER

请进来，上校。

Come inside, Colonel.

 

 

 

 

山麓地区

EXT. THE FOOTHILLS

 

 

切从附近最高的树上爬下来，加入了这群人。

Che climbs down form the tallest tree in the area and joins the group.

另外，在我们需要时，请小心地提供 slugline。不要用一段场景描述带我们去几个地方，却不添加必要的 slugline 来告诉我们我们在哪里。这里，Nic 走出了门外，我们没有得到 slugline。

Also be careful to give us sluglines whenever we need them. Don’t have a block of scene description that takes us several places without adding the requisite sluglines to show us where we are. Here, Nic walks outside and we don’t get a slugline.

 

 

尼克看到附近有一面镜子，便走了过去。他检查了一下受伤的嘴唇，发现白衬衫上有几滴血迹。他皱起眉头，走出了门。他打电话约瑟夫在外面。你需要一个新的 slugline，因为他走出了酒吧。添加：外部。酒吧之夜

Nic sees a mirror nearby and walks over to it. He examines his wounded lip and notices there are drops of blood on his white shirt. He frowns and walks out the door. He calls Joseph from outside. YOU NEED A NEW SLUGLINE HERE, AS HE’S WALKED OUTSIDE THE BAR. ADD: EXT. BAR NIGHT

此处缺少一些 slugline：

A handful of missing sluglines here:

 

 

INT. XN 兄弟会之家日

INT. XN FRAT HOUSE DAY

 

 

兄弟们围坐在一起看电视。有些人在玩啤酒乒乓球。穿着滑稽服装的新人继续做家务。杰西躺在二楼房间里的床上。

Brothers sit around watching TV. Some play beer pong. Pledges dressed in silly costumes carry on with chores. Jesse lies in bed in his second story room.

 

 

敲门声不断。兄弟们没有理会。杰西向窗外望去，看到校园警察局长米奇·罗克尼以马丁·路德的风格把传单钉在门上。其他兄弟会宿舍也贴着同样的传单。

BANGING on the door. Brothers pay little attention. Jesse looks out the window to see chief of campus police MITCH ROCKNY nailing a flyer to the door in Martin Luther fashion. Identical papers cling to other frat houses.

不要把我们放在客厅里，然后，就像《我梦见珍妮》中那样——眨眼！杰西在他的房间里，一整层楼远。然后，再次眨眼，我们来到前门。然后，回到杰西的房间，从窗户向外看警察把传单钉在门上，然后，精疲力竭、困惑不已，去了其他兄弟会宿舍，其他地方。

Don’t put us in the living room and then, like I Dream of Jeannie — blink! to Jesse in his room, a whole floor away. Then, blinking again, we’re at the front door. Then, back up to Jesse’s room, looking out his window to the cop nailing a flyer to the door, then, exhausted and confused, to other frat houses, elsewhere.

使用正确的 slugline 后，上述场景将呈现如下效果：

With the right sluglines, the above scene would look like:

 

 

INT. XN 兄弟会之家 - 客厅日

INT. XN FRAT HOUSE - LIVING ROOM DAY

 

 

兄弟们围坐在一起看电视。有的在玩啤酒乒乓球。新人穿着滑稽的服装继续做家务。

Brothers sit around watching TV. Some play beer pong. Pledges dressed in silly costumes carry on with chores.

 

 

 

 

杰西的房间日

INT. JESSE’S ROOM DAY

 

 

杰西躺在二楼房间的床上。

Jesse lies in bed in his second story room.

 

 

 

 

INT. XN 兄弟会之家 - 客厅日

INT. XN FRAT HOUSE - LIVING ROOM DAY

 

 

敲门声。兄弟俩没有理会。

BANGING on the door. Brothers pay little attention.

 

 

 

 

杰西的房间日

INT. JESSE’S ROOM DAY

 

 

杰西向窗外望去，看到校园警察局长米奇·罗克尼 (MITCH ROCKNY) 以马丁·路德·金的方式将一张传单钉在门上。

Jesse looks out the window to see chief of campus police MITCH ROCKNY nailing a flyer to the door in Martin Luther fashion.

 

 

外部各种兄弟会日

EXT. VARIOUS FRAT HOUSES DAY

 

 

其他兄弟会也贴着同样的文件。

Identical papers cling to other frat houses.

虽然占用了更多空间，但动作很清晰。尽量做到清晰。

It takes up more room, but the action is clear. Endeavor to be clear.

53. 你对演员的指导过多了！

53. You over-direct your actors!

 

不要在脑子里告诉我们电影里发生的一切。编辑。

Don’t tell us everything that happens in the movie in your head. Edit.

 

 

她转向马戏团团长，拿起扩音器并将其递给他。

She turns to the ringmaster, picks up her megaphone and hands it to him.

导演告诉演员如何移动。你不用告诉他们。或者，演员自己想办法。不要告诉读者演员转身，然后伸手到钱包里拿名片，脸上是什么表情，等等。

The director tells the actors how to move. You don’t. Or, the actors figure it out for themselves. Don’t tell the reader that the actor turns, then reaches into his wallet for his business card, what expression is on his face, etc.

 

 

她把扩音器递给马戏团团长。

She hands the ringmaster her megaphone.

这里对演员的指导有些过度。这里也有一些校对错误。

Here’s some over-direction of actors. Here, too, are a pair of proofreading mistakes.

 

 

克里斯汀抬起头，看着琼，又看了看手表，然后又看着琼。她站起来，走到车旁，上了车，但再也没有看向她的母亲。

Kristin looks up, stares at Jean, then at her wristwatch, and then back at Jean. She stand up, walks over to the car, and gets in, but doesn’t make any more looks towards her mother.

 

 

琼走到冰箱前，拿出一壶马提尼酒，给自己倒了一杯。

Jean walks to the refrigerator, pulls out a martini pitcher, and pours herself a glass.

 

 

吉恩终于走过去，看着艾伦的肩膀，然后抬头看着他惊恐而沮丧的脸。

Jean finally walks over and looks at Allen’s shoulder and then up at his terrified, frustrated face.

 

 

吉恩走进来，站在威尔逊右侧后方几英尺处。

Jean walks in and stands as few feet behind and to the right of Wilson.

 

 

CNBC 播放广告。威尔逊转身面对吉恩。

CNBC goes to commercial. Wilson turns around to face Jean.

这里的细节太多了：

Way too much detail here:

 

 

他把她拉向自己，用另一只手抚摸着她的脸颊。

He pulls her towards him, caressing her cheek with his other hand.

 

 

他先用双手握住她的前臂，然后滑到她的手上，握住她的手，然后抚摸它。

He first wraps his hands on her forearm then slides down to her hands, cupping them, then stroking them.

金

KIM

我父亲早些时候抱怨过这枚戒指。

My father complained about the ring earlier.

 

 

谭低头看着戒指，用拇指和食指滑过宝石。

Looking down at the ring, Thanh slides his thumb and pointer finger over the gem.

这部电影有两个错误：对演员的指导过多以及括号使用不正确。

This one has two sins: over direction of actors and incorrect use of a parenthetical.

困境

LURCH

（突然转身）您打电话了吗……？

(Lurch turns) You rang...?

因此，当我们讨论这个话题时：

So, while we’re on the subject:

54. 您使用括号错了！

54. You use parentheticals wrong!

 

不要觉得受委屈了。几乎我教过的每个学生都用错了括号。也许我是个糟糕的老师。对他们要小心，因为一旦制片人打开你的剧本检查页数，他们就会大喊“格式错误！”

Don’t feel rained on. Nearly every student I’ve ever had uses parentheticals incorrectly. Maybe I’m a lousy teacher. Be careful with them because they can cry out “Format mistake!” to the producer the instant he opens your script to check the page count.

仅当对话含义尚不清楚时才使用括号。

Only use a parenthetical if the meaning of the dialogue is not already clear.

吉米

（松了一口气）

JIMMY

(relieved)

呼。感谢上帝！

Whew. Thank God!

我们知道他松了一口气，所以你不需要再告诉我们第二次。

We know he’s relieved, so you don’t need to tell us twice.

吉米

JIMMY

呼。感谢上帝！

Whew. Thank God!

 

你需要一个：

You need one here:

CLEO

（讨厌他）

CLEO

(loathes him)

我爱你。

I love you.

此外，无论您在书店购买或在互联网上阅读的剧本中看到什么，您都不应该在括号中给出动作。

Also, despite what you see in screenplays you buy at a bookstore or read on the Internet, you should not give action in a parenthetical.

卡鲁索

（点燃香烟）

CARUSO

(lighting cigarette)

我的扁桃体有问题。

I am having trouble with my tonsils.

你经常看到这种事，但你不应该这么做。好吧，也许可以做一点。

You see it a lot, but you’re not supposed to do it. Well, maybe a little.

括号不是句子。开头没有大写字母，结尾没有句号。接下来的内容是错误的！

A parenthetical is not a sentence. No capital letter at the start, no period at the end. What’s next is wrong!

埃尔伍德

（看着香烟。）

ELWOOD

(Looks at cigarettes.)

给我一个，杰克。

Gimme one, Jake.

不要对“演员”进行微观管理，因为含义和手势应该通过对话传达出来。仔细阅读剧本，删除任何告诉演员该做什么的括号。现在就做。现在。继续。我会等的。

Don’t micromanage your “actors,” because meaning and gestures should come across in dialogue. Go through your script and take out any parentheticals that tell the actors what to do. Do it now. Right now. Go on. I’ll wait.

拉尔菲

（用手抹了抹眉毛）

RALPHIE

(swipes hand across brow)

Zowee！我以为你是认真的。

Zowee! I thought you were serious.

安妮

（看了他一眼）

ANNE

(shoots him a look)

你一定是疯了。

You gotta be nuts.

这里不需要括号：

No need for parentheticals here:

马特

（环顾四周）

MATT

(looking around)

谁？在哪里？

Who? Where?

阿尔贝蒂娜

ALBERTINA

（指着）

(pointing)

和露西一起在那边。看到了吗？

Over there, with Lucy. See?

不要使用“打断”这个词。

Don’t use the word “interrupting.”

大卫

DAVID

亲爱的，晚餐几点开始？

What time is dinner honey?

玛吉

MAGGIE

（打断）

(interrupting)

我想要离婚。

I want a divorce.

使用破折号执行此操作：

Do this, with dashes:

大卫

DAVID

亲爱的，晚餐几点开始？

What time is dinner honey--

玛吉

MAGGIE

——我想离婚。

--I want a divorce.

不要这样做：

Don’t do this:

罗伯特

ROBERT

（笑）

(laughs)

奇怪的是，我是罗伯特·唐恩......

Oddly, I’m Robert Donn...

糖果

CANDY

（惊讶，打断他）

(surprised, interrupts him)

唐纳利。你应该给我的飞机安装新的航空电子设备。对吗？

Donnely. You’re supposed to be putting the new avionics in my plane. Is that right?

使用破折号执行此操作：

Do this, with dashes:

罗伯特

ROBERT

（笑）

(laughs)

奇怪的是，我是罗伯特·唐恩——

Oddly, I’m Robert Donn--

糖果

CANDY

（吃惊）

(surprised)

——唐纳利。你应该给我的飞机安装新的航空电子设备。对吗？

--Donnely. You’re supposed to be putting the new avionics in my plane. Is that right?

基本上，通过在对话中明确表达意思来消除所有括号。此外，括号位于对话之上。而不是相反。

Basically, eliminate every parenthetical you can by making the meaning clear in the dialogue. Also, the parenthetical sits on the dialogue. Not vice versa.

罗伯特

ROBERT

这是我一生中见过的最令人惊奇的事情！

That’s the most amazing thing I’ve ever seen in my entire life!

（当他悬浮起来时）

(as he levitates)

那是错的。请改正。

That was wrong. Please do it right.

一般来说，它们只需要一行。而且也不经常出现。想想 Tabasco — 偶尔出现一点点。告诉读者你希望她如何想象你的场景是很有诱惑力的，但要给她一点想象空间。这些太冗长，插入太频繁了：

Generally, they need to be one line only. And not often, either. Think Tabasco — just a tad, now and then. It’s tempting to tell the reader exactly how you want her to imagine your scene, but leave a little to her imagination. These are too wordy and inserted too often:

弗朗西斯

FRANCIS

（大声，关切而温柔）

(loudly, with concern and tenderness)

我的朋友们，我是方济各会的方济各兄弟，我们的主耶稣永远不会如此贪婪地要求我们归还救赎的礼物。

My friends, I am Brother Francis of the Franciscan Order, and our Lord Jesus would never be so greedy as to demand the gift of salvation back from us.

司仪

OFFICIANT

（对“主啊

(wincing at “Lord

耶稣”和

Jesus” and

打断，圆滑）

interrupting, slick)

兄弟，我不再用那个名字了，尽管我向你保证我就是那个人。

Brother, I no longer use that name, though I assure you that I am he.

弗朗西斯

FRANCIS

（困惑和

(puzzled and with

日益加深的担忧

deepening concern)

我的朋友，我担心你最好是一个异教徒，最坏是一个亵渎者......

My friend, I am afraid that you are a heretic at best and a blasphemer at worst...

司仪

OFFICIANT

（怒不可遏，但说话

(livid, but speaking

慢慢地

slowly with

权威和

authority and

控制）

control)

安静！看着我，知道我是你的主人。现在离开，我会惩罚这个异教徒。

Silence! Look upon me and know that I am your master. Leave now while I punish this infidel.

最后，不要使用括号重复我们已经知道的内容：

Finally, don’t use parentheticals that repeat what we already know:

阿诺德

ARNOLD

他们的钱从哪里来的？

Where did their money come from?

丽塔

RITA

搜查我。抢劫加油站？

Search me. Rob a gas station?

（沮丧，大喊）

(frustrated, yelling)

这些钱他妈到底是从哪儿来的？！

Where the fuck did that money come from?!

埃洛伊丝（OS）

ELOISE (O.S.)

（大喊）

(yelling)

也许他们救了它，你这个傻瓜。

Maybe they saved it, you fool.

尝试一下：

Try this:

阿诺德

ARNOLD

他们的钱从哪里来的？

Where did their money come from?

丽塔

RITA

搜查我。抢劫加油站？

Search me. Rob a gas station?

（沮丧的）

(frustrated)

这些钱到底是从哪儿来的？！

WHERE THE FUCK DID THAT MONEY COME FROM?!

埃洛伊丝（OS）

ELOISE (O.S.)

也许他们保存了它，你这个傻瓜。

MAYBE THEY SAVED IT, YOU FOOL.

括号是邪恶的塞壬，引诱您走上邪恶之路。抵制它们阴险的歌声！

Parentheticals are evil Sirens, tempting you down the path of wickedness. Resist their insidious song!

人物

Characters

 

55. 你给我们改了角色名！

55. You change character names on us!

 

确保角色名称保持一致。如果一个女人被称为 Glam-Fab Woman，请不要在场景描述的下一部分中称她为 Skinny Glam Woman。如果场景描述中他被称为 Major Humphreys，当他说话时请称他为 Major Humphreys — 不要叫他 Hap。

Make sure character names stay consistent. If a woman is called Glam-Fab Woman, don’t call her Skinny Glam Woman in the next chunk of scene description. If he’s called Major Humphreys in scene description, call him Major Humphreys when he speaks — don’t call him Hap.

外景，富兰克林之家

EXT. FRANKLIN’S HOUSE DAY

彼得的妻子格雷西欢迎大卫进屋。

Peter’s wife, GRACIE, welcomes David inside.

如果主角是大卫，他的伙伴是彼得·富兰克林（大家都叫他彼得），但你在广告词中称其为“富兰克林之家”，那么你就让读者感到困惑了。他们沿着漂浮在沼泽中的睡莲叶奔跑，一时之间失足了。然后他们恢复了过来，但你让他们有点紧张。

If the hero is David, and his buddy is Peter Franklin, whom everyone calls Peter, but you call it “Franklin’s House” in the slugline, then you’ve confused the readers. Just for a moment, they misstep as they race down the lily pads floating in the swamp. Then they recover, but you’ve made them a little jittery.

选择一个角色名并坚持下去。如果他所有的朋友都叫他彼得，那么当他有对话时你就叫他彼得。

Pick a character name and stick with it. If all his friends call him Peter, you call him Peter when he has dialogue.

大卫

DAVID

咖啡，彼得？

Coffee, Peter?

彼得

PETER

请给我加点糖。

I’ll have sugar with that, please.

不要这样做：

Don’t do this:

大卫

DAVID

好吧，彼得，糖终于

Well, Peter, that sugar’s finally

会杀了你的。

gonna kill ya.

富兰克林

FRANKLIN

如果我先杀了它就不会。哈哈哈。

Not if I kill it first. Ha ha ha.

糟糕的对话。我自己的。但是，你不会相信 1) 这有多令人困惑，以及 2) 我见过多少次这种错误。

Horrible dialogue. My own. But, you wouldn’t believe 1) how confusing this is, and 2) how many times I see this mistake.

所以，当你带我们去他家的时候，请叫它彼得之家。拜托。

And so, when you take us to his house, call it PETER’S HOUSE. Please.

56. 你的角色中有太多名字了！

56. Too many of your characters have names!

 

从第 1 页开始，读者就开始试图在情感上与你的角色产生共鸣。当她遇到一个名叫JOSEPH的人时，她会开始了解他，并投入精力去记住他是谁。如果他在介绍完两页后就死了，那么读者就浪费了精力去了解 Joseph，而他应该被称为NERVOUS STOCK BROKER。

From page 1, your reader is trying to emotionally attach to your characters. When she meets someone named JOSEPH, she will start to learn about him and devote energy to remembering who he is. If he dies two pages after he was introduced, the reader has wasted her energy getting to know Joseph, when he should have been called NERVOUS STOCK BROKER.

或许是：肥胖的警察、冷静的女服务员、歹徒、微笑的牧师，或者像《动物屋》中那样，我个人最喜欢的一组无名角色名称：

Or perhaps: OBESE POLICEMAN, CALM WAITRESS, HENCHMAN, SMILING PRIEST, or, like in Animal House, my personal favorite set of non-name character names:

大家伙

BIG DUDE

大个子

BIGGER DUDE

      巨人

      GIGANTIC DUDE

我写过很多剧本，在上次改编的初稿中我犯了这个错误，所以如果你也犯了同样的错误，不要感到难过。

I’ve written a bunch of screenplays and I made this mistake in the first draft of the last adaptation I did, so don’t feel bad if you do it too.

读者大概能记住八个名字。之后，他们就无从下手了。

A reader can absorb about eight names. After that, they’re drowning.

我选择了HALEY、FLETCHER、RILEY、CRYSTAL、BO、HANNAFORD、GYWN、DADDY，因为他们是主角。我们经常看到他们，需要知道他们的名字。

HALEY, FLETCHER, RILEY, CRYSTAL, BO, HANNAFORD, GYWN, DADDY are the ones I settled on, because they are the main characters. We see them a lot and need to know their names.

愚蠢的是，在我的初稿中，我还使用了小说中的名字（包括其他人！）ELSA、LETCHY、MAMA HATCHEY、SPIER、GYPSY、JOY DOUGLAS、CALLEY PEARL、JUDGE GREEL、BIG BERTHA和LEAN。为了保持直截了当，我需要向每位读者分发一个剧中人物。“没有记分卡，你就无法分辨出玩家！”我真是个笨蛋。

Stupidly, in my first draft, I also used the novel’s names for (among others!) ELSA, LETCHY, MAMA HATCHEY, SPIER, GYPSY, JOY DOUGLAS, CALLEY PEARL, JUDGE GREEL, BIG BERTHA and LEAN. To keep it straight, I would have needed to hand out a dramatis personae to each reader. “You can’t tell the players without a scorecard!” What a bonehead I was.

最后我醒了，闻到了咖啡的香味。我把这些名字改成了：商店女士、腿部支架男、烧烤女士、理发师、格温的妹妹、离婚女人乔伊、一文不值的兄弟、弗莱彻的父亲、鸡肉女士和苏打水机上的男子。

Eventually I woke up and smelled the coffee. I changed those names to: STORE LADY, GUY IN LEG BRACES, BBQ LADY, THE BARBER, GWYN’S SISTER, JOY THE DIVORCEE, WORTHLESS BROTHER, FLETCHER’S FATHER, CHICKEN LADY, and MAN ON SODA MACHINE.

我去掉了这么多名字，没看过小说的人读了剧本也能知道是怎么回事了。这样就没那么让人困惑了。你也可以这样做！

After I got rid of so many names, someone who has not read the novel could read the screenplay and know what’s going on. It’s less confusing. You do it too!

57. 角色名字以同一个字母开头！或者更糟的是，它们押韵！

57. Character names begin with the same letter! Or WORSE, they RHYME!

 

令人惊讶的是，许多初学写作的人都这样做。检查一下，确保你不是其中之一！如果不是，那就为自己鼓掌吧。如果是，请继续阅读：

It’s uncanny how many beginning writers do this. Check to make sure you’re not one of them! If not, pat yourself on the back. If so, read on:

《希德姐妹帮》的作者丹尼尔·沃特斯写下了整个字母表，并给每个角色起了一个以不同字母开头的名字。你也可以。

Daniel Waters, author of Heathers, writes down the entire alphabet and gives each character a name beginning with a different letter. So can you.

阿洛伊修斯

Aloysius

伯特伦

Bertram

康拉德

Conrad

黛利拉

Delilah

伊森

Ethan

弗格斯

Fergus

优雅

Grace

海伦

Helen

艾琳

Irene

詹金森

Jenkinson

克卢普

Klup

槊

Lance

玛丽亚

Mariah

诺伯特

Norbert

奥斯卡

Oscar

矮牵牛

Petunia

昆西

Quincy

罗斯林

Rosslyn

李·斯塔格

Stagger Lee

特伦斯

Terrence

乌利亚

Uriah

维多利亚

Victoire

华盛顿

Washington

泽维尔

Xavier

扬西

Yancy

佐伊（不过现在每个剧本里的女孩都叫佐伊！）

Zoe (except every girl in every script these days is called Zoe!)

一定存在某种天生的肌肉抽搐，让作家想要使用相似的名字。我在学生的剧本中经常看到这种情况。不要这样做：

There must be some sort of innate muscle twitch that makes writers want to use names that are similar. I see it all the time in my students’ scripts. Don’t do this:

担

DAN

戴尔

DALE

迪克

DICK

大学教师

DON

戴夫

DAVE

或者这样：

Or this:

 
 
 

查德和克里斯

LENA和LYLE

托尼亚和特雷弗

 
 

CHAD and CHRIS

LENA and LYLE

TONYA and TREVOR

或者，来自我朋友的剧本……

Or, from a script by a friend of mine…

 
 
 

吉娜和格温

 
 

GINA and GWEN

吉娜是女儿，故事的女主角。格温是被人讨厌的母亲。我读着读着，却搞不明白为什么被人鄙视的母亲会被邀请到儿子家吃饭。我不得不回过头来才明白，不，吉娜是好人，格温是泼妇。我完全糊涂了。我喜欢假装自己不傻，你的读者也是。让他们觉得自己很聪明：

Gina is the daughter, heroine of the story. Gwen is the hated mother. I was reading along, and couldn’t figure out why the despised mother had been invited to the son’s house for dinner. I had to flip back and figure out that, no, Gina is the good guy and Gwen is the harridan. I was totally confused. I like to pretend that I’m not stupid, and so too does your reader. Make them feel intelligent:

这样做：

Do this:

担

DAN

阿尔吉侬

ALGERNON

弗兰基

FRANKIE

ZAP

ZAP

可怕的坏脾气

SCARY CURMUDGEON

求求你，求求你，求求你，哦亲爱的上帝，不要让它们押韵：

Please, please, please, oh dear Lord, don’t make them rhyme:

丹尼

DANNY

BILLY 比利

BILLY

威利

WILLIE

卡莉

CALLIE

鲍比

BOBBY

罗比

ROBBY

莎莉

SALLY

倫尼

LENNY

维妮

VINNIE

或者，看在上帝的份上，名字的长度是一样的：

Or, for pity’s sake, names that are the same length:

汤姆

TOM

鲍勃

BOB

蒂姆

TIM

乔

JOE

起诉

SUE

拍

PAT

ANN

ANN

我让一个学生在同一个剧本、同一个场景、同一个页面上使用了JEN、JON和JESSIE ！啊啊啊！

I had one student use JEN, JON, and JESSIE in one script, in one scene, on the same page! Arggghhh!

有些作家喜欢给女性角色起男性的名字。为什么人们会这样做？这真是个谜。你是想让我们困惑吗？

Some writers delight in giving male names to female characters. Why do people do this!? It’s a mystery. Are you trying to confuse us?

萨姆。亚历克斯。特蕾西。杰西。桑迪。克里斯。杰基。麦迪逊。卡里。卡梅伦。史黛西。特里。比利。惠特尼。迪伦。泰勒。莱斯利。林赛。瑞安。朱尔斯。史蒂夫。肖恩。帕特。杰米。梅雷迪思。布莱尔。金。阿什利。贝弗利。德鲁。布莱克。安迪。布莱斯。海登。莱利。乔迪。凯利。里斯。洛根。佩顿。尼基。莱恩。凯里。乔。布雷特。马克斯。道格拉斯。泰勒。等等，令人厌烦。

Sam. Alex. Tracy. Jesse. Sandy. Chris. Jackie. Madison. Cary. Cameron. Stacy. Terry. Billy. Whitney. Dylan. Tyler. Leslie. Lindsay. Ryan. Jules. Stevie. Sean. Pat. Jamie. Meredith. Blair. Kim. Ashley. Beverly. Drew. Blake. Andy. Bryce. Hayden. Riley. Jody. Kelly. Reese. Logan. Peyton. Nicky. Lane. Kerry. Jo. Bret. Max. Douglass. Taylor. Etc., ad nauseam.

尽管 Shirley 也是一个男人的名字，但你永远不会在剧本中给一个男人起这个名字，对吧？所以，请不要给你的女主角起名叫 Alex 或 Sam。

Even though Shirley is also a man’s name, you’d never name a man that in your script, would you? So please, please, please don’t call your main female character Alex or Sam.

詹森先生

MR. JANSEN

我明白你的意思了吗，比尔先生？

Am I getting through to you, Mr. Biel?

即使是知道自己在做什么的人也会犯这个错误。我目前正在读迈克尔·托尔金的《玩家》续集。它有这些令人困惑的名字：

Even people who know what they’re doing make this mistake. I am currently reading the sequel to the book The Player, by Michael Tolkin. It has these wrenchingly confusing names:

 
 

莉萨

·薇拉·

杰莎

 

Lisa

Willa

Jessa

这些句子都押韵，长度相同：一个是第二任妻子，一个是第一任妻子的孩子，一个是第二任妻子的孩子。

all of which rhyme and are the same length: one is the second wife, one is the first wife’s child, and one is the second wife’s child.

 
 

六月

 

June

是杰莎的第一任妻子和母亲，这很容易让人混淆，因为她们的名字都很短，而且都以“J”开头。最后，还有另外两个角色：

is the first wife and mother of Jessa, which is confusing because they both are short names and both start with “J.” And, finally, there are two other characters:

 
 

伊莱·

伊桑

 

Eli

Ethan

啊啊啊啊啊。我读到一半就一直往前翻看格里芬·米尔和哪位妻子生了哪些孩子。

ARGGGGHHHH. I’m halfway through the book and keep flipping to the front to see which children Griffin Mill had by which wife.

你是个作家。要有创意！多想想！买一本婴儿名字书。使用历史上的名字，使用老足球运动员或一级方程式赛车手或你四年级时一起上课的孩子的名字。如果没有别的，看看www.imdb.com并结合演员和剧组名单中的名字。看看哈罗德和莫德。看看这些令人惊奇的名字！巴德·科特、维维安·皮克尔斯、西里尔·库萨克、查尔斯·泰纳、埃里克·克里斯马斯、汤姆·斯凯里特、戈登·德沃尔、哈维·布鲁姆菲尔德、哈尔·阿什比、林恩·斯塔尔马斯特、查尔斯·穆尔维希尔和巴迪·乔·胡克。

You’re a writer. Be original! Think harder! Buy a baby name book. Use names from history, use the names of old football players or Formula 1 drivers or kids you were in fourth grade with. If nothing else, look at www.imdb.com and combine names from cast and crew lists. Check out Harold and Maude. Look at the amazing names! Bud Cort, Vivian Pickles, Cyril Cusack, Charles Tyner, Eric Christmas, Tom Skerritt, Gordon Devol, Harvey Brumfield, Hal Ashby, Lynn Stalmaster, Charles Mulvihill, and Buddy Joe Hooker.

我从《哈罗德与莫德》中偷取了一些很酷的名字。

Stealing from Harold And Maude, I came up with some pretty cool names.

维维安·德沃尔

Vivian Devol

西里尔·斯塔尔马斯特

Cyril Stalmaster

巴德·穆尔维希尔

Bud Mulvihill

戈登·泰纳

Gordon Tyner

哈尔·库萨克

Hal Cusack

巴迪·乔·圣诞节

Buddy Joe Christmas

查尔斯·皮克尔斯

Charles Pickles

艾瑞克·斯克里特

Eric Skerritt

汤姆·布鲁姆菲尔德

Tom Brumfield

哈维·科特

Harvey Cort

像查尔斯·狄更斯那样编造名字。他的名字有助于描述人物。你也可以这样做！

Make up names like Charles Dickens did. His names help describe the characters. You can do that too!

普姆布尔乔克

Pumblechook

莎莉·布拉斯

Sally Brass

约西亚·邦德比

Josiah Bounderby

阿贝尔·马格韦奇

Abel Magwitch

亨利埃塔·博芬

Henrietta Boffin

简·默德斯通

Jane Murdstone

托马斯·普洛尼什

Thomas Plornish

索菲·沃克尔斯

Sophie Wackles

一定要在imdb.com上检查你角色的名字，确保它们从未被使用过。你还年轻。“乔治·贝利”和“亚历克西斯·卡林顿”可能对你来说不太显眼，但对制片人来说却会。

Do check your character names on imdb.com to make sure they’ve never been used before. You’re young. “George Bailey” and “Alexis Carrington” may not pop out to you, but will to the producer.

读者在脑海中念出的名字是否符合您的意图？如果您给角色起了一个奇怪的名字，也许应该重新考虑一下。Peter Dubchek 可以发音为“Doobcheck”或“Dub check”。不要让读者感到困惑。

Is the reader pronouncing the name in his head the way you intend? If you’ve got an odd name for a character, perhaps rethink it. Peter Dubchek can be pronounced “Doobcheck” or “Dub check.” Don’t confuse your reader.

记住，在牛仔电影中，好人戴白帽子。坏人戴黑帽子。很容易区分。现在想象一下，如果电影制片人给每个人都戴白帽子会怎样？你绝不会犯这么愚蠢的错误。对吧？没错。

Remember, in cowboy movies, the good guy wears the white hat. The bad guy wears a black hat. Easy to tell them apart. Now imagine if the filmmaker had given everybody white hats? No way you’d make a mistake that silly. Right? Riiight.

58. 你没有用简洁、生动、两句左右的句子来描述主角！

58. You do not describe main characters with a concise, telling, two (or so) sentence character description!

 

请告诉我们一些我们刚刚遇到的角色的情况。你只有一次机会直接与读者讨论这些人是谁。不要错过。

Tell us a wee bit about the character we’ve just met. You only have one chance to talk directly to the reader about who these people are. Don’t miss it.

这位作家需要告诉我们更多关于她的主要女性角色的信息：花园管理员穆里尔·里德 (MURIEL REED) 让加里着迷。她将苏打水灌入喷雾器，在草地上喷洒出棕色的喷雾。

This writer needs to tell us more about her main female character: MURIEL REED, a grounds keeper, captivates Gary. She fills the sprayer with soda and mists brown over the grass.

讲述他们的个性、性格、缺点或缺陷，但不要描述身体细节，除非非常重要。比如，如果他们身高七英尺。尽量不要提及种族、身高、体重、头发颜色、眼睛颜色等。如果你描述的角色只能是裘德·洛，而汤姆·克鲁斯读了它（假装！）并想成为其中的一员，但认为他不适合这个角色，想象一下你要从多高的楼上跳下来！

Tell about their personality, their character, their foibles or flaws, but no physical details unless it’s incredibly important. Like, if they’re seven feet tall. Try to leave race out of it, as well as height, weight, hair color, eye color, etc. If you describe a character who could only be Jude Law, and Tom Cruise reads it (as if!) and wants to be in it, but thinks he’s wrong for the part, imagine how high a building you’re going to jump off!

尽量模糊地描述角色的年龄。“30 多岁”比“32 岁”好得多。同样，一定要给演员一个机会来出演你的电影。

Be as vague as vague can be about your character’s age. “30s” is much better than “32.” Again, always give any actor a way to be in your film.

我的一个朋友正在改编一部小说。小说中的角色是 52 岁。她把这一点写进了剧本。主要演员先生觉得自己不能扮演一个 52 岁的人。他 47 岁。如果剧本上写着“40 多岁”，他会同意扮演这个角色的。算了。

A friend of mine was adapting a novel. The character in the novel is 52. She put that in the script. Mr. Major Actor didn’t feel he could play someone who was 52. He was 47. He’d have agreed to play the role if it had said, “Late 40s.” Oh well.

学习这些人的做法，然后效仿他们。摘自马特·达蒙和本·阿弗莱克的《心灵捕手》 ：

Study what these folks do, and do likewise. From Good Will Hunting by Matt Damon & Ben Affleck:

主持会议的人是查基·沙利文，20 岁，是这群人中个子最高的。他声音大，精力旺盛，天生就是个娱乐家。他旁边是威尔·亨廷，20 岁，英俊而自信，说话温和，是个领导者。威尔的右边坐着比利·麦克布莱德，22 岁，身材魁梧，沉默寡言，你肯定不想跟他纠缠。最后是摩根·奥马利，19 岁，比其他人个子小。摩根身材瘦削，焦虑不安，他带着厌恶的神情听着查基讲述恐怖故事。

The guy holding court is CHUCKIE SULLIVAN, 20, and the largest of the bunch. He is loud, boisterous, a born entertainer. Next to him is WILL HUNTING, 20, handsome and confident, a softspoken leader. On Will’s right sits BILLY MCBRIDE, 22, heavy, quiet, someone you definitely wouldn’t want to tangle with. Finally there is MORGAN O’MALLY, 19, smaller than the other guys. Wiry and anxious, Morgan listens to Chuckie’s horror stories with eager disgust.

达伦·阿罗诺夫斯基和休伯特·塞尔比的《梦之安魂曲》

Requiem for a Dream by Darren Aronofsky and Hubert Selby

电视上

ON THE TV -

- 是 Tappy Tibbons，美国最受欢迎的电视名人。他的魅力让全世界都为之倾倒。

- is Tappy Tibbons, America’s favorite television personality. His charismatic personality shines for the entire world to see.

西尔维斯特·史泰龙的《洛奇》

Rocky by Sylvester Stallone

拳击台上有两个重量级拳击手，一个是白人，另一个是黑人。白人拳击手是洛基·巴尔博亚。他三十岁了。他的脸上布满伤疤，鼻子周围很厚……他的黑发闪闪发光，垂在眼睛上。洛基打斗时动作缓慢，机器般的风格。黑衣斗士舞动着，精准地将各种组合拳猛击到洛奇的脸上。但洛奇连眼睛都没眨一下……他对对手咧嘴一笑，继续向前冲刺。

In the ring are two heavyweights, one white the other black. The white fighter is ROCKY BALBOA. He is thirty years old. His face is scarred and thick around the nose... His black hair shines and hangs in his eyes. Rocky fights in a plodding, machine-like style. The BLACK FIGHTER dances and bangs combinations into Rocky’s face with great accuracy. But the punches do not even cause Rocky to blink... He grins at his opponent and keeps grinding ahead.

搏击俱乐部（吉姆·乌尔斯）

Fight Club by Jim Uhls

泰勒一只手搂着杰克的肩膀，另一只手握着一把手枪，枪管抵在杰克的嘴里。泰勒坐在杰克的腿上。他们俩都大汗淋漓，衣冠不整，都在 30 岁左右；泰勒是金发碧眼，英俊潇洒；杰克是黑发，有点冷酷的魅力。泰勒看了看手表。

TYLER has one arm around Jack’s shoulder; the other hand holds a HANDGUN with the barrel lodged in JACK’S MOUTH. Tyler is sitting in Jack’s lap. They are both sweating and disheveled, both around 30; Tyler is blond, handsome; and Jack, brunette, is appealing in a dry sort of way. Tyler looks at his watch.

艾伦·鲍尔的《美国丽人》

American Beauty by Alan Ball

卡罗琳·伯纳姆在伯纳姆家门前照料玫瑰花丛。她是一位四十多岁的女性，打扮得非常得体，穿着色彩协调的园艺服装，拥有许多实用而昂贵的工具。

CAROLYN BURNHAM tends her rose bushes in front of the Burnham house. A very well-put together woman of forty, she wears color-coordinated gardening togs and has lots of useful and expensive tools.

哈罗德·雷米斯和丹·阿克罗伊德的《捉鬼敢死队》。“句子末尾最重要的词”的一个很好的例子：

Ghostbusters by Harold Ramis & Dan Ackroyd. Nice example of “most important word at the end of the sentence”:

彼得·温克曼博士正在对两名学生志愿者进行 ESP 测试，一男一女，两人坐在他对面，中间隔着一块屏幕。温克曼是一名副教授，但他皱巴巴的西装和眼中闪烁的狂躁光芒表明他性格中存在潜在的不稳定因素。然而，虽然学历不高，但温克曼却充满自信、魅力和推销技巧。

DR. PETER VENKMAN is administering an ESP test to two student volunteers, a boy and a girl, who sit across the table from him separated from each other by a screen. Venkman is an associate professor but his rumpled suit and the manic gleam in his eyes indicate an underlying instability in his nature. However, while a little short on academic credentials, Venkman is long on confidence, charm and salesmanship.

这是我最喜欢的！作者写得太棒了。介绍人物的方式真是太棒了！乔尔和伊桑·科恩的《谋杀绿脚趾》：

This one’s my favorite! This writing is FANTASTIC. What a way to introduce a character! The Big Lebowski by Joel & Ethan Coen:

天色已晚，超市里几乎空无一人。我们在乳制品柜台旁跟踪一位穿着百慕大短裤、戴着太阳镜的四十多岁的男子。他就是 Dude。他那凌乱的外表和轻松的举止表明他是一个随和的人。

It is late, the supermarket all but deserted. We are tracking in on a fortyish man in Bermuda shorts and sunglasses at the dairy case. He is the Dude. His rumpled look and relaxed manner suggest a man in whom casualness runs deep.

场景

描述

Scene

Description

 

59. 你的语言很新颖！

59. You use novelistic language!

 

最快的提示就是“意识到”这个词。

The quickest tip is the word “realize.”

这个词看起来无害。就像白蚁一样，这是严重问题的征兆——小说写作。要格外小心，不要使用让读者陷入角色思维的语言。在大屏幕上，你看不到泰迪头上的灯泡：

Seems so innocuous, that little word. Like termites, it’s a sign of serious trouble — novelistic writing. Be monumentally careful not to use language that puts the reader in the character’s mind. On the big screen, you can’t see the light bulb over Teddy’s head:

泰迪看到弗雷迪很惊讶，并意识到自己已经好几年没见过他了。

Teddy is surprised to see Freddy, and realizes he hasn’t seen him in several years.

（您是否因为 Teddy 和 Freddy 这两个名字太相似而感到困惑？哈！现在您知道为什么读者讨厌编剧使用押韵或拼写相似的名字了！）

(Were you confused because the names Teddy and Freddy were so similar? Ha! Now you know why readers hate it when screenwriters use names that rhyme or are spelled alike!)

从三年级开始，在你的写作中，最自然不过的就是这样写：“苏珊怀念大学时光。”这在短篇小说中很管用。但在剧本中却不行。在电影中，我们无法像在小说中那样感受到人物的想法。我们只能看到他们做什么，听到他们说什么。我们看不到他们的想法！在散文中，很容易进入人物的内心——但不要这样做。如果摄像机看不到，你就写不出来了。

In your writing, since third grade, it’s been the most natural thing in the world to say, “Susan remembers with fond nostalgia the fun she had in college.” It works in a short story just fine. You can’t do it in a screenplay. In a movie, we can’t sense a character’s thoughts like we can in a novel. We only see what they do and hear what they say. We can’t see them think! In prose, it’s so easy to go into the character’s mind — but don’t. If the camera can’t see it, you can’t write it.

我们如何看待这两个“内部思考”过程？我们不知道。

How do we see these two “interior thought” processes? We don’t.

当客人意识到戒指丢失时，酒庄内传出了好奇的客人发出的噪音和紧张的谈话声。

NOISE and nervous chatter from the curious guests pour from the winery as the realization that the ring is missing sets in.

戴夫意识到卡罗琳实际上是马丁与泽克特隆星球的奎诺克公主的私生子。

Dave realizes that Carolyn is actually Martin’s love child with Princess Queenock of the planet Zectron.

对于一些读者来说，这是一大痛处。他们讨厌“进入角色的头脑”，如果你这样做，他们会讨厌你的剧本。

This is a major bête noire for some readers. They hate “getting inside the character’s head” and will loathe your script if you do it.

“假设”是另一个词，它提醒你已经进入了角色的头脑。

“Assume” is another word that alerts you to the fact you have entered the character’s head.

突然，她转向那道光亮。她猜想那人就是保罗。

Suddenly, she turns toward the light. She assumes it’s Paul.

让她说“保罗？”

Have her say, “Paul?”

你必须在屏幕上看到它，否则它就不存在。这很难做到。你必须严格训练自己，才能注意到自己是否已经越界进入小说写作。找出“假设”、“意识到”、“感觉”、“出现”和“思考”。摆脱它们。找到在纸上看到动作、人物、紧张和冲突的方法。让我们看看发生了什么。像无声电影一样写场景。

You have to see it onscreen, or it doesn’t exist. This is difficult to do. You must rigorously school yourself to notice when you’ve wandered across the line into novelistic writing. Search out “assume,” “realize,” “feels,” “appears,” and “think.” Get rid of them. Find ways to see the action, the character, the tension, and the conflict on the page. Show us what is going on. Write the scene like a silent movie.

这非常困难，但好处巨大。强迫自己创造一些时刻，通过角色的行为告诉读者发生了什么，而不是通过对话。当你回过头来添加一些对话时，你不需要太多。尤里卡！写得好！租一本《他们都笑了》，看看伟大的博格丹诺维奇在几乎没有对话的情况下能传达多少信息。或者看看《美丽城三重奏》，它没有对话。

This is extraordinarily difficult and of colossal benefit. Force yourself to create moments that tell the reader what’s going on by what the characters are doing, but not through dialogue. When you go back and add a smattering of dialogue, you won’t need much. Eureka! Great writing! Rent They All Laughed and see how much the great Bogdanovich is able to get across with next to no dialogue. Or look at The Triplets of Belleville, which has zero dialogue.

但是，亲爱的读者，不要绝望。

But, gentle reader, do not despair.

在让你对小说写作保持警惕并吓得魂飞胆丧之后，让我轻声细语地说，在小说中插入一点点人物的感受是半合法的。在《长日留痕》剧本中，艾玛·汤普森问起安东尼·霍普金斯正在读的书，我们被告知，“他感到受到威胁，她只是想接近他。”

Having put you on your guard and scared you silly about novelistic writing, let me softly whisper that it is sort of semi-legal to toss in a TEENSY LITTLE BIT of what characters are feeling. In The Remains of the Day screenplay, Emma Thompson asks about the book Anthony Hopkins is reading and we are told, “He feels threatened and she just wants to get close to him.”

时不时地，你可以给演员们讲一点心理学知识。但要适量。

From time to time, you may give a wee bit of psychology for the actors. Sparingly.

鲍勃和沃森中士交换了一下眼神。他们最好的士兵疯了吗？

Bob and Sgt. Watson exchange glances. Is their best soldier losing his mind?

当惊慌失措的难民围在他身边时，他拿出了卡特的录音机。他想把它扔掉。但他却按下了录音键。心碎。

As panicked REFUGEES swirl around him, he pulls out Carter’s tape recorder. Thinks about throwing it away. Presses the record button instead. Heartbroken.

这是我最喜欢的通过场景描述来表达人物情感的例子。这是我的一个学生写的。

Here’s my favorite example of telling a character’s emotions in scene description. One of my students wrote it.

马克的太浩湖

INT. MARK’S TAHOE

马克开车回家，耳边响起一首缓慢的情歌。他沿着高速公路疾驰，寻找任何能让他产生感觉的东西。

Mark is driving home as a slow love ballad plays. He speeds down the highway, looking for anything to make him feel anything.

小说写作。写一点或者不写。“不写”比较安全。就像跳伞一样。

Novelistic writing. Do it a little tiny bit or not at all. “Not at all” is safer. Just like, for example, parachute jumping.

60. 你在场景描述中毒害了“是”！

60. You poisoned your scene description with “to be”!

 

这是提高写作水平最有益（也是最简单）的方法之一。即使你不是一位出色的作家，失去“to be”也会让你看起来知道自己在做什么。

This is one of the most beneficial (and easiest) things you can do to improve your writing. Even if you’re not a great writer, losing “to be” will make you look like you know what you’re doing.

我五年级的老师 Hale 女士总是告诉我要使用“主动动词”。我从来都不知道她的意思。不过，我知道如何去掉“to be”。仔细检查每一行场景描述，如果其中有任何形式的动词“to be”，就将其重写为主动动词。

Mrs. Hale, my fifth grade teacher, always told me to use “active verbs.” I never had a clue what she meant. I do, however, understand how to get rid of “to be.” Go through every line of scene description, and if it has the verb “to be” in any form, rewrite it so it is active.

 

“是” 在第一页就向读者表明你不是一位经验丰富的作家，因为当你爬上成为威廉·戈德曼的阶梯时，“是” 是最先消失的东西之一。

“To be” signals the reader on page one that you aren’t an experienced writer, as “to be” is one of the first things to fall away as you climb the ladder toward becoming William Goldman.

戴夫跑向他的车。保险杠被胶带粘住了。

Dave runs to his car. The bumper’s being held on with duct tape.

戴夫跑向他的车。保险杠用胶带粘住。

Dave runs to his car. The bumper held on with duct tape.

在“你的剧本糟透了！”清单上的所有项目中，这是最简单的，并且具有最高的功率重量比。如果你遵循这个简单的规则，你的写作水平将会突飞猛进：

Of all the items on the Your Screenplay Sucks! checklist, this is the simplest and has the highest power-to-weight ratio. Your writing will improve by leaps and bounds if you follow this simple rule:

去掉“是”。

Get rid of “is.”

 

 

现在你知道了。

Now you know.

“Is” 并不是编剧经典中唯一值得称赞的词。

“Is” isn’t the only worty dird in the screenwriting canon.

61. 你还没有尽可能地删去“thes”和“thats”！

61. You haven’t cut as many “thes” and “thats” as possible!

 

如果读者看到到处都是“the”，他们就会知道你不是顶尖作家。“that”也是一样。

If a reader sees “the” all over everywhere, they’re going to know you’re not a top writer. Same with “that.”

键入“Ctrl F”或“Apple F”并搜索“the”和“that”，然后删除其中的许多单词。这样会使您的写作更加紧凑。

Type “Ctrl F” or “Apple F” and search out “the” and “that” and get rid of a lot of them. It will tighten up your writing.

亚历克斯只是低头看着，把蟹腿里的肉挤出来。

Alex just stares down and squeezes the meat out of a crab leg.

亚历克斯只是低头看着，并从蟹腿中挤出肉。

Alex just stares down and squeezes meat out of a crab leg.

这句话中有五次“the”。呃。

Here is one sentence with five instances of “the.” Ugh.

当船靠近海滩时，海浪开始在附近的礁石上冲击船头。

As the boat approaches the beach, the waves start breaking off the bow on the nearby reefs.

当船靠近海滩时，海浪开始冲击船头附近的珊瑚礁。

As the boat approaches the beach, waves start breaking off the bow on nearby reefs.

你想让我继续说下去吗？当然想！

Do you want me to go on? Of course you do!

正是他们夫妻俩的橡树力量、孩子们鼓舞人心的信件以及他哥哥的忠诚给了克劳斯未来旅程所需的力量。

It is their oak tree strength as a couple, the inspirational letters from his children, and his brother’s devotion that give Claus the strength he needs for the journey ahead.

我们看到艾布尔侦探正在偷听。

We see that Detective Able is eavesdropping.

 

“每当你想写“very”的时候，就用“damn”来代替；你的编辑会删除它，而你的文章就会恢复原样。”马克·吐温

“Substitute damn every time you’re inclined to write very; your editor will delete it and the writing will be just as it should be.” Mark Twain

编剧的七宗罪

Seven Deadly Sins of Screenwriting

 

使用计算机中的“查找”（Ctrl F 或 Apple F）功能，以任何您找到的形式追踪这些单词。丢失它们或更改它们将增强您的工作能力。

Using Find (Ctrl F or Apple F) in your computer, chase down these words in any form you find them. Losing them or changing them will strengthen your work.

“查找”空间应该只查找您要查找的单词，而不是剧本中的每个“是”。

“Find” space is space should find only the word you’re looking for, not every “is” in your screenplay.

是

is

他咧嘴笑着——变得——他咧嘴笑着。

He is grinning — becomes — He grins.

是

are

犯人正在唱歌剧——犯人正在唱歌剧。

The convicts are singing opera — The convicts sing opera.

这

the

纳乔 (Nacho) 飞快地离开了小镇。—— 纳乔 (Nacho) 飞快地离开了小镇。

Nacho hightails it out of the town — Nacho hightails it out of town.

那

that

拉尔夫看不出来她是法国人——拉尔夫看不出来她是法国人。

Ralph can’t tell that she’s French — Ralph can’t tell she’s French.

然后

then

她笑了。然后她看着爱丽丝——她笑了。她看着爱丽丝。

She laughs. She then looks at Alice — She laughs. She looks at Alice.

走

walk

Tika 沿着走廊走去 — Tika 沿着走廊走去。

Tika walks down the hall — Tika prisses down the hall.

坐

sit

坐在扑克牌桌旁，Doc 发牌 — 在扑克牌桌旁，Doc 发牌。

Sitting at the poker table, Doc deals the cards — At the poker table, Doc deals.

站立

stand

外科医生站在手术台前工作——在手术台上，外科医生工作。

The surgeon stands at the operating table and works — At the operating table, the surgeon works.

看

look

谢丽尔正在看着斯蒂芬妮——谢丽尔研究斯蒂芬妮。

Cheryl is looking at Stephanie — Cheryl studies Stephanie.

只是

just

我真的累坏了——我真的累坏了。

I am just totally exhausted — I am totally exhausted.

的

of the

汤姆坐在商场入口处。— 汤姆坐在商场入口处。

Tom sits by the entrance of the mall — Tom sits by the mall entrance.

开始

begin

磁带开始播放 — 磁带播放。

The tape begins playing — The tape plays.

开始

start

她开始向书房走去——她向书房走去。

She starts moving toward the den — She moves toward the den.

真的

really

贝蒂确实漂亮——贝蒂像一把两美元的手枪一样性感，大摇大摆地走了进来。

Betty is really pretty — Betty, hot as a two-dollar pistol, struts in.

非常

very

孩子们唱一首非常古老的歌曲——孩子们唱一首传统歌曲。（“非常”表示后面的单词很弱）

The kids sing a very old song — The kids sing a traditional song. (“very” means the following word is weak)

利

ly

（如在副词末尾！）搜索ly space 也搜索ly。和ly，因为ly space 不会在句子末尾找到副词，等等。小学作家对副词很着迷。你现在已经过了那个阶段。尽量少用它们。如果有的话。

(as on the end of an adverb!) search for lyspace Also search for ly. and ly, as lyspace will not find an adverb at the end of a sentence, etc. Grade school writers go wild over adverbs. You’re past that now. Use them, um, sparingly. If at all.

无论你写什么，只要改变这些词，结果就会更加紧密和强大。

Change these words in whatever you write and the results will be tighter and stronger.

好吧，这是 16 宗罪。所以起诉我吧。

Okay, it’s 16 deadly sins. So sue me.

62. 你没有把最重要的词放在句子的末尾！

62. You don’t put the most important word at the end of the sentence!

 

提高写作水平的简单规则：将最重要的单词放在句子末尾。将最重要的句子放在段落末尾。

Simple rules for better writing: Most important word at the end of the sentence. Most important sentence at the end of the paragraph.

我已经听到斧头的呼啸声了。

I could hear the whistle of the axe already.

我已经听到了斧头的呼啸声。

I could already hear the whistle of the axe.

句子的力量在于结尾。最后一个词。当句子正确表达时，你可以感受到它。哎呀！就像每个笑话一样。妙语在结尾，妙语是笑话的最后一个词。在你听到最后一个词之前，这个笑话并不好笑！

The power in a sentence comes at the end. The last word. You can feel it when the sentence is done correctly. Ooompf! It’s like every joke. The punch line is at the end, and the punch word is the last word of the joke. Until you hear the last word, the joke’s not funny!

让读者满怀期待地读到最后……最后一个字——这就是关键所在。以下是初稿：

Leave your reader leaning forward in anticipation until the very… last… word — that’s where the punch comes. Here’s the first draft:

菲茨比根先生

MR. FITZBIGGON

好了。就这样。你可以期待快速

Well. That’s all. You may expect swift

代表航空公司进行诉讼。

litigation on behalf of the airline.

现在，重写它。

Now, rewrite it.

菲茨比根先生

MR. FITZBIGGON

好了。就这些。代表

Well. That’s all. On behalf of the

航空公司，您可能会遇到迅速的诉讼。

airline, you may expect swift litigation.

这个故事最近在互联网上流传。请注意，你不知道接下来会发生什么，直到最后一个字。你想知道故事的发展方向，期待结局，然后他们给你一个火箭助推器！

This story had a recent run on the Internet. Notice how you don’t know what’s going to happen, literally until the very last word. You’re wondering where the story’s headed, anticipating the finish, and then they give you the socko rocket boost!

 

罗伯特的父亲病重丧偶，他要继承一大笔财产，因此他决定找个女人陪他共享。于是他去了一家单身酒吧，四处寻觅，终于发现了一个美貌让他惊叹不已的女人。“现在，我只是一个普通人，”他走到她面前说道，“但一两个月内，我父亲就会去世。到时候我将继承 2000 多万美元。”这个女人和罗伯特一起回家，四天后，她成了他的继母。

Due to inherit a fortune when his sickly, widower father dies, Robert decided he needed a woman to enjoy it with. So he went to a singles bar and he searched until he spotted a woman whose beauty took his breath away. “Right now, I’m just an ordinary man,” he said, walking up to her, “but within a month or two, my father will pass on. Then I will inherit over 20 million dollars.” The woman went home with Robert, and four days later she became his stepmother.

如果你有一个朋友不会讲笑话，那不是因为他或她不会讲笑话，而是因为他们记不住笑点。最有可能是因为他们记不住笑点中的词序。

If you have a friend who can’t tell a joke, it’s not because he or she can’t tell a joke, it’s because they can’t remember the punch line. And it’s most likely because they can’t remember the word order in the punch line.

一个不雅的笑话说明了这一点：

An off-color joke illustrates this point:

 

夫妻性交分为哪三个阶段？

整屋性交。卧室性交。还有走廊性交。

走廊性交就是你们撞到一起然后说“操你妈的。”

What are the three stages of marital intercourse?

Whole house sex. Bedroom sex. And hallway sex.

Hallway sex is where you bump into each other and say, “Fuck you.”

好吧，这不是世界上最棒的笑话，但如果你搞砸了笑点，那就一点也不好笑了。有一次，一个朋友走过来，迫不及待地想给我讲一个笑话：

Okay, it’s not the greatest joke on earth, but if you mess up the punch line it’s not funny at all. Once, a friend came up, busting to lay one on me:

 

“你听说过，你听说过婚姻性交的三个阶段吗？！”

“没有，告诉我。”

“嗯，有整间房子里的性爱，有卧室里的性爱，还有走廊里的性爱。”戏剧性的停顿。“走廊里的性爱就是你们撞到一起时说‘去你妈的’。”

“Didja hear, didja hear about the three stages of marital intercourse?!”

“No, tell me.”

“Well, there’s whole house sex, and there’s bedroom sex and then there’s hallway sex.” Dramatic pause. “Hallway sex is where you say ‘Fuck you’ when you bump into each other.”

它就像一条死狗一样躺在阳光下，现在我不再回应它的电话。

It lay there like a dead dog in the sun and now I don’t return his calls.

63. 你在场景描述中描述对话！

63. You describe dialogue in scene description!

 

如果有人在说话，除非是背景音乐，否则就写下对话。

If someone is talking, unless it’s background walla, write the dialogue.

一个男孩抓住恶霸的脖子，用头撞他，弄得他鼻子流血。恶霸开始哭喊着让他们停下来。

One boy grabs the Bully by the neck and head butts him, bloodying his nose. The Bully starts crying for them to stop.

你必须写出恶霸的对话。

You have to write the Bully’s dialogue.

这是背景墙。描述一下还可以：

This is background walla. It’s okay in description:

暴徒们涌向工厂大门，对着工贼发出嚎叫和尖叫。

The RIOTERS surge toward the factory gates, YOWLING and SCREECHING at the scabs.

这不是华拉。认真写她的对话。

This is not walla. Buckle down and write her dialogue.

这个讨厌的哥特小子 (Bratty Goth Kid) 不会停止胡言乱语。

The Bratty Goth Kid won’t stop dishing some lip.

也不要这样做（并且在你这样做的时候，运行你的拼写检查！）：

Don’t do this, either (and while you’re at it, run your spellcheck!):

两个九岁的双胞胎男孩，奥斯汀和克里斯蒂安，像旋转舞者一样冲进厨房。多蒂拦住他们，让他们把里脊肉端进餐厅。

Two nine-year-old twin boys, AUSTIN and CHRISTIAN, rush in the kitchen like whirrling dervishes. Dottie stops them and tells them to bring the tenderloin into the dining room.

如果演员要说这句话，就把对话写下来。

If an actor is going to say it, write the dialogue.

一名警察介入了骚乱。他是身着巡警服的利奥。戴尔叫利奥过来检查一个蓝色手提箱里的东西。戴尔举着几袋海洛因。

A policeman comes into the commotion. It’s Leo dressed as a beat cop. Dale calls Leo over to inspect the contents of a blue suitcase. Dale holds up bags of heroin.

重写后变为：

Rewritten, this becomes:

一名警察闯入骚乱现场。他是装扮成巡警的利奥。

A policeman comes into the commotion. It’s Leo dressed as a beat cop.

戴尔

DALE

利奥！把这个蓝色行李箱拿上来！

Leo! Get a load of this blue suitcase!

戴尔举着几袋海洛因。

Dale holds up bags of heroin.

作者本可以写“戴尔招手让利奥过来检查一个蓝色手提箱里的东西”，这样就没问题了。不会暗示任何对话。

The writer could have written “Dale waves Leo over to inspect the contents of a blue suitcase,” and it would have been fine. No dialogue would have been implied.

这是“不要在场景描述中加入对话”和“不要在场景描述中告诉我们，然后在对话中再次告诉我们”的组合。

This is a combination of “don’t put dialogue in scene description,” and “don’t tell us in scene description and then again in dialogue.”

黑色继续……格里高利圣咏……火红的字句开始在屏幕上书写。一个带有法国口音的男人开始说话，仿佛在朗读这些字句。

BLACK CONTINUES... GREGORIAN CHANT... Flaming words begin writing themselves across screen. A MAN’S VOICE with a French Accent begins speaking, as if reading them.

塞隆（画外音）

THERON (V.O.)



1677 年 10 月 4 日。英诺森七世侄子塞隆的回忆录，第四章：

关于圣弗朗西斯·阿西西。

October 4, 1677. The memoirs of Theron,

nephew of Innocent VII, Chapter Four:

Concerning St. Francis of Assisi.

删除场景描述的最后一句话。将（法语口音）放在括号中并继续。最后，将“VII”改为演员可以说的单词。

Cut the last sentence of scene description. Put (French accent) in a parenthetical and press on. Finally, change “VII” to a word an actor can say.

黑色继续……格里高利圣咏……火焰般的文字开始在屏幕上书写……一个男人的声音读着它们。

BLACK CONTINUES... GREGORIAN CHANT... Flaming words begin writing themselves across screen... a MAN’S VOICE reads them.

塞隆（画外音）

THERON (V.O.)

（法国口音）

(French accent)



1677 年 10 月 4 日。英诺森七世侄子塞隆的回忆录，

第四章：关于圣弗朗西斯·德·阿西西。

October 4, 1677. The memoirs of Theron,

nephew of Innocent the Seventh, Chapter

Four: Concerning St. Francis of Assisi.

64. 你在场景描述中没有注意图像顺序！

64. You have not paid attention to image order in scene description!

 

当有人阅读您的场景描述时，他们会在脑海中创建图像。一个又一个图像浮现在他们的脑海中，按照他们阅读的顺序讲述您的故事。您必须按照正确的顺序向他们提供，否则他们不会以您想象的方式看待它。

As someone reads your scene description, they create images in their mind. Image after image pops into their head, telling your story — in the order that they read it. You have to give it to them in the right order, or they won’t see it the way you imagine.

以下是一个图像顺序混乱的例子：“美国独立战争期间，安德鲁·杰克逊被英国士兵抓获并打伤。”这是否意味着他们抓住了他，给他戴上手铐，然后开枪打死了他？可能不是。

Here’s an example of confusing image order: “During the American Revolution, Andrew Jackson was captured and wounded by British soldiers.” Does that mean they grabbed him, handcuffed him, and then shot him? Probably not.

劳拉和达奇在电子游戏厅里驾驶巨型卡车比赛。

Laura and Dutch race monster trucks at a video arcade.

当读者在句子中逐个查看图像时，它在读者脑​​海中的呈现方式如下：

Here’s how it appears in the reader’s mind as he moves image by image through the sentence:

劳拉和达奇驾驶怪物卡车 哇，劳拉和她的爷爷什么时候买怪物卡车了？！我以为他们只赛马……哦，等等，现在我明白了……在电子游戏厅。我明白了。终于。哎呀。

Laura and Dutch race monster trucks WOW, WHEN DID LAURA AND HER GRANDPA BUY MONSTER TRUCKS?! I THOUGHT THEY ONLY RACED HORSES... OH, WAIT, NOW I SEE... at a video arcade. I GET IT. FINALLY. OOPSIE.

这样说吧：

Say it this way:

在电子游戏厅里，劳拉和达奇驾驶巨型卡车进行比赛。

At a video arcade, Laura and Dutch race monster trucks.

我想到读者，站在相机旁边，脚站在画面边缘，看着故事一幅又一幅地展开。

I think about the reader, standing beside the camera, their feet on the edge of the frame, watching the story unfold, image after image.

街道

THE STREET

当休伊直升机飞到树梢高度时，惊慌失措的越南人从支柱上跳下来。

Frantic Vietnamese drop from the struts as the Huey reaches treetop height.

第一张图片是越南人从直升机支柱上跳下。但我们不知道任何可以让我们将该图片放在上下文中的信息。重新排列后，它变得更有意义了。

The first image is of Vietnamese dropping from helicopter struts. But we don’t know anything that allows us to place that image in context. After rearranging, it makes better sense.

街道

THE STREET

当休伊直升机飞到树梢高度时，惊慌失措的越南人从支柱上跳了下来。

As the Huey reaches treetop height, frantic Vietnamese drop from the struts.

如果我们不知道直升机已经到达树梢高度，过早地谈论人员从支柱上掉下来会引起混淆。

If we don’t know a helicopter has reached treetop height, it’s confusing to prematurely talk about people dropping from the struts.

发现这个问题的最好方法就是大声朗读你的作品！

The best way to unearth this problem is to read your work out loud!

这也算在 slugline 中。告诉我们我们需要知道什么，因为我们需要看到它。这是我犯的一个错误。

This counts in sluglines too. Tell us what we need to know as we need to see it. Here’s a mistake I made.

原始台词：

Original slugline:

外部：混乱的街道 - 春禄（“天鹅锁”）之夜

EXT. CHAOTIC STREET - XUAN LOC (“SWAN LOCK”) NIGHT

难民们川流不息。工作人员迅速准备就绪。记者埃伦三十多岁，精力充沛，身体健康，是一名专业记者。一名工作人员图是一名年轻的越南男子。

REFUGEES stream past. The CREW rapidly sets up, The reporter, ELLEN, exuberant, healthy, in her thirties, is a total pro. One crew member, TU, is a young Vietnamese man.

同一页上还有一条说明：

And a slugline on the same page:

外景，美国海军陆战队 - 西贡下午

EXT. U.S. MARINE - SAIGON AFTERNOON

一名年轻的黑人海军陆战队警卫戴着白色帽子，眼睛一眨不眨地向外张望。他热得满头大汗。

A young black MARINE GUARD looks out unblinking from under his white cap. He sweats with the heat.

呃，愚蠢。

Uhh, stupid.

我应该先拍广角镜头，然后再拍特写镜头。告诉我们我们在春禄，然后说这是一条拥挤的街道。告诉我们我们在西贡，然后告诉我们我们看到的是一名海军陆战队员。

I should have had the wide shot first, then the close up. Tell us we’re in Xuan Loc and then say it’s a crowded street. Tell us we’re in Saigon, then tell us we’re looking at a Marine.

外部 XUAN LOC（“天鹅锁”）- 混乱的街夜

EXT. XUAN LOC (“SWAN LOCK”) - CHAOTIC STREET NIGHT

难民们川流不息。工作人员迅速准备就绪。记者埃伦三十多岁，精力充沛，身体健康，是一名专业记者。一名工作人员图是一名年轻的越南男子。

REFUGEES stream past. The CREW rapidly sets up, The reporter, ELLEN, exuberant, healthy, in her thirties, is a total pro. One crew member, TU, is a young Vietnamese man.

并且，在同一页上：

And, on the same page:

外景，西贡，美国海军陆战队下午

EXT. SAIGON - U.S. MARINE AFTERNOON

一名戴着白色帽子的年轻黑人海军陆战队警卫目不转睛地向外张望。他热得满头大汗。

A young black MARINE GUARD looks out unblinking from underhis white cap. He sweats with the heat.

这样更有意义，而且每一点都有帮助。

Makes more sense this way, and every little bit helps.

请记住，场景描述只是摄像机看到的内容。不要说“一个装满一叠纸的马尼拉信封”，直到他打开信封，你向摄像机透露里面是一叠纸。你可以说“一个鼓鼓囊囊的信封”，但除非摄像机能看到信封，否则你无法告诉我们里面是什么。

Remember, scene description is only what the camera sees. Don’t say “a manila envelope filled with a stack of papers” until he opens it and you reveal to the camera that it’s a stack of papers. You can say “a bulging envelope,” but you can’t tell us what’s inside unless the camera can see it.

以下是错误图像顺序的示例：

Here is an example of incorrect image order:

外部人行道日

EXT. SIDEWALK DAY

美国哥特风格的 Gary 和 SOD SQUAD 出现在广告牌上，上面写着“有草吗？Grassguru.com ”。

American Gothic-like Gary and the SOD SQUAD are on a billboard reading, “Got Grass? Grassguru.com”.

这里有有趣的写作问题。当你重读你写的内容时，你必须记住读者。他们看到的第一个单词将是他们脑海中浮现的第一个画面。“美国哥特式，加里”让我想象加里正拿着干草叉笔直地站在人行道上。然后我看到了“草皮队”这个词。我想他正站在一群人旁边，他们都在人行道上。然后，也只有那时，我才看到“广告牌”这个词。突然间，我不得不重新整理脑海中的画面。这很令人困惑。你必须意识到你为读者描绘的画面。读者只能按照你给出的顺序获取信息。

Interesting writing problem here. When you re-read what you have written, you have to keep the readers in mind. The first words they see will be the first picture they put in their head. “American Gothic-like, Gary” makes me imagine that Gary is standing up straight on the sidewalk with a pitchfork. Then I see the words “sod squad.” I am thinking he is standing next to a bunch of people, all of them on the sidewalk. Then, and only then, do I see the word “billboard.” Suddenly, I have to rearrange the picture in my mind. This is confusing. You must be aware of the picture you’re creating for the reader. The reader can only get information in the order you give it.

外部人行道日

EXT. SIDEWALK DAY

在他们上方高处的广告牌上，Gary 和 SOD SQUAD 的广告像美国哥特式的一样。“有草吗？Grassguru.com。”

High above them, on a billboard, Gary and the SOD SQUAD, American Gothic-like. “Got Grass? Grassguru.com.”

最后的例子：

Final example:

弗朗西斯滚开后，木桩撞到了岩石地面。

The stake hits the rock floor as Francis rolls out of the way.

弗朗西斯必须先滚开，然后木桩才能落地。不要让我们想象木桩落地，然后试图想象弗朗西斯滚开。如果木桩落地了，他为什么还要滚到任何地方呢？

Francis has to roll out of the way FIRST. Then the stake can hit the floor. Don’t make us imagine the stake hitting the floor and then try to conjure up Francis rolling out of its path. If it’s hit the floor, why does he have to roll anywhere?

图片顺序。这很重要！

Image order. It matters!

再一次，但这不是最后一次，大声朗读你的东西！

Again, and not for the last time, read your stuff out loud!

65. 你还没有将场景描述删减到最精简的部分！

65. You haven’t cut scene description to the bone!

 

如果说编剧更接近诗歌而非小说写作（确实如此），那么伟大的编剧就与俳句相近。你的新个人神应该是沃尔特·希尔，他是“少即是多”的禅宗大师，在文字方面很有造诣。他写了《艰难时世》、《48 小时》和《异形》的一大段。

If screenwriting is closer to poetry than it is to novel writing (it is), then great screenwriting is next door to haiku. Your new personal deity should be Walter Hill, the Zen master of “less is more” in the words-on-the-page department. He wrote Hard Times, 48 Hrs, and a goodly chunk of Alien.

这是我对 Walter Hill 风格的尝试。几乎无需多言。每个人都可以朝着这个极简主义的方向迈出一大步。

Here’s my stab at the Walter Hill style. Almost no words. Everybody can take a giant step in this minimalist direction.

停放车辆的角度

ANGLE ON PARKED CAR

黑暗的内饰。

Dark interior.

一支香烟闪闪发光。

A cigarette glows.

安全而安静，贝克·马图奇微笑着。

Safe and quiet, Bake Martucci smiles.

后座上是 Mutt Masso。

In the back seat, Mutt Masso.

马特把一个纸袋递给一位瘦瘦的黑人。

Mutt gives a paper sack to a SKINNY BLACK MAN.

 

 

墓地日

EXT. CEMETERY DAY

波特的田野。可悲。

Potter’s Field. Pathetic.

传教士和哀悼者唱浸信会赞美诗。

PREACHER and MOURNERS sing a Baptist HYMN.

T-Money 的家人。他的妈妈哭了。

T-Money’s FAMILY. His mom cries.

瓦妮莎和艾斯利在一起。艾斯利真的很伤心。

Vanessa with Isley. Isley’s real hurt.

NOD 看着，感到悲伤但又厌恶。

N.O.D. looks on, sad, but disgusted.

孩子们穿着印有 T-Money 脸的 T 恤。

Kids wearing tee shirts with T-Money’s face.

在背景中，白色政客在电视摄像机前若隐若现。

In b.g., WHITE POLITICO oozes for a TV camera.

赞美诗渐渐结束。

The hymn grinds to a close.

牧师

PREACHER

现在让我们花一点时间来缅怀所有

身陷囹圄的家人。

Let us now take a moment to remember all of

our family members who are in jail.

艾斯利引起了 NOD 的注意。

Isley catches N.O.D.’s eye.

每个人都祈祷。

Everyone prays.

 

 

外部运河街日

EXT. CANAL STREET DAY

巴士停了下来。

Bus pulls up.

艾斯利下车了。忧心忡忡。

Isley gets off. Careworn.

 

 

外部布罗德莫尔 - 小房子日

EXT. BROADMOOR - SMALL HOUSE DAY

整洁的房屋、草坪。

Tidy house, lawn.

艾斯利拿起报纸和邮件。

Isley picks up the paper and mail.

斗牛犬发现艾斯利。警报。

Pit bull spots Isley. Alert.

艾斯利停了下来。

Isley stops.

摊牌。

Showdown.

斗牛犬凶猛地向前走去......然后摇着屁股。

Pit bull steps forward, fierce... then wags his butt off.

艾斯利

ISLEY

嘿，祖鲁。你在照顾我妈妈吗，

姑娘？

Hey, Zulu. You lookin’ after my momma,

girl?

艾斯利被舔死了。

Isley is licked to death.

谨慎选择词语，只使用精确的词语。想象一下你的铅笔重 50 磅，你不愿意使用它。这并不像看起来那么容易，但值得一试。

Choose your words with extreme care and use only the exact precise ones. Imagine your pencil weighs 50 pounds, and be reluctant to use it. It’s not as easy as it looks, but it’s well worth trying.

如果您在www.script-o-rama.com上阅读《异形》剧本并同时观看 DVD，您会发现剧本与电影一模一样，但文字却很少，这真是令人着迷。这是好莱坞读者的理想页面。他脑海中的动作清晰，几乎没有文字！

If you read the Alien screenplay at www.script-o-rama.com and watch the DVD at the same time, it’s fascinating how the script is EXACTLY like the movie, but with few words. This is the ideal page for the Hollywood reader. Clear action in his head and almost no words!

Terse 很好。Blabby 则很糟糕。

Terse is good. Blabby is, well, doom.

当你去一个新地方时，用一个简介和一点场景描述来介绍它，然后继续。不要写冗长、密集、充满室内装饰的细节。那是小说家的活儿。在脑海中创建一个形象，然后继续下去。这是我最喜欢的场景描述：

When you go to a new location, introduce it with a slugline and a bit of scene description, and then get on with it. Do not go into lengthy, dense, interior decoration–laden detail. That’s for novelists. Create an image in our mind and press on. This is my all time favorite scene description:

内景，鲍勃的公寓之夜

INT. BOB’S APARTMENT NIGHT

一间糟糕的房间。

A shitty room.

它为读者提供了即时的画面。你的画面和我的画面不会相同，但或多或​​少，我们都能理解。而且我们能经济地理解。我不记得我第一次在哪里读到这句话，但我希望我写下来。

It makes an instant picture for the reader. Your picture and my picture will not be the same, but more or less, we get it. And we get it economically. I don’t remember where I read that the first time, but I wish I’d written it.

然而，如果他们必须知道一些事情，你就必须告诉他们。

If, however, there is something they must know, you have to tell them.

内景，鲍勃的公寓之夜

INT. BOB’S APARTMENT NIGHT

一间肮脏的房间。沙发后面有九个饥饿的火星人。

A shitty room. Behind the sofa, nine HUNGRY MARTIANS.

每段最多五行场景描述。四行更好。很幼稚，不是吗？好莱坞也是如此。克利夫·霍林斯沃思和阿基瓦·高斯曼的《铁拳男人》中的场景描述段落只有两行。再也没有了。天哪，读起来真快！

Five lines of scene description, per paragraph, maximum. Four is better. Childish, isn’t it? So is Hollywood. Scene description paragraphs in Cinderella Man by Cliff Hollingsworth and Akiva Goldsman are two lines long. Never more. Boy, is that a quick read!

长段落会让我们错过重要内容。更糟糕的是，读者往往会跳过它们。

Long paragraphs make us miss the important stuff. Also, and worse, readers tend to skip them.

房间里还有其他椅子，但康纳独自坐着。他在电脑上打字，膝盖上放着一堆文件。他看着窗外草坪上休息的人们。一对对情侣，其中一些人在睡觉。他叹了口气。他的生活单调乏味。他的电话响了，他带着热情的微笑接了电话。

There are other chairs in the room, but Conner sits alone. He types on the computer with a pile of papers in his lap for filing. He looks out the window at PEOPLE relaxing on the lawn. Couples, some of them sleeping. He sighs. The humdrum of his life. His phone RINGS, he answers with an enthusiastic smile.

描述太多了。第一次读的时候，我错过了他电话响的部分。把段落分成几个短小的部分，每个部分都有自己的意义。第一段是关于他破旧的办公室的世界。第二段通过讨论完全不同的东西来推动故事的发展。因为了解电话响对我们来说至关重要，所以给它一个单独的段落。

That’s a lot of description. First time I read it, I missed the part about his phone ringing. Bust up paragraphs into shorter chunks that have their own meaning. The first paragraph becomes about the world of his ratty office. The second paragraph moves the story forward by discussing something completely different. As it’s crucial for us to understand that the phone rings, give it its own paragraph.

房间里还有其他椅子，但康纳独自坐着。他在电脑上打字，膝盖上放着一堆文件。他看着窗外草坪上休息的人们。一对对情侣，其中一些人在睡觉。他叹了口气。他的生活真是单调乏味。

There are other chairs in the room, but Conner sits alone. He types on the computer with a pile of papers in his lap for filing. He looks out the window at PEOPLE relaxing on the lawn. Couples, some of them sleeping. He sighs. The humdrum of his life.

他的电话响了，他带着热情的微笑接了电话。

His phone RINGS, he answers with an enthusiastic smile.

瞧，这不是更好吗？遗憾的是，它更长了，但我们生活在一个不完美的世界里。

See, isn’t that better? Sadly, it’s longer, but we live in an imperfect world.

你的场景描述必须用尽可能少的词语传达你想要的含义。

Your scene description must convey the meaning you want with as few words as possible.

吉米从后视镜中看到一辆警车紧跟在他身后，警灯闪烁。

In his rearview mirror, Jimmy sees a cop car, lights blazing, right behind him.

吉米在后视镜中看到一辆警车，车灯闪烁。

Jimmy sees a cop car, lights blazing, in his rearview.

我们仍然能理解。速度更快。我们看到了更好的图像，而且阅读时间更短。这是初稿句子。

We still get it. It’s quicker. We see a better image that takes less time to read. Here’s a first draft sentence.

草坪上散落着啤酒瓶和卷起的“滑梯”。

The lawn has beer bottles and a rolled up “Slip n’ Slide” scattered about.

这将变成：

This becomes:

草坪上散落着啤酒瓶和卷起的“滑梯”。

Beer bottles and a rolled up “Slip n’ Slide” scattered about the lawn.

一个更强有力的句子。以一个更好的词结尾，而且，嘿！它更短了！第三稿对它进行了进一步的改进：

A stronger sentence. Ends on a better word, and, hey!, it’s shorter! The third draft improves it even more:

草坪上散落着……啤酒瓶和卷起的“滑梯”。

Scattered about the lawn... beer bottles and a rolled up “Slip n’ Slide.”

删减内容以加快阅读速度，并让读者理解你想要表达的意思。不要用堆积如山的文字来掩盖图片的含义。你不再是按磅领工资的英语专业学生了。想想极简主义。记住，除非读者是你的男朋友，否则他一开始并不想读你的材料，所以尽量让它变得轻松。页面上有空白=读者会继续读下去。

Cut for the speed of the read as well as the reader’s understanding of what you’re trying to get across. Don’t hide the meaning of your image by piling on tons of words. You’re no longer an English major, getting paid by the pound. Think minimalism. Remember, unless the reader is your boyfriend, he doesn’t really want to read your material in the first place, so make it as painless as possible. White space on the page = reader keeps going.

您是否尽可能多地保存了线路？

Have you saved a line as often as you can?

吉米放慢车速，驶入右侧车道。警察加速驶过。

Jimmy slows down and pulls one lane to the right. The copspeeds by.

吉米放慢车速并靠边停车。警察加速驶过。

Jimmy slows and pulls over. The cop speeds by.

记住读者，让整个剧本尽可能紧凑，记住页数。浏览整个剧本，看看你是否能找出一两个词并省掉一行。

Remembering the reader, make the entire script as tight as possible, and, remember your page count. Go through the entire script and see if you can pull up one or two words and save a line.

塞雷娜

SERENA

我见过你的母亲；她

看起来不像是那种

类型。

I’ve met your mother; she

doesn’t really seem like the

type.

康纳

CONNER

她知道她的观点

在主流

资产阶级社会中不受欢迎。她害怕遭到

报复。

She knows her views are not

welcome in the mainstream,

bourgeois society. She fears

reprisals.

你可以用 Final Draft 来作弊，提取最后一个单词，然后保存一行！耶！

You can cheat with Final Draft, pull up that last word, and save a line! Yee ha!

将光标放在“她”上，点击并按住页面顶部的小本垒板形状的东西。将出现一条垂直线。将其向右滑动。该对话块的边距将变宽。将“欢迎”向上移动，即可节省一行。它只比实际边距多了一个空格，而且没有人会注意。但是你，聪明的家伙，省了一行！呼呼。在对话的下一部分重复一遍。

Put the cursor at “she” and click and hold on the little home-plate-shaped-thing at the top of the page. A vertical line will appear. Slide it to the right. The margin for that chunk of dialogue will widen. Move up “welcome” and you save a line. It’s only stretched one space past the actual margin, and no one will notice. But you, clever chap, saved a line! Wheeee. Do it again for the next side of dialogue.

塞雷娜

SERENA

我见过你的母亲；她

看起来不像是那种类型。

I’ve met your mother; she doesn’t

really seem like the type.

康纳

CONNER



她知道她的观点在主流资产阶级社会中不受欢迎

。她害怕遭到报复。

She knows her views are not welcome

in the mainstream, bourgeois

society. She fears reprisals.

保存一行 55 次，就等于保存了一页！这很可悲，我知道，但这就是你选择的职业。

Save a line 55 times and you save a page! Pathetic, I know, but this is the career you’ve chosen.

露西皱起眉头，收拾好切好的水果片，沿着走廊走去。

Lucy frowns, packs the sliced fruit pieces, heads down hallway.

保安人员

SECURITY OFFICER

没关系。他喜欢吃切片的东西

。

It’s okay. He likes things sliced

up.

它也适用于场景描述。拉开边距，没人会注意到——耶！

It also works for scene description. Pull the margins over and no one will notice — yee ha!

露西皱起眉头，重新包装切好的水果片，沿着走廊走下去。

Lucy frowns, re-packs the sliced up fruit pieces, heads down hallway.

保安人员

SECURITY OFFICER

没关系。他喜欢吃切片的东西。

It’s okay. He likes things sliced up.

为什么要削减“她的权力”？因为，如果福斯特曼博士能做到，那她就有权力这么做！不要成为多余的人。

Why cut “in her power?” Because, if Dr. Forstman can do it at all, it’s in her power! Don’t be redundant.

从现在开始，福斯特曼博士将尽其所能阻挠沃尔特。

From here on in, Dr. Forstman will do anything in her power to obstruct Walter.

从现在开始，福斯特曼博士会尽一切努力阻挠沃尔特。

From here on in, Dr. Forstman will do anything to obstruct Walter.

不要重复告诉我们同样的事情（哈！）。

And don’t tell us the same thing twice (ha!).

她呕吐起来，吐在肖恩的腿上。

She heaves: throwing up in Sean’s lap.

她在肖恩的腿上起伏。

She heaves in Sean’s lap.

“失败”的意思是“未能履行”。

“Failing” means “failing to perform.”

正当看上去可以正常工作时，计算机却出现故障。

Just when it looks like it will work the computer fails to perform.

正当计算机看似可以正常工作时，它却出现故障。

Just when it appears to work, the computer fails.

这个很有意思。你能猜出为什么我在两个句子之间加了“as”吗？这与意义的清晰度和语言创造的形象有关。这是挑剔的东西，但你要很多钱，所以你最好挑剔到极致。为什么那里有“as”？

This one is interesting. Can you guess why I added the “as” between the two sentences? It has to do with clarity of meaning and the image the language creates. This is picky, picky stuff, but you’re asking for tons of money, so you’d best be a nitpicker to the extreme. Why is the “as” there?

十吨瓦砾倒塌。沃尔特和他的团队努力爬上地面，但关键文物却被砸成了粉末。

Ten tons of rubble collapse. Walter and his team claw their way to the surface, but the crucial artifacts are smashed to powder.

当沃尔特和他的团队努力爬到地面时，十吨瓦砾倒塌了，但关键的文物却被砸成了粉末。

Ten tons of rubble collapse as Walter and his team claw their way to the surface, but the crucial artifacts are smashed to powder.

我读到第五遍才发现这个，但它仍然是错的。如果天花板塌了，沃尔特和他的团队就会被砸得粉碎。如果他被压扁了，他怎么能爬上去呢？加上“as”会使天花板掉落和沃尔特爬梯子这两个动作同时发生。如果它们同时发生，印第安纳琼斯就会安全地爬到顶部！挑剔，是的。没错，也是。

I only found this on about the fifth read, but it’s still wrong. If the ceiling collapses, it will to smash Walter and his team to smithereens. How can he climb if he’s squished? Putting the “as” there makes the two actions, ceiling falling and Walter climbing the ladder, simultaneous. If they’re happening at the same time, Indiana Jones makes it to the top without dying! Picky, yes. True, also yes.

因此，通常越短越好。

So, shorter is generally better.

我们开始听到男人和女人做爱的声音。

We begin to hear the sounds of a man and woman making love.

我们开始听到男人和女人做爱的声音。

We begin to hear a man and woman making love.

我们开始听到做爱的声音。

We begin to hear lovemaking.

我们听到了做爱的声音。

We hear lovemaking.

听到“咔”的一声。

咔。

A CLICK is heard.

CLICK.

山姆吃鸡蛋就像猪一样。他狼吞虎咽，喝着咖啡。

Sam eats his eggs like a total PIG. He stuffs his face and slurps his coffee.

山姆吃得像头猪。他喝咖啡的时候发出咕噜咕噜的声音。

Sam eats like a total PIG. He slurps his coffee.

他立即警觉起来。他问发生了什么事。

He is instantly alert. He asks what is going on.

他立即警觉，询问发生了什么事。

He is instantly alert, asks what is going on.

他立即警觉，询问发生了什么事。

Instantly alert, he asks what is going on.

这是另一个你必须阅读很多次才能找到问题的地方，但你的读者可能会在第一次尝试时就遇到困难！

Here’s another one where you have to read it a bunch of times to find the problem, but your reader may trip over it on his first try!

彼得森先生知道有一天他必须将控制权移交给加文，但放弃控制权会让他崩溃。

Mr. Peterson knows someday he’s got to hand the reins over to Gavin, but giving up control tears him apart.

彼得森先生知道有一天他必须将控制权移交给加文，但放弃控制权会让他崩溃。

Mr. Peterson knows someday he’s got to hand the reins over to Gavin, but giving up control rips him apart.

“tears” 这个词有两种发音方式。既像把某样东西撕成两半，又像泪水顺着脸颊流下。我把它改成了“rips”，以避免产生丝毫混淆的可能性。

The word “tears” can be pronounced two ways. Like tearing something in half, but also like tears trickling down a cheek. I changed it to “rips” to avoid the slightest hint of the possibility of confusion.

这一点很明显！你现在已经掌握诀窍了！

This one’s obvious! You’re getting the hang of it now!

没有人会改变自己的投票，也没有人知道谁是弃权者。

No one will change their vote and no one knows which one is the one who abstained.

没有人会改变他们的投票，也没有人知道谁弃权了。

No one will change their vote and no one knows who abstained.

这可能会成为一种狂热。更短、更清晰、更快捷更好。把这个贴到你的显示器上：长度。讨厌它。

It can get to be a mania. Shorter, clearer, swifter is BETTER. Tape this to your monitor: Length. Abhor it.

读者、制片人和导演实际上关心这些内容。如果你的描述给他们留下深刻印象，让他们觉得你是一个懂得如何写好文章的人，那么你的写作就会脱颖而出，辉煌的金色大门就会为你打开。让你的场景描述充满魅力！

Readers and producers and directors actually care about this stuff. If your description impresses them as someone who understands good writing, it will make your writing stand out from the pack and glorious, golden doors will open for you. Make your scene description sing!

让散文尽可能生动。斯皮尔伯格在《第三类接触》中做到了：

Make the prose as vivid as possible. Spielberg did, in Close Encounters of the Third Kind:

卡车的油漆与栅栏柱互换了。

The truck swapped paint with the fencepost.

展示给我们，而不是告诉我们！用文字创造令人兴奋的图像。不要无聊。不要太有创意让读者感到困惑，而是让每个场景都成为读者的小电影——并且要拍得好！

Show us, don’t tell us! Use words to create exciting images. Don’t be boring. Don’t be so creative the reader is confused, but make each scene a little movie for the reader — and make it a good one!

永远不要告诉我们一些我们不必知道的事情。如果你能删掉它，它就消失了。要么推动故事发展，要么死掉。不要闲聊。不要使用可爱的语言。

Never tell us something we do not absolutely have to know. If you can cut it, it’s gone. Move the story forward or die. No idle banter. No cute use of language.

这里有一些不错的场景描述。没有脂肪。图像很好。

Here’s some nice scene description. No fat. Good images.

本吉把球扔进一个黏糊糊的垃圾箱。温尼贝戈车滚走了，留下小男孩在一片烟尘中。

Benji tosses the ball into a slimy dumpster. The Winnebago rolls off, leaving the boy in a cloud of soot.

卡迈恩“耳朵”迪贝内代托（70 岁）走了出来。他像狐狸一样敏捷，像秃鹰的喙一样强硬，他身上有一种不寻常的感觉。也许是因为他穿着 70 年代的休闲西装。也许是因为他的右耳比左耳大得多。

CARMINE “THE EAR” DiBENEDETTO (70) steps out. Spry as a fox and tough as a buzzard’s beak, there’s something off-kilter about the guy. Maybe it’s his ‘70s leisure suit. Maybe it’s because his right ear is much bigger than his left.

本吉吐了口唾沫，然后疯狂地整理拖车，把脏衣服扔进浴室。他打开了前门。

Benji spits, then frantically tidies the trailer, tossing dirty clothes into the bathroom. He opens the front door.

嬉皮士女孩走过去，和萨姆法式接吻，往他嘴里吹着大麻烟。萨姆拿着烟，微笑着。

The Hippie Chick walks over and French kisses Sam, blowing pot smoke into his mouth. Sam holds the smoke and smiles.

她紧紧地抱住了他。穆克什呜咽着。

She grabs him in a bone-crunching bear hug. Mukesh whimpers.

要清楚：

Be clear:

戴夫

DAVE

他每隔一晚就会来这里。

He was here every other night.

你是什​​么意思？他每天晚上都来这里，但谋杀案发生的那晚，或者他每隔两天晚上就会来？

What do you mean? He was here every night, but the night of the murder, or he visited regularly, every two nights?

如果我们还没有看到某样东西，就不要说“the”。“The walking track encircles the police station” 应该是“A walking track”。在我们第一次看到它之后，你可以说“the”。

Don’t say “the” something if we’ve not seen that something yet. “The walking track encircles the police station” should be “A walking track.” After we’ve seen it the first time, you can say “the.”

除非非常关键，否则不要使用（节拍）！你和罗素·克劳对时间的想法可能不同。仔细检查你的剧本，然后把它们删掉。

Don’t use (beat) unless it’s CRITICAL! Your idea of timing and Russell Crowe’s may be different. Go through your script and take them out.

不要使用“行走”这个词。如果可能的话，请尽量使用：蹒跚而行、拖着脚步、昂首阔步、溜达、漫步、匆忙、慢步走、移动、冲刺、蜿蜒、滑行、轻松。让场景描述在读者的脑海中形成有用的形象。以下是一些初稿写作：

Don’t use the word “walk.” If at all possible: shamble, shuffle, strut, oil, stroll, hurry, amble, cut, move, dash, meander, glide, ease. Get your scene description to make a useful image in the reader’s mind. Here’s some first-draft writing:

苏珊娜走进房间。

Susanna enters the room.

给我们更多！通过展示她的走路方式来告诉我们她的性格和情绪。

Give us more! Tell us about her character and emotions by showing how she walks.

苏珊娜轻快地走进房间。

Susanna breezes into the room.

苏珊娜走进了房间。

Susanna oozes into the room.

苏珊娜走进房间。

Susanna marches into the room.

苏珊娜气冲冲地走进房间。

Susanna flounces into the room.

苏珊娜悄悄溜进房间。

Susanna slinks into the room.

苏珊娜在房间里咕哝道。

Susanna grumps into the room.

这里有什么问题？

What’s wrong here?

最后一个座位上坐着一位漂亮的年轻女孩——20 多岁，一头凌乱的金发。她疲惫地把头靠在窗玻璃上，打着瞌睡。

On last seat sits a pretty YOUNG GIRL - 20s, straggly blonde hair. Her head rests wearily on the window glass, dozing off.

不要重复。我们知道窗户是玻璃。另外，校对是个好主意。

Don’t be redundant. We know the window is glass. Also, proofreading is a jolly idea.

最后一个座位上坐着一位漂亮的年轻女孩——20 多岁，一头凌乱的金发。她疲惫地将头靠在窗户上，打起了瞌睡。

On the last seat sits a pretty YOUNG GIRL - 20s, straggly blonde hair. Her head rests wearily on the window, dozing off.

说清楚点。窗户没有打瞌睡，她的头也没有打瞌睡。

Be clear. The window is not dozing off, nor is her head.

最后一个座位上坐着一位漂亮的年轻女孩——20 多岁，一头凌乱的金发。她疲惫地把头靠在窗户上。她打瞌睡了。

On last seat sits a pretty YOUNG GIRL - 20s, straggly blonde hair. Her head rests wearily on the window. She dozes off.

你也可以省略“坐”这个词。如果是座位，我们假设她正坐着。

You can also lose the word “sits.” If it’s a seat, we assume she’s sitting.

最后一个座位上坐着一位漂亮的年轻女孩——20 多岁，一头凌乱的金发。她疲惫地将头靠在窗户上。她打起了瞌睡。

Last seat, a pretty YOUNG GIRL - 20s, straggly blonde hair. Her head rests wearily on the window. She dozes off.

如果她还年轻，就不要告诉她年龄。这样你还能省下一大笔钱！哇哦！

If she’s young, don’t tell her age. You also save an entire line! Whoopee!

最后一个座位上坐着一位年轻漂亮的女孩，一头凌乱的金发。她疲惫地将头靠在窗户上。她打起了瞌睡。

Last seat, a pretty YOUNG GIRL, straggly blonde hair. Her head rests wearily on the window. She dozes off.

我再说一遍：不要告诉我们任何我们不需要知道的事情。以下是初稿：

I repeat: Don’t tell us anything we don’t have to know. Here’s a first draft:

外景：诺曼路——日出之前

EXT. NORMAN ROAD – JUST BEFORE SUNRISE

塞隆扎营，卸下行李，把马拴好，铺开床垫，然后躺下。

Theron makes camp, unburdening and picketing his horse, spreading a bedroll and lying down.

外景，塞隆的营地——白天

EXT. THERON’S CAMP – DAY

一只小黄鼠狼在塞隆被随意扔到一边的背包里翻找。它翻遍了酒袋。塞隆在不远处打着呼噜。

A small WEASEL rummages through Theron’s packs, which have been carelessly tossed aside. It rummages through the wineskins. Theron snores a short distance away.

外景，塞隆的营地——傍晚

EXT. THERON’S CAMP – EARLY EVENING

塞隆醒来，开始收拾行装，准备第二天晚上的旅行。他发现他的酒袋散落在各处，被咬得支离破碎，上面沾满了干涸的血迹。他咒骂着，翻找着这些乱七八糟的东西，终于找到了最后一只完好无损的酒袋。他签了字，打开了瓶塞，喝了里面的血。

Theron awakes, and begins getting his gear together for the next night’s travel. He finds his wineskins strewn about, chewed to bits, with dried blood covering all. He curses and rummages through the mess, finally finding one last undamaged skin. He signs and uncorks it, drinks blood from it.

上述场景中发生的事情很有趣，也很引人注目。但场景的核心被作者不必拥有的东西所掩盖。修剪后：

What happens in the above scenes is interesting, and compelling. But the meat of the scene is hidden by stuff the writer doesn’t have to have. After the trims:

外景：诺曼路——日出之前

EXT. NORMAN ROAD – JUST BEFORE SUNRISE

塞隆扎营。

Theron makes camp.

外景，塞隆的营地——白天

EXT. THERON’S CAMP – DAY

一只黄鼠狼在翻找塞隆的背包。他在不远处打着呼噜。

A WEASEL rummages through Theron’s packs. He snores a short distance away.

外景，塞隆的营地——傍晚

EXT. THERON’S CAMP – EARLY EVENING

塞隆醒来，发现他的酒袋已被咬得支离破碎，上面全是干涸的血迹。他咒骂着，终于找到了一只完好无损的酒袋。他喝了里面的血。

Theron awakes, and finds his wineskins chewed to bits, with dried blood covering all. He curses and finally finds one undamaged skin. He drinks blood from it.

比较一下两者。细微差别的缺失可以通过速度、长度和清晰度来弥补。试着弄清楚我为什么删减了这些。我是不是做得太过了？有时确实如此。

Compare the two. What was lost in nuance is made up for in speed, length, and clarity. Try to figure out why I cut what I cut. Did I go too far? Sometimes I do.

看看这个精彩的文章——它迫切地需要被分成简短、紧凑的段落。当作者完成重写后，他的页面应该看起来像这样，可爱又对读者友好：

Check out this doozy — it desperately cried out to be broken into short, intense paragraphs. When the writer finished his rewrite, his page should have looked like this, all cuddly and reader friendly:

HRE. KTSDMFSDLL SSI

HRE. KTSDMFSDLL SSI
