Olk sroir djdjs enn jfjskjjdskj lksk ekslks qeuruhs edj jedjs smd。 Slkdlsk mcx、mcskhedfdlka sdlds sdkjds skjdks ejeiogtl dk kkzs jkmxlk ddj flflroeiu djd jjsja vmfndn sllslsss。

Olk sroir djdjs enn jfjskjjdskj lksk ekslks qeuruhs edj jedjs smd. Slkdlsk mcx, mcskhedfdlka sdlds sdkjds skjdks ejeiogtl dk kkzs jkmxlk ddj flflroeiu djd jjsja vmfndn sllslsss.

Yiyiy fjfjd fk wwir fngnfh ssss、ktjrh ssbxvs gkhkk dkdkkcjcj kg、cmcmcc。 Fjdjs ssik dssgsgs yuigmkinecxct。 Xtdxd drd r rxr rx。

Yiyiy fjfjd fk wwir fngnfh ssss, ktjrh ssbxvs gkhkk dkdkkcjcj kg, cmcmcc. Fjdjs ssik dssgsgs yuigmkinecxct. Xtdxd drd r rxr rx.

Uskekss secttctc in ininin n I ni mojin plmohtf。 Seazxrc knm mtcrsx kmijx ftx。

Uskekss secttctc in ininin n I ni mojin plmohtf. Seazxrc knm mtcrsx kmijx ftx.

相反，他提交了：

Instead, he submitted:

外部礼堂日

EXT. AUDITORIUM DAY

礼堂门外的一张松垮的沙发上坐着杰夫和萨莉。萨莉是个安静的书呆子，而杰夫则有点哥特怪胎的风格。他穿着一件没人能忍受的脏兮兮的夹克，但他不是瘾君子。从他们的着装来看，显然他们在普通高中都不会受欢迎。两人正在分享一个滴着水的汉堡包。杰夫喝着健怡可乐，萨莉喝着巴黎水。今天天气很热，所以这对他们来说是件好事，沙发在几棵树下，可以遮荫。他们之间沉默了一会儿。萨莉看到杰夫正茫然地盯着太空。

On a saggy sofa just outside the auditorium doors are Jeff and Sally. Sally is a quiet nerdy thing while Jeff is more goth-weird. He wears a grubby jacket that no one can stand, but he’s not a stoner. Obviously from their dress, neither would be popular in a normal high school. Both are sharing a drippy hamburger. Jeff sips a diet Coke while Sally is drinking a Perrier. It is boiling hot today, so it’s a good thing for them, the sofa is under some trees which provide shade. A silent moment between them. Sally sees that Jeff is staring blankly into space.

如果你在早期草稿中这样做了，那没关系，因为现在修复它还不算太晚。所以，修复它吧。欢迎来到……

If you did this in an early draft, it’s all right, because it’s not too late to fix it. So, fix it. Welcome to…

重写

Rewriting

 

66. 永远不要重复任何事！

66. Don’t repeat! Anything! Ever!

 

像杰克·斯派洛那样重写！切割、砍伐、凿刻、修剪、砍掉腐烂的部分！

Rewrite like Jack Sparrow! Cut, slash, gouge, trim, hack away the putrid parts!

“我写下来。我阅读它。如果它听起来像写作，我就会重写它。”

埃尔莫尔·伦纳德

“I write it. I read it. If it sounds like writing, I rewrite it.”

Elmore Leonard

这有什么问题？

What’s wrong with this?

内景，菲茨吉本先生的办公室，白天

INT. MR. FITZGIBBON’S OFFICE - DAY

豪华的办公室。透过落地玻璃窗，可以一览城市美景。

A plush office. Sweeping views of the city through floor-to-ceiling glass windows.

我们知道窗户是玻璃做的。不要告诉我们任何我们已经知道的事情。永远永远永远不要。有时很难意识到我们已经知道了一些东西。这就是为什么你要大声朗读你的作品。

We know windows are made of glass. Don’t tell us ANYthing we already know. Ever, ever, ever. Sometimes it’s hard to realize we already know stuff. That’s why you read your work out loud.

除了 Cam 之外，所有人都认真地听着。他变得焦躁不安。明显地发生了变化。

All listen intently except Cam. He grows restless. Shifts noticeably.

马修面无表情地倒在地上。

Matthew falls to the floor with an expressionless face.

马修面无表情地倒在地上。

Matthew falls to the floor, expressionless.

如果故事中有些内容是观众已经理解的，就不要重复。换句话说，不要告诉我们我们已经知道的内容。不要重复。确保不要重复同样的事情。始终保持最佳行为，不要告诉我们我们已经知道的内容。如果这是观众之前理解为真实的事情，请始终保持最佳行为，并提醒自己不要告诉我们我们已经知道的内容。

If something is understood in the story don’t repeat it. In other words, don’t tell us what we already know. Don’t be redundant. Be sure not to say the same thing twice. Always be on your best behavior not to tell us something that we already know. If it’s something that the audience previously understands to be true, always be on your best behavior and remind yourself not to tell us something that we already are aware of.

哈哈。懂了吗？

Ha ha. Get it?

奥斯汀和克里斯蒂安眯起眼睛，仿佛在总结明迪。

Austin and Christian squint their eyes as if summing up Mindy.

他们拥抱在一起。爱丽丝坐进出租车的后座，开车走了。

They hug. Alice gets in the back seat of the cab and drives off.

梅洛迪冲出了办公室。

Melody rushes out of her office.

最简单的例子是，如果有人在床上睡着了，就告诉我们他睡着了。这个人在医院里：

The simplest example of this is if someone’s asleep in the bed, just tell us that he’s asleep. This guy’s in a hospital:

路易正在床上睡觉，身上连接着呼吸机。

Louie’s sleeping in bed, hooked up to a ventilator.

路易正在睡觉，身上连着呼吸机。

Louie’s sleeping, hooked to a ventilator.

或者这个：

Or this one:

他看了看墙上的钟。

He looks at the clock on the wall.

你不需要知道时钟是否挂在墙上，因为大多数时钟都挂在墙上。如果一个女孩跳进游泳池，那么直到她从游泳池出来我们才知道她在游泳池里，所以在接下来的场景中不要告诉我们她在游泳池里。不要说“她游过游泳池”。要有趣。说“她溅到深水区”。

You don’t need to know the clock is on the wall, because most clocks are on walls. If a girl dives into a swimming pool, then we know until she gets out of the pool that she’s in the pool, so don’t tell us for the rest of the scene that she’s in the pool. Don’t say “she swims across the pool.” Be entertaining. Say “she splashes to the deep end.”

他笑容满面地看着斯蒂芬妮。

He looks at Stephanie with a huge grin on his face.

他笑容满面地看着斯蒂芬妮。

He looks at Stephanie with a huge grin.

没人会用手肘笑。当然，你可以再修剪一下。

No one grins with their elbow. You could trim it one more time, of course.

他朝斯蒂芬妮咧嘴一笑。

He grins at Stephanie.

如果角色刚刚听到一个巨大的 KERANK KERANK 噪音：

If the characters just heard a big KERANK KERANK noise:

特拉维斯

TRAVIS

是啊！啥？

Yeah! What?

卡拉

KARA

那是格兰特的车。我知道那个声音。

That was Grant’s car. I know that noise.

不要在同一个地方重复使用引人注目的词语。不要在一页纸上两次提到女孩的“健美体格”。这位作者还漏掉了一个句号：

Don’t repeat noticeable words in the same neighborhood. Don’t mention a girl’s “toned physique” twice on a page. This writer also left out a period:

外景，海滩黎明

EXT. BEACH DAWN

拍摄麦迪逊（MAD）格林斯潘健美的体格奔跑的背影。

SHOT of the back of MADISON (MAD) GREENSPUN’S toned physique running.

日出照片

SHOT of sunrise

室内浴室日

INT. BATHROOM DAY

从淋浴间跳出来并脱掉毛巾。

Body hops out of shower and towels off.

室内厨房日

INT. KITCHEN DAY

小麦面包从烤面包机里弹出。用手将果冻涂抹在上面。

Wheat bread pops from the toaster. Hand spreads jelly onto it.

外部停车场日

EXT. PARKING LOT DAY

玛德开着一辆 1974 年的棕色雪佛兰皮卡停了下来。她把车停在一个明显很窄的地方，前后颠簸着才能停进去。

Mad pulls up in a 1974 brown Chevy pick-up. She parallel parks in an obviously tight spot, bumping the car in front and behind her in order to fit.

她跳下车，从乘客座位下拿出背包、棕色午餐袋和一束向日葵。

She hops out of her car, grabs her backpack, a brown lunch bag, and a bouquet of sunflowers from below the passenger seat.

她身材娇小，体态健美，身穿运动服和黑色匡威鞋。她朝医院走去，然后又转身走向她的卡车。

Her petite, toned physique sports scrubs and black converse. She starts towards the hospital and turns back towards her truck.

不要经常使用同一个词：

Don’t use the same word often:

凯特转过身，开始用一个大红色记号笔在地图上标记各个点。

Kate turns around and begins marking points on the map with a large red marker.

然后两行之后，不要这么说：

Then two lines later, don’t say this:

她拿出另一支记号笔，开始标记旧的谋杀地点。

She pulls out a different marker and begins marking the old murder sites.

读者会注意到这些。如果他们认为你懒惰，他们就不会雇用你。一旦你告诉我们一个女孩很性感，就停下来。

Readers notice this stuff. They won’t hire you if they think you’re lazy. Once you tell us a girl’s hot, stop.

一只手拍拍马克的肩膀。他转过身。站在那里的是艾丽西亚·萨西，一个 23 岁的芭比娃娃，有着一头淡金色的头发，穿着《花花公子》杂志的插页服装，身材曲线让碧昂斯羡慕不已。

A hand taps Mark on the shoulder. He turns. Standing there is ALICIA SASSY, a 23 year-old Barbie doll with platinum blonde hair, a Playboy centerfold rack, and curves Beyonce envies.

请不要在标题中重复您刚刚告诉我们的信息：

Don’t repeat information you just told us in the slugline:

圣詹姆斯医院日间

INT. ST. JAMES INFIRMARY DAY

圣詹姆斯医院内部。

Inside of the St. James Infirmary.

法拉利内部 - 早上

INT. FERRARI - MORNING

邓恩已将车速减慢至正常行驶速度。

Dunn has slowed the car to normal driving speed.

不要通过描述和对话再次告诉我们一些事情。

Don’t tell us something in description and again in dialogue.

内景，舞台右侧/慈善晚会 - 夜晚

INT. STAGE RIGHT / BENEFIT - NIGHT

整个演出过程中，各种表演不断上演，伊芙和鲁迪则在后台观看。最后，到了压轴戏。

Various performances take place throughout the production as Eve and Rudy look on from backstage. Finally, it is time for the finale.

前夕

EVE

终于到了决赛的时间了。

It’s time for the finale.

或者在这里：

Or here:

室内酒吧电视之夜

INT. BAR TV NIGHT

电视上还在播放大卫找到被绑架男孩的故事。晚间新闻也在重播这个故事。

The story about David finding the kidnapped boy is still on the TV. The evening news is retelling it.

新闻记者:

NEWS REPORTER:

绑匪据称是 Hedges

团伙，当地男子 DAVID

在商场看到孩子后介入，绑匪随后逃脱。

the kidnapper’s, reputed to be the Hedges

gang, got away after DAVID, a local man,

saw the child at the mall and intervened.

趁此机会，找出作者在上述对话中所犯的语法错误。我发现了两个。另外还有两个格式错误。

While you’re at it, find the grammar mistakes that writer made in the above dialogue. I found two. Plus two format errors.

不要在对话中重复某些事情。医院里的每个人都已经知道对讲机女孩了。

Don’t tell us something twice in dialogue, either. Everyone who works at the hospital already knows about the intercom girl.

接待员

RECEPTIONIST

等一下，你是对讲机女孩吗？每天早上通过对讲机

说话的那个人

。

Wait a sec, you’re the intercom girl?

The one who spoke every morning over the

intercom.

“It's” 用错了。另外，“the table” 出现了两次：

“It’s” is used wrong. Also, “the table” is here twice:

内景，皮特和萨姆的

INT. PETE AND SAM’S

这家意大利餐厅看起来就像是直接从《教父》中搬出来的。餐厅氛围阴暗，食物是老派意大利菜，店里都是常客。气氛很欢乐。角落里的桌子却不是。

The Italian restaurant appears lifted straight out of the Godfather. It’s atmosphere is dark, it’s food is old school Italian, and all there are regular customers. The mood is jubilant. The table in the corner is not.

角落里的一张小桌子旁坐着马克和布里杰斯先生。

At a small table in the corner sits MARK and MR. BRIDGERS.

不重复更快捷、更干净。那就去做吧！

Not repeating is quicker and cleaner. Do it!

67. 一边写一边重写！

67. You rewrite while you write!

 

撰写初稿时，不要回头重写已写内容。这会导致蓝屏死机。

Do not, while you’re writing your first draft, go back and rewrite what you’ve written. This is the Big Blue Screen of Death.

每次写作结束时，打印出当天完成的页面，将它们堆放在昨天完成的页面上，然后去喝一杯或散步或阅读杂志。

At the end of each writing session, print the pages you did that day, stack them on the pages you did yesterday and go have a drink or take a walk or read a magazine.

下次你坐下来写作时（第二天！），阅读前一天写的页面，记下一些你可能想要更改的内容，然后开始写今天的页面。不要阅读前天写的页面。不要回头看开头。如果你现在重写，你将永远无法完成你的剧本！

Next time you sit down to write (the very next day!), read the pages you wrote the day before, make a few notes about things you might want to change, and begin writing today’s pages. Do not read the day-before-yesterday’s pages. Do not look back to the beginning. If you rewrite now, YOU WILL NEVER FINISH YOUR SCREENPLAY!

回头会暴露出之前未曾发现的问题。回头会让你更加焦虑。因为你的剧本会被发现不充分、不完美，而且不像 Zaillian 那样，所以回头往往令人沮丧不已。如此沮丧以至于你可能会决定最好放弃并开始另一个剧本。不要上这个傻瓜的当。

Going back will reveal hitherto unseen problems. Going back will jack up your angst. Because your script will be revealed to be inadequate, imperfect, and not Zaillian-esque, going back tends to be monumentally depressing. So depressing that you may just decide it’s better to — give up and start another script. Do not play into this sucker’s game.

每天写作。继续写下去。几周后，你的纸堆就会变少。一个月后，你的纸堆就会令人印象深刻。你有很多值得骄傲的地方。继续写下去。当你写完第一遍时，去喝两杯。

Write every day. Add to that slim pile of pages. After a couple of weeks, it will be a less-slim pile of pages. A month into it, your pile will be quite impressive. You have a lot to be proud of. Keep writing. When you finish your first pass, go have two drinks.

休息一会儿。不要停下写作，而是从故事中抽身。仔细思考一些想法。为你的下一个剧本塑造一个角色。仔细拟定提纲。休息一段时间后，剧本在你脑海中会冷却下来。重新回到剧本时，你会感到很开心，因为你已经完成了一部 110 页的作品。现在，既然你有了草稿，是时候重写了。

Take some time off. From that story, not from writing. Noodle around a few ideas. Work on a character for your next script. Pound on an outline. After some time off, the script will be cold in your mind. Come back to your screenplay fresh, happy you have finished a 110-page opus. Now, now that you have a draft, it’s time to rewrite.

但在此之前不会。相信我。

But not before. Trust me on this.

68. 一次性阅读整个剧本并进行重写！

68. You do a rewrite by reading the whole script at once!

 

伊克斯奈。生日。

Ixnay. Eathday.

你说：“你什么意思，不读完整个剧本？不然你还能做什么？”

You say, “What do you mean, don’t read the whole script? How else can you do it?”

如果你拿起一支红笔说：“嘿，该重写一下了。我想我会坐下来喝点浓咖啡，仔细阅读一下这个小故事”，那你就陷入了困境。不要只是从头到尾阅读剧本；要像激光手术一样仔细阅读。我的意思是，你可以从头到尾阅读剧本，偶尔这样做是个好主意，但我衷心建议你每次通读时都要有一个具体的计划。

If you grab a red pen and say, “Hey, time for a rewrite. I think I’ll sit down with some strong coffee and churn through this puppy,” you are in deep quicksand. Don’t just read the script from top to bottom; go in there like laser surgery. I mean, you can read the script from start to finish, and it’s a good idea to do now and again, but I heartily recommend you have a specific agenda for each read-through.

我把剧本想象成一团九英尺长的口香糖，漂浮在我面前，就像一颗黏糊糊的粉色星球。如果你想一次看完整个剧本，那是不可能的。但如果你取一个核心样本，你就可以研究那一小部分，真正理解你在看什么。如果你用激光手术刀而不是火枪阅读，每次阅读都会对你有更好的帮助。

I imagine a script as a nine-foot wad of chewing gum, floating in front of me, like a gooey pink planet. If you try to see the whole thing at once, it’s impossible. But if you take a core sample, you can study that small part and actually understand what you’re looking at. If you read with a laser scalpel instead of a blunderbuss, each read will serve you better.

举几个例子：

A few examples:

阅读时只看谋杀悬疑侦探故事（或情节的 ________ 方面，随便什么）。如果您在检查谋杀情节时很难不去想剧本的其余部分，请打印那些特定的页面。阅读并反复修改这 15 页，直到您满意故事的这一部分，就像冰块上的冰一样顺畅。然后将这些页面放回去，再进行一次激光束阅读。

Read it to look at only the murder mystery detective story (or the ________ aspect to the plot, whatever). If it’s hard for you not to think about the rest of the script while you’re checking out the murder plot, print those specific pages. Read and rework that 15-page stack, over and over and over until you’re happy that slice of your story tracks as smooth as ice on ice. Then stick those pages back in and do another laser-beam read.

看看你两个主角之间的爱情故事。所有鲍勃和卡罗尔的场景。只有鲍勃和卡罗尔的场景。你会对故事那部分发生的事情有一个奇妙的想法，错误会突然出现。就像老鼠着火一样，它们会突然出现。后来，只研究泰德和爱丽丝的场景。然后是鲍勃和爱丽丝，然后是卡罗尔和泰德。你会对发现的东西感到惊讶：例如，爱丽丝在剧本中消失了 30 页，而你却一无所知！

Check out the love story between your two main characters. All the Bob and Carol scenes. Just the Bob and Carol scenes. You’ll get a fantastic idea what’s going on in that part of your story and mistakes will leap out at you. Like rats on fire, they’ll leap out at you. Later, study only the Ted and Alice scenes. Then, Bob and Alice, and then Carol and Ted. You’ll be amazed what you find: like, for example, that Alice vanishes from the script for 30 pages and you had no idea!

只阅读标题行。它们是否满足您的期望？

Read just the sluglines. Are they doing for you what you want them to?

浏览脚本并检查是否存在逻辑缺陷。

Go through the script and check for logic flaws.

阅读后，了解帕森·埃尔顿·史密瑟斯的对话。（顺便说一句，每个角色的对话都是如此。）他是否从头到尾都像他应该的那样说话？他应该是苏格兰人，但他说话时听起来像英国人吗？他听起来总是像年近 100 岁吗？他是否会说一些他实​​际上可能不会说的话，例如“哟，兄弟，我的凯雷德在哪儿？”

Read it to check out Parson Elton Smithers’ dialogue. (By the way, this is true for every character’s dialogue.) Does he talk exactly like he’s supposed to the whole way through? Does he ever sound English when he’s supposed to be Scottish? Does he always sound like he’s nearly 100 years old? Does he ever say things that he might not actually say, like “Yo, bro, where’s my Escalade?”

读一遍，检查错别字和校对错误。不是故事，只是拼写。

Read it one time for typos and proofreading errors. Not story, just spelling.

阅读只是为了检查每个场景中的情感。这是你想要的吗？

Read just to check on emotion in each scene. Is it where you want it?

只读场景描述，不读对话。是否流畅？你是否已经去掉了“to be”的所有令人讨厌的小变化？图像顺序是否正确？你是否已经删除了所有可能的单词？你是否已经仔细研究过剧本创作的七宗罪，并修改了你的场景描述，直到它焕然一新？你的场景描述是否诙谐有趣？你是否已经将其分成短段落？

Read only scene description, no dialogue. Is it smooth? Have you gotten rid of “to be” in all its nasty little variations? Is the image order correct? Have you cut every single possible word? Did you go through the Seven Deadly Sins of Screenwriting and massage your scene description until it glows? Is your scene description witty and interesting? Have you broken it into short paragraphs?

通过脚本检查每天和每夜是否一致且跟踪正确。

Go through the script to check that every DAY and NIGHT is consistent and tracks correctly.

 

“等等，等等，等等！” 《国王与我》

中的暹罗国王

“Et cetera, et cetera, et cetera!”

King of Siam, in The King and I

激光束读取是一种有用的工具，因为这些小部分加起来是一个统一的整体，任何有缺陷的部分在制作电影时都可能是一个真正的问题。但是，如果你不在乎是否有人真正制作你的电影，因为你只是在写剧本，这样你就可以和你的写作伙伴一起欺骗你的配偶，那么，跳过整个步骤吧。

The laser-beam read is a helpful tool, as these little parts add up to a unified whole and any flawed piece can be a real problem when they get around to making your film. However; if you don’t care if anyone will actually make your movie because you’re only writing the script so you can get with your writing partner to cheat on your spouse, heck, skip this whole step.

不过我很高兴你买了这本书。很贴心。

I am glad you bought the book, though. Nice touch.

69. 你的第一页不够吸引人！

69. You don’t have a killer first page!

 

读者只要读半页就能知道你是否知道自己在做什么。如果你的作品真的很棒或很糟糕，他可能在第一句结尾就能看出来。当然，读者读完第一页就能知道你是否能写。

A reader can tell if you know what you’re doing by reading about half a page. If your stuff is really great or really awful, he can probably tell at the end of the first sentence. For sure, the reader will know if you can write by the end of the first page.

这有点令人沮丧，不是吗？

That’s sort of depressing, isn’t it?

或者说，令人振奋。因为，如果你的第一页写得很棒，你就会把读者引向第二页，然后是第五页、第十页、第三十页，然后嗖嗖，就像泥石流上的水獭一样，直接跳到第 110 页！只需要一页精彩的内容！还有什么比这更简单的吗？！

Or, exhilarating. Because, if you have a swell first page, you’re going to launch them into page two, then five, and ten and thirty and whooooooosh, like an otter on a mudslide, straight to page 110! All it takes is one great page! What could be easier?!

第一页需要考虑的事情：

Things to think about on page one:

对话越少越好。这是你唯一能营造气氛的机会，所以请花点时间在这里写点东西。告诉我们我们在哪里。告诉我们感觉如何。告诉我们它是什么样子。让我们感受一下这个世界。

As little dialogue as possible. This is the only chance you have to set a mood, so take your time and do a little actual writing here. Tell us where we are. Tell us what it feels like. Tell us what it looks like. Give us a sense of the world.

我们遇见的是好人还是坏人？

Do we meet either the good guy or the bad guy?

我们是否了解地点、时间段和流派？

Do we get a sense of the place, time period, and genre?

如果你有拼写错误或者语法错误，你就死定了。

If you’ve got typos or grammar mistakes, you’re dead.

如果你使用“to be”的次数超过一点点，你就死定了。

If you use “to be” more than just a teeny bit, you’re dead.

读者的触角已经伸出，警惕着你的写作是否不够出色的迹象。读者，以及后来的演员，都在祈祷你知道自己在做什么。你所要做的就是让他保持冷静，这样你就不用担心了。

A reader’s antennae are out, alert for signs that your writing is anything but stellar. The reader and, later on, the actor, is praying you know what you’re doing. All you have to do is keep him on the lily pads and you have no worries.

你吸引住了读者吗？第 1 页上是否有什么东西会迫使他们翻到第 2 页？看看《爱情故事》的开篇。一个男人在寒冷的日子里独自坐着。在旁白中，他说：“你对一个死去的女孩有什么看法？”这很吸引人。

Have you hooked the reader? Is there something on page 1 that will force them to turn to page 2? Check out the opening of Love Story. A guy is sitting by himself on a cold day. In V.O., he says, “What do you say about a girl who died.” That’s a grabber.

淡入和淡出在正确的位置吗？没有什么比这个弥天大谎更能说明你不知道自己在做什么了，而且就在首页的最顶端。

Are FADE IN and FADE OUT in the right place? Nothing advertises that you don’t know what you’re doing like this whopper, and on the very top of the very first page, no less.

淡入。

FADE IN.

 

室内洗车日

INT. CAR WASH     DAY

Bob's Car Wash 深受居住在 Perriwinkle Falls 的所有人的喜爱。

Bob’s Car Wash is beloved by all who live in Perriwinkle Falls.

它应该是这样的。请注意FADE IN:后面有一个冒号。

It’s supposed to be like this. Notice that FADE IN: has a colon after it.

淡入：

FADE IN:

室内洗车日

INT. CAR WASH     DAY

Bob's Car Wash 深受居住在 Perriwinkle Falls 的所有人的喜爱。

Bob’s Car Wash is beloved by all who live in Perriwinkle Falls.

另外，请注意FADE IN:下方有一个空格。如果您和我一样，每行 slugline（或 Final Draft 中的“场景标题”）上方都有两个空格，那么您需要调整第一个 slugline，以便FADE IN:下方只有一个空格。

Also take a gander at the fact that FADE IN: has one space underneath it. If you’re like me and you have two spaces above every slugline (or “Scene Heading” in Final Draft) then you’ll need to adjust the very first slugline so FADE IN: only has one space below it.

在 Final Draft 中，将光标放在第一个 slugline 的左侧。单击格式 / 元素 / 场景标题 / 段落 / 前空格 / 1

Do this, in Final Draft, by putting your cursor to the left of the very first slugline. Click Format / Elements / Scene Heading / Paragraph / Space Before / 1

它看起来应该是这样的：

It should look like this:

淡入：

FADE IN:

外太空的寒冷黑暗永恒之夜

EXT. COLD DARKNESS OF OUTER SPACE     ETERNAL NIGHT

卡罗尔·哈肯萨克是一位美丽的家庭主妇和宇航员，她在一次惊心动魄的太空行走中修剪指甲。

CAROL HACKENSACKER, a great looking housewife and astronaut, files her fingernails while on a thrilling spacewalk.

不是这样的：

Not like this:

淡入：

FADE IN:

 

 

斯特布里奇家庭厨房日

INT. STURBRIDGE FAMILY KITCHEN     DAY

 

一只三色猫优雅地走过昨晚争吵和扔盘子比赛的残局。

A calico cat walks daintily through the debris of last night’s argument and plate-throwing contest.

经过光学效果处理后也是如此。不是这样的：

This is also true after optical effects. Not like this:

解散为：

DISSOLVE TO:

 

 

 

YOAKUM 卧室之夜

INT. YOAKUM BEDROOM NIGHT

 

年轻夫妻性生活毫无激情，看着都难受，太浪费了。

The young married couple has unenthusiastic sex. It’s painful to watch. What a waste.

在视觉效果 (Final Draft 称之为过渡) 之后，标题行上方有一个空格。如下所示：

One space above a slugline after an optical effect (which Final Draft calls a Transition.) Like this:

解散为：

DISSOLVE TO:

 

 

 

室内马戏团帐篷之夜

INT. CIRCUS TENT NIGHT

 

蒂米大笑着，拉住妈妈的袖子，指着那个没穿裤子的小丑。

Timmy, laughing, jerks his mom’s sleeve, points out the clown with no pants.

当然，你对FADE OUT 的处理并不重要。到那时，他们已经决定购买你的剧本，为你提供豪华轿车和司机，并支付你的孩子上大学的费用。有些人在FADE OUT后面加了一个句号。有些人什么都不加。但是，因为故事不是从这里开始的，所以没有冒号。

Of course, what you do with FADE OUT doesn’t matter so much. By then they’ve decided to buy your screenplay, give you a limo and a driver, and pay for your kids to go to college. Some people put a period after FADE OUT. Some put nothing. But, because the story is not beginning here, no colon.

淡入：位于左边距，因为那是您开始阅读时眼睛所在的位置。淡出位于右边距，因为那是您结束阅读时眼睛所在的位置。

FADE IN: goes on the left margin, because that’s where your eye is when you start reading. FADE OUT is on the right margin because that’s where your eye is when you finish reading.

淡入：

FADE IN:

淡出。

FADE OUT.

 

如果你购买剧本或在互联网上看到剧本，你会发现剧本中通常会有场景编号，即位于标题行旁边边缘的小数字。

If you buy screenplays or see them on the Internet, they often have scene numbers, little numbers in the margins, right beside the sluglines.

51     外部 桥梁 - 从高处俯瞰黄昏            51

51     EXT. BRIDGE - FROM HIGH ABOVE     DUSK            51

货车停了下来，车门打开。几名暴徒将布雷瓦德和莱弗里特的尸体卸下来。

The van stops, doors open. Several THUGS unload the bodies of Brevard and Leverett.

它们被丢进河里，被油水吞没。

They are dropped in the river. Oily water swallows them.

场景编号（你可以告诉 Final Draft 输入这些编号）在你重写时很有用，但是当需要将那只小狗发送出去时，请删除这些编号。

Scene numbers, which you can tell Final Draft to put in, are helpful when you’re rewriting, but when it’s time to send that puppy out, get rid of the numbers.

场景编号是制作经理在准备预算等时使用的。她会进行编号。你应该很幸运，他们会打电话要求提供最终草稿副本，以便对其进行编号。否则，规格材料没有编号，因为它还没有被购买。不要这样做。他们会扣分！

Scene numbers are for the Production Manager when she prepares a budget, etc. She will do the numbering. You should be so lucky that they call and ask for a Final Draft copy so they can number it. Otherwise, spec material has no numbers because it hasn’t been bought yet. Don’t do it. They’ll take points off!

尽快让读者感到舒服。不要让她疑惑，“我想知道这是什么时候发生的？”消除她可能产生的所有不安情绪，其中第一个是“我什么时候在哪里？”

Get your reader comfortable as quickly as possible. Don’t make her wonder, “I wonder when this takes place?” Remove all prickly feelings she may have, the first of which is “When and where am I?”

淡入：

FADE IN:

 

 

内部黑暗厨房

INT. DARK KITCHEN

（今天）

(PRESENT DAY)

空间站内部

INT. SPACE STATION

（公元 5035 年）

(A.D. 5035)

内部。褶边闺房

INT. FRILLY BOUDOIR

（很久很久以前）

(LONG, LONG AGO)

外景，怀俄明州小镇

EXT. SMALL WYOMING TOWN

（1857年）

(1857)

看看接下来的前两页。两位学生都很好地掌握了格式，但第一页有足够多的问题，让读者担心接下来的 109 页。

Look at the next two first pages. Both students have a good grasp of format, but this first page has enough hiccups to make the reader worry about the upcoming 109.

淡入：

FADE IN:

 

 

外景，阿拉巴马州塔拉瓦西斯，夜晚

EXT. TALLAWASSESE, ALABAMA NIGHT

 

黄昏。松树树冠。

Twilight. Canopy of pine trees.

镜头向下，可以看到一栋不起眼的两层小房子坐落在起伏的草坪上。三辆满是泥土的皮卡车停在前院，旁边是一辆亮黄色的大众汽车和一辆迷你面包车。夕阳西下，典型的美国中产阶级家庭笼罩在夕阳下。

TILT DOWN to a modest, two-story house sits atop a rolling lawn. Three muddy pick-up trucks are stalled in the front yard, next to a shiny yellow VW and a Mini-van. The sun is setting on the typical middle-class American home.

 

 

内部厨房晚会

INT. KITCHEN EVENING

 

多蒂·费舍尔，46 岁，身材匀称，保养良好，像个母亲，在她豪华但杂乱的厨房里疯狂地处理猪里脊肉。精致的瓷器堆在柜台上。炉子上一锅米饭沸腾着。新鲜切好的蔬菜被一堆堆美国大兵包围着。

DOTTIE FISHER, 46, in shape, well-kept, maternal figure, frantically doctoring a pork tenderloin in her luxurious, but messy kitchen. Fine China piled high on the counter. A pot of rice boils over on the stove. Fresh cut vegetables are encased by a battle field of GI Joes.

微波炉里粘满了凝固的粘稠物。四壶刚泡好的甜茶放在岛台上，周围是玉米皮头发。厨房里到处都是赤褐色的洗碗巾和锅垫。门框上排满了孩子们的身高标尺。

Microwave is slimed with a solidified goop. Four pitchers of freshly brewed sweet tea rest on an island amidst pieces of corn husk hair. Auburn dish towels and pot holders strewn throughout kitchen. Door frame covered in lines of children’s heights.

多蒂

DOTTIE

吉姆博，我需要你的帮助！

Jimbo, I need your help!

吉姆博·费舍尔，55 岁，多蒂的丈夫，一个肌肉发达、疲惫不堪、充满男子气概的男人，正把头探进厨房。

JIMBO FISHER, 55, Dottie’s husband, muscular, tired, and masculine man poke his head in the kitchen.

吉姆博

JIMBO

什么？

What?

多蒂开始做沙拉。

Dottie beigns to fix a salad.

JIMBO（继续）

JIMBO (CONT’D)

我只是不擅长与人打交道，而 Bo 却很擅长，也就是说，他的家人可能异常友好。我并不害怕。这只是一个长周末。我周二就会离开这里。周二……

I just not a people person and Bo is which means, his family is probably freakishly friendly. I’m not freaking out. It’s just a long weekend. I’ll be out of here by Tuesday. Tuesday...

 

 

内景，多蒂的厨房之夜

INT. DOTTIE’S KITCHEN     NIGHT

 

多蒂往杯子里倒了甜茶。她擦了擦汗。书房里传来一声大吼。

Dottie pours sweet tea into glasses. She wipes sweat. A LARGE ROAR from the den.

 

现在，我担心一些可能会让读者停下来思考的时刻：

Now, my concerns about moments that might give a reader pause:

 

FADE IN：下面应该有一个空格，而不是两个。

你没有告诉我们时间段。

第三句有语法错误。应该是“house that sits atop”。

在第二段中，“to be”出现了两次。

皮卡车真的“停着”吗？我们怎么看出来的？它们只是停着吗？

房子被描述为“简朴”，但厨房被描述为“豪华”。这是逻辑缺陷吗？

每当你说某件事“典型”时，我们都会想知道为什么这个家庭值得我们付出努力。Dottie



的外表被描述，但没有她的个性。

你最好说“40 多岁”，而不是确定她的年龄。

我不清楚“母亲形象”是什么意思。这是说“妈妈”的花哨方式吗？还是你在评论她的身体？

不要重复。“身材好”和“保养良好”基本相同。

“Doctoring”应该是“doctors”。也许不是。

米饭沸腾了。Dottie 对此做了什么吗？

战场是一个词。

“被 GI Joes 的战场包围。” 我不知道这幅图是什么意思。

四壶茶现实吗？ 似乎太多了。 也许可以。

“玉米壳头发” 就可以。你不需要“碎片”，因为头发没有被剪掉。

赤褐色是许多人的颜色。第一次说“奥本大学”。

不要重复：如果 Jimbo 肌肉发达，我们假设他是男性。如果他是她的丈夫，我们就知道他是个男人。 不要告诉我们我们已经知道的东西。

同样，我们需要一些关于角色性格的描述，而不仅仅是外貌。

你不需要说“开始”。只要说“Dottie 做沙拉”就可以了。

“开始”和 TALLAWASSEE 拼写错误。第 1 页出现永久致命错误！

Dottie 向 Jimbo 求助，然后忘记她问过。这是一个逻辑缺陷吗？

“Bo is” 后面需要一个逗号，这样我们才能感受到对话的正确节奏。

那么，“which means” 后面可能不需要逗号。

你的意思是让 Jimbo 说两次“freak”？



“Dottie pours sweet tea。”我们已经被告知茶是甜的。

从现在开始，就叫它茶吧。

“Roar” 是一种声音。我不确定你能发出“large roar”的声音。不过，这可能太挑剔了。

我还不知道我们在讲什么故事。戏剧？

喜剧？

FADE IN: should have one space below it, instead of two.

You have not told us the time period.

Third sentence has a grammar mistake. Should be “house that sits atop.”

In the second paragraph, “to be” appears twice.

Are the pickup trucks actually “stalled?” How do we see that? Are they simply parked?

The house is described as “modest” but the kitchen, “luxurious.” Is that a logic flaw?

Any time you say “typical” about something, we wonder why this family is worth our effort.



Dottie is described by physical appearance, but nothing about her personality.

You’re better off saying “40s” instead of nailing down her age.

I’m unclear what is meant by “maternal figure.” Is this a fancy way of saying “mom?” or are you commenting on her body?

Don’t repeat. “In shape” and “well kept” are basically the same.

“Doctoring” should be “doctors.” Maybe not.

The rice is boiling over. Does Dottie do anything about it?

Battlefield is one word.

“encased by a battle field of GI Joes.” I have no idea what this image means.

Is four pitchers of tea realistic? Seems excessive. May be fine.

“Corn husk hair” is fine. You don’t need “pieces” as the hair has not been cut up.

Auburn is a color to many people. Say “Auburn University” the first time.

Don’t repeat: If Jimbo is muscular, we assume masculine. If he’s her husband, we know he’s a man. Don’t tell us what we already know.

Again, we need some description of the character’s character, not just physical appearance.

You don’t need to say “begins.” Just say “Dottie fixes a salad.”

“Begins” and TALLAWASSEE are spelled wrong. Permanent Fatal Error on page 1!

Dottie asks Jimbo for help, then forgets she asked. Is this a logic flaw?

Need a comma after “Bo is” so we can feel the correct rhythm of the dialogue.

Probably, then, don’t need a comma after “which means.”

Do you mean for Jimbo to say “freak” twice?



“Dottie pours sweet tea.” We’ve already been told the tea is sweet.

From now on, just call it tea.

“Roar” is a sound. I’m not sure you can have a “large roar.” That may be too nitpicky, though.

I have no sense of what kind of story we’re in yet. Drama?

Comedy?

这些睡莲叶子上有足够的藤蔓、树枝和光滑的斑点，让读者真的放慢脚步，小心脚下。遗憾的是，“多蒂开始做沙拉了。”这句话足以让读者把剧本扔进沼泽。

There are enough vines, sticks, and slick spots on these lily pads to make the reader really slow down and watch his step. The “Dottie beigns to fix a salad.” is, sadly, enough to cause the reader to fling the script into the swamp.

这是另一个第 1 页：

Here’s another page 1:

 

两只雪白的鸽子

（今天）

透过金色鸟笼的栅栏凝视着。等待这场婚礼结束。等待他们获得自由的机会。

 

内部。拥挤的犹太教堂日

 

年轻的准新娘 SHOSHANNA GOLD 走在红毯上。

她容光焕发。衣着讲究的人群也被迷住了。

25 岁的本吉·斯帕尔是她未来的丈夫，他关注着她的一举一动。每一步都让她更亲近。幸福的生活正在等待着他们。他们的目光相遇。他流下了眼泪。

本吉（画外音）

你应该知道我以前结过婚。差不多吧。

当新娘走到一半时，一位年长的商人走进过道，挡住了她的去路。他握住她的手，单膝跪下。他低声对她说。

她扔下手中的花束，泪流满面，并给老傻瓜一个热情的吻。

本吉惊恐地往后退去。然后从舞台上摔了下去。

本吉（画外音）

没有成功。

内部接待厅

医护人员正在对本吉的断腿进行治疗。他悲痛欲绝。

73 岁的萨姆·斯卡尔是一名衣衫褴褛、留着一头漂亮的犹太卷发的律师，他正与新娘的父亲激烈争执。他们正在为一件结婚礼物而展开拉锯战。

本吉（画外音）

听说过萨姆·施帕尔吗？他是

六十年代著名的民权律师。我的父亲。

 

TWO SNOWY WHITE DOVES

(PRESENT DAY)

Staring through the bars of a golden birdcage. Waiting for this wedding to end. Waiting for their shot at freedom.

 

INT. CROWDED SYNAGOGUE     DAY

 

SHOSHANNA GOLD, a young BRIDE-TO-BE walks down the aisle.

She’s radiant. A well-heeled CROWD is enthralled.

BENJI SCHPALL, 25, her soon-to-be husband, soaks in her every move. Every step brings her closer. A life of happiness awaits. Their eyes lock. He tears up.

BENJI (V.O.)

You should probably know I was married before.Almost.

As the bride reaches the halfway point, an ELDERLY BUSINESSMAN steps into the aisle, blocking her way. He takes hold of her hand and drops to one knee. He whispers to her.

She drops her bouquet, bursts into tears, and lays a passionate kiss on the Old Coot.

Benji recoils in horror. And falls backward off the stage.

BENJI (V.O.)

It didn’t take.

INT. RECEPTION HALL

Paramedics work on Benji’s broken leg. He’s devastated.

SAM SCHPALL, 73, a rumpled lawyer with a terrific jew-fro, is engaged in a mighty struggle with the BRIDE’S FATHER. They’re playing tug-of-war with a wedding gift.

BENJI (V.O.)

Ever heard of Sam Schpall? He was a famous

civil rights lawyer in the sixties. My father.

 

你可以看到其中的差别。读者可以快速浏览这些睡莲！

You can see the difference. The reader can sprint across those lily pads!

 

没有淡入淡出：也许这并不重要。

有趣的开场画面。“等待自由的机会”感觉很好。



断断续续的段落很容易阅读。

视觉写作：我们毫不费力地看到了图像。

我想要一些关于 Shoshana 的人物描述，但我愿意等待时机。

本吉的对话很好。吸引我们。

我不太明白老傻瓜之吻是什么意思，但再次，写作吸引了我，所以我会继续下去。



“医护人员”需要大写。

在“jew-fro”之后，“is”之前有一个空格太多了

There’s no FADE IN: Maybe it doesn’t matter.

Interesting opening image. Good feel to “waiting for their shot at freedom.”



The choppy paragraphs are easy to read.

Visual writing: we see the image with no effort.

I’d like some character description of Shoshana, but I’m willing to bide my time.

Benji’s dialogue is good. Hooks us.

I don’t quite understand what the Old Coot kiss means, but, again, the writing is pulling me on, so I’ll keep with it.



“Paramedics” needs to be in CAPS.

One space too many after “jew-fro,” before “is”

我们遇到了压力重重的 Benji，第一页上有几个有趣的瞬间。他父亲，一位著名的律师，与新娘的父亲争夺结婚礼物的画面是一个很好的人物介绍。配音简短有力。场景描述写得很好，用很少的文字创造了快速生动的画面。我最喜欢的是“幸福的生活正在等待。”我可以看到新娘穿着白色衣服，慢动作地对 Benji 微笑。

We meet Benji under pressure, and there’re a couple of funny moments on page one. The image of his father, the famous lawyer, tugging it out with the Bride’s Father over a wedding gift, is a good character introduction. The V.O. is short and punchy. The scene description is nicely written and creates quick, telling pictures with few words. My favorite is “a life of happiness awaits.” I can SEE the bride in white and slow motion, smiling at Benji.

读者会翻页并继续阅读！

The reader will turn the page and read on!

70. 你把前十页都写烂了！啊啊啊啊啊！

70. You blew your first ten pages! ARGGGGGHHHH!

 

出色的前十页 = 生活。平庸的前十页 = 麻风疮、眼睛里的酸和永远沸腾的肠子。这至关重要。非常重要！非常重要。前十页以及你对它们的处理将决定你的剧本的成败。

Great first ten pages = life. Mediocre first ten pages = leprous sores, acid in your eyes, and boiling intestines for all eternity. This is critically important. So important! Reeeeeeally important. The first ten pages, and what you do with them, will make or break your script.

这些页面是你唯一能保证的东西。有些人会读到 20 页，其他人如果没有发生重大事件，则会在 30 页时停止，但无论如何，他们都会阅读前 10 页。他们可能会在读到第 11 页时将其扔进垃圾箱，但你至少可以锁定 10 页！耶！

It’s the only guarantee you’ve got, those pages. Some people will read to 20, others will stop at 30 if something major hasn’t happened, but no matter what, they’re going to read the first ten pages. They may chuck it in the rubbish bin halfway through page 11, but you’ve got a lock on at least ten! Yee ha!

让他们有价值。

Make ’em count.

开头是攻击点，某些事情已经发生。问题已经存在。我们可能不知道是什么，但角色知道，我们想找出答案。

The beginning is the point of attack, where something is already happening. There is already a problem. We may not know what it is, but the character knows, and we want to find out.

丹尼尔·伍德雷尔的小说《冬天的骨头》情节紧凑，故事以瑞·多莉为主角，她是奥扎克山区一个贫穷的年轻女人，家里有两个孩子，一个疯疯癫癫的母亲和一个制作冰毒的父亲。作者刚一确定了地理位置，一名警察就开车过来告诉瑞，她父亲的审判将在一周后举行，但最近没人见过他。然后约翰·劳告诉她，为了保释，她父亲在她的土地和房子上签了字。如果他周一不出庭受审，瑞将失去她的农场，不得不搬家。

Daniel Woodrell’s intense novel, Winter’s Bone, opens on Ree Dolly, a young, hard-scrabble-poor woman up in the Ozark mountains, way up in the Ozarks, with two little children, a crazy mother, and a father who makes crystal meth. As soon as the author establishes that geography, a policeman drives up and tells Ree that her father’s trial is in a week, but no one’s seen him around lately. Then John Law tells her that, to go his bail, her father signed the note on her land and her house. If he doesn’t show up for trial on Monday, Ree will lose her farm and have to move.

现在她必须去找她的爸爸。故事开始得非常仓促。

Now she’s got to go find her daddy. The story starts off in a big hurry.

前十页。故事开始时，我们对 Ree 的情况了解不多，但我们知道她有一个非常大的问题，而这正是我们感兴趣的问题。

First ten pages. We don’t know much about Ree when the story gets going, but we do know she’s got ONE HELL OF A PROBLEM and it’s a problem we’re interested in.

您不想设置。

You don’t want set up.

你想要一个已经动人心弦的故事——而且是轻快的。

You want a story that’s already moving — with alacrity.

向我们展示平凡的世界——英雄在哪里生活、如何生活。

Show us the ordinary world — where and how the hero lives.

介绍主要人物。

Introduce the main characters.

确保我们知道我们属于什么类型。

Make sure we know what genre we’re in.

告诉我们中心冲突、前提和主题是什么。

Tell us what the central conflict, premise, and theme are going to be.

第十页左右是引发事件。

Somewhere around page ten is the inciting incident.

你如何介绍主角？花很多时间介绍他。他们的开场是否戏剧化、生动、引人入胜或令人感动？这是正确的开场吗？你可以做些什么来改进它？让它更具戏剧性？

How do you introduce your main character? Spend a lot of time with that one. Is their opening moment dramatic or telling or compelling or heartwarming? Is it the right intro? What can you do to improve it? Make it more dramatic?

《鬣蜥之夜》以雨水淋漓的隔板教堂外景开场，布道的标题印在招牌上。然后我们慢慢走进教堂，看到牧师理查德·伯顿和他的教区居民挤满了教堂。跳到屋顶上，一心想看他。然后（仍然是在电影的前 45 秒），伯顿发疯了，痛斥他的会众，完全失去了控制。这就是开场！

Night of the Iguana opens with a rainy exterior of a clapboard church, the sermon’s title on the sign. Then we slowly go inside, to see the pastor, Richard Burton, and his parishioners, jammed to the rafters, hungrily intent on watching him. Then (still in the first 45 seconds of the film), Burton goes nuts, excoriates his congregation, and totally loses control. That’s an opening!

我们迫切想知道这个人是谁，以及他为什么要发表如此疯狂的布道。他遭受着折磨，显然是在受刑。我们对他的问题很感兴趣。我们想知道他过去做过什么，因为他谈到了亲戚们的“欲望”，而他现在仍然有。开场以他的会众从教堂涌出，像从沉船上涌出的老鼠一样冲进雨中结束。多么迷人的开头，由一个我们想了解更多的人物推动着。我们想翻开这一页，继续阅读……

We desperately want to know who this guy is and why he’s giving this frenzied sermon. He’s tortured, obviously on the rack. We’re intrigued by his problem. We want to find out what he did in his past, because he speaks of “appetites” that his relatives had, that he still has. The opening scene ends with his congregation pouring out of the church into the rain, like rats from a sinking ship. What a fascinating beginning, shoved forward by a character we want to learn more about. We want to turn the page and keep reading.

那么，我们如何应对对手呢？同样的问题。

And, how do we meet the opponent? Same questions apply.

快速浏览前十页：

A quick look at first ten pages:

 

亡命天涯——男主角的妻子被谋杀。他被捕了。他乘坐的火车出事了，他逃脱了。

巴顿将军——那段精彩的演讲！（不是通常的前十页，但真的很吸引人！）

西雅图不眠之夜——他的妻子去世了，他搬到了西雅图。窈窕淑男——男主角找不到演艺工作。他和特瑞·加尔在一起，但她没有得到这份工作，但这为他最终决定穿得像个女人埋下了伏笔。

真实罗曼史——男孩遇到一个女孩，他们共度良宵。她承认他的老板雇她来勾引他作为生日礼物。他们意识到他们相爱了。

毕业生——本的毕业典礼派对。他被告知未来是“塑料的”。罗宾逊太太要求载他回家。在她的日光浴室里，故事进行了十分钟后，他说：“罗宾逊太太，你是想勾引我吗？”

The Fugitive — Hero’s wife is murdered. He’s arrested. The train he’s being transported on crashes and he escapes.

Patton — That amazing speech! (not the usual first ten pages, but a real grabber!)

Sleepless in Seattle — His wife has died, and he moves to Seattle. Tootsie— Hero can’t get an acting job. He goes with Teri Garr and she doesn’t get the job, but the seed is planted for his eventual decision to dress like a woman.

True Romance — The guy meets a girl and they spend the night together. She confesses his boss hired her to seduce him for his birthday. They realize they’re in love.

The Graduate — Party for Ben’s graduation. He’s told the future is “plastics.” Mrs. Robinson asks for a ride home. In her sunroom, at ten minutes into the story, he says, “Mrs. Robinson, are you trying to seduce me?”

看看《变相怪杰》前十分钟他们讲了多少故事。很多！男主角是斯坦利·伊克皮斯，一个胆小鬼。被房东鄙视，不受女人尊重。

Look at how much ground they cover in the first ten minutes of The Mask. A lot! The hero is Stanley Ikpiss, nebbish. Despised by his landlady and disrespected by women.

 

1. 一次海底打捞事故后，一个古老的箱子破开，面具浮到了水面。

1. After an undersea salvage accident, an ancient chest breaks open and the mask floats to the surface.

 

2. 斯坦利的女同事让他把为他们俩买的票给她，这样她就可以带她的朋友去听音乐会了。他真可怜。

2. Stanley’s female co-worker makes him give tickets that he’d bought for the two of them to her so she can take her friend to the concert. He’s pathetic.

 

3. 他的伙伴告诉斯坦利，他需要改变。他们要去参加一场爱情之旅！闪电劈啪作响。

3. His buddy tells Stanley that he needs a change. They’re going on a love safari! Lightning crackles.

 

4. 一位美丽的女孩从雨中走进银行。她无视伙伴，直奔我们的英雄而去，这让所有人都感到惊讶。

4. A gorgeous girl comes out of the rain into the bank. Ignoring the buddy, she beelines for our hero, which surprises everybody.

 

5. 斯坦利想为她开一个支票账户，但很难打开他的办公桌抽屉。她用他的面巾纸擦了擦身体。

5. Stanley wants to open a checking account for her, but struggles to get his desk drawer open. She dabs herself off with his Kleenex.

 

6. 她用领带将他拉向自己，性感时刻。他的领带本应让他感到强大。她问这是否有效。

6. She pulls him toward her with his tie, sexy moment. His tie is supposed to make him feel powerful. She asks if it works.

 

7. 他查看了所有类型的账户。我们看到她的包里有一台相机。呵呵！镜头切换到：二号坏人和他的帮凶。他们谈论银行的报警系统。他们讨论一号坏人。

7. He goes over all the types of accounts. We see she has a camera in her bag. Ho ho! CUT TO: The #2 Bad Guy and his Henchman. They talk about the bank’s alarm system. They discuss the #1 Bad Guy.

 

8. #2 坏人有野心，想成为第一。镜头切换：斯坦利去汽车修理店。

8. #2 Bad Guy has ambition, wants to be number one. CUT TO: Stanley goes to a car repair shop.

 

9. 汽车修理工对斯坦利不屑一顾，敲诈他钱财。他得到的是一辆比糟糕还要糟糕的“借用”汽车。

9. The car repairmen treat Stanley like dirt, fleecing him for money. He gets the worse-than-awful “loaner” car.

 

10. Coco Bongo 俱乐部。斯坦利开着借来的车去见他的伙伴和两个可爱的女孩。2 号坏人和他的追随者在俱乐部外面。斯坦利再次受到虐待，被意外地留在了俱乐部外面。

10. Coco Bongo club. Stanley bumps up in the loaner to meet his buddy and two cute girls. #2 Bad Guy and his Henchman are outside the club. Stanley, again treated badly, is accidentally left outside the club.

我们见到了所有主要角色，包括面具和头号坏蛋的照片。我们知道这是现代喜剧类型。我们了解到斯坦利没有女朋友，基本上是女人、汽车修理工和他接触到的其他人的受气包。

We meet all the major players, including the mask and a photo of the #1 Bad Guy. We know the genre, which is modern-day comedy. We learn Stanley has no girlfriend and is basically a doormat for women, car repairmen, and everyone else he comes in contact with.

十分钟内就搞定了！我累坏了！

All that in ten minutes! I’m exhausted!

就在第三分钟，斯坦利的朋友告诉他，他需要改变——这部电影的重点就在于此，用一句台词就表达出来了。《四十岁的老处男》中也这么做了！

Right there in minute three, Stanley’s buddy tells him he need a change — the whole point to the movie, laid out there in one line of dialogue. They do it in The 40-Year-Old Virgin, too!

大卫

DAVID

你就像所有这些人物模型一样，

密封得严严实实。你全身都绷紧了。

You’re like all of these action figures,

hermetically sealed. You’re all wound up.

这是我的两个学生写的剧本的前几页。

Here are the first couple of pages from a script by two of my students.

 

 

现在，你开始明白我认为什么是重要的了。我不是唯一一个这么认为的人。

By now, you’re beginning to see what I think is important. I’m not the only one.

71. 你还没有撕掉前 20 页！

71. You haven’t ripped out the first 20 pages!

 
 

“没有背景故事。”

沃尔特·希尔

“There is no backstory.”

Walter Hill

几乎每个人都会犯将背景故事放在第一幕的错误。

Putting backstory in the first act is a mistake nearly everyone makes.

新手作家通常需要很长时间才能开始创作一部电影。没有必要犹豫不决地等待引擎预热。你的读者非常喜爱你的剧本，你需要避免让她失望。当你完成初稿时，看看删掉前 15-20 页是否有帮助。

Beginning writers often take a long time to start a movie. There’s no need to shilly shally around waiting for the engine to warm up. Your reader is dying to love your screenplay and you need to keep from disappointing her. When you have your first draft finished, see if ripping out the first 15–20 pages will help.

电影更接近短篇故事而非小说，因为它讲究简洁，以及向观众提供多少信息。你必须非常挑剔和优雅地选择要告诉观众什么以及什么是重要的。

Movies are closer to short stories than novels, because it’s all about brevity and how much information you give the audience. You have to be really picky and elegant about what you chose to tell them and what matters.

在前 20 页中，找到你绝对需要的微小背景故事，并将它们放在第 40、62 和 93 页上。然后扔掉前 20 页。如果读者在第 20 页停止，但你的故事直到第 30 页才真正开始，他们将永远看不到你的故事。

In the first 20 pages, find the tiny pieces of backstory that you absolutely have to have and salt them in on page 40, 62, and 93. Then toss the first 20. If the reader stops on page 20, but your story doesn’t really get going until page 30, they will never see your story.

 

“我总是试图找到一个地方，故事可以讲到哪里，又不会让观众感到困惑……15 分钟后，他们会跟上吗？”

彼得·威尔

“I always try to find a place, how far into the story can I start and still not confuse the audience… in 15 minutes, will they have caught up?”

Peter Weir

作家们经常花太多时间“设置故事”，而他们应该直接讲述故事。不要解释每个人是谁。通过让他们向前发展、做事来向我们展示他们是谁。一个典型的例子：

Writers often take too long “setting up the story” when they should just get on with telling it. Don’t explain who everyone is. Show us who they are by putting them in forward motion, doing stuff. A classic example:

 

男人早上醒来。

男人洗澡、刮胡子。

男子开车前往火车站。

男子买了一张票。

男子上了火车。火车驶出车站。

观众发现，男子的行李箱里有一颗炸弹。

Man wakes up in the morning.

Man showers and shaves.

Man drives to the train station.

Man buys a ticket.

Man gets on the train. Train pulls out of station.

It is revealed to audience that Man has a bomb in his suitcase.

揭露得很棒，但是，尽管在最初的场景中可能有很多精彩的人物时刻，但直到我们发现炸弹后，故事才变得精彩。“但我需要告诉你这个人是谁！”当我拿着我的大红笔走近时，你会哀怨地对我说。我会说，“不行！把这个人放到火车上，让我们在火车飞驰在轨道上时找出他是谁。”

Great reveal, but, even though there may have been lots of great character moments in those first scenes, the story doesn’t get rocking until we find out about the bomb. “But I need to show you who this guy is!” you will say to me, plaintively, as I approach with my Big Fat Red Pen. I will say, “Ixnay! Put the guy on the train and let us find out who he is as the train is hurtling down the track.”

从以下位置开始：

Start with:

 

一名男子上了火车。火车驶离车站。

观众发现，该男子的行李箱里有炸弹。

Man gets on a train. Train pulls out of station.

It is revealed to audience that Man has a bomb in his suitcase.

后来，我们发现他离婚了，被孩子讨厌，等等。在巨大的压力下，从这个男人（他迫切需要一个不与任何人押韵的名字！）嘴里挤出一些话来学习。

Later on, we find out he’s divorced, hated by his children, etc. Learn stuff by having it squeezed out of the Man (who desperately needs a name that doesn’t rhyme with anybody else’s!) under great pressure.

通常，当你仔细阅读前 20 页时，你会发现一个场景感觉就像电影的开场场景；淡入淡出：很自然地想去那里。听听你脑海里的小声音。很多你认为重要的信息可以被抛弃，或者用一小段对话代替：

Often, as you peruse your first 20 pages, you will find a scene that just feels like the opening scene of a movie; FADE IN: just naturally wants to go there. Listen to the little voice in your head. A lot of what you thought was important information can be thrown out, or replaced by just a little dialogue:

灰姑娘

CINDERELLA

我的童年很艰难。

I had a tough childhood.

呼！前 17 页——没了！

Whoosh! First 17 pages — gone!

72. 你还没有删掉所有多余的动作！

72. You haven’t cut every bit of extraneous action!

 

您是否已尽可能地清除掉无用之人了？

Have you eliminated as much dead wood as possible?

 

“你写完然后擦掉。你把这叫做职业吗？”

索尔·贝娄的父亲

“You write and then you erase. You call that a profession?”

Saul Bellow’s father

如果苏丹说：“把白色种马牵给我们的朋友”，你是会让仆人走到马厩，给马备好鞍，牵着它穿过阅兵场来到王座室，还是让苏丹说：“把白色种马牵给我们的朋友”，然后镜头切换到：我们的英雄骑在白色种马背上，急忙回来，准备出发？

If a sultan says, “Bring the white stallion to our friend,” do you show the servant walk to the stable, saddle the horse, and walk him across the parade ground to the throne room, or do you have the Sultan say, “Bring the white stallion to our friend,” and CUT TO: our hero sitting astride the white stallion, rarin’ back, ready to go?

看《独行杀手》的 DVD 时，阿兰·德龙在长长的走廊、街道、楼梯和小巷里走来走去的场景太多了，我最终放弃了，用快进模式快速看完了这些浪费时间的场景。如果你写了人物烧鞋革的场景，当你删掉这些场景时，故事会变得更紧凑。如果读者希望她有一个快进按钮，那你就太痛苦了。

Watching the DVD of Le Samourai, there were so many scenes of Alain Delon walking up and down long hallways and down streets and up streets and up staircases and down alleys, I finally gave up and zipped through those time-wasting scenes on Fast Forward. If you wrote scenes where characters burn shoe leather, the story will get tighter when you cut them. If the reader wishes she had a Fast Forward button, you’re hurting.

即使是大牌科波拉也免不了要做一些整容手术。在《现代启示录》 DVD 的第 13 章中，船上的人收到了邮件。他们遭到岸上的射击。克林被杀了。他们经过一架坠毁的飞机，继续在雾中逆流而上。在雾气笼罩的画面左侧有一个很酷的镜头，威拉德手持 M-16 步枪。雾越来越大，他们遭到岸上的袭击，只是这次是箭。当他们意识到箭是无害的，每个人都放松了下来——然后酋长胸口被一支长矛刺穿，就像康拉德原著小说《黑暗之心》中的姆夫木一样。

Even il grande Coppola is not immune from the need for a little cosmetic surgery. In Chapter 13 of the Apocalypse Now DVD, the guys on the boat get their mail. They get shot at from shore. Clean gets killed. They pass a downed airplane and continue up river in fog. There’s a cool shot of Willard on the left of a fog-shrouded frame, with his M-16. More fog and they get attacked from shore, only this time, it’s arrows. Once they realize the arrows are harmless, everyone relaxes — and then Chief gets a spear through his chest, just like Mfumu in the source-material Conrad story, Heart of Darkness.

整洁。整齐。一个人以现代方式死去；另一个人以老式方式死去。故事像比得兔一样向前发展。喋喋不休。

Neat. Tidy. One guy dies in a modern way; another guy dies in an old-fashioned way. The story moves forward like Peter Rabbit. Lippity lippity.

然而，如果你看看《现代启示录：重现版》第 24 章中的同一时刻：他们逆流而上，克莱恩被杀，当他们进入坠毁的飞机下方后，出现了一个很酷的镜头，威拉德拿着他的 M-16 站在雾中的船头——然后一个法国人从雾中出现，欢迎威拉德和暴躁的法国人一起吃一顿毫无意义的饭，然后和一个老女人无聊的性爱，然后这个法国人把他们放回雾中的船上，然后我们看到了威拉德和他的 M-16 的镜头的后半部分。吃得好，睡得好，至少，他们逆流而上，遭到箭击，克莱恩被杀。除了性和一顿美餐，这就是威拉德所得到的一切。整个25 分钟（25 页！）的片段中，没有任何事情推动威拉德的故事向前发展。

However, if you look at the same moment in Chapter 24 of Apocalypse Now: Redux: they chug up river, Clean gets killed, and, after they go under the downed airplane, there’s the cool shot of Willard with his M-16 on the front of the boat in the fog — and then a Frenchman materializes from the fog and welcomes Willard to a pointless meal with irritable French people followed by boring sex with an older woman, then the French dude puts them back on the boat in the fog aaaaand we see the second half of the shot of Willard and his M-16. Well fed and well laid, at least, they head upriver for the arrow attack and Clean’s death. Other than sex and a nice meal, that’s all Willard gets. Nothing happens in the entire 25-minute (25 pages!) sequence that does anything to move Willard’s story forward.

那么，想象一下这是你的初稿——做得很好，但有点松弛：

So, imagine this is your first draft — nicely done, but a little flabby:

REDUX

REDUX

第23章：清洁先生之死

Chapter 23: “Mr. Clean’s Death”

第 24 章：“法国种植园”

Chapter 24: “The French Plantation”

第25章：《清洁的葬礼》

Chapter 25: “Clean’s Funeral”

第26章 “晚餐”

Chapter 26: “Dinner”

第27章：“永远的士兵”

Chapter 27: “Les soldats perdus”

第28章：箭袭

Chapter 28: “Arrow Attack”

在重写时，你会毫不留情地删除那些对故事发展没有推动作用的内容。

In your rewrite, you ruthlessly cut stuff that doesn’t shove your story ahead.

现代启示录

APOCALYPSE NOW

第 13 章：“清洁先生之死”

Chapter 13: “Mr. Clean’s Death”

融入雾中（哎呀！法国人在哪里

DISSOLVE IN THE FOG (Whoopsie! Where’s the French

种植序列？）

Plantation sequence?)

第14章：箭袭

Chapter 14: “Arrow Attack”

一堂精彩的编剧课。谢谢你，科波拉先生！削去那些枯木，将你的剧本卖到十亿美元！

An amazing lesson in screenwriting. Thank you, Mr. Coppola! Slice that dead wood and sell your script for a zillion dollars!

相信我。越短越好。

Trust me. It’s better when it’s shorter.

你可以通过删掉无聊的内容来增加紧张感。很酷吧？

You can increase tension by cutting out the boring stuff. Cool, huh?

每个场景都必须向前推进。好的场景会推动下一个场景。当你阅读它时，你可以感觉到结尾的突然性，因为它会无情地将你推向前方。你的故事应该像一列没有刹车的货运列车一样移动。

Each scene must crackle with forward motion. Good scenes shove ahead to the next one. When you read it, you can feel the snap at the end as it launches you relentlessly down the road. Your story should be moving like a freight train with no brakes.

初稿。结尾有点拖沓。其实没必要这样。

First draft. This droops a bit at the end. It doesn’t have to.

卡罗琳还没来得及阻止他，他就跳下了出租车，飞快地沿着街道前行。

He jumps out of the cab before Carolyn can stop him. He hauls ass down the street.

卡罗琳

CAROLYN

拜托！别这样！

Come on man! Don’t do this!

出租车司机

CAB DRIVER

去哪儿？

Where to?

卡罗琳沉默了。

Carolyn is silent.

出租车司机

CAB DRIVER

去哪儿？

Where to?

卡罗琳

CAROLYN

自助洗衣店。

The laundromat.

如果你剪掉最后的一小段，你就会以“啪”的一声结束这个场景，保持高昂的能量，并推动我们前进。

If you cut the last little bit, you finish the scene with a “snap,” keep the energy high, and push us forward.

卡罗琳还没来得及阻止他，他就跳下了出租车，飞快地沿着街道前行。

He jumps out of the cab before Carolyn can stop him. He hauls ass down the street.

卡罗琳

CAROLYN

拜托！别这样！

Come on man! Don’t do this!

出租车司机

CAB DRIVER

去哪儿？

Where to?

外部。希望洗净的日子

EXT. WISHY WASHY     DAY

出租车进站了。戴夫坐在车里，踢着找零机。

The cab pulls in. Dave’s inside, kicking the change machine.

你也可以在中间放弃一些无聊的东西：

You can also drop out boring stuff in the middle:

“爸爸，我的肚子疼。”

“Daddy, my tummy hurts.”

下一幕

NEXT SCENE

孩子在医院里濒临死亡。

Kid’s in the hospital near death.

在温柔的怜悯中：

In Tender Mercies:

“你想过结婚吗？”

“You ever think about getting married?”

下一幕

NEXT SCENE

他们结婚已有一段时间了。

They’ve been married for a while.

删去中间部分就是省略。它有助于保持紧张感。使用它来推动你的故事向前发展。事情发生了，并不意味着你需要向我们展示！

Cutting out the middle is ellipsis. It helps keep tension high. Use it to move your story forward. Just because stuff happens, doesn’t mean you need to show us!

这是我的剧本中的一页，上面有我的潦草笔记。

Here’s a page from a script of mine, with my scribbles on it.

 

让我们来看看我做了什么。请注意。这会很无聊。

Let’s walk through what I did. Be forewarned. This will be boring.

 

我删去了“他的遐想破灭了”，因为我已经说过他很孤独，并且认为读者会明白，当闪电击中树时，他在做其他事情。

I cut “his reverie shatters” because I’d already said he was lonely, and figured the reader would get that he was on to other things when lightning strikes the tree.

 

如果他“一瞬间”看到了海盗，那么我们就已经知道“幽灵已经消失了”。

If he sees a pirate “for an instant” then we already know the “apparition is gone.”

 

我将“Matt”改为“他”，因为我在该段落中已经使用了两次“Matt”。

I changed “Matt” to “he” because I’d already used “Matt” twice in that paragraph.

 

“岩石滚落” 变成了“土块滚动”，因为这是一片玉米地。没有岩石。

“Rocks tumble” became “dirt clods roll” because it’s a corn field. Not rocky.

 

“Matt hears a” 消失了，因为 SPLASH 是他听到的音效。

“Matt hears a” is gone because SPLASH is a sound effect that he hears.

 

首先，我删去了“远”，因为他把一块石头扔进了田野。谁在乎有多远？然后我删去了“进入黑暗的田野”，因为我们从上下文中知道他把石头扔到了哪里，所以何必重复呢？

First I cut “far” because he heaved a rock into the field. Who cares how far? Then I cut “into the dark field” because we figure out where he heaved it from the context, so why repeat?

 

我把 slugline 一直缩减到“THE TOWN”。实际上，我在下一稿中又放回了“DISTANT”。我喜欢 slugline 有助于创造形象的想法。

I trimmed the slugline all the way down to “THE TOWN.” I actually put “DISTANT” back in the next draft. I liked the idea that the slugline helps create the image.

 

“前方”——我们已经知道这座城镇就在他面前。

“Ahead” — we already know the town is in front of him.

 

这个小镇很远，所以“像 7 月 4 日一样灯火通明”就足够了，尽管我很喜欢“达尔格利什海盗节完全失控了”这句话。不要重复。

The town is far away, so “lit up like the 4th of July” suffices, despite how much I love the line “the Dalgleish Pirate Festival is deliriously out of control.” Don’t repeat.

 

不需要“镜头对准马特”。我不是导演。只要告诉我们摄像机在哪里就行。

Don’t need “ANGLE ON MATT.” I’m not the director. Just tell us where the camera is.

 

“奔向城镇” 删除“the”。有趣的是，当它消失时，你就不再需要它了。

“runs toward the town” Cut the “the.” Interesting how, when it’s gone, you never needed it.

 

“他的脚把更多的泥土踢下路堤”比我初稿中的写法更干净。

“His feet kick more dirt down the embankment” is cleaner than what I had in the first draft.

 

不需要“击打”玉米，我曾经说过“让玉米像水一样荡漾”。

Don’t need “striking” the corn, once I said “causing the corn to ripple like water.”

 

我对“马特没看到”这句话犯了一个错误，所有事情都应该用现在时。

I made a mistake with “Matt didn’t see,” in that everything should be in present tense.

 

我放弃了 EXT，因为我们现在知道我们在哪里。

I dropped the EXT. because we know where we are by now.

 

“马特飞奔而过，冲进了小镇。”如果他在跑，我们就知道他往下走的时候会经过路标。另外，还有一个没用的“the”。

“Matt flies past, into the town.” If he is running we know he’s going to be passing the sign as he heads toward down. Also, another useless “the.”

 

我仍然不确定我在这里做出了正确的决定。“剑和手枪和‘Argghhhs’比比皆是”是一句有趣的台词。“Full tilt pandemonium”的字数较少，但可能不是最好的形象。

I’m still not sure I made the right decision here. “Swords and pistols and ‘Argghhhs’ abound” is a fun line. “Full tilt pandemonium” has fewer words, but may not be the best image.

 

首先，我去掉了副词“害羞地”——然后将“漫步在街道上”改为“探索”。这个词更好，因为它比“漫步”更能讲述故事。

First, I got rid of the adverb — “shyly” — then changed “wanders through the streets” to “explores.” Far better word, as it tells more story than “wanders.”

 

“Walks past” 与“passes” 意思相同，但占用的空间更大。

“Walks past” is the same as “passes” but takes up more space.

 

“好吧，亲爱的，你拿到地图了吗？”以最重要的一句话结尾。

“Well, me hearty, have ye got me map?” ends with the most important word.

 

我很聪明，我把“惊呆了”从场景描述中移到了括号中，省去了一行。今天再看，我决定删掉它。

Clever me, I saved a line here by moving “stupefied” from scene description into a parenthetical. Looking at it today, I’d cut it.

 

在现实生活中，保罗·里维尔不会喊“英国人来了！英国人来了！”而是会说“正规军出动了！正规军出动了！”哪个台词更好？当然是改写版。

In real life, instead of shouting, “The British are coming! The British are coming!” Paul Revere actually said, “The Regulars are out! The Regulars are out!” Which makes for better dialogue? The rewritten version, naturally.

重写，否则消亡。

Rewrite or perish.

73. 你认为你的第一稿（或第九稿）已经完美了！

73. You think your first (or ninth) draft is perfect!

 

这不是你想要的。

Not what you want.

假装法官朱迪正在审阅你的草稿，她是个讨厌的批评家——如果你不能很好地解释为什么某些东西在那里，她就会狠狠地批评你。你必须变成你自己的法官朱迪。这并不容易。如果你喜欢写它，也喜欢读它，那么你可能有麻烦了。把它搁置一段时间，当你拖出来重写时，问一些尖锐的问题。

Pretend Judge Judy is looking at your draft, being an obnoxious critic — if you don’t have a good answer for why something is there, she hammers you flat. You must turn into your own Judge Judy. This is not easy. If you love it when you write it and you love it when you read it, you’re probably in trouble. Put it away for a while and ask tough questions when you drag it out for the rewrite.

 

这是否传达了我想要传达的信息？

故事开始得够晚吗？

结尾是否有足够的情感和力量？

角色的行为是否符合他们的本意，是否像在其他场景中一样？

我们关心角色和她的问题吗？

风险是否很高，是否会越来越高？

关心幕间休息的人能找到它们吗？

所有场景描述是否简洁明了？

每个角色的对话是否显然都是他们自己说的？（“你必须将角色的对话分开”的戒律）

页面看起来是否像它们应该的那样？

剧本真的很好还是我只是希望它好？

我可以从几乎每个场景中挤出更多关于角色的内容吗？

我能做些什么让场景更好、更令人难忘、更有趣？

我是否已经完成了整个“你的剧本糟透了！”清单？

Does this communicate what I wanted it to?

Do I start the story late enough?

Does the ending have enough emotion and power?

Do the characters behave like they should, and like they do in every other scene?

Do we care about the character and her problem?

Are the stakes high and do they go higher?

Will people who care about act breaks be able to find them?

Is ALL scene description terse and crystal clear?

Is every character’s dialogue obviously being spoken by them and them alone? (the Thou Shalt Separate the Character’s Dialogue commandment)

Do the pages look like they are supposed to?

Is the script really good or do I just hope it is?

Can I squeeze something more about the character from nearly every scene?

What can I do to make the scene better, more memorable, more interesting?

Have I done the entire Your Screenplay Sucks! checklist?

重写不仅仅是为了使阅读更轻松而修改文本。它还意味着出于各种原因改变场景。为了让角色更深刻，调整对话，修复结构问题，细化故事情节——任何能让剧本更好地讲述故事的事情。

Rewriting is not only massaging the text to make the read easy. It also means changing the scene for any number of reasons. To make a character deeper, tweak dialogue, fix a structural problem, nuance a story beat — anything that makes the screenplay work better as a story.

你必须不断阅读、大声朗读和重写，直到一切都按你想要的方式发生，而且以对角色和故事来说最好的方式发生。批判的眼光是有帮助的。不要太喜欢你的写作也是有帮助的。

You must keep reading and reading aloud and rewriting until everything is happening, not just the way you want it to, but in the best possible way for the characters and the story. It helps to have a critical eye. It helps not to love your writing too much.

这是我写的一个场景。

Here’s a scene I wrote.

第一个版本：

FIRST VERSION:

室内商业摄影工作室日

INT. COMMERCIAL PHOTOGRAPHY STUDIO   DAY

音乐震耳欲聋。一位粗犷的年轻摄影师、半裸的模特、理发师、经纪人、马琳和十几个衣冠楚楚的衣架。整个摇滚盛宴。

MUSIC pounding. A rugged young PHOTOGRAPHER, half-dressed MODELS, HAIRDRESSERS, AGENCY TYPES, Marlene, a dozen HANGERS ON. The whole rock and roll enchilada.

摄影师拍摄了三名女性。罗伯特手持法律文件，像雷神一样冲了进来。砰的一声关门声让一切突然停止。

The photographer shoots three women. Holding the legal papers, Robert blows in like Thor. The SLAMMING DOOR smacks everything to a sudden halt.

摄影师

PHOTOGRAPHER

（对入侵感到愤怒）

(pissed at intrusion)

这很专业。

This is professional.

每个人都看着，很恼火。

Everyone watches, annoyed.

马琳

MARLENE

罗伯特。我在上班。

Robert. I’m at work.

罗伯特

ROBERT

我也是，而且我在

演示过程中就得到了服务！

So was I and I got served in the middle of

a presentation!

马琳

MARLENE

抓紧。

Get a grip.

罗伯特

ROBERT

我以为我们正在解决这个问题。

I thought we were working this out.

摄影师

PHOTOGRAPHER

显然你错过了一份备忘录。

Obviously you missed a memo.

马琳催促罗伯特走到前面。身后一片寂静。

Marlene hustles Robert out front. Behind them, silence.

在第一个版本中，我对这个版本很满意，但很长一段时间里，与罗伯特离婚的妻子玛琳并不是一个好人。在读了大约一百遍剧本后，我意识到，如果玛琳是一个爱抓脸的泼妇，那么读者就会认为罗伯特娶她是白痴。

In the first version, which I was totally happy with for a long time, Marlene, the wife who is divorcing Robert, is, um, not a nice person. After reading the script about a hundred times, I realized that if Marlene is a face-scratching harpie, then the reader will think Robert is an idiot for marrying her.

在重写中，她的语气淡了下来。整个场景都变得淡了。这些变化很微妙，但很有说服力。

In the rewrite, she gets toned down. The entire scene gets toned down. The changes are subtle, but telling.

第二个版本：

SECOND VERSION:

室内商业摄影工作室日

INT. COMMERCIAL PHOTOGRAPHY STUDIO   DAY

音乐震耳欲聋。马琳，一位粗犷的年轻摄影师，半裸的模特，理发师，代理商，十几个衣冠楚楚的衣架。整个摇滚盛宴。

MUSIC pounding. Marlene, a rugged young PHOTOGRAPHER, halfdressed MODELS, HAIRDRESSERS, AGENCY TYPES, a dozen HANGERS ON. The whole rock and roll enchilada.

摄影师拍摄了三名女性。

The photographer shoots three women.

罗伯特拿着法律文件，溜到后面。他没想到门突然像雷声一样关上了。一切都戛然而止。

Holding the legal papers, Robert slips in the back. What he doesn’t count on is the door SLAMMING LIKE A THUNDERCLAP. Everything jerks to a halt.

摄影师

PHOTOGRAPHER

（对入侵感到愤怒）

(pissed at intrusion)

这很专业。

This is professional.

大家都看着，觉得很有趣。

Everyone watches, amused.

马琳

MARLENE

罗伯特。我在上班。

Robert. I’m at work.

罗伯特

ROBERT

（摇摆论文）

(wags papers)

我在演讲进行到一半时得到了服务。

I got served in the middle of a presentation.

马琳

MARLENE

哦天啊。我很抱歉。

Oh God. I’m sorry.

罗伯特

ROBERT

我以为我们正在解决这个问题。

I thought we were working this out.

摄影师

PHOTOGRAPHER

显然你错过了一份备忘录。

Obviously you missed a memo.

马琳领着罗伯特走到前面。他们身后是闲聊声。

Marlene leads Robert out front. Behind them, gossip.

玛琳对他好多了，不再那么尖刻了。她不再催他走。他爱她，看起来并不像个傻子。

Marlene is kinder to him, not as biting. She no longer hustles him out. He doesn’t seem like a fool for loving her.

即使是上述这些看似微不足道的改变，也会产生长期的累积效应。你在第 48 页所做的更改将影响第 49、50 和 51 页——每一页，一直到第 110 页。想象一下你的故事就像一条流淌的河流。每个场景都顺着前一个场景而下。如果你在第 48 页做了一些改变，比如让玛琳变得更友善一些，这就像你把一桶蓝色染料倒进河里——随着你的故事继续流动，它会给下游的一切染上颜色。

Even seemingly insignificant changes like the ones above will have a long-term, cumulative effect. A change you make on page 48 will affect page 49 and 50 and 51 — every single page, all the way to 110. Imagine your story like a river flowing by. Every scene is downstream from the one before. If you make a change on page 48, like making Marlene a little nicer, it’s as if you pour a bucket of blue dye into the river — as your story continues to flow, it will color everything downstream.

挑剔，挑剔，挑剔

Picky, Picky, Picky

 

74. 你不知道剧本里每个字的意思！

74. You don’t know the meaning of every word in your script!

 

读者关心这些事情。在现实生活中你可能不会关心，但在“我是一名编剧”的生活中，你最好把这些事情做好。

Readers care about this stuff. You may not in your real life, but in your “I’m a screenwriter life,” you better get it right.

例如，“水泥”这个词。你可能用错了。你听到别人这么说并不意味着它是正确的。水泥是一种装在袋子里的粉末。混凝土是水、沙子、石头和水泥的混合物。车道不是水泥。克兰佩特奶奶称它为“薄荷池”，而不是混凝土游泳池。但谁在乎呢，她不是想卖剧本。

For instance, the word “cement.” You probably use it wrong. Just because you heard someone say it doesn’t mean it’s correct. Cement is a powder that comes in bags. Concrete is a mixture of water, sand, stone, and cement. Driveways are not cement. Granny Clampett called it a “see mint pond” instead of a concrete swimming pool. But who cares, she wasn’t trying to sell a screenplay.

 

“他拿出他总是放在夹克内袋里的自动铅笔，然后……在‘这本书依然像以往一样新颖独特’这句话上做了他一贯的整洁校对。他把它改成了‘依然独一无二，像以往一样新颖。’‘独特性没有等级之分，’肖恩先生礼貌地说。”

莉莲·罗斯 (Lillian Ross) 评价威廉·肖恩

“He took out the mechanical pencil he always carried in his inside jacket pocket, and… made his characteristically neat proofreading marks on a sentence that said ‘the book remains as fresh and unique as ever.’ He changed it to read, ‘remains unique and as fresh as ever.’ ‘There are no degrees of uniqueness,’ Mr. Shawn said politely.”

Lillian Ross on William Shawn

由于您在写作时可能处于在线状态，因此请继续使用www.dictionary.com — 大量使用！

Since you’re probably online while you’re writing, go ahead and use www.dictionary.com — a lot!

戴夫和蒂莫西在镇上四处游荡，欣喜若狂，极度迷恋。

Dave and Timothy bang around the town, ecstatic and extremely besotted.

 

首先，不要用“the”。如果这些男人都迷恋对方，他们是喝醉了还是恋爱了？到底是哪一种情况呢？

First, lose the “the.” If these guys are besotted with each other, are they drunk or perhaps in love? Which might it be?

一些地雷：

Some landmines:

 

影响，效果

为了所有意图和目的与（我最喜欢的，教了十三年

）“为了所有密集的目的”

你的，你

在那里，他们的，他们是

地幔，壁炉

架 事业与照顾（“事业”意味着匆匆走下路，“照顾”意味着倾斜，就像把船靠在海滩上刮藤壶一样）

迫不及待与咬紧牙关（查一下。你只认为你知道。）

离开道奇（道奇是一座城市，大写字母。）

她控制着他。 她让他陷入困境。 她控制着他。 哪一个是正确的？去找出答案。

泰然自若的

女英雄。女主角。角色经常想把女人射进他们的血管里。 奇怪。

高峰。偷看。激怒。当她无法偷看高峰时，她很生气。

站点。视线。引用。三个词的含义截然不同，却被白痴互换使用。

affect, effect

for all intents and purposes vs. (my favorite, after thirteen years,

teaching) “for all intensive purposes”

your, you’re

there, their, they’re

mantle, mantel

career vs. careen (“career” means hurry down the road, “careen” means to tilt over, like leaning a ship over on a beach to scrape barnacles)

champing at the bit vs. chomping at the bit (Look it up. You only think you know.)

get the hell out of Dodge (Dodge is a city, gets a capital letter.)

She reigns him in. She rains him in. She reins him in. Which is correct? Go find out.

unfazed

Heroin. Heroine. Characters often want to shoot women into their veins. Odd.

Peak. Peek. Pique. She was piqued when she couldn’t get a peek of the peak.

Site. Sight. Cite. Three words with vastly different meanings, used interchangeably by morons.

It's 与 its 相对。将计算机设置为搜索模式，搜索每个 it's，并确保正确使用了 it's。“It's” 表示它是。“Its” 是所有格。

It’s vs. its. Set your computer on search and search for every it’s and make sure you’ve used it correctly. “It’s” means it is. “Its” is possessive.

狗看着它的碗。碗是空的。狗撅起嘴。

The dog looks at its bowl. It’s empty. The dog pouts.

 

仅供参考，“它的，它的”故障确实惹恼了某些读者。

FYI, the “its, it’s” glitch really pisses some readers off.

如果一个名叫 Billy Ray 的人说“我赞成！”，这和名叫 Nigel 的人说“我赞成！”的意思一样吗？ 完全不是。Nigel 是英国人，他陷入了困境，可能会入狱。Billy Ray 只是认为“它”是个好主意。你必须知道自己在写什么。

If somebody named Billy Ray says “I’m for it!” does it mean the same thing as someone named Nigel saying “I’m for it!”? Not hardly. Nigel, who is English, is in deep trouble and may end up in prison. Billy Ray just thinks “it” is a good idea. You have to know what you’re writing.

除非你是一个读这本书的六年级学生，并且（想像一下！）同时在写你的第一篇学期论文和第一部剧本，否则你已经知道你是否掌握了相当好的英语水平。对于一些人来说，语法和拼写错误是可怕的怪物。这不是犯罪。这类似于需要戴眼镜。不可原谅的是，如果你需要戴眼镜，但开车时不戴！如果你犯了语法错误，读者和制片人会严厉批评你，所以，如果你的语法使用不当，找个朋友让他们纠正你的错误。当然，说“我的语法很糟糕”很尴尬，但把所有时间都花在剧本上，然后因为你的散文混乱，或者更糟的是，难以理解而浪费了一次阅读时间，这更糟糕。对吧？

Unless you are a sixth grader reading this book, and (fancy that!) working on your first term paper and first screenplay at the same time, you already know whether or not you have a decent command of the English language. For some people, grammar and spelling are terrible bugaboos. This is not a crime. It’s akin to needing glasses. What’s unforgivable is if you need glasses but don’t wear them when you drive! Readers and producers will crucify you if you make mistakes in grammar, so, if your use of grammar is not what it should be, find a friend and get them to correct your mistakes. Sure, it’s embarrassing to say, “My grammar is stinko,” but it’s worse to spend all that time on a screenplay and then waste a read because your prose is muddled, or worse, incomprehensible. Right?

当然，这并不适用于对话。并非每个角色都像简·奥斯汀那样说话。你不应该在对话中使用完美的语法。废话。

This, of course, does not apply to dialogue. Not every character talks like Jane Austen. You’re not supposed to use perfect grammar in dialogue. Duuh.

75. 你用数字代替文字！

75. You use numbers instead of words!

 

尤其是在对话中。

Especially in dialogue.

戴夫

DAVE

我们必须在5点到达那里。

We have to be there at 5.

康妮

CONNIE

有 135 个丘比特娃娃吗？

With all 135 kewpie dolls?

戴夫

DAVE

实际上是 235。

It’s 235, actually.

你正在写对话，让演员说，让读者读——按照你希望的方式。所以，用文字代替数字。

You are writing dialogue for an actor to say, and for a reader to read — the way you want it to sound. So, use words instead of numbers.

戴夫

DAVE

我们必须在五点到达那里。

We have to be there at five.

康妮

CONNIE

和所有一百三十五只丘比娃娃一起吗？

With all one hundred and thirty-five kewpie dolls?

戴夫

DAVE

实际上，现在是两点三十五分。

It’s two thirty-five, actually.

这也适用于角色名称。最好给他们起一个能告诉我们一些关于他们的事情的名字。很酷的朋友。

This also applies to character names. It would be better to give them names that tell us something about them. COOL FRIEND.

浪漫的男人。迷人的宝贝。利用可用资源 — 随时告诉我们您能告诉我们的一切。

ROMANTIC GUY. SWELL BABE. Use the available resources — tell us all you can, all the time.

朋友 #1

FRIEND #1

她现在一定得打扮得漂漂亮亮。

She’s totally going to get dolled up right now.

朋友 #2

FREIND #2

毫无疑问。我也会。汉克斯真是太梦幻了。

Without a doubt. I would too. Hanks is so fucking dreamy.

朋友 #3

FRIEND #3

如果安吉和他勾搭上，那该有多糟糕啊。

How bad ass would it be if Angie hooked up with him.

朋友 #2

FRIEND #2

她是我们当中最有胆量的人。

She is the most balls-y o fall of us.

请记住，糟糕的校对会让制作人很生气！还有，亲爱的，一定要记得运行你的#$%@!&! 拼写检查！！！不像上面的作者，他没有做到这两点！

Do keep in mind, piss-poor proofreading pisses producers off! And do, sweet thing, do remember to RUN YOUR #$%@!&! SPELLCHECK!!! Unlike the above writer who failed to do both!

76. 你发号施令！

76. You call shots!

 

这一点几乎是常识，但值得一提。如果你有一位编剧老师或一本书告诉你，写这样的 slugline 是个聪明的主意：

This one is pretty much common knowledge, but worth mentioning. If you’ve got a screenwriting teacher or book that tells you it’s a clever idea to write sluglines like this:

潜艇内景 - 中景 - 夜晚的 BITSY 掌舵

INT. SUBMARINE - MEDIUM SHOT - BITSY AT THE HELM NIGHT

 

外部广角镜头 - 老麦当劳农场日

EXT. WIDE SHOT - OLD McDONALD’S FARM DAY

 

外部特写 - 爱因斯坦鹦鹉

EXT. MEDIUM CLOSE UP - EINSTEIN’S PARAKEET

 

...把你的书或者你的老师放到一边。

...put your book or your teacher out to pasture.

永远不要发号施令。那不是你的职责所在。他们有电影导演和摄影师，他们拿着高薪来处理这些事情。很久以前，在普雷斯顿·斯特吉斯的时代，剧本里包括了镜头角度。现在没有了。

Never call a shot. That’s not your department. They have movie directors and cinematographers who are well paid to figure out that stuff. Long ago, in Preston Sturges’ time, scripts included camera angles. No more.

我说“绝不”。我的意思并不是这样。在整个剧本中，你可以两三次随意发出一个镜头，但最好是极其重要的。例如，如果为了让读者了解正在发生的事情，摄像机必须高高地位于即将爆炸的汽车上方，那么你可以给出摄像机角度。

I said “never.” I didn’t quite mean it. You can, maybe two or three times in an entire screenplay, get away with calling a shot, but it better be diabolically important. For instance, if, for the reader to understand what is going on, the camera has to be high above the car that’s about to explode, then you can give the camera angle.

但只能出现一两次。超过两次，你会惹恼别人，为什么要冒这个险呢？不过，你仍然可以通过编写场景描述来“放置摄像机”。

But only once or twice. More than that, you’re going to irritate someone, and why take that risk? However, you can still “place the camera” by how you write scene description.

金门大桥日

EXT. GOLDEN GATE BRIDGE   DAY

 

托拜厄斯的身影很小，在桥中央摇曳。

A tiny figure, Tobias wavers at the center of the bridge.

 

任何半文盲的傻瓜都会认为这是一张广角镜头，而 Tobias 在画面中非常小。你不需要告诉我们这是一张广角镜头。此外，你不需要这样做来让我们更近距离地观察：

Any semi-literate goofball gets the idea that this is a wide shot, and that Tobias is pretty small in frame. You don’t need to tell us it’s a WIDE SHOT. Furthermore, you don’t need to do this to move us closer:

金门大桥日

EXT. GOLDEN GATE BRIDGE DAY

 

托比亚斯的身影很小，在桥中央摇摇晃晃。摄影机从很远的地方推入，显示这个小家伙正在哭泣。

A tiny figure, Tobias wavers at the center of the bridge. CAMERA DOLLYS IN from far far away to reveal that the little fellow is crying.

 

你可以通过控制告诉读者的内容来做到这一点：

You do it by controlling what you tell the reader:

金门大桥日

EXT. GOLDEN GATE BRIDGE DAY

 

托拜厄斯的身影很小，在桥中央摇曳。

A tiny figure, Tobias wavers at the center of the bridge.

 

一滴泪水顺着他的脸颊滑落。

A tear slides down his cheek.

 

因为你告诉我们他的脸颊和一滴泪水，我们感觉我们就在他的脸旁边，因此，特写镜头实际上没有使用可怕的相机描述。

Because you tell us about his cheek and a tear, we sense we are next to his face, hence, a CLOSE UP without actually using the dread camera description.

使用场景描述在读者的脑海中创建一个画面——这与调用摄像机角度相同，但你不会惹恼导演。或者读者。

Use scene description to create a picture in the reader’s mind — which is the same as calling camera angles, but you don’t annoy the director. Or the reader.

77. 你会点特定的歌曲！

77. You call specific songs!

 

不要告诉我们播放的是什么歌曲，除非你打算因为不播放这些音乐而割喉。即使那样，也不要。

Don’t tell us what songs are playing unless you’re going to cut your throat if they don’t use that music. Even then, don’t.

康纳坐在沙发上，旁边是一个男人。他看着《白头神探》，但声音没有盖过背景音乐——拱廊之火乐队的《醒来》。他看起来很无聊。

Conner sits next to a guy on the couch. He watches “Naked Gun” but the sound doesn’t carry over the MUSIC, “Wake Up” by the Arcade Fire, in the background. He looks bored.

 

首先，读者可能不知道 Arcade Fire 的《Wake Up》听起来像什么。我肯定不知道。其次，制作人可能认为你很难打交道，因为你要为这首歌拼死一搏。第三，他们可能担心这首歌太贵了。只需说“一首浪漫的民谣”或“硬派朋克”或“大胆的蓝调歌曲”或其他能告诉我们音乐听起来像什么但又不真正称呼这首歌的词。

First of all, the reader may not know what “Wake Up” by Arcade Fire sounds like. I sure didn’t. Second, a producer may think you’ll be difficult to deal with because you’re going to fight to the death for that one song. Third, they may fear the song is prohibitively expensive. Just say, “A romantic ballad” or “hard-edged punk” or “balls-to-the-wall blues number” or something that tells us what the music sounds like without actually calling the song.

无论如何，这是导演的工作。

That’s the director’s job, anyway.

《落水狗》的编剧并没有把割耳朵的场景称为 Stealers Wheel 的《Stuck in the Middle With You》。他把这个任务留给了导演。不，等等。他确实叫了那个名字，因为他是导演。

The guy who wrote Reservoir Dogs didn’t call “Stuck in the Middle With You” by Stealers Wheel for the ear-cutting-off scene. He left that up to the director. No, wait. He did call it, because he was the director.

所以，只有当你自己导演自己的作品时，你才能创作音乐。否则，这不是一个好主意。

So, only if you’re going to direct your own work, can you call the music. Otherwise, it ain’t a great idea.

78. 你没有运行拼写检查，你这个白痴！

78. You didn’t run your spellcheck, you moron!

 

对很多人来说，这是一个热门话题。我也是其中之一。

This is a hot-button issue for a lot of people. I’m one.

她把花塞进了雷蒙多的胸袋里。

She tucks the flower into Raymundo’s breats pocket.

 

一个笨拙的孩子手里拿着冰淇淋跑过马路。

A CLUMBSY KID runs across the street, ice cream cone in hand.

 

我过去常常在学生的作业上圈出拼写错误的单词，并写上“运行拼写检查”。我厌倦了一周又一周在同一个人的作业上写“运行拼写检查”，所以我改变了我的政策。如果一个单词拼写错误，我就给作业打 F。拼写检查！！这能有多难？如果你认为这很苛刻，那么想想看，如果他们发现一个错字，制片人会把你的剧本扔进垃圾桶！

I used to circle misspelled words in students’ homework and write “run your spellcheck.” I got tired of writing “run your spellcheck” on the same people’s homework week after week, so I changed my policy. If a word is spelled wrong, I just give the homework an F. Spellcheck!! How hard can it be? If you think this is harsh, consider that, if they find a typo, producers will throw your script in the trash!

请记住，他们正在寻找任何理由停止阅读，以便他们可以去和救生员或电影明星，或者也许不是他们的母亲一起出去玩。

Remember, they are looking for ANY reason to quit reading so they can go hang out with lifeguards or movie stars or, perhaps not, their mothers.

 

“为什么那些发生在蠢人身上的事情总是发生在我身上？”荷马·辛普森

“How come things that happen to stupid people keep happening to me?” Homer Simpson

好的剧本是电影的蓝图。如果电气系统出现问题，你会买房子吗？正确的拼写是基本要求。如果没有基本要求，没人会买剧本。此外，拼写错误会让读者失去阅读兴趣，分散他们对写作质量的注意力。

A good screenplay is the blueprint for a movie. Would you buy a house if the electrical system were messed up? Correct spelling is a basic. No one will buy a script if the basics aren’t there. Plus, a typo takes the reader out of the read and diverts their attention from the quality of the writing.

所以，请检查一下拼写。这真的非常重要。也许对你来说不是，但对那些可能把你的脚本交给老板的人来说却很重要。

So, run your spellcheck. It really, really matters. Maybe not to you, but to the people who might give your script to their boss.

解散为：

DISSOLVE TO:

 

回顾——20 年前

FLASHBACK – 20 YEARS AGO

 

我的第一部剧本经过九稿后才完成，就是在这台打字机上写的。IBM Correcting Selectric II 是文字处理的黄金标准。我有时仍会用它来写对话。1980 年，它的价格是 1,000 美元，它只做打字。非常漂亮。它仍然拥有人类有史以来最好的键盘。用那台打字机打字轻而易举。不过，有时我会犯错误。

My first screenplay, which, after nine drafts, got made, was written on this typewriter. An IBM Correcting Selectric II, the gold standard of word processing. I still use it sometimes to write dialogue. In 1980, it cost $1,000 and all it did was type. Beautifully. It still has the best keyboard ever conceived by man. Typing with that thing was a breeze. Sometimes, though, I’d make mistakes.

在 IBM Correcting Selectric II 上，如果你输入错误，你可以后退一个空格并点击“更正”按钮。屏幕上会出现一条白色胶片带，你再次输入错误的字母。错误的字母会被白色字母覆盖。然后你输入正确的字母，用正确的字母覆盖被覆盖的错误字母。听起来很复杂？与之前相比，这简直是涅槃。你不会想知道 Liquid Paper 的。

On an IBM Correcting Selectric II, if you made a mistake, you backed up one space and hit the “correction” button. A white piece of film ribbon came up and you typed the wrong letter again. The wrong letter got covered by a white letter. Then you typed the correct letter, covering up the covered-up wrong letter with the right letter. Sound complicated? It was nirvana compared to what had come before. You don’t want to know about Liquid Paper.

IBM 打字机的纠错功能非常有效 — 只要纸张在打字机中，并被中世纪的滚轴和弹簧系统紧紧固定住。如果您一直打到页面底部，回头查看发现页面顶部有印刷错误，您可以将其卷回顶部，将字母对准正确的位置，按下“纠错”按钮，遮住错误的字母，输入正确的字母，然后您就可以继续工作了。

The correcting feature of the IBM typewriter worked like a charm — as long as the paper was in the typewriter, held tightly by a medieval system of rollers and springs. If you typed your way to the bottom of the page, looked back and found a typographic error at the top of the page, you rolled back up to the top, lined up the letter in exaaaaactly the right spot, pressed the “correction” button, covered up the bad letter, typed the good one, and you were back in business.

但前提是纸张还在打字机里。

But, only as long as the paper was in the typewriter.

一旦你把纸抽出来，情况就完全不同了。如果你在纸被恶意地放在桌子上时发现了打字错误，尖叫着“你这个笨蛋，你没发现这个错误！”，你就没有办法把纸放回打字机的正确位置——所以这意味着，你必须重新打出整页。

Once you yanked the page out, it was a whole new ballgame. If you found a typo once the paper was lying malevolently on your desk, screaming “You clod, you didn’t see this mistake!” there was no way to get the paper back in the typewriter in exaaactly the right place — so this meant, you had to retype the entire page.

我重复一遍，“重新输入整页。”

I repeat. “Retype the entire page.”

这意味着要放入另一张纸（后面还要放一张纸，以保护压纸滚筒（滚轮）不会因为受到元件（球）的猛烈撞击而凹陷！），然后查看刚刚输入的页面（校对不及时），然后重新输入整页。这个令人抓狂的操作需要两到十分钟，具体取决于您的打字水平。

That means putting in another piece of paper (and a second sheet behind it to protect the platen [roller thing] from being dented because the element [the ball] hit it so hard!) and looking at the page you had recently typed (and proofread poorly) and then retyping the whole damn thing. This maddening operation would take from two to ten minutes, depending how good a typist you were.

这真是太糟糕了，因为，在你浪费时间重新输入整页剧本（希望你能用沃尔特·希尔的风格来写！）的同时，你还在焦急地等待，因为你没有注意到那个该死的打字错误。

And it was doubly horrible, because, all the while you’re wasting your time retyping an entire page of your screenplay (wishing you’d written in the Walter Hill style!), you were stewing because you hadn’t noticed the damn typo.

解散为：

DISSOLVE TO:

 

今天

PRESENT DAY

 

现在几乎没人使用打字机了。这就是 Royal 和 Smith Corona 啤酒销量不佳的原因。几乎每个人都使用电脑。而且，如果你在电脑上发现打字错误，你只需点击 BACKSPACE 键，改正这个小东西，然后按 PRINT 键，瞧，一张崭新的纸张从你的打印机中喷涌而出，像一杯波旁威士忌一样干净利落。

Almost no one uses a typewriter anymore. Which is why Royal and Smith Corona are pushing up daisies. Almost everyone uses a computer. And, if you find a typo on a computer, all you have to do is tap BACKSPACE, correct the little beast, press PRINT, and lo and behold, a shiny new page comes spewing out of your printer, nice and neat as a glass of bourbon.

而且您只需大约十秒钟即可完成！

And it ONLY TOOK YOU ABOUT TEN SECONDS TO DO IT!

所以，请解释一下，亲爱的读者，为什么当我开始写作时，我花了三分钟来纠正一个错别字，但现在人们却不愿意花十五秒钟来纠正？是加工食品吗？是电视的阴险影响吗？是世界范围内的共产主义阴谋，要消耗和污染我们宝贵的体液……？

So please explain, dear reader, why, when I started writing it took me three minutes to correct a single typo, but people won’t take fifteen seconds to do it now? Is it processed food? The insidious effect of television? A worldwide Communist conspiracy to sap and impurify our precious bodily... fluids?

我知道这很难令人相信，但制片人和经纪人（其中有些人实际上和我一样老）不喜欢错别字。尽管这可能会让身处象牙塔的你感到震惊，但他们不喜欢在剧本中留下错别字的人。

Hard to believe, I know, but producers and agents, some of whom are actually as old as I am, don’t like typos. And, while this may come as a shock to you in your ivory tower, they don’t like people who leave them in their scripts.

在电影行业，人们被聘用的最常见原因不是才华、魅力或认识的人——而是因为人们喜欢他们并想与他们合作。如果你有错别字，人们就不会喜欢你，也不会想和你一起工作。

The most common reason people get hired in the movie business is not talent or charm or who they know — it’s because people like them and want to work with them. If you have typos, people won’t like you and won’t want to work with you.

“因为？”你问道，脸上挂着我已经习惯看到的幼稚天真的微笑。

“Because?” you ask, with that corn-fed naive smile I’ve grown accustomed to seeing.

因为他们认为，如果你太马虎，连剧本都校对不上，甚至连求职信都校对不上，他们就不相信你。而且，在一个每天都有数百万美元流失的行业里，可靠性是能否被聘用的关键因素。

Because they think that if you’re too sloppy to proofread a script, or God forbid, a cover letter, you’re not going to be someone they can rely on. And, in a business where millions of dollars go flying out the door every day, reliability is a key component to hire-ability.

有一次，我在 Borders Books 开过关于编剧的研讨会。我带好莱坞编剧和制片人去不同的城市，并回答了关于写作的问题。我永远不会忘记一位制片人说，如果她收到的求职信中有错别字，她就会把它扔掉。人群中的一位女士惊恐地说道：“你怎么能这样做？！如果剧本很棒怎么办？！”制片人看着她说：“我不在乎。如果你写不出语法正确的求职信，我凭什么认为你能写出好的剧本？”人群中的这位女士觉得，因为她花了一年时间写剧本，所以有人欠她一读。

Once upon a time, I did seminars on screenwriting at Borders Books. I brought Hollywood writers and producers to different cities, and they answered questions about writing. I’ll never forget when a producer said that if she got a cover letter with a typo in it, she threw it away. A woman in the crowd reacted in horror, “How can you do that?! What if the script is fantastic?!” The producer looked at her and said, “I don’t care. If you can’t write a grammatically correct letter, why should I think you can write a good screenplay?” The woman in the crowd felt that because she’d spent a year writing a script that Someone Out There owed her a read.

错误的。

Wrong.

他们不欠你什么。什么都不欠。什么都不欠！

They owe you nothing. Nothing. Nothing!

因此，如果你知道，如果你的信中有错别字，他们会直接把它扔掉，也许你会非常非常非常出色地检查拼写并校对你的询问信和脚本。或者不。你自己决定。

So, if you know that, if there’s a typo in your letter, they’ll just throw it away, perhaps you’ll do a really, really, really good job of spellchecking and proofreading your query letter and script. Or not. Your call.

记住。他们不想和愚蠢的人一起工作。你为什么想让他们认为你很愚蠢？

Remember. They don’t want to work with people who are stupid. Why would you want them to think you’re stupid?

美国编剧协会每年登记成千上万个新剧本，所以请放心，经纪人和制片人会收到大量没有错别字的询问信和剧本。他们可以扔掉一些。包括你的。

The WGA registers thousands and thousands of new screenplays per year, so rest assured, agents and producers are getting plenty of query letters and scripts with no typos in them. They can afford to throw away a few. Including yours.

79. 你相信你的拼写检查！啊哈哈

哈哈哈哈！

79. You trust your spellcheck! Ah haa ha

haaa ha ha!

 

把拼写检查当成邪恶的婆婆！尽可能使用她，但要尽可能信任她。永远不要忘记，仅仅因为一些计算机告诉你某件事是对的，并不意味着它真的是正确的。如果你不校对，你就有祸了。反复校对，用很大的力度校对。

Treat spellcheck like an evil mother-in-law! Use her when you can, but trust her as far as you can throw the Chrysler building. Never, ever forget, just because some computer tells you something’s right, doesn’t mean it’s really right. Woe unto you if you do not proofread. Repeatedly, with great vigor.

莎莉和杰西卡都露出笑容，像两头母狮一样露出牙齿。

Sally and Jessica both smile and bear their teeth like two lionesses.

 

如果你找不到上面这句话的问题，你需要找个朋友帮你校对。趁我还没引起你的注意，把“both”和“two”删掉。更多的校对错误。别犯。

If you can’t find the problem in the above sentence, you need to find a friend to proofread for you. While I’ve got your attention, cut “both” and “two.” More proofreading mistakes. Don’t make ’em.

男孩只带着十字架回到了圣坛。

The boy returns to the alter with only the crucifix.

 

卡门从窗户往里看。

Carmen peaks through the window.

汤米停下来欣赏科琳。

Tommy stops to admire at Colleen.

罗布看着伊丽莎白床边的书。
