Rob looks at the books adjacent Elizabeth’s bed.

牧师以闪电般的速度解除了凯特的武装。

With lightening speed the Priest disarms Kate.

如果不校对，你就会显得很愚蠢。

Failing to proofread makes you look sooooo stupid.

80. 你认为越长越好！

80. You think longer is better!

 

越大并不一定越好。曾经的铁律是最多 120 页，理论是“每分钟屏幕时间一页，120 页剧本 = 一部两小时的电影。”如果超过 120 页，他们会想，“好吧，这个 Bozo 不知道自己在做什么，所以我甚至不需要阅读它。”

Bigger ain’t better. The iron clad rule used to be 120 pages, tops, the theory being, “One page per minute of screen time, a 120-page script = a two-hour movie.” Longer than 120 pages, they thought, “Well this Bozo doesn’t know what he’s doing, so I don’t even need to read it.”

毫无疑问，每个拿起你的剧本的人都会做同样的事情：他们会翻到最后一页看看它有多长。过去，每个人都认为，如果你的剧本少于 120 页，你就安全了。现在情况已经不同了。

It’s a cinch that every person who picks up your screenplay will do the exact same thing: they will flip to the last page to see how long it is. Everyone used to feel that if you were under 120 pages, you were safe. This is no longer the case.

因为电影制作成本太高，所以现在是 110-115。

Because movies are so expensive to make, now it’s 110–115.

不要说：“但有些电影长达三个小时。那些剧本超过 120 页，所以如果有必要，我可以打破这个规则。”是的，但那些电影不是由试图获得第一个经纪人的无名作家写的。它们是由获得数十万美元报酬的作家写的，如果一个作家每周通过重写制作赚取 25 万美元，她可以绕过一两个规则。

And don’t say, “But some movies are three hours long. Those scripts are way over 120 pages, so I can break that rule if I have to.” Yeah, but those movies weren’t written by unknown writers trying to get their first agent. They were written by writers paid hundreds and hundreds of thousands of dollars, and if a writer is raking in a quarter of a million bucks a week on a production rewrite, she can scoot around a rule or two.

不是你，也不是我。如果你想进入这个行业，就把这个数字降到 115 到 110 之间。更接近 110。另外，因为高管们都读过编剧书籍，他们相信 115 页规则，所以你必须遵守它。

Not you. Not me. If you’re trying to break into the industry, get it down between 115 and 110. Closer to 110. Plus, because the executives have all read the screenwriting books, they believe the 115-page rule, so you have to adhere to it.

请记住，《英国病人》是他们从 104 页的剧本中挤出来的一部长达 3 个小时的电影！

Remember, The English Patient is a three-hour movie they squeezed out of a 104-page script!

81. 你没有大声读出你的剧本！

81. You didn’t read your script out loud!

 

约翰·麦克菲（我最喜欢的非小说类作家）会大声朗读自己的作品。你也应该这样做。为什么？因为当你在脑海里读的时候，你会觉得它听起来很棒。流畅。就像在婴儿的屁股上拍打爽身粉一样。如此完美，还有什么可修改的呢？如果你大声朗读，你肯定会听到错误。

John McPhee (my favorite non-fiction author) reads his writing out loud. So should you. Why? Because when you read it in your head, to yourself, it sounds good. Smooth. Like patting baby powder on a baby’s bottom. So perfect, what’s to fix? If you read something out loud, you have a prayer of hearing the mistakes.

通过大声朗读，你会发现场景描述中的小问题。你也会发现故事中的问题。最后，你会听到对话。演员会说对话，所以你怎么能不大声朗读对话呢？

By reading aloud, you find glitches in scene description. You also find story problems. Finally, you hear the dialogue. Actors will be saying it, so how can you NOT read dialogue out loud?

我刚开始写作时就定了一条规则。这是一条超级规则。当我有要重写的草稿时，我会坐在沙发上，手里拿着装在三孔活页夹里的剧本。我会大声朗读。如果我把一页大声朗读了三遍，没有做任何修改，我就会翻到下一页。如果我发现有什么需要修改的地方，我会进行编辑，然后从第一页重新开始。如果在第三次阅读时，我在页面底部改了一个逗号，我会再把那一页读三遍。这是一项令人麻木的练习，需要疯狂的纪律。翻阅剧本花了很长时间，但却是改进素材的绝妙方法。

I had a rule when I first started writing. It was a super-duper rule. When I had a draft I was rewriting, I would sit on the sofa with the script in a three-ring binder. I’d read it out loud. If I read a page out loud three times and made no changes, I’d turn to the next page. If I found something to change, I’d make the edit and start over at read #1. If, on the third read, I was at the bottom of a page and changed a comma, I’d read that page three more times. This was a numbing exercise and required maniacal discipline. It took forever to churn through the script but was a marvelous way to improve the material.

如果你想真正听到自己的错误，就让别人大声朗读给你听。原本完美的东西现在在夏日的阳光下会像垃圾一样臭气熏天。在科学上，这被称为观察者效应。“观察的行为会改变被观察的现象。”这就是为什么我们在车里唱得一流，但在试镜时却唱得一塌糊涂。如果给你朗读的人遇到一些问题，或者听不懂对话，或者其他什么，就给自己写个便条，恳求他们继续读下去。当你的朋友帮完你后，请她吃午饭！

If you want to really hear your mistakes, have someone read it aloud to you. What seemed perfect will now stink like garbage in the summer sun. In science, this is called the Observer Effect. “The act of observing will change the phenomenon being observed.” It’s why we sing top-notch in the car, but tragically at the audition. If the person reading to you stumbles over something or can’t make sense of dialogue, or whatever, scribble a note to yourself and beg them to press on. When your friend is done helping you, buy her lunch!

82. 你用的打印机太差了！

82. You used a crummy printer!

 

剧本是否用好的打印机打印，墨水是否好？页面是否被弄脏了？是否模糊？是否有点乱了？质量控制是你的工作。你不会为你那台廉价的打印机道歉。洛杉矶没有人能看到你那屋顶漏水的佃农小屋。他们不会同情你，因为你没有鞋子穿，你的孩子已经好几个星期没吃东西了。虽然你和我都知道，你很幸运，因为你能打印出一份副本，而你的房子却没有被烧毁，但好莱坞没有人关心。

Is the script printed on a good printer, with good ink? Are pages smeared? Blurry? A little messed up? Quality control is your job. You won’t be there to apologize for your cheap ass printer. No one in Los Angeles can see your sharecropper’s cabin with the leaky roof. They can’t feel sorry for you because you have no shoes and your children haven’t eaten in weeks. While you know and I know that you’re lucky just to have been able to print out one single copy without your house burning to the ground, no one in Hollywood cares.

他们只看你的剧本。剧本最好看起来不错。你的剧本给人留下了深刻印象。而不是你本人。而且你只有一次机会。

They see only your screenplay. It had better look good. Your script makes the impression. Not you. And you only get one chance.

在寄出剧本之前，您是否仔细检查过整个剧本，确保每页都正确无误、顺序正确、正面朝上？您会惊讶地发现，复印机根本就不关心您的利益。

Before you mail it out, have you gone through your entire script to make sure every page is there, in the right order, and right side up? You’d be amazed how copy machines don’t have your best interest at heart.

最后：

And finally:

运行你的拼写检查，我恳求你。

Run your spellcheck, I beg you.

淡出。

FADE OUT.

 

第三幕：

ACT III:

 

现在怎么办？

What Now?

编写剧本是比较容易的部分。

Writing the screenplay was the easy part.

 

 

“宇宙就像一个保险箱，有一个密码。但密码被锁在保险箱里。”

“The universe is like a safe to which there is a combination. But the combination is locked up in the safe.”

彼得·德·弗里斯

Peter De Vries

“原始部落尊重讲故事的人，但如果他讲不出精彩的故事，他们就会杀了他，并把他当晚餐吃掉。”

“The primitive tribe honors the storyteller, but if he doesn’t tell a great story, they kill him and eat him for dinner.”

威廉·弗鲁格

William Froug

“我知道。你和我一样。你不想做任何工作。

你只想兑现支票。”

“I know. You’re like me. You don’t want to do any work.

You just want to cash checks.”

从制片人到主要演员，签订电视合同

Producer to Major Actor, setting up a television deal

“我不敢相信电影行业的残酷性对我的自信心造成了多大的打击，资金的匮乏又对我的自我价值感造成了多大的伤害。”

“I can’t believe how much my confidence had been blown by the brutality of the film business and how much the lack of money had hurt my sense of self-worth.”

前编剧

former screenwriter

“悲观主义者抱怨风；乐观主义者期待风向改变；现实主义者调整船帆。”

“The pessimist complains about the wind; the optimist expects it to change; the realist adjusts the sails.”

威廉·阿瑟·沃德

William Arthur Ward

 

 

淡入：

FADE IN:

剧本创作 50% 是写作，50% 是销售。

Screenwriting is 50% writing and 50% selling.

 

不要再担心“你会写出一个很棒的剧本吗”。如果这是你的第一个剧本，它很可能会很糟糕。不要担心失败。先写一些剧本，然后再担心“你写得对吗？”现在，跳进虚空，不要担心没有网络。享受这个过程，不要在意后果。试着玩得开心。如果这不有趣，为什么会有这么多人想做这件事？

Quit worrying about “are you going to write a great script.” If this is your first one, it’ll most likely stink. Don’t worry about failing. Get some screenplays under your belt, and then sweat about “are you doing it right?” For now, leap into the void and don’t worry there’s no net. Enjoy the process and damn the consequences. Try to have fun. If this weren’t fun, why would so many people want to do it?

如果你担心失败，好莱坞就会把你吞噬。

If you’re worried about failure, Hollywood will eat you alive.

这是一个艰难的行业。很多人都想进入这个行业。出于某种原因，它以魅力四射而闻名。我不知道为什么。如果你曾经去过电影片场，你就会知道这没什么性感的。这只是一份工作。

This is a tough business. Lots of people want to get into it. For some reason, it has the reputation of glamour. Beats me why. If you’ve ever been on a movie set, you’ll know there’s nothing sexy about it. It’s work.

 

“编剧不像采煤那么难。只是更黑暗。”杜布·科内特，编剧/制片人

“Screenwriting isn’t as hard as coal mining. It’s just darker.” Dub Cornett, writer/producer

当作家处于金字塔的顶端时，人们会善待作家。大约有十五个男人和女人。他们受到的待遇就像独裁者的兄弟一样。除此之外，我不知道为什么，好莱坞的人对作家并不好。也许是因为每个人都能写一两句话，他们讨厌你，因为你比他们已经能做的事情更出色。也许是因为在作家完成她正在做的事情之前，没有人能得到报酬。也许是因为当电影失败时，只有作家能得到报酬。

People treat writers well when the writer is at the tippy tip top of the pyramid. That’s about fifteen men and women. They get treated like the dictator’s brother. Other than that, and I can’t figure out why, people in Hollywood aren’t very nice to writers. Maybe it’s because everyone can write a sentence or two, and they resent you because you are better at something they can already do. Maybe it’s because no one gets paid until the writer finishes what she’s doing. Maybe it’s because when the movie goes south, only the writer got paid.

 

“这很奇怪。作曲家学习和声和音乐形式理论；画家不会在不了解颜色和设计的情况下画画；建筑需要基础教育。只有当一个人决定开始写作时，他才会相信他不需要学习任何东西，任何学会把文字写在纸上的人都可以成为作家。”

屠格涅夫

“It is a strange thing. A composer studies harmony and theory of musical forms; a painter doesn’t paint a picture without knowing something about colors and design; architecture requires basic schooling. Only when somebody makes a decision to start writing, he believes that he doesn’t need to learn anything and that anybody who has learned to put words on paper can be a writer.”

Turgenev

也许每个人都认为自己可以写作。我不知道。不管出于什么原因，拉斯维加斯以西的人通常对作家不友好。知道这一点，最好不要让这种事情激怒你。保持愉快。享受美味的饭菜。享受工作。为自己有才华而感到高兴。如果这让你生气，告诉你的治疗师。但对从事这个行业的人生气并不是你进入这个行业的好方法。

Maybe everybody thinks he can write. I dunno. Whatever the reason, west of Las Vegas they’re often unkind to writers. Knowing this, it’s best if you don’t let get under your skin. Be pleasant. Enjoy the nice meals. Enjoy doing your work. Be glad you have a talent. If it makes you angry, tell your therapist. But getting pissed off at someone who is in the business is not a good way for you to get into the business.

进入这个行业的一个好方法是写出一部出色的剧本。但这只是第一个障碍。

A good way for you to get into the business is to write a crackerjack screenplay. But that’s only the first hurdle.

现在你必须把它卖掉。

Now you have to sell it.

不要做

傻瓜，要

专业

Don’t Be

a Jackass, Be

Professional

 

83. 你想出名远胜于你想写作！

83. You want to be famous more than you want to write!

 

许多作家不想写剧本，他们只想致富。

Lots of writers don’t want to write a screenplay, they just want to be rich.

如果这对你来说几乎是真的，那就花点时间静静地盯着你的肚脐，如果你认为这是真的，那就把这本书扔掉，退出写作游戏吧。写作很难，你很可能会失败。如果你只想要金钱和名声，我帮不了你。

If this is anywhere close to true for you, spend some quiet time staring at your belly button, and if you decide it is true, throw this book away and bail out of the writing game. Writing is tough and you’re most likely going to fail. If all you want is money and fame, I can’t help.

 

“这可不全是可卡因和阴道。”

PA 的一位老灯光师在 PA 的

10K 灯掉到他的脚上后

“It ain’t all coke and pussy.”

Older lighting guy to P.A. after P.A.

dropped a 10K on his foot

你需要有正当的理由去写作，而事实上，只有一个理由。你需要写作是因为你必须写作。不是因为你想拍电影。不是因为它能帮你还房贷。

You need to be writing for the right reasons, and they are, well, actually, there’s only one reason. You need to write because you have to write. Not because you want to have movies made. Not because it will pay your mortgage.

真正优秀的作家即使没有报酬也会写作。这对他们来说是一种强迫。而且这能给他们带来超越经济层面的满足。你必须写作，因为如果你不写作，你就会死。

Really, really good writers will write even if they’re not paid for it. It’s a compulsion for them. And it feeds something in them that goes beyond the financial. You must be writing because if you don’t write, you’ll die.

如果还有其他原因，比如你的照片登上了《人物》杂志，那么你就会陷入惊人的痛苦之中。快乐（或半快乐）的作家是那些喜欢写作，不太担心成功的人。

If there is any other reason, like having your photograph in People magazine, then you are headed for astounding misery. The happy (or semi-happy) writers are the ones who like writing and don’t worry so much about success.

相信我。

Believe me.

不要寻求快速成功的途径。你必须花时间在剧本上，让它像瑞士手表一样完美无缺。除非你知道你的剧本很棒，否则不要把它发出去。我的意思是真的、真的很棒。

Don’t be looking for a quickie route to success. You have to spend the time on your screenplay to make it fit together like a Swiss watch. Do not send your script out until you know it’s great. And I mean really, really incredible.

我写的最后一个剧本，读到最后一页时我哭了。最先读到它的两个人都哭了。剧本太棒了。当我把它交给别人时，我不知道他们是否会买，但他们会认为这是一部不可思议的作品。

The last script I wrote, I cried when I got to the last page. The first two people who read it, cried. The script is amazing. When I hand it to someone, I don’t know if they’re going to buy it, but they are going to think it’s an incredible piece of work.

因为我投入了时间。

Because I put in the time.

你也必须这样做。不要以为如果你写了有史以来最棒的询问信，就会有人买下你还没准备好的剧本。你的剧本在发出去之前必须是无懈可击的。先打好草稿。把它搁置一段时间。再写一个剧本。然后拿出第一个剧本，看看它。回去，卷起袖子，做让剧本成功所需的重活。

And you have to, too. Do not think that if you write the all-time greatest query letter, that someone will buy your not-really-ready script. Your script has to be fucking bulletproof before you send it out. Do the draft. Put it away a while. Write another script. Then pull the first one out and look at it. Go back in, roll up your sleeves, and do the heavy lifting required to make the script sing.

检查一下是否有你在另一部电影中看到的东西。如果有，就改变它。让它变得更好。改进它。不要抄袭另一部电影，因为读你剧本的人一定看过那部电影。我保证。我最好的学生之一的散文和对话非常有创意。我问过他。他说，“我读了它，如果它听起来像我以前听过的东西，我就改它。”

Check to see if there’s anything you’ve seen in another movie. If there is, change it. Make it better. Improve it. Don’t copy another movie, because the people reading your screenplay will have seen that movie. I guarantee it. One of my best students’ prose and dialogue were smokin’ inventive. I asked him about it. He said, “I read it and if it sounds like something I’ve heard before, I change it.”

所有的艺术追求都离不开纪律。玛戈特·芳婷、朱利安·施纳贝尔、米克·贾格尔、索尔·贝斯、罗恩·贝斯、毕加索、多娜泰拉·范思哲、米尔顿·卡尼夫。每个人都是勤奋的人。这意味着比别人起得早、比别人工作得更努力，并且足够专业地对待你热爱的这门手艺。

All artistic pursuits are about discipline. Margot Fonteyn. Julian Schnabel. Mick Jagger. Saul Bass. Ron Bass. Picasso. Donatella Versace. Milton Caniff. Worker bees every one. It’s about waking up earlier than the other guy and working harder than the other guy and caring enough to be professional about this craft you say you love.

您要向其推销产品的人都是专业人士。为了能够购买您的作品，他们投入了大量的时间。您为什么要付出更少呢？

The people you are trying to sell to are professionals. To be in a position to buy your work, they put in the time. Why would you do any less?

84. 你认为你的剧本很特别，规则

不适用！

84. You think your script is special and rules

don’t apply!

 

遗憾的是，不管你妈妈怎么说，你其实并没有那么特别。好吧，也许你很特别，但你的剧本并不特别。你最好现在就学会这一点，而不是以后再学。

Sadly, despite what your mother tells you, you’re not all that special. Well, maybe you are, but your script isn’t. It’s best you learn this now, instead of later.

剧本一百年来一直都是这个样子。你最精彩的剧本并不能改变好莱坞的行事方式。读者只想读你的剧本。他们希望它看起来和其他剧本一样。标题页。剧本。请采用常规剧本格式。

Scripts have looked the way they look for going on a hundred years. It’s not up to your most wonderful screenplay to change the way Hollywood does things. Readers want to read your script and nothing but your script. They want it to look like every other script. Title page. The script. In regular screenplay format, please.

这些错误是否也适用于你的剧本？希望没有。

Do any of these mistakes apply to your script? Hope not.

不要用三枚钉子。傻瓜。他们在纸上打三个洞，引诱你落入他们邪恶的陷阱。用两枚钉子。在为这本书做研究期间，我和一位制片人交谈过，当我问他关于三枚钉子的事时，他笑了。“是的，当我告诉初学写作的人只用两枚钉子时，我会笑，因为这是一个非常愚蠢的规定，但是，当我看到一个有三个钉子的剧本时，我会把它扔掉。”然后他又笑了。有点像这样：“呜呜哈哈哈哈！”

Don’t use three brads. Chucklehead. They put three holes in the paper to lure you into their nefarious trap. Use two brads. During the research for this book, I talked to a producer who smirked when I asked him about three brads. “Yeah, I laugh when I tell beginning writers to only use two brads, because it’s such a stupid rule, but then, when I see a script that has three brads, I throw it away.” And then he laughed again. Sort of like this: “Mwuu uu ha ha haaaa!”

为什么会有“两枚钉子”这种胡说八道？助理们需要复印你的剧本，他们不想花时间拆掉三枚钉子，因为两枚钉子就能把你的剧本固定在一起。所以，当他们看到一个剧本有三个钉子时，他们就知道你不了解他们的需求。他们开始讨厌你。只要拿起你的剧本！

The reason for this “two brads” nonsense? The assistants, who have to photocopy your screenplay, don’t want to take time undoing three brads when two will hold your script together. So, when they see a script with three brads, they know you’re not hip to their needs. And they begin to loathe you. Just by picking up your screenplay!

你有合适的图钉吗？在www.writersstore.com购买。

Do you have the right brads? Buy them at www.writersstore.com.

它们是 1¼” #5 实心黄铜紧固件。你在你的家乡买不到它们。你能买到的是更薄的金属，而且不会牢牢固定。没有什么比封面上写的“业余”一词更能彰显“业余”了，但劣质的 Office Depot 钉子紧随其后。

They’re 1¼” #5 solid brass fasteners. You can’t buy them in your hometown. The ones you can buy are thinner metal and won’t hold. Nothing shouts “amateur!” like the word “amateur” written on your cover page, but crappy Office Depot brads run a close second.

不要为了让你的过长剧本看起来有 110 页而扩大页边距。不要你以为这些人只是从萝卜车上掉下来的吗？如果你加宽边距，他们只会认为“想成为”，然后把你的孩子扔出窗外。继续，做这项工作，让它变短。

Don’t widen the margins in an effort to make your over-long screenplay look like it’s come in at the cherished 110 pages. Do you think these people just fell off the turnip truck? If you widen the margins, they’ll just think, “wannabe,” and toss your baby out the window. Go ahead, do the work, make it shorter.

不要添加艺术品、照片或地图来帮助“更好地解释事情”。女士，只需脚本。您必须用文字讲述故事。只有文字。没有什么比在中途尖叫“失败者”更让人尖叫的了：“现在打开地图……”

Don’t include artwork, photos, or maps to help “explain things better.” Just the script, ma’am. You have to tell the story with words. Only words. Few things shriek “loser” more than, partway through: “Open the map now….”

没有原声音乐 CD，没有角色列表。没有将来可能想扮演角色的演员的照片。只有剧本。你当然想脱颖而出，但你希望脱颖而出是因为你的剧本，而不是因为你在他们办公室的 1,500 份剧本旁边看起来像个傻瓜。

No CD of soundtrack music, no list of characters. No photographs of actors who might someday want to play the roles. Nothing but the script. You want to stand out, sure, but you want to stand out because of your writing, not because you look like a goof-ball next to the 1,500 scripts in their office.

不要扩大对话范围。

Don’t extend the dialogue margins.

不要把它送到 Kinko's 去装订。

Don’t have it bound at Kinko’s.

不要将其放在三孔活页夹中寄送。

Don’t send it in a three-ring binder.

仅使用卡片纸封面！

Only use card stock covers!

不要以 95% 大小复印，这样看起来会有更多的空白。好主意。不要这么做。

Don’t photocopy it at 95% size so it will look like there’s more white space. Cute idea. Don’t do it.

不要使用令人眼花缭乱的新格式，以为好莱坞一直在等待你为他们的幸运之桌带来的生动的天才风格。很遗憾地告诉你，好莱坞不会等你。如果你做了一些非常古怪的事情，以为它是新的和改进的，他们只会认为你疯了。

Don’t use a dazzling new format, thinking Hollywood has been waiting for the vivid style of genius you’re bringing to their lucky table. I’m sorry to report, Hollywood is not waiting for you. If you do something really outlandish, thinking it’s new and improved, they’ll just think you’re nuts.

而且他们不会接听你的电话。

And they won’t return your calls.

85. 您在标题页上放了错误的内容！

85. You put the wrong stuff on your title page!

 

标题页上没有©符号。

No © symbol on the title page.

标题页上没有 reg. WGAw。

No reg. WGAw on the title page.

或者 WGAe，就此而言。

Or WGAe, for that matter.

标题页上没有 WGA 注册编号 349683。

No WGA registration number 349683 on the title page.

标题页上没有“保留所有权利”。

No “All Rights Reserved” on the title page.

 

 

 

我的精彩剧本

作者

威廉·M·埃克斯

 

 

 

myname@domain.com

我居住的街道

我的家乡，州 12345

212/555-1212

 

 

 

 

 

 

MY FANTASTIC SCREENPLAY

written by

William M. Akers

 

 

 

myname@domain.com

The Street Where I Live

My Hometown, State 12345

212/555-1212

 

 

 

 

只有头衔、姓名和联系信息。你可能会问，为什么？

Nothing but the title, your name, and contact information. Why, you ask?

在这个阶段，当你为剧本付出了不知多久的心血，并且有了一个很棒的剧本时——你仍然可能在最后一刻搞砸它。我敢说，你想表现得很酷。但你不想表现得偏执。

At this stage of the game, when you’ve sweated blood over your screenplay for who knows how long, and you’ve got a great script — you can still blow it at the very last minute. You want to appear, dare I say, cool. What you do not want to appear is paranoid.

如果你在标题页和求职信中写上“如果你窃取我的想法，我会起诉你”之类的废话，你就完蛋了。如果你给人留下哪怕一丁点担心他们可能会窃取你宝贵成果的印象，你都会立刻被送进档案室，我的朋友。

If you put all that “If you steal my idea, I’ll sue you to kingdom come” malarkey on the title page and in your cover letter, you’re hosed. If you give the slightest impression you’re worried they may steal your precious work, you will earn yourself an INSTANT trip to the round file, my friend.

但等等，还有更多！如果你和你的写作伙伴把这个放在标题页上：

But wait, there’s more! If you and your writing partner put this on the title page:

作者

written by

威廉·M·埃克斯和威廉·戈德曼

William M. Akers and William Goldman

这立即告诉他们你不知道自己在做什么！现在我们不想这样，对吧？“and”是一个公认的术语，意思是第一个作家被解雇了，第二个作家来了并取代了他。“&”表示你们是一个写作团队。

It instantly tells them you don’t know what you’re doing! Don’t want that, now, do we? The “and” is a recognized term that means the first writer got fired and the second writer came along and replaced him. An ampersand — “&” — means you are a writing team.

作者

written by

威廉·M·埃克斯 & 威廉·戈德曼

William M. Akers & William Goldman

这意味着我们坐在一个房间里一起写。就像。

This means we sat down in a room and wrote it together. As if.

知道了这一点，你现在可以坐在电影院里咯咯笑了，“嘿，那个女人被解雇了，他们雇了两个家伙来代替她，把他们解雇了，最后一个家伙打了扫除一切。”当然，屏幕上的字幕并没有告诉你其他十九位编剧的情况，他们在途中像苍蝇一样死去，没有得到任何荣誉。

Knowing this, you can now sit in the movie theater and cackle, “Hey, that woman got fired, and they hired those two guys to replace her, fired them, and this last guy batted cleanup.” Of course, the screen credits tell you nothing about the nineteen other writers who died like flies along the way and didn’t get any credit.

你的剧本太烂了，因为你在标题页上写了日期！永远，永远，永远！！

Your screenplay sucks because you put a date on the title page! Never, ever, ever!!

要知道，在好莱坞，年轻人最受重视。新剧本比旧剧本更有价值，即使旧剧本更好。这很愚蠢，但事实就是如此。

Understand that, in Hollywood, youth is prized above all else. A new script is worth more than an old script, even if the old one is better. Stupid, but that’s the way it goes.

一旦你把它交给别人，你永远不知道你的剧本会经历什么样的变化。如果你给剧本标上日期，两年后可能会有人拿起它，认为这是一部没人写的陈旧垃圾，因此它一定是垃圾。

Once you let it out of your hands, you never know what peregrinations your script will take. If you put a date on that script, someone might pick it up two years hence, think it’s a tired old piece of garbage that nobody made, ergo it must be junk.

我曾经写过一个剧本。当然，封面上没有写日期。我的经纪人把它寄出去了，但没人买。有人读了它，差点就拍成了电影。后来就没拍了。时间流逝。另一位经纪人把它寄给了一位开发主管，他很喜欢它。不幸的是，她的老板不喜欢它，所以她不得不把它放在抽屉里，直到她有了新老板，而他们也确实喜欢它。又过了一段时间，他们找到了一位执行制片人和一位导演。

I wrote a screenplay once. Naturally, no date on the title page. My agent sent it out and nobody bought it. Somebody read it and it almost got made into a movie. Then it didn’t. Time passed. A different agent sent it out to a development executive, who liked it. Unfortunately, her bosses didn’t like it, so she had to keep it in her drawer until she had new bosses, and they did like it. More time passed, and they found an executive producer and a director.

我去洛杉矶与制片人、执行官和导演共进午餐。午餐期间，他们的对话如下：

I went to Los Angeles to have lunch with the producers, the exec, and the director. At some point during lunch, the conversation went like this:

 

“那么，你什么时候写的剧本？”

我准备好了回答。“天哪，很久以前。我甚至不记得了。”

EP 说：“是的，有时老剧本是最好的。”

桌子周围响起了“是的”和“绝对”的齐声。

EP 然后说：“前几天我在读一个旧剧本。没有人写过，但它太棒了。它是五年前写的！”

“So, when did you write the script?”

I had my response well prepared. “Gosh, a while ago. I don’t even remember.”

The E.P. said, “Yeah, sometimes the old scripts are the best.”

A general chorus of “Yes” and “Absolutely” rumbled around the table.

The E.P. then said, “I was reading an old script the other day. No one had made it, but it was incredible. And it was written five years ago!”

桌上再次传来一种切实的感觉——这么老的剧本是在内燃机出现之前写的。我自然是闭口不谈的。我的剧本，也就是所有这些谈话和免费午餐的对象，是 20 年前写的。如果他们知道它有多老，他们会把它像烫手山芋一样扔掉，因为每个人都知道，如果好莱坞的东西是老的，那么它的存在本身就是坏的——因为，如果它如果好的话，现在就会有比他们更聪明的人把它拍成电影了！

Again, a tangible sensation shot around the table — a script that old was written before there were internal combustion engines. I, naturally, kept my mouth shut. My screenplay, the object of all this conversation and free lunch, had been written 20 years earlier. Had they known how old it was, they would have dropped it like a hot potato, because everyone knows that if something in Hollywood is old, it is by its very existence, bad — because, if it were any good, someone smarter than they are would have made it into a movie by now!

他们都不知道，因为二十年前，我还没有在扉页上注明日期。

None of them knew, because, twenty years earlier, I had not put a date on my title page.

86. 你还没有读过剧本！

86. You haven’t done a table read!

 

对话是为了被听到。

Dialogue is meant to be heard.

先在脑子里写下来，然后写在纸上，再在脑子里读一遍，其实行不通。为了发现对话中的问题，你必须听。

Writing it in your head, then putting it on a piece of paper, and then reading it again in your head, doesn’t really work. In order to find problems in your dialogue, you have to hear it.

剧本阅读是个好主意，特别是如果你认识一些演员的话。如果只是朋友一起，可能用处不大，但仍然非常有帮助。把大家聚在一起，请他们吃晚饭，让他们坐在桌边，然后花一个半小时或两个小时阅读剧本。你不应该只读角色或场景描述。你需要坐在那里，听，并做笔记——也许在笔记本电脑上，或者在你面前的剧本副本上潦草地写写画画。

A table read is a great idea, especially if you know some actors. If it’s just your friends, it may be less useful, but it’s still incredibly helpful. Get people together, give them dinner, sit them around the table, and then take an hour and a half or two hours and read the script. You shouldn’t read, not a character or scene description. You need to sit there, listen, and take notes — perhaps on a laptop, or scribbling on a copy of the script in front of you.

请务必：

Be sure to:

 

给演员们时间熟悉材料。

多喝咖啡和水。

带上你的幽默感。

带上巧克力一起分享。

抛开你的期望。

简明扼要地直接回答所有问题。

做好即兴发挥的准备。

做好失望的准备。没有什么是绝对的。

深呼吸。

Give the actors time to familiarize themselves with the material.

Have plenty of coffee and water.

Bring your sense of humor.

Bring chocolate to share.

Leave your expectations at the door.

Answer all questions succinctly and directly.

Be prepared to improvise.

Be prepared to be disappointed. There are no guarantees.

Breathe.

请允许我稍微提醒一下。如果你或演员们没有做好准备，台读可能会让人非常沮丧。如果演员们打电话过来（这意味着你不给他们钱，他们只是觉得必须这么做），当台读结束后，你会有自杀的念头。

Allow me to give you a slight caveat. If you or the actors aren’t prepared for them, table reads can be monumentally depressing. If the actors phone it in (which means you’re not feeding or paying them and they are just doing it because they feel they have to), when it’s over, you’re going to be suicidal.

我当时在伦敦参加制片人和融资机构的剧本朗读会。一家豪华酒店的私人餐厅挤满了演员、制片人和我自己。在融资人员到来之前，他们通读了剧本。演员们平淡无奇、毫无新意、毫无趣味。这是我整个创作生涯的最低谷。走出那个房间时，我觉得自己毫无天赋，我拍的每一部电影都是笑话，我不配从事这个行业。我当时并不知道演员们的“表演水平”还不够，只是在熟悉剧本。当融资人员出现时，他们表演得非常出色。台词飞出书页，在房间里传遍了整个房间。根据剧本朗读会，融资人员决定为这部电影提供资金。

I was in London for a table read for a producer and financing entities. A fancy hotel private dining room was jammed full of actors, the producer, and myself. They did a read-through before the finance guy arrived. The actors were bland, insipid, uninspired, and uninteresting. It was the lowest point of my entire creative life. I walked out of that room feeling I was talentless, that every movie I’ve had made was a joke, and that I did not deserve to be in this business. Little did I know that the actors weren’t up to “performance level” and were only familiarizing themselves with the material. When the financing guy showed up, they turned in a blistering performance. The dialogue lifted off the page and flew around the room. Based on the table read, the guy decided to finance the movie.

87. 你还没真正准备好就急着把剧本发出去！

87. You’re dying to send the script out before you’re really, really ready!

 

如果你能找到一个“真正”愿意阅读你剧本的人，那你就是个幸运的作家。所谓“真正”，我指的是能够帮助你制作电影的导演、制片人、开发人员或演员。电影界的某个人。

If you can find someone “real” who wants to read your script, you’re a lucky writer. By real, I mean a director or producer or development person or actor who is in a position to help you get your movie made. Someone in the movie business.

珍惜这个机会。如果你把你的剧本交给了某个真实的人，而他们读了之后发现剧本并不出色，那么他们 a) 以后再也不会读你写的任何东西，或者 b) 如果他们读了你的下一个剧本，他们会记得第一个剧本并不那么出色，这会影响他们对你新作品的看法。这很可怕，但却是事实。

Treat this opportunity like gold. If you give your script to someone real and they read it and it wasn’t FANTASTIC, they’ll a) never read anything you write in the future, or b) if they do read your next screenplay, they’ll remember the first one wasn’t so hot and it will color their perception of your new work. Ghastly, but true.

他们可以说他们非常期待阅读你的作品，但你可别相信。不要陷入这样的陷阱：“这个人想读它，所以我最好快点把它寄给他。”他们不在乎你是否寄出去，所以你最好再花六个月的时间让它变得令人眼花缭乱。每隔几个月就给他们写封信，告诉他们你还活着，这样他们就不会忘记他们答应过要读它。

They can say how excited they are to read your work, but don’t you believe it. Don’t fall into the trap of, “This guy wants to read it, so I better hurry up and get it to him.” They don’t care if you ever send it, so you may as well take an extra six months to make it dazzling. Do drop them a line every couple of months to say you’re not dead, so they won’t forget they promised to read it.

我写的第一个剧本是《威洛比蔡斯的狼》，一部改编自书籍的作品。我花了三四个月的时间不停地创作这部剧本。大概六个月。有一天，我完成了剧本。我欣喜若狂。我希望下周就能投入制作。哦，真是幸福的一天，我姐姐的一个朋友正在和一位知名女演员约会。她自愿阅读我的剧本，而且，令人惊讶的是，她还帮助了我。我欣喜若狂。我开车去了 Chateau Marmont 酒店，把剧本放在桌子上。我欣喜若狂地离开了。我的剧本完成了，通往财富和幸福的道路就在我面前闪闪发光。

The first script I wrote, The Wolves Of Willoughby Chase, a book adaptation, took me three or four months of non-stop work. Maybe six months. One fine day, I finished it. I was ecstatic. I wanted it to go into production the next week. Oh happy day, a friend of my sister’s was dating a well-known actress. She volunteered to read my screenplay, and, amazingly, to help me. I was doubly ecstatic. I drove up to the Chateau Marmont and dropped it at the desk. I left on a cloud. My script was finished and the road to wealth and happiness lay shining before me.

我在朋友史蒂夫·布鲁姆家停了下来。后来，他与人合写了《The Sure Thing and Tall Tale》和《James and the Giant Peach》。他自愿阅读我刚刚完成的剧本。当时就读完了！我慢悠悠地走到他的客厅，读了一本书。等他读完时天已经黑了，我又回到他的办公室。

I stopped off at my friend Steve Bloom’s house. Later on, he would co-write The Sure Thing and Tall Tale, and James and the Giant Peach. He volunteered to read my hot-off-the-presses screenplay. Right then! I trundled off to his living room and read a book. It was dark by the time he finished, and I went back into his office.

我还记得他坐在椅子上，向后靠着，我的剧本放在他的膝盖上。他开始翻阅，但他没有称赞我，而是把它撕成碎片。就像他用十六英寸的炮弹射击它一样，它在我眼前爆炸了。当他开始轻轻地剖开它时，我立刻就能看清楚了。我看到了很多错误，甚至他都没有指出来。当然，这很令人沮丧，因为我以为我的工作已经完成了，但这也很令人兴奋，因为有了他出色的批评，我将能够让剧本变得更好！

I still remember him in his chair, rocked back, my script on his lap. He started flipping through it, but instead of singing my praises, he tore it to pieces. Like he’d shot it with a sixteen inch shell, it exploded in front of my eyes. As soon as he began gently disemboweling it, I was instantly able to see it clearly. I saw tons of mistakes, ones he hadn’t even pointed out. It was depressing, of course, because I had thought my work was done, but it was exhilarating because, armed with his stellar criticism, I was going to be able to make the script even better!

然后我想起了那位著名女演员。她有我的剧本！她打算读这个垃圾剧本，不仅不会帮助我，而且可能会因为我浪费她的时间而追捕我并杀死我。

Then I remembered the famous actress. She had my script! She was going to read this monumental piece of garbage and not only not help me, but probably have me hunted down and killed for wasting her time.

我感到很糟糕，很愚蠢，还有其他一千种让人汗流浃背的情绪。我羞愧难当，打电话给纽约的她，告诉她我必须重写剧本，嗯，呃，啊，请不要读它。但是，在我还没来得及说话之前，她就道歉了，因为酒店把它弄丢了！耶！好消息！

I felt terrible and stupid and a thousand other sweat-inducing emotions. Mortified, I called her back in New York to tell her I had to rewrite the script and, um, er, ah, please not read it. But, before I could say a word, she apologized because the hotel had lost it! Yee ha! Good news!

躲过了一劫。

Dodged a bullet there.

我又重新投入剧本，又花了三个月的时间重写。总写作时间：九个月。但当我写完时，这部剧本写得不错。它获得了选择权，并最终投入制作。我成为一名作家。这一切都是因为我的朋友批评了我那本不成熟的剧本，我曾认为它很完美。

I dove back into my script and spent three more months rewriting it. Total writing time: nine months. But, when I was done, it was good. It got optioned and eventually was produced. I was launched as a writer. All because my friend blasted my half-baked script, that I had thought was perfect, clean out of the water.

请记住这些永恒的名言：

Keep in mind these deathless quotations:

 

“即使你厌倦了你的剧本，也不意味着它已经完成了。”

威廉·M·埃克斯

“Just because you’re sick of your script doesn’t mean it’s finished.”

William M. Akers

和

and

 

“你怎么知道你的剧本什么时候准备好了？当你唯一的选择是再写一稿或者开枪自尽的时候。”

制片人 Max Wong

“How do you know when your script is ready? When the only choice is do another draft or blow your brains out.”

Max Wong, producer

行业

​

The

Industry

 

88. 你根本不知道这个行业是怎样运作的！

88. You haven’t the first clue how the business works!

 

不要表现出对电影制作过程缺乏了解。做好功课。要专业。

Do not show a lack of understanding of how a movie gets made. Do your homework. Be professional.

 

“他不仅仅是一名牙医。他还在写剧本！”

苏珊·萨兰登在《Anywhere But Here》中说道

“He’s not just a dentist. He’s writing a screenplay!”

Susan Sarandon in Anywhere But Here

现在你的剧本已经写完了，你必须把它卖掉。这意味着要找个人来读它。除非你男朋友经营一家工作室，否则就找个人来读。如果是这样的话，给我打电话。

Now that your script is finished, you have to sell it. That means getting someone to read it. Someone other than your boyfriend, unless he runs a studio. If that’s the case, call me.

翻开你的通讯录。然后，翻开你朋友的通讯录：你认识的那个家伙的堂兄是电影导演吗？你前男友的妈妈是克林特·伊斯特伍德的剧本监督的朋友吗？你的老师在洛杉矶有联系人吗？你见过住在洛杉矶的人吗？他们可能认识谁？

Mine your address book. Then, those of your friends: Do you know a guy who has a cousin who’s a gaffer? Is your old boyfriend’s mom a friend of Clint Eastwood’s script supervisor? Does your teacher have any contacts in Los Angeles? Have you ever met anyone who ever lived in Los Angeles? Whom might they know?

如果你不认识任何与好莱坞有关系的人，那么找人阅读你的剧本的一种方法就是使用好莱坞创意目录 ( www.hcdonline.com )。它列出了每家制作公司以及在那里工作的人员的联系信息。永远不要把你的剧本寄给制片厂。找到一家制作类似你剧本的电影的公司，写信给开发总监，试着说服她阅读你的作品。因为人们每 18 个月就会换一次工作，所以创意目录中将近一半的内容是不准确的，所以一定要买新的。

If you don’t know anybody with a connection to Hollywood, a way to find someone to read your screenplay is the Hollywood Creative Directory (www.hcdonline.com). It lists every production company and the contact information for the people who work there. Never send your script to a studio. Find a company who makes movies like your screenplay and write the Director of Development and try to convince her, sweetly, to read your work. Because people change jobs every 18 months, nearly half the Creative Directory will be inaccurate, so always buy the new one.

你的询问信最好写得精彩一些。花很长时间来写。比如几周。

Your query letter best be fantastic. Take a looooong time to write it. Like weeks.

同时，在等待读者同意阅读您的作品时：组建一个作家小组。获取反馈并采纳部分或全部反馈，然后继续创作您的作品。请记住，任何阅读您剧本的人都是在帮您。

Meanwhile, while you’re waiting for a reader to agree to read your work: Form a writer’s group. Get feedback and take some of it or all of it and work on your material. Remember, anyone who reads your script is doing you a favor.

同时，给自己多一点商业技能。你可以成为一名演员，你可以成为一名剧作家，你可以写一本小说等等，但不要只成为一名编剧。

Meanwhile, give yourself another skill in the business. You can be a performer, you can be a playwright, you can write a novel, etc., but don’t be just a screenwriter.

同时，制作短片。《南方公园》预告片非常搞笑。这让那些家伙有了工作。现在人们因为向www.YouTube.com或www.funnyordie.com提交了短片而得到了交易。

Meanwhile, make short films. The South Park trailer was hilarious. It got those guys work. People are getting deals now because they submitted a short to www.YouTube.com or www.funnyordie.com.

如果你能让公司里的某个人同意阅读你的剧本，他们会给你发一份释放表，这是他们应对骚扰诉讼的手段。你最好找一位娱乐律师来提交你的剧本，因为你不必签署释放表。

If you can get someone at a company to agree to read your script, they’ll send you a release form, which is what they have to combat nuisance lawsuits. You’re better off getting an entertainment attorney to submit your screenplay, because you won’t have to sign a release form.

收到剧本后，公司会将其交给审阅人。如果是小公司，审阅人可能是接待员、助理或无薪大学实习生。代理机构的审阅人会阅读你的整个剧本，但制作公司的审阅人则不必阅读。因此，你必须在十页之内赢得或失去你的读者。

When they receive your script, the company will give it to a reader. If it is a small company, the reader will be a receptionist, an assistant, or an unpaid college intern. While a reader at an agency will read your entire screenplay, the production company reader doesn’t have to. Therefore, you have to win or lose your reader in ten pages.

当读者读完剧本后，他会写评论，也就是对剧本的概述，并建议其他人是否阅读。评论会比你的整个职业生涯都存在得更久，而且你只有一次机会。如果他们不喜欢你的剧本，他们就不会再读你的剧本了。因此，不要提交你的第一个剧本，而要提交你的第一个好剧本。

When the reader finishes reading, he will write coverage, which is a synopsis of your script and a recommendation for someone else to read it, or not. That coverage will stick around a lot longer than your entire career, and you only get one chance at it. If they don’t like your script they will never read your stuff again. Therefore, don’t send in your first script, send your first great script.

如果读者推荐你的作品，开发主管就会阅读它。如果他们喜欢它，他们会把它交给制片人。如果制片人喜欢它，你就会接到电话。

If the reader recommends your work, the Development Executive will read it. If they like it, they’ll give it to the Producer. If the Producer likes it, you’ll get a phone call.

准备好第二份剧本总是一个好主意，因为制片人可能会说：“嘿，这是个好剧本，但我们对这个故事不感兴趣。你还有其他的吗？”如果你有，他们可能会请你来告诉他们你的下一个想法。

It’s always a good idea to have Script #2 ready to go because the Producer may say, “Hey, this is good writing, but we’re not really interested in this story. Have you got anything else?” If you do, they may ask you to come to town and tell them your next idea.

你听到过很多关于推销的说法。推销就是讲故事。

You hear a lot about pitching. It’s storytelling.

如果你确实要开会，计划花 20 分钟讲完所有事情。闲聊结束后，花 10 分钟做演讲然后离开。事先排练，对着人——而不是对着镜子。

If you do get a meeting, plan on taking 20 minutes for the whole shebang. As soon as the chit-chat is over, take ten minutes to do your pitch and leave. Rehearse beforehand, to a person — not the mirror.

 

我喜欢快速地建立故事的世界。先营造一点氛围，然后继续。

先介绍一下主角、她的个性、她的问题以及她想要什么。

再介绍一下坏人以及他想要什么。

第一幕结束：事情如何变化？

通往第二幕结束的道路上的一些重大障碍。

英雄的低谷，她认为一切都完了。

她会做什么来解决她的问题？

当整个事情结束时，她是如何通过这段经历改变自己的？

I like to set up the world of the story, quickly. A little atmosphere, then move on.

A bit about the main character, her personality, her problem, and what she wants.

A bit about the bad guy and what he wants.

First Act break: how do things change?

A few of the major bumps in the road leading to and including the Second Act break.

The hero’s low point, where she thinks all is lost.

What does she do to solve her problem?

And, when the whole thing is over, how has she been transformed by the experience?

轰隆隆，就这样了。

Boom. That’s it.

拿上你的免费水然后逃走。

Take your free water and skedaddle.

如果他们对这个想法或你的剧本感兴趣，那么你就可以轻而易举地找到经纪人，因为经纪人可以不费吹灰之力就自动赚钱！公司会选择你的剧本，并要求你重写。或者，他们会选择你的剧本，不要求重写（哇哦！），并开始尝试招募人才。如今，你可以免费重写这些剧本。你会向你的新经纪人抱怨这件事，但制片人已经习惯了免费获得东西，所以你会进行大量重写，希望他们能卖出剧本。还有谁对你的剧本感兴趣？没有人，对吧？

If they are interested in that idea or your script, then you can get an agent, easy-peasey, because there is automatically money for the agent to make with no effort! The company will option your script and ask you for rewrites. Or, they will option your script and not ask for rewrites (woo hoo!) and start trying to attach talent. These days, you will do those rewrites for free. You will whine to your new agent about it, but producers are used to getting stuff for free, so you’ll do a raft of rewrites in hopes they can sell the thing. Who else is showing interest in your screenplay? Nobody, right?

也许他们会卖掉它。也许不会。也许他们会浪费你一两年的时间在无用的重写上。也许不会。这是这是最令人沮丧的业务领域之一，没有办法绕过它。开发。如果你很幸运，制片人擅长讲故事，你的剧本就会得到改善。如果你出生在一个坏星座，制片人几乎没有故事感，会强迫你免费销毁你的剧本，然后把它扔掉，因为它不再有用了。真是难缠。

Maybe they’ll sell it. Maybe they won’t. Maybe they’ll waste a year or two of your life on useless rewrites. Perhaps not. This is one of the most frustrating areas of the business, and there’s no way around it. Development. If you’re lucky, the Producer is good with story and your script will improve. If you were born under a bad sign, the Producer has little story-sense and will force you to destroy your screenplay, for free, and then will throw it away because it’s no good any more. Tough beans.

如果他们找到了导演或演员，他们就会追求金钱。

If they get a director or an actor attached, they’ll go after money.

如果他们获得融资，他们就会拍摄你的电影，你会在主要摄影的第一天收到一张大额支票。

If they get financing, they’ll make your movie and you’ll get a big check on the First Day of Principal Photography.

然后，让别人阅读你的下一个剧本就会变得容易一些。

And then, it will be a tiny bit easier to get someone to read your next screenplay.

永远不要忘记，竞争是令人难以想象的。当汤姆·舒尔曼刚从学校毕业时，他正在拜访一位朋友，这位朋友正在为理查德·德莱福斯看房子。晚餐后，一个信使带着剧本来到德莱福斯先生的家中。如果一个信使把剧本送到演员家中，那就意味着剧本已经在食物链中占据了很高的位置。

Never forget, the competition is mind boggling. When he was fresh out of school, future Academy Award winner Tom Schulman was visiting a friend who was house-sitting for Richard Dreyfuss. After dinner, a messenger showed up with a script for Mr. Dreyfuss. If a messenger delivers a screenplay to an actor’s home, that means that script has already fought its way darn high up the food chain.

舒尔曼的朋友说：“所以你想成为一名作家？”她走下大厅，打开一扇门，把剧本扔了进去。舒尔曼忐忑不安地跟了进去，往里面看了看。他看到一间空荡荡的小卧室，地板中央有四英尺高的一堆剧本。

Schulman’s friend said, “So you wanna be a writer?” She walked down the hall, opened a door, and tossed the script in. With trepidation, Schulman followed and looked in. He saw a small empty bedroom and in the center of the floor was a four foot pile of screenplays.

他差点吐了。

He nearly threw up.

知道会发生什么。你的生活会更轻松。

Know what to expect. Your life will be easier.

89. 你不知道好莱坞的人什么时候吃午饭！

89. You don’t know what time they eat lunch in Hollywood!

 

否则，你就不会在太平洋时间 1:15 打电话了。猎鹰。

Otherwise, you wouldn’t call at 1:15 Pacific. Nimrod.

娱乐圈里的每个人都在 1:00 吃午饭。全城都是这样。所以，不要在洛杉矶时间 12:45 给别人打电话，当他们正对助理大喊大叫，抱怨最后几个电话时，当他们正挤进高跟鞋时，当他们正尖叫着让服务员把车停在楼下时，——就在这时！——你从 Podunk 打来电话。他们为什么要和你说话，一个显然不懂三垒的人？

Everyone in the entertainment business eats lunch at 1:00. All over town. So, don’t call someone at 12:45 Los Angeles time, just as they are shouting at their assistant about the last phone calls, just as they are cramming into their high heels, and just as they are screeching for the valet to have their car ready downstairs, and — right then! — you call from Podunk. Why on Earth would they want to talk to you, someone who obviously doesn’t know their ass from third base?

不要看起来像个傻瓜。请在工作时间打电话。请在 12:30 之前和 2:30 之后打电话。

Don’t look like a putz. Call during business hours. Call before 12:30 and after 2:30.

除非——总是有一个“除非”。

Unless — and there’s always an “unless.”

不要在午餐时间打电话，除非你只想回电话，而实际上根本不想和他们说话。那么，午餐时间打电话就是为了躲避别人！如果这就是你在午餐时间打电话的原因，那么你就可以在 Sammy Glick 的成功阶梯上再上两步了。

Don’t call at lunchtime unless you only want credit for having returned their call and don’t actually want to talk with them at all. Then, avoiding people is what lunchtime phone calls are all about! If this is why you call during lunch, permission granted to move two steps up the Sammy Glick Ladder To Success.

说到打电话：好莱坞是一个不断变化的泥潭，充斥着粗鲁无礼、彬彬有礼和野蛮残忍的行为。过去被认为是反社会、不道德、不可原谅的行为，如今已成为常态。当大联盟、一线导演、经纪人和制片人将材料发给演员的经纪人，却从未被告知他们喜欢、不喜欢，甚至不知道他们读过，那么你我都不应该指望任何人回答我们关于任何问题的问题。

Speaking of phone calls: Hollywood is an ever-changing morass of bad manners, exquisite politeness, and savage cruelty. What used to be considered anti-social, immoral, inexcusable behavior has become the norm. When major league, A-list directors, agents, and producers send material out to actors’ agents and are never told that they liked it, didn’t like it, or even that they read it, then you and I have got no business expecting anyone to give us an answer to a question about anything.

沉默意味着拒绝。

Silence means no.

这并不意味着他们不喜欢它。这并不意味着他们喜欢它，但还没有回复你。这意味着你永远不会收到他们的消息，而你的职责就是永远不要问为什么。法律允许你发送一封无聊的电子邮件或打一个无聊的电话，然后放弃，舔舐伤口，回到你的洞穴去制定更好的策略或写一个更好的剧本。

It doesn’t mean they didn’t like it. It doesn’t mean they liked it, and aren’t back to you yet. It means you’re never going to hear from them, and it is your job never to ask why. The law allows you one noodge email or one noodge phone call, and after that give up, lick your wounds, and retire to your cave to plan a better strategy or write a better screenplay.

90. 你的权利意识太强了！又名“不要与笔记作对！”

90. Your sense of entitlement is in overdrive! a.k.a. “Don’t fight the notes!”

 

没人欠你读书。

No one owes you a read.

 

“如果我读到了一个糟糕的剧本，花了我四十五分钟，我既不能要求退款，也不能要求退还我的时间，而且我会感到无比愤怒。”

洛杉矶制片人

“If I read a bad script, which takes me forty-five minutes, I can’t ask for my money back or my time back and I am filled with incalculable amounts of rage.”

Los Angeles producer

没人欠你什么。你花时间写了精彩的剧本，并不意味着任何人都有义务去读它。这可能是世界上最伟大的剧本，但还有很多剧本在流传，如果他们错过了你的剧本，他们也不会为此失眠。

No one owes you anything. Just because you took the time to write your fabulous screenplay doesn’t mean anybody Out There is honor bound to read it. It may be the greatest screenplay on earth, but there are plenty of scripts floating around and if they miss out on reading yours, they won’t lose sleep over it.

站在你要求阅读剧本的人的角度去思考。记住，从事影视行业需要付出巨大的压力和时间。当你“真实”地接触某个人时，要了解他们的日程安排以及你要求他们做的事情。如果你要求某人阅读你的剧本，你就是在乞求他们为你付出几个小时的时间，而这是你无法回报的。你可以给他们一份精美的礼物、一本很酷的书或一张星巴克礼品卡，但听取他们的建议并采纳他们的建议也不错。

Get into the mind of the person you are asking to read your material. Remember the massive amount of stress and time involved to be in the movie and television business. When you approach someone “real,” be aware of their schedule and what you are asking them to do. If you ask someone to read your script, you are begging for a couple of hours out of their life, that you can’t give back. You can give them a nice present, a cool book, or a Starbucks gift card, but listening to their advice, and taking their suggestions, is not a bad idea either.

你必须非常有礼貌，不要过分强迫，并且非常善解人意。如果有人同意阅读你的剧本，你必须像对待珍宝一样对待他们，不要以为他们这个周末就能读完，不管他们怎么说。

You must be endlessly gracious, not overly pushy, and very understanding. If someone agrees to read your screenplay, you must treat them like a precious jewel and never assume they’ll get to it this weekend, despite what they say.

不要在周一打电话询问他们的想法。你必须时刻记住有多少人将他们拉向了多少不同的、痛苦的方向。几周内不要给他们打电话。然后给他们发一封温和的电子邮件。一个月后，也许再发一封。之后，忘掉他们。

Don’t call them Monday to see what they thought. You have to constantly keep in mind how many people are pulling them in how many different, and painful, directions. Don’t call for a couple of weeks. Then send them a gentle email noodge. A month later, maybe another one. After that, forget them.

要温柔。要有耐心。要宽容。不要像个傻瓜一样行事。

Be sweet. Be patient. Be tolerant. And don’t act like an idiot.

你最不想做的事情就是大张旗鼓地向别人抱怨，说他们还没看懂你那出色的剧本速度足够快，适合您。他们接听您的电话就算幸运了，所以请采取相应的行动。

The last thing you want to do is come at somebody, guns blazing, put out that they haven’t gotten to your phenomenal screenplay quickly enough to suit you. You’re lucky they’ll take your calls, so act accordingly.

而且，如果他们很贴心地给你笔记，那就记下来吧！

And, if perchance, they are thoughtful enough to give you notes, take them!

 

“没有人比初学者更傲慢。”

伊丽莎白·阿什利

“No one is as arrogant as a beginner.”

Elizabeth Ashley

如果有人读了你的剧本，但并不想像你希望的那样迅速地将你奉为偶像，但他们有笔记，那么请尽职尽责地写下来并表现出感兴趣的样子。我经常遇到从未创作过任何作品的作家。新手通常不太愿意接受批评。也许他们认为这些建议值得他们付出代价。

If somebody reads your script and doesn’t want to canonize you as quickly as you’d like, but they have notes, then dutifully write them down and act interested. I get this a lot with writers who have never had anything produced. Newbies are often less open to criticism. Maybe they figure the advice is worth what they paid.

不要与提供笔记的人争吵。不要说，“但是幕间休息就在那里，你只是看不到它。”不要像在奥马哈海滩一样每码都抓着。记下他们说的话，低声说一声接受，最后说“谢谢”。不要表现得好像你比他们更了解剧本。不要因为他们不理解你如此慷慨地花时间写的东西而表现得像他们是白痴！

Do not fight the guy giving notes. Do not say, “but the act break is there, you just can’t see it.” Do not claw for every yard like it’s Omaha Beach. Copy down what they say, murmur gracious acceptance, and say “thank you” at the end. Don’t act like you know more about screenplays than they do. Don’t act like they’re idiots because they don’t understand what you’ve so generously taken the time to have written!

当我还在电影学校的时候，我们展示了我们可怜的早期项目，其中一个人做的很糟糕。这种事时有发生。所以，我们在房间里走来走去，发表我们最害怕被伤害的评论，然后他说，真的很生气，“这是一部个人电影！你不应该理解它！”他很快就消失了。

When I was in film school, we showed our pathetic little first projects and one guy’s was terrible. It happens. So, we were going around the room and giving our most afraid-of-being-hurtful comments, and he said, really put out, “It’s a personal film! You’re not supposed to understand it!” He vanished soon thereafter.

如果你找到一个真正的人来阅读你的剧本，好莱坞的大门就会为你打开。只是稍微打开了一点。

If you find someone real to read your script, the door to Hollywood opens. Slightly.

如果有人读了你的剧本，并好心地给你笔记，但你出于某种疯狂的权利意识，在笔记上与他们争吵，那扇伟大的金门就会开始关闭。你也不会看到它关闭，因为这些人很圆滑，就像大学兄弟会里的 Flusher 一样——在抢购期间把失败者带到后门的和蔼可亲的人，魅力十足、优雅而善解人意。他温和地向那个呆子解释说，也许他可以在路上的兄弟会里试试运气，那个家伙满脸笑容地离开，却没有意识到自己已经是行尸走肉。好莱坞大门关闭时就是这样。你永远不会感觉到针头刺入你的大脑。

If someone reads your script and is kind enough to give you notes, but because of some insane sense of entitlement, you fight them on the notes, that great golden door will begin to close. You won’t see it close either, because these guys are smooth, like the Flusher in college fraternities — the pleasant guy during rush who leads the loser to the back door, all charm and grace and understanding. He gently explains to the dweeb that perhaps he might try his luck at a frat house down the road, and the guy leaves all smiles, unaware he’s a dead man walking. That’s how it is when the Hollywood door closes. You never feel the needle enter your brain.

这些人每周要阅读 20 或 30 份剧本。他们没有时间或容忍傲慢。请记住，读者只会想到阅读花了多长时间，而不是你花了多长时间写出来。

These people read 20 or 30 scripts a week. They have no time or tolerance for arrogance. Remember, it only crosses the reader’s mind how long it took to read, not how long you took to write it.

如果你反驳这些笔记，他或她绝对会想，“老兄，我周末花了一个小时读你的剧本。你是一个从未做过任何事情的人，我可能知道我在说什么——至少听听！”

If you refute the notes, he or she is absolutely going to think, “Dude, I took an hour of my weekend to read your fucking script. You’re a guy who has never done anything, and there’s a shot I could know what I’m talking about — at least listen!”

然后那扇巨大的金色大门就会锁上。制片人会去参加她的制作会议、选角会议、免费午餐、按摩和主要摄影的第一天，而你将被独自留在阴冷多风的人行道上，紧紧抓住你的剧本，看着高墙和紧闭的钢门，想知道为什么它没有把手。

And the great, golden door will lock. The producer will go off to her production meetings and casting sessions and free lunches and massages and first days of principal photography, and you will be left alone on a raw, windy sidewalk, clutching your screenplay, looking at the high wall and the closed steel door, wondering why it’s got no handle.

91. 你不知道什么是一封像样的询问信！

91. You don’t know what a decent query letter is!

 

打开你的询问信的人会问：“我为什么要关注你？”即使是最小的精品代理机构，在 WGA 代理名单上标记为“不接受未经请求的材料”，每天也会收到五封询问信。

The question the person opening your query letter asks is, “Why should I pay attention to you?” Even the tiniest boutique agency, marked on the WGA agent list as “does not accept unsolicited material” gets five query letters a day.

有创意是好的，但“有创意”不是。不要太复杂，也不要显得绝望。不要给五十名经纪人寄信。不要把一根假断指和你的恐怖剧本一起寄给一群高管。一栋巨大的办公楼因此被疏散。猜猜哪个作家的名字永远是泥土？

Creative is good, “creative” is not. Don’t be elaborate and appear desperate. Don’t send a message in a bottle to fifty agents. Don’t send a fake severed finger to a bunch of executives with your horror script. A huge office building got evacuated over that one. Guess which writer’s name is forever mud?

在你的询问信中，直奔主题。写出日志行。给出你拥有的任何写作荣誉：记者、剧作家、小说家，说写作是你的生命。也许让你的信寄给洛杉矶的朋友，因为非洛杉矶作家会让经纪人的生活更加困难。如果你不住在洛杉矶，她可能会推销你的信。让你的信和剧本看起来正常。如果剧本的格式不完全正确，或者钉子重量不对，他们就会把它扔掉，而它可能价值一百万美元。

In your query letter, get to the point. Tell the log line. Give whatever writing credit you have: reporter, playwright, novelist, that says that writing is your life. Perhaps have your letter mailed by a friend in Los Angeles, as non-L.A.-based-writers make the agent’s life more difficult. If you don’t live in Los Angeles, she will likely pitch your letter. Make your letter and script look normal. If the script is not exactly the right format, or has the wrong weight brads, they just trash it, and it could be worth a million dollars.

 

“我会看看这个人是否有线索。如果剧情简介或梗概看起来很有趣，我就会继续。但很少会这样。三年来，我只通过这种方式发现了两位作家，结果发现他们真的很优秀，他们来到好莱坞时一无所知，也不认识任何人，而是通过一封询问信尝试了一番。”

前创意主管

“I’d look at it and see if this person has a clue. If the log line looks interesting, or the synopsis, I’d go on. Rarely was it. In three years, I only discovered two writers that way, who turned out to be really good, who had come to Hollywood knowing nothing and knowing no one, and tried it via a query letter.”

Former creative executive

你必须记住，制片人很忙，不在乎。你必须有出色的作品，而且必须准备好让她毫不费力地出售。我想，像这样的作品会得到回电：“我控制着我祖父温斯顿·丘吉尔的终身权利。”

以下是一位开发主管对询问信的看法。

You have to remember, the producer is busy and doesn’t care. You have to have something spectacular, and it has to be ready for her to sell — with no effort. Something like this would get a call back, I should think: “I control the life rights of my grandfather, Winston Churchill.”

Here are a development executive’s thoughts about query letters.

 

“如今，他们大多通过电子邮件来信。我们也收到一些信件和传真。由于我们收到的信件太多，而且我们严格意义上不接受未经请求的投稿，所以大多数都被忽略了。最好的策略可能是有人给我打电话，然后我会让他们通过电子邮件向我发送信息，因为我们有过交谈，所以我会认真阅读电子邮件，而不是将其扔掉。”

“These days they mostly come by email. We get some by letter and fax too. Since we get so many, and since we don’t technically accept unsolicited submissions, most get ignored. The best strategy would probably be for someone to call me, then I’d ask them to email me information, and because we’ve had a conversation I would actually read the email versus trashing it.”

一个想法：如果大多数都是通过电子邮件发送，为什么不发送蜗牛信件呢？不过，也许不行。

A thought: If most come via email, why don’t you send a snail mail letter? Then again, perhaps not.

 

“即使通过电子邮件发送，也请将其格式化为正式信函。我收到很多以‘艾琳，我想让你看看’开头的电子邮件，这些邮件都是来自我不认识的人，这让我很生气，因为这让我觉得他们在试图欺骗我，让我以为我认识他们。”

“Even if you’re sending them by email, still format them as a formal letter. I get lots of emails that start with ‘Irene, thought you’d like to take a look at’ from people I don’t know, which pisses me off since it makes me think they’re trying to trick me into thinking I know them.”

别做混蛋。他们知道你是否在撒谎。

Don’t be a jerk. They know if you’re lying.

 

“一个拼写错误或语法错误就足以让我停止继续阅读。如果信件的书写不完美，我只能想象实际的书写方式。”

“One misspelled word or grammatical error is enough to stop me from reading on. If the writing of the letter isn’t perfect, I can only imagine the writing in the actual script.”

还记得我说过拼写检查吗？我可不是那么笨，对吧？

Remember what I said about spellcheck!? I’m not such a doofus, huh?

 

“避免将‘虎胆龙威’与‘海滩’进行比较。说一部电影属于某种风格是可以的（例如，一部高中喜剧属于‘美国派’风格），但将平淡无奇与平淡无奇进行比较总是会让人觉得陈词滥调。”

“Avoid the ‘Die Hard meets Beaches’ comparisons. It’s okay to say a movie is in the vein of something (e.g., a high school comedy in the vein of AMERICAN PIE) but the blah meets blah comparison always feels clichéd.”

 

“避免使用诸如‘他会吗？’之类的夸张的短语。”

“Avoid dramatic phrases like, ‘or will he?’ ”

 

“当人们提到我们制作的其他电影，并说他们的项目如何与我们的总体计划相契合时，我们会感到非常高兴（例如，‘就像我很喜欢你的电影《无声的游泳》一样，这个剧本也将个人故事与更大的政治问题结合在一起’）。”

“It’s great when people reference other films we’ve produced and say how their project would fit in with our general slate (e.g. ‘Much like your film, Silent Swim, which I loved, this script also combines a personal story with a larger political issue’).”

 

“如果您参加了比赛并入围决赛，请将这一点写在询问信的第一句中。‘我是 _________ 的决赛选手’，第一行。”

“If you enter a contest and you are a finalist, put that in the first sentence of your query letter. ‘I was a finalist in the _________,’ top line.”

 

“如果你写了一部喜剧，那么你的询问信就应该有趣。”

“If you’ve written a comedy, make your query letter funny.”

这里有一些询问信，嗯，没有完全……成功。

Here are a few query letters, that, um, didn’t quite... make it.

除了语法糟糕、没有故事感、列出 WGA 编号以及过多使用“非常”之外，这位作者犯下的最严重错误是继续给开发主管发送电子邮件，就好像她请求了剧本一样，在主题行中写上“ Re :”，并在邮件开头写上“感谢您的回复”，尽管她没有回复。绝对不行。

Besides appalling grammar, no real sense of the story, listing his WGA#, and using “very” too much, the worst mistake this writer made was continuing to Email the development exec as if she had requested the script by putting Re: in the subject line and starting his Emails “Thank you for your reply” even though she had not replied. The ultimate no-no.

 

__________________________________________________

来自：年轻作家 (youngwriter@domainname.com)

致：developmentexec@productioncompanyproductions.com

主题：投稿

__________________________________________________

From: Young Writer (youngwriter@domainname.com)

To: developmentexec@productioncompanyproductions.com

Subject: Submission

 

卡罗琳，我在下面附上了剧本的简介和概要。希望你喜欢它们，如果你有任何问题请告诉我。

Carolyn, I attached below the Logline and the Short Synopsis for the script. I hope you like them and please let me know if you have any questions.

 

剧本：“Buddy, buddy, buddy”，喜剧

WGA 注册号 # 1234567

Feature Script: “Buddy, buddy, buddy”, Comedy

WGA Registration # 1234567

 

我认为《哥们，哥们，哥们》对制片公司来说是个不错的选择。主要演员，男主角和女主角，应该都在 30 岁出头，很好外表、聪明、智慧，同时也是脆弱的人。从片头字幕开始，这部电影就有很多惊喜，笑声开始全力以赴。电影的第一幕发生在酒吧里，为电影设定了节奏和滑稽的环境，从那时起，事情变得更加有趣和更具娱乐性。这是一个非常聪明的故事，一部非常轻松可爱的浪漫喜剧，以聪明的幽默、爱情和有趣的惊喜为主。

希望你喜欢它！

I believe that “Buddy, buddy, buddy” could be a good pick for Production Company Productions. The main stars, the two male and female leads, are supposed to be in their early 30’s, good looking, smart, intelligent, and also vulnerable people. Right from the opening credits, the movie has many surprises and the laughs begin to come full force. The movie’s first Act which takes place in a bar sets the pace and comical environment of the film, and from then on, things get funnier and much more entertaining. This is a very smart story, a very nice lighthearted and adorable romantic comedy dominated by intelligent humor, love and funny surprises.

I hope you enjoy it!

 

剧情

简介 高中时她很肤浅、很刻薄，在舞会上甩了他，因为他的长相“尤其是他的大鼻子”。所以当他 13 年后看到做了鼻子整形手术的她和他三个有趣的朋友时，复仇的时刻到了。

Logline

She was superficial and mean in high school and dumped him on prom night because of his looks “specially his big nose”. So when he sees her 13 years later, with a nose job and his three funny friends, it’s revenge time.

 

谢谢，祝您

有愉快的一天。

Thank you,

Have a great day.

 

年轻作家

(212) 555-1212

Young Writer

(212) 555-1212

 

_____________________________________________

______________________________________________

开发主管没有读完第二段关于这个美女的内容。请注意，作者通过顶部的电子邮件列表让她感觉多么特别。“我们会把这个发给每个人！”而且，其中很多都是匿名电子邮件地址，甚至连人名都没有！很好的研究。

The development executive didn’t make it past the second paragraph on this beauty. Notice how special the writer has made her feel because of the Email list at the top. “We’re sending this to everybody!” And, a lot of them are blind Email addresses, not even a person’s name! Nice research.

 

_________________________________________________

__________________________________________________

 

发件人：年轻电影制作人

收件人：reader@bigfilms.com；edwinag@bigmovies.com；contact@literaryhat.com；mail@fabulousfilms.com；contact@giantmovies.net；timsmith@immensemovies.com；info@bigmoviesentertainment.com；madisonpewitt@bigmovies.org.uk；films@bigmovies.ca；josephine@bigmovies.tv；ipfreeley@hugeproductions.com；prq@thebigmoviecompany.com

From: Young Filmmaker

To: reader@bigfilms.com; edwinag@bigmovies.com; contact@literaryhat.com; mail@fabulousfilms.com; contact@giantmovies.net; timsmith@immensemovies.com; info@bigmoviesentertainment.com; madisonpewitt@bigmovies.org.uk; films@bigmovies.ca; josephine@bigmovies.tv; ipfreeley@hugeproductions.com; prq@thebigmoviecompany.com

 

主题：为我们的电影项目

《RETROACTIVE》寻找制片人

Subject: Seeking producer for our film project titled

RETROACTIVE

 

尊敬的制片人和电影制作人，

Dear Fellow Producers and Film Makers,

 

In the Groove Productions 正在寻找其他制片人加入我们，帮助我们制作名为 RETROACTIVE 的电影项目（具有巨大的国际吸引力）并将其搬上大银幕。以下是这个真实而引人入胜的故事的概要。如果感兴趣，请联系我们。

We here at In the Groove Productions are looking for other producers to come on board, to help get our film project titled RETROACTIVE, (with huge international appeal) made and onto the big screen. Below is a synopsis of this true and compelling story. If interested please contact us.

 

《追溯》讲述了一个关于戏剧、冒险、勇气、爱和失去的故事。它将带你经历一场情绪的过山车之旅，因为这个真实的故事将深深触动你，触及人类情感的核心。

Retroactive is a story of drama, adventure, courage, love and loss. It will take you on a emotional roller coaster ride, because this true story, will touch you deeply, at the core of human emotion.

 

故事讲述了这两个年轻人的非凡冒险、他们为生存而奋斗，以及迈克尔在自由之地挪威找到的生活和爱情。但自由总是有代价的。

The story follows the extraordinary adventure of these two young men, their struggle for survival, and the life and love Michael finds in Norway, the land of the free. But freedom always comes at a cost.

 

追溯性向我们展示了一个人为了寻求自由会付出多大的努力（这种事情今天仍然在发生），同时也展示了我们想要在世界上找到自己地位的渴望，以及我们因与家人分离而感到的内疚。

Retroactive shows us the lengths one will go, to search for freedom, (something that is still happening today) and the simultaneous desire to find our own place in the world, and the guilt we feel about separating ourselves from our families.

 

致以最诚挚的问候，

年轻电影人

Best Regards,

Young Filmmaker

 

_____________________________________________

______________________________________________

这是一封来自制片人从未见过的邮件，他发邮件时就像是好友一样。他确实正确地拼写了“绝对”这个词，但请看一下糟糕的主题校对。请注意标题行中的长句子和结尾处陈词滥调的戏剧性台词。

Here’s one from someone the producer never met who Emailed as if they were buddies. He did spell “definitely” correctly, but check out the poor subject line proofreading. Notice the run on sentence in the logline and the clichéd dramatic line at the end.

 

_________________________________________________

__________________________________________________

 

发件人：年轻导演

收件人：制片人先生

主题：想看看项目

From: Young Director

To: Mr. Producer

Subject: thought to see project

 

你好，大卫，希望你一切都好。

Hi there David, hope all’s been well with you.

 

我觉得你肯定想看看一些东西。这是一部完整的戏剧剧本，由一位曾获得过制片人、获奖剧作家撰写，他也是尼科尔奖学金的决赛入围者。

There’s something I definitely thought you might want a chance to see. It’s an available full-length drama script by a produced screenwriter and award-winning playwright who’s also been a Nicholl Fellowship finalist.

 

如果您愿意的话我可以把它发给您...只要说一声。

I can have it sent over to you if you’d like...just say the word.

 

“劫掠蓝色海洋（完整版电视剧）...”

“ROBBING THE BLUE SEA (full length drama)...

 

一位父亲的婚姻陷入困境，朋友都认为他无趣，他可能会失去自己正在疏远他的十几岁的儿子，而且没有任何希望可以阻止这种情况发生，除非他最终面对与自己父亲的类似疏远……但那个男人已经在越南失踪了三十八年。

A father whose marriage is in trouble, whose friends think him boring, risks losing his own teenage son who is drifting away from him and there’s no hope of preventing it, unless he finally confronts a similar estrangement from his own father...but that man’s been M.I.A. in Vietnam for thirty-eight years.

 

他踏上了一段旅程，遇见了与父亲并肩作战的滑稽老兵，然后又遇见了战争中当厨师的神秘泥瓦匠。当他最终得知父亲身上可怕的秘密时，他彻底改变了自己。他回家试图与家人和解，但为时已晚吗？”

He undertakes a journey that leads him to the comical veteran who fought alongside his father, and then the mysterious bricklayer who was a cook in the war. When he eventually learns the awful secret of what happened to his father, it changes him forever. He goes home to attempt reconciliation with his family, but is it too late?”

 

谨致问候，

年轻导演

Best regards,

Young Director

 

_____________________________________________

______________________________________________

我听说过一封很棒的咨询信。可惜一直没能找到。信的作者是连体双胞胎中的一位，他写了一个关于连体双胞胎生活的剧本。这是一封标准的、愚蠢的信，里面有一些蹩脚的笑话，但信的背面有手写的内容：“我哥哥是个怪胎，是个十足的骗子。如果你想读我的剧本，给我打电话，但如果你打电话时他接了，就告诉他你是从干洗店打来的。”

I heard about a great query letter. Never was able to track it down, sadly. The writer was one half of conjoined twins, and had written a screenplay about life as Siamese twins. It was a standard, stupid letter with bad jokes that didn’t work, but on the back of the letter, written by hand: “My brother is a freak and a total hack. If you want to read my screenplay, call me, but if you call and he answers, tell him you’re calling from the dry cleaners.”

整件事都是骗局，而这个人现在从事喜剧写作事业。

The whole thing was a hoax, and the guy now has a career in comedy writing.

92. 您在询问信中提出了愚蠢的要求！

92. You made boneheaded demands in your query letter!

 

我再次引用阿什利女士的话：“没有人比初学者更傲慢。”

I re-quote Ms. Ashley. “No one is as arrogant as a beginner.”

如何通过一个简单的步骤让你的信件被扔进垃圾桶：“我很依赖指导，我从来没有做过任何事情，但我对此有自己的想法。”

How to get your letter thrown in the trash in one easy step: “I’m attached to direct, and I’ve never done anything but I’ve got the vision for this.”

你必须明白。如果剧本中涉及威尔·法瑞尔，那么制作剧本非常困难。如果剧本中不涉及任何内容，那么制作剧本更是困难至极。用毫无意义的附件制作的。而你，作为导演，毫无意义。

You’ve got to understand. It’s very hard to get a script produced with Will Ferrell attached. It’s incredibly hard to get a script produced with no attachments. It’s unbelievably hard to get a script produced with meaningless attachments. And you, as director, are meaningless.

我不想对此太苛刻，但你做了什么？看过很多电影吗？记住，他们正在寻找不读你剧本的理由。做一个傲慢的笨蛋是很好的借口。

I hate to be harsh about it, but what have you done? Seen a lot of movies? Remember, they are looking for reasons not to read your script. Being an arrogant bonehead is a great one.

他们不让新手拍电影。所以，如果我没记错的话，女演员玛德琳·斯托（她比你更有名）最近写了一部西部片。剧本似乎很棒。她想导演。据说他们为剧本提供了500 万美元。她仍然想导演。哈！童话结束了。在 imdb 上搜索她。她没有被列为“导演”。如果玛德琳·斯托不能成功，你不要尝试。好吗？

They don’t let beginners make movies. So, if memory serves, actress Madeline Stowe (who has a higher profile than you) recently wrote a western. The script, apparently, was fantastic. She wanted to direct. They supposedly offered her five million dollars for the screenplay. She still wanted to direct. Ha! End of fairy tale. Look her up in the imdb. She’s not listed anywhere as “director.” If Madeline Stowe can’t pull it off, don’t you try. Okay?

 

“拿走那里的东西。”

Richard Sylbert

“Take what’s there.”

Richard Sylbert

职业生涯只能容忍少数重大错误。如果你继续犯这样的错误，你会在五十岁时抬起头来，想知道这一切到底都去哪儿了。

A career can only tolerate a small number of gigantic mistakes. If you continue making them, you’ll look up, at fifty, wondering where the hell it all went.

我的建议是，用一种温柔的、老大哥般的、仁慈的、抚慰人的、令人欣慰的声音说出来：

My advice, in a gentle, Big Brother, benevolent, soothing, all-comforting voice:

 

就让他们制作你的电影吧……

Just… let them… make… your movie…

让他们为你的剧本付钱。让他们把你的作品带给观众。让它在有线电视上播出。让它直接制作成 DVD。你在乎什么？别做个傲慢的白痴。傲慢的白痴在 Safeway 的装卸码头上工作。让别人买自己作品的人可以兑现支票，和他们心满意足的妻子做爱！

Let them pay you for your screenplay. Let them bring your work to the audience. Let it be made for cable. Let it be made for direct to DVD. What do you care? Don’t be an arrogant moron. Arrogant morons work on the loading dock at Safeway. People who let other people buy their material get to cash checks and have hot sex with their terribly contented wives!

93. 你不想签署释放他们的协议！

93. You don’t want to sign their release!

 

如果你的询问信让他们兴奋不已，他们会给你发一份授权书，让你签字，这样他们就可以阅读你的剧本而不会被起诉。如果你不让他们阅读你的剧本，他们就不能拍摄你的电影。

If your query letter thrills them, they will send you a release to sign so they can read your script without being sued. If you don’t let them read your script, they can’t make your movie.

这些文件大部分都很基础：“目前的想法就这么多，我们可能正在开发类似的东西。我们很乐意阅读，但你必须承认我们可能正在开发类似的东西。” 就是这样。是的，这些文件偏向于生产者，但他们是买家，而你不是。

Most of these documents are pretty basic: “There are only so many ideas out there and we may be developing something like this. We’ll be happy to read it, but you must acknowledge that we may be working on something similar.” Like that. Yes, these documents are weighted toward the producers, but they’re the buyers and you’re not.

 

“买家和卖家有什么区别？《发条橙》前半部分和后半部分的区别。”

Brandon Tartikoff

“What’s the difference between being a buyer and a seller? The difference between the first half of A Clockwork Orange and the second.”

Brandon Tartikoff

如果你足够幸运，有人愿意阅读你的剧本，不要拒绝签署免责声明，从而毁掉这个机会！他们不断收到大量剧本，少一个剧本也无所谓。你必须明白，他们不在乎你的剧本是否会成为下一部《泰坦尼克号》。他们宁愿把它扔掉，因为他们只想熬过这一周，不被人起诉。

If you’re lucky enough to get someone to want to read your screenplay, don’t spoil the opportunity by refusing to sign the release! They have a constant flood of scripts coming at them and one less won’t matter. You have to understand that they don’t care if your script might be the next Titanic. They’d rather throw it away because all they want is to get through the week without someone suing them.

签署豁免书并希望一切顺利。无论如何，这都是整个业务的基础，希望。

Sign the release and hope for the best. That’s what this whole business is built on anyway, hope.

安格斯特·奥·拉玛

Angst-o-Rama

 

94. 你认为好莱坞会窃取你的创意！

94. You think Hollywood will steal your idea!

 

对偏执保持警惕。

Be paranoid of paranoia.

 

“不要担心别人会窃取你的想法。如果你的想法很好，你就必须强迫别人接受。”

霍华德·艾肯

“Don’t worry about people stealing your ideas. If your ideas are any good, you’ll have to ram them down people’s throats.”

Howard Aiken

这一点我真的搞不懂。很多初学写作的人都害怕有人会窃取他们的想法。好莱坞的人可没时间窃取你的故事！首先，付钱买你的想法，然后雇别人来写，这样更便宜。其次，你打算怎么办？什么也做不了。记住，他们有好几层楼的律师。不要生活在偏执狂的土地上。这不是一个健康的地方。第三，如果他们哪怕有一瞬间感觉到一丝偏执的气息，钢筋安全门就会关上，你再也打不到他们的电话了。他们逃离偏执狂就像罗得逃离所多玛一样。

This one I truly do not get. An inordinate proportion of beginning writers are terrified someone is going to steal their idea. People in Hollywood don’t have time to steal your story! First, it’s cheaper to pay you off for your idea and hire someone else to write it. Second, what are you going to do about it? Nothing. Remember, they have floors of attorneys. Don’t live in the Land of Paranoia. It’s not a healthy place to be. Third, if they even for a moment get the ghost of a whiff of paranoia, a reinforced steel security gate will drop closed and you will never, ever get them on the phone again. They run from paranoia like Lot leaving Sodom.

所以他们窃取了你的创意？再想一个吧。如果你只有一个好创意，那你为什么还要做这个行业？

So they steal your idea? Come up with another one. If you’ve only got one good idea, why are you in this business?

 

如果他们想知道你的其他想法，就告诉他们。

如果他们想读你的剧本，就把剧本给他们。

让他们很容易喜欢你。

让他们很容易帮助你。

如果你紧张、怪异或神秘，他会说他需要再来一杯酒，礼貌地转过身去，然后，就像凯撒·索泽一样，他就走了。

不要提到你的律师。

不要说你已经在编剧协会登记了。

不要在授予他们阅读剧本的权利之前要求他们签署免责声明。他们会笑着说不，然后飞到阿斯彭，再也不会想起你。

不要将你的剧本复印到深黄色的纸上，这样他们就无法复印。

不要告诉他们，一家制片厂偷了你的最后一份规格，你要起诉他们。

If they want to know your other ideas, tell them.

If they want to read your script, give it to them.

Make it easy for them to like you.

Make it easy for them to help you.

If you are twitchy or weird or secretive, he will say he needs a refill on his wine, politely turn away, and, like Kaiser Soze, he is gone.

Do not mention your attorney.

Do not say you’ve registered it at the Writers Guild.

Do not ask them to sign a release before you’ll grant them the right to read your script. They’ll smile, say no, jet off to Aspen, and never think of you again.

Do not photocopy your screenplay onto dark yellow paper to make it impossible for them to Xerox.

Don’t tell them a studio stole your last spec and you’re suing.

谁会想和一个正在与制片厂打官司的偏执狂一起工作呢？没人会。

Who wants to work with a paranoiac who’s in a lawsuit with a studio? Nobody.

不要浪费时间想办法阻止他们窃取你的剧本，而是花时间重写剧本。

Instead of wasting time trying to figure out a way to keep them from stealing your screenplay, invest that time in a rewrite.

不要表现得偏执。偏执是可以的，只是不要让任何人知道！一定要向工会注册你的剧本（www.wga.org，如果你住在密西西比河以东，www.wgaeast.org）。我强烈建议你为你的剧本撰写文案（www.copyright.gov）。如果你同时做这两件事，你将损失约 50 美元。

Do not act paranoid. It’s okay to be paranoid, just don’t let anybody know! Do register your script with the Guild (www.wga.org or, if you live east of the Mississippi, www.wgaeast.org). I highly recommend copywriting your screenplay (www.copyright.gov). You’ll be out about $50 if you do both.

你可能认为有人窃取了你的想法，但这种可能性很小。我写过一个试播电视片，讲述夏洛克·福尔摩斯的孙子和华生医生的孙女在华盛顿特区联手当侦探的故事。一年后，我在电视上看到了这个故事。我是否认为有人窃取了我的想法？我并不这么认为。因为，第一，我并不偏执，第二，我从未向任何人展示过我的剧本。

You may think someone stole your idea, but it’s quite unlikely. I wrote a spec TV pilot about Sherlock Holmes’ grandson and Dr. Watson’s granddaughter teaming up as detectives in Washington, D.C. A year later, I saw that story on the air. Did I think someone had stolen my idea? I did not. Because, one, I am not paranoid, and two, I had never shown anyone my script.

业务是有周期的。一位开发主管曾经告诉我：“我已经五年或十年没看过马戏电影了。一部都没有。突然间，上周，三部马戏电影剧本就出现在我的桌子上。”

The business works in cycles. A development executive once told me: “I haven’t seen a circus movie in five or ten years. Not one. All of a sudden, last week, three circus screenplays landed on my desk.”

时不时地，创意会被窃取。谷歌搜索“Art Buchwald”和“ Coming To America ”。但这种情况发生的频率还不足以让你感到不安！想要阅读你的剧本的人会窃取它的可能性远小于如果你假装他们会窃取它，想要阅读你的剧本的人会拼命逃跑的可能性。

From time to time, ideas do get stolen. Google “Art Buchwald” and “Coming To America.” But it doesn’t happen often enough for you to get your knickers in a twist! The chance that the person who wants to read your screenplay is going to steal it is FAR more remote than the chance the person who wants to read your screenplay is going to run like hell if you act like they might steal it.

不相信吗？下次你和制片人或电影公司高管交谈时，他们想阅读你的剧本（并且到目前为止，您参与过多少次这样的对话？），像 Travis Bickle 那样对他们大发雷霆，拿出释放表并要求他们签字。看看会发生什么。

Don’t believe me? Next time you get in conversation with a producer or studio executive who wants to read your screenplay (and how many of those conversations have you been in up to now?), go all Travis Bickle on them, whip out a release form and demand they sign it. See what happens.

95.你不懂汉隆剃刀原理！

95. You don’t understand Hanlon’s Razor!

 

你为什么要这么做？你从来没听说过。

Why should you? You’ve never heard it.

 

“永远不要把可以用愚蠢充分解释的事情归咎于恶意。”

汉隆剃刀

“Never attribute to malice that which can be adequately explained by stupidity.”

Hanlon’s Razor

这在娱乐行业重要吗？如果你想进入娱乐行业，这很重要。

Does this matter in the entertainment industry? It matters if you’re trying to get into the entertainment industry.

您将给不认识您的人发送电子邮件、写信和打电话，希望他们会回电或阅读您的剧本并回复您。这将比您想象的要花更长的时间。更长的时间。您会怀疑他们不喜欢您，或者决定永远不给您打电话，或者怀疑您自尊心低落时遇到的一百个邪恶小精灵中的任何一个。您会认为他们心怀恶意，您会担心他们生您的气或讨厌您的剧本或忙着窃取您的想法。

You’re going to be emailing and writing and calling people who do not know you, hoping they will return your call or read your script and get back to you. It’s going to take longer than you thought it would. Eons longer. You’ll suspect they don’t like you, or have decided never to call you, or any of a hundred wicked gremlins that your low self esteem visits upon you. You will assume malice and you will fear they are mad at you or hate your script or are busy stealing your idea.

而有 99% 又 44/100 的时间，你都会是错的。

And 99 and 44/100ths percent of the time, you will be wrong.

如果你不考虑他们可能疯了（就发生在我朋友的经纪人身上），或者放错了你的电话号码，或者他们的飞机坠毁了，剧本烧毁了（就发生在我身上！），或者，再次，无数个无能的原因——如果你生气地写信或打电话给他们，说“你这个混蛋为什么不看我的剧本？！”那么他们会永远把你从他们的名单上划掉。

If you don’t consider the possibility that they may have lost their mind (happened to a friend’s agent) or mislaid your phone number or their plane crashed and the script burned up in it (happened to me!) or, again, any of an unlimited number of reasons that incompetence ruled the day — if you write or call them up angry, and say, “Why haven’t you read my script, you jerk?!” then they’re going to scratch you off their list forever.

您将成为不死之人，并且再也无法获得他们的青睐。因此，请耐心对待那些您希望听到他们消息的劳累过度的人——总有充分的理由，通常是愚蠢的理由，导致某人不回复您。

You will become one of the undead and you will never find your way back in their good graces. So be patient with the overworked people you wish to hear from — there can always be a perfectly good reason, stupidity, generally, why someone isn’t getting back to you.

要友善。要有耐心。不要破坏关系。

Be nice. Be patient. Never burn a bridge.

他们可能没有收到你的电子邮件。冷静一下。

They may not have gotten your email. Chill.

96. 你不知道 Natalie Merchant 和 Patti Smith 之间的区别！

96. You don’t know the difference between Natalie Merchant and Patti Smith!

 

无论您在哪里下载或购买音乐，都可以获得 10,000 Maniacs 和 Patti Smith 的“Because the Night”。10,000 Maniacs — MTV Unplugged。Patti Smith Group — 复活节。

Go wherever you download or buy music and get “Because the Night” by both 10,000 Maniacs and Patti Smith. 10,000 Maniacs — MTV Unplugged. Patti Smith Group — Easter.

先听听《10,000 Maniacs》的版本。太棒了。一首很棒的歌曲，令人难以置信的音乐，以及 Merchant 女士极具感染力的表演。想象一下她演绎的这首歌成为你的剧本。在去年写的所有剧本中排名前 5%！也许是前 2%！很棒的对话、故事、人物塑造。一切都是一流的。

Listen to the 10,000 Maniacs version first. It’s fantastic. A great song, incredible music, and a hugely powerful performance by Ms. Merchant. Imagine her rendition of the song to be your screenplay. In the top 5% of all scripts written last year! Maybe the top 2%! Great dialogue, story, characterization. Everything is top drawer all the way.

现在，放上 Patti Smith 的 CD。把音量调大。按下“播放”，等一下，然后祈祷宽恕。一旦她开始表演，她的表演就如此生硬，如此痛苦，如此冷酷，相比之下，Natalie Merchant 远远落后。可怕的是，两者之间的差异是如此之小。两张唱片听起来几乎一模一样，但差异却令人震惊。与 Patti Smith 声音的强烈强度相比，Natalie Merchant 的声音听起来就像温水。

Now, put in the Patti Smith CD. Turn it up loud. Press “Play,” hang on, and pray for mercy. Once she gets that sucker rolling, her performance is so raw, so painfully steel-edged, that, in comparison, Natalie Merchant is a distant also-ran. The scary part is how small the difference is. Both records sound almost precisely the same, but the difference is stunning. Compared to Patti Smith’s voice’s shearing intensity, Natalie Merchant’s seems like lukewarm tap water.

回到剧本的话题：《因为那一夜》两个版本之间存在着细微但巨大的差异，就像一个写出来的、非常好的剧本和一个拍出来的剧本之间的差异。

Going back to screenplays: the slight but gigantic difference between the two versions of “Because the Night” is like the difference between a screenplay that gets written, and is really good, and one that gets made.

 

“当似乎什么都帮不上忙时，我会去看一个石匠，他用锤子敲打石头，也许一百次，石头上却连一条裂缝都没有。然而，在第一百零一次敲击之后，石头就裂成了两半，我知道这不是那一次敲击造成的，而是之前发生的所有事情造成的。”

雅各布·A·里斯

“When nothing seems to help, I go and look at a stone-cutter hammering away at his rock perhaps a hundred times without as much as a crack showing in it. Yet at the hundred and first blow it would split in two, and I know it was not that blow that did it, but all that had gone before together.”

Jacob A. Riis

在寄出剧本之前，你的剧本必须达到帕蒂·史密斯的水平。遗憾的是，如果你的水平只有娜塔莉·麦钱特，你就无法获得第一垒。

Before you send it out, your script has to be at the Patti Smith level. Sad to say, if you’re only at Natalie Merchant, you won’t get to first base.

97. 你不知道你可以通过写作摆脱困境！

97. You don’t know you can write your way out of a hole!

 

无论您的剧本有多么不符合 Zaillian 风格，您都可以保存它！

No matter how un-Zaillian-esque your screenplay may be, you can save it!

 

“如果我有一个优点，那可能就是坚持不懈。”

布鲁斯·斯普林斯汀

“If I have a good trait, it’s probably relentlessness.”

Bruce Springsteen

对于初学写作的人来说，当你在剧本上遇到麻烦时，很难知道你能否修复它。这就像被你的初恋男友抛弃一样。你的心碎了，你的思想崩溃了，你以为未来只有黑暗、死亡、沮丧和无尽的痛苦。最终，你学会了你可以克服那个白痴，同样，作为一名作家，你会明白你可以重写剧本，直到你解决了它的问题。

For the beginning writer, when you get into trouble with a screenplay it’s difficult to know that you can fix it. It’s like being dumped by your very first boyfriend. Your heart was broken, your mind was shattered and you thought the future held only blackness, death, depression and endless agony. Eventually you learned you could get over that cretin, and, similarly, as a writer, you will come to understand you can rewrite a script until you solve its problems.

我卖出的第一个宣传就是一个很好的例子。那时候，像我这样的傻瓜，三页纸就能卖出东西。如果你能给好莱坞三页非常好的宣传，他们就能给你足够的钱让你生活一年！可惜，那些日子已经一去不复返了。

The first pitch I ever sold is a great example. This was back when a schmo like me could sell something based on three pages. Hollywood would give you enough money to live on for a year if you gave them three really good pages! Sadly, those days are long gone.

不管怎样，我写了三页精彩的剧本。我的经纪人把它们寄了出去。一位好莱坞大牌制片人很喜欢这些剧本，于是我来到城里和他一起为工作室做宣传。飞机在星期六早上降落，我打车去了他的办公室。他和他的助手和我整个周末都在工作。基本上，他一直在就这个故事对我进行猛烈抨击。猛烈抨击，猛烈抨击，猛烈抨击。不幸的是，他不理解一个初学写作、心存恐惧的作家的心态，在我走进房间五分钟后，他就让我感觉自己不适合这份工作。

Anyway, I wrote three killer pages. My agent sent them out. A big-time Hollywood producer loved them, and I came to town to work with him on a pitch to take to the studio. The plane landed on Saturday morning and I took a cab to his office. He and his assistant and I worked and worked all weekend long. Basically, he beat me up about the story. Pounding, pounding, pounding. Unfortunately for me, he did not understand the mindset of a beginning, terrified writer, and starting five minutes after I walked into the room, he made me feel like I was the wrong guy for the job.

起草大纲的过程非常痛苦，因为我觉得他觉得我永远无法完成。周一我们去工作室推销时，他开始讲述我们上周末编好的故事，令我惊讶的是，他讲故事的能力竟然弱爆了。他太糟糕了！他讲了五句话后，我意识到，除非有人站出来，否则这件事情会一败涂地。所以，我接手了推销工作。我是一个相当不错的讲故事的人，部分原因是我来自南方，主要原因是我一生都在讲故事。我顺利完成了推销，工作室接受了我的想法，我开始写剧本。

Working on the outline was agony because I felt like he thought I was never going to be able to deliver. When we went to the studio on Monday to pitch, he started to tell the story we had worked out over the weekend, and much to my amazed surprise, he couldn’t tell a story to save his life. He was Godawful! After he said about five sentences, I realized that this thing was going in the toilet unless someone stepped up to the plate. So, I took over the pitch. I’m a pretty good storyteller, partially because I’m from the South, and mostly because I’ve been telling stories my entire life. I sailed through the pitch, the studio bought my idea, and I started to write the screenplay.

开发过程并不轻松，剧本变成了一团黏糊糊的烂摊子。我真是郁闷至极。最后我陷入了写作瓶颈。我写完一个句子，看着它，然后想，“他不会喜欢这个的。”然后我就把这个句子删掉了。这太可怕了——这是我写作生涯中最低谷。我离开电脑，两天没工作，然后我回来，坐下来，咬紧牙关，决定，“管他呢，我不在乎他怎么想”，然后我继续写下去。

The development process was not easy, and the script turned into a sticky, gooey mess. Man, was I depressed. I ended up getting writer’s block. I would write a sentence, look at it, and think, “He wouldn’t like this.” And I would erase the sentence. It was ghastly — the lowest point I have ever been in my writing career. I pushed away from the computer, didn’t work for two days, and then I came back, sat down, gritted my teeth and decided, “Screw him, I don’t care what he thinks,” and I pressed on.

一旦我决定不再关心，情况就好多了。我放松了。如果我把事情搞砸了，我会努力解决它，直到问题解决。

Once I decided I didn’t care any more, it got better. I loosened up. If I messed something up, I worked on it until I solved the problem.

我当时不知道但现在我知道的是，无论你作为一名作家陷入了多深的困境，如果你不断努力、不断探索，最终你会通过写文章走出困境，解决问题。

What I did not know then that I do know now is that, no matter how deep a hole you put yourself in as a writer, if you keep pushing and prodding and poking, eventually you’ll write your way out of the hole, and solve the problem.

重要的是不要放弃。不要因为困难就放弃写作。不要因为在第二幕中遇到困难就放弃。不要因为把天才的想法搞砸了就停下来。如果你得到了报酬，你确实可以保留这笔钱，不管你把它搞得多么糟糕，但要继续下去。知道每个编剧都会遇到问题，每个剧本在某个时候都会变成泥潭，这是很有帮助的，但你必须完成它。如果这是你的如果你写了第一个剧本而没有完成它，你最终会得到一堆半成品剧本。

What’s important is that you don’t abandon ship. Don’t quit writing something just because it’s difficult. Don’t bail out just because you run into turbulence in the middle of Act II. Don’t stop just because you’ve made a mess of your genius idea. If you’re getting paid, you do get to keep the money, no matter what a hash you make of it, but keep on going.
