It is helpful to know that every screenwriter has problems, that every script becomes a quagmire at some point, but you have to finish it. If this is your first script and you don’t finish it, you’re going to end up with a bunch of half-written screenplays lying around.

不断地在脑子里思考这个问题。和朋友交流。阅读有关编剧的书籍。观看与你的电影相似的电影。尽你所能解决你的问题，在投入足够的时间和铅笔芯后，你就会解决问题。如果你放弃它，问题将永远无法解决，你将有一个被遗弃的剧本放在架子上看着你，做鬼脸，对你竖中指。

Keep turning the problem over in your head. Talk to friends. Read books about screenwriting. See movies that are like your movie. Do anything you can to solve your problem and, after investing enough time and pencil lead, you will solve your problem. If you abandon it, the problem will never be solved, and you’ll have an abandoned screenplay sitting there on the shelf looking at you, making faces, and giving you the finger.

没有什么比一堆未完成的剧本更糟糕的了。尤其是当他们对你竖中指的时候。

There are few things worse than a pile of unfinished screenplays. Especially if they are giving you the finger.

98. 你不知道如何找经纪人！

98. You don’t know how to get an agent!

 

其他人也同样如此。

Neither does anybody else.

在写作研讨会上，当讲到“我怎样才能找到经纪人？”这个问题时，讲台上的人们只是举起手抱怨。

At seminars about writing, when they get to the “how can I get an agent?” question, the people on the podium just throw up their hands and moan.

这有点像“我如何才能找到女朋友？”这个严峻的难题。如果你没有女朋友，你会像毕加索一样忧郁，懒散地四处走动，好像你希望被打脸一样。你很痛苦。你非常需要一个女朋友。那么当你遇到那个对的人时会发生什么？她嗅到了绝望的气息，跑向地平线。真的吗？当你有女朋友，她喜欢你的辣椒时，你会飘飘然。当然，你还是前一周的那个人，只是现在，女人会向你走来，把电话号码塞进你的口袋，在眼皮上写上“我爱你”。这也是真的。

It’s a bit like the grim “how do I get a girlfriend?” conundrum. If you don’t have a girlfriend, you’re blue as Picasso and slouching around like you expect to be struck in the face. You’re miserable. You need a girlfriend, badly. So what happens when you meet the Right One? She smells desperation and runs for the horizon. True? When you’ve got a girlfriend, and she digs your chili, you’re walking on air. Of course, you’re the same guy you were the week before, only now, women are coming up to you, shoving phone numbers in your pocket and writing “I love you” on their eyelids. Also true.

拍电影比找经纪人容易多了。这就是为什么我提倡拍自己的电影，对经纪人说“呸！”。一旦你拍了自己的电影，好莱坞就会像拿破仑追击俄罗斯一样向你进军。

Getting a movie made seems like cake compared to getting an agent. Which is why I advocate making your OWN movie and saying, “Pah!” to the agent machine. Once you’ve made your own film, Hollywood will march on you like Napoleon went after Russia.

但现在，还要考虑找经纪人的事情。

But for now, a bit about getting an agent.

首先，写几个非常棒的剧本。我指的不是那些很好的剧本。我指的是那些让人们说“天哪，这太棒了！我能把它给我的朋友吗？他认识一个在 UTA 街对面的车身修理厂打扫地板的人？求求你，求求你，求求你？”

First, write a couple of FANTASTIC scripts. I don’t mean good ones, either. I mean scripts where people say, “Holy cow, this is amazing! Can I give it to my friend who knows someone who sweeps the floor of the body shop across the street from UTA? Please, please, please?”

UTA 对面没有车身修理厂，不过你明白我的意思。

There’s not a body shop across from UTA, but you get my drift.

我不得不说，询问信对我来说从来没用过。一次也没有。我有过的经纪人比我愿意承认的还要多。每一个都是我的朋友或朋友的伙伴拿着枪指着经纪人的脑袋说：“读读这家伙的作品。你会感谢我的。他能干。”有一次，在我拍完两部电影后，我正在寻找一位新经纪人。我卖掉了宣传材料，卖掉了试拍材料，当时我正在担任全国有线电视连续剧的监制。我有非常棒的剧本样本。但这并不重要，因为到那时，我已经用尽了一切办法让某人把剧本交给经纪人。换句话说：我的朋友们都厌倦了我。

I hate to say, the query letter thing has never worked for me. Not once. And I’ve had more agents than I care to admit. Every one came from some friend or buddy of a friend holding a gun to an agent’s head and saying, “Read this guy’s stuff. You’ll thank me. He walks on water.” Once, after I’d had two films produced, I was looking for a new agent. I’d sold pitches, sold spec material, and right then was supervising producer on a national cable television series. I had killer writing samples. Not that it mattered, because, by that time, I’d exhausted every avenue to get someone to hand an agent a script. Translation: my friends were sick of me.

于是我尝试了询问信的方法。我花了一周时间写了一封，寄出了四十封。一位助理给我回了电话。他说：“你的信是她考虑本月回电的三封信之一。”那位经纪人一年回复十二封询问信！我再也没有收到她的消息。

So I tried the query letter approach. Spent a week writing one and sent out forty of the little suckers. One assistant called me back. He said, “Your letter is one of three she’s considering to be the one she calls back this month.” That agent answers twelve query letters a year! I never heard from her again.

我一直等到有了一些不讨厌我的新朋友，然后才找了一位新经纪人。

I waited until I had some new friends who weren’t sick of me. Then I got a new agent.

 

与了解经纪人的人交朋友。这不容易。永远不要花钱请人阅读你的材料（批评是另一回事）。即使在大型经纪公司，新经纪人也会阅读新材料。阅读交易。看看谁刚刚晋升为经纪人。

在你寄出信之前，先找一个名字。

你的信必须介绍你自己，介绍材料。它必须说明你是谁，你想卖什么。讲一点关于剧本的内容。

不要写标准的信。吸引他们的眼球。要有创意。

把它寄给大大小小的公司。精品公司和大公司。当然，大经纪公司可以打包。当然，在大经纪公司，作家会迷失方向。

参加比赛。赢或接近赢。

给全国的每一位大学电影制作教授打电话，询问他们是否有学生担任经纪人助理。把你的东西寄给他们。

搬到洛杉矶，通过你的爱好认识新朋友。

Make friends with people who know agents. Not easy to do. Never pay to have your material read (critiqued is another matter). Even in large agencies, new agents are the ones who will read new material. Read the trades. See who has just gotten promoted to agent.

Before you send the letter, get a name to send it to.

Your letter must introduce you, and introduce the material. It has to tell about who you are and what you’re trying to sell. Tell a little bit about the script.

Don’t do a standard letter. Catch their eye. Be creative.

Send it out to large and small. Boutique and big. Of course, big agencies can package. Of course, at a big agency, writers get lost.

Enter contests. Win or come close.

Call every college filmmaking professor in the country and ask if they have any students who are agents’ assistants. Send your stuff to them.

Move to Los Angeles and meet people through your hobbies.

这是值得买本书的建议。如果你有幸遇到经纪人、制片人或某个“真实”的人，不要告诉他们你的事。

Here is advice worth the price of this book. If you ever are fortunate enough to meet agents or producers or someone “real,” DO NOT TELL THEM ABOUT YOUR STUFF.

这听起来有悖常理，但请忍耐一下。

That sounds counterintuitive, but bear with me.

与他们之前遇到的五十或三百人有所不同！谈论模型铁路或您对说法语的兴趣。给他们讲一个非常有趣的笑话。询问他们抚养孩子的问题。谈论您读过的最后一本好书。问他们为什么约翰·休斯不再拍电影了。谈论除了您辉煌的职业生涯、您令人眼花缭乱的想法和您该死的剧本之外的任何事情。

Be different from the last fifty or three hundred people they met! Talk about model railroading or your interest in speaking French. Tell them a killingly funny joke. Ask about their problems raising their children. Talk about the last good book you read. Ask them why John Hughes doesn’t make movies any more. Talk about anything OTHER than your illustrious career and your dazzling ideas and your damn screenplay.

我在洛杉矶有一个朋友，他是一名经理。很久以前，在我知道我现在知道的那一点点事情之前，我和他共进晚餐。我说：“嘿，昨晚我见到了史蒂夫·马丁的律师。”他绝望地盯着我，脸上带着恐惧。“你没有让他读你的剧本，是吗？”我想，“这难道不是我应该做的吗？”我点了点头，我的朋友垂下了头，慢慢地把脸埋在手中，叹了口气。

I have a friend in Los Angeles, a manager. Long ago, before I knew the little bit I know now, I was having dinner with him. I said, “Hey, last night, I met Steve Martin’s attorney.” He stared at me with despair laced with horror. “You didn’t ask him to read your script, did you?” I thought, “Isn’t that what I’m supposed to do?” I nodded and my friend sagged, slowly put his face in his hands, and sighed.

我再也没有和那位律师说话。如果我没有把剧本强行塞给他，而是给那家伙讲了一个下流的笑话，也许他会请我去吃午饭。

I never spoke to the lawyer again. If, instead of trying to shove a script at him, I’d told the guy a filthy joke, maybe he’d have taken me to lunch.

他们不想读你的东西。所以，如果你在研讨会上遇到某人，问问他们是否需要办事，因为你有车。带他们去药店。或者古董商场。或者主动请他们喝咖啡。发誓你不会向他们推销，你可能会被他们逗笑。让他们喜欢你，然后让他们要求阅读你的东西。

They don’t want to read your stuff. So, if you meet someone at a seminar, ask, since you’ve got a car, if they need to run an errand. Take them to the drugstore. Or an antique mall. Or offer to get them coffee. Swear you won’t pitch them and you’ll probably get a laugh. Make them like YOU and then let them ask to read your stuff.

可能需要一年的时间。

It may take a year.

但如果他们问你，他们就会读。

But, if they ask you, they’ll read it.

99. 当他们说喜欢它时，你会很兴奋！

99. You get excited when they say they like it!

 

好莱坞是让你因鼓励而死的地方。没有人，没有人想惹你生气，以防你成为下一个大人物。因此，没有人会告诉你你的剧本很烂。也许除了我。但可能不会。

Hollywood is where you go to die from encouragement. Nobody, but nobody, wants to make you angry in case you turn out to be the Next Big Thing. Consequently, no one is going to tell you your script sucks. Except, maybe, me. But probably not.

有两种方法可以知道某人喜欢你的作品。两种，而且只有两种。除此之外，他们还对你赞不绝口。

There are two ways to know someone likes your work. Two and only two. Anything else, they’re shining you on.

 

1) 支票。呃。2

) 如果他们把你的剧本给了别人。

1) A check. Duuh.

2) If they give your script to someone else.

他们可以说他们喜欢它：

They can say they liked it:

 

“我喜欢你的剧本。我不骗你。太棒了！”

“这是我今年读过的最好的剧本。”

“你真是个作家。”

“这太棒了。”

“我们正在开发类似的剧本，但我很想看你的下一部作品。”

“情节很棒。动作场面很棒。你的对话写得很棒。”

“我的女朋友很喜欢。”

“I loved your screenplay. I kid you not. It’s fantastic!”

“Best script I’ve read this year.”

“You are a real writer.”

“This is amazing.”

“We’ve got something like this in development, but I’d love to see your next one.”

“Wonderful plotting. Great action scenes. You write killer dialogue.”

“My girlfriend loved it.”

...但这些美好的情感毫无意义。他们可能喜欢它。他们可能讨厌它。你永远不会知道。

...but these lovely sentiments mean precisely nothing. They may have loved it. They may have hated it. You’ll never, ever know.

这不是因为他们是骗子。嗯，不一定。他们不想伤害你的感情。他们想结束这场没有冲突的对话。谁能责怪他们呢？他们不是来给你笔记的。你给了他们一个剧本让他们读。他们不喜欢。也许他们确实喜欢，但他们不想买账。故事结束。

It’s not because they’re liars. Well, not necessarily. They don’t want to hurt your feelings. They want to get out of the conversation conflict-free. Who can blame them? They are not there to give you notes. You gave them a script to read. They didn’t like it. Maybe they did like it, but they don’t want to buy it. End of story.

这是一条漫长而坎坷的路。不要因为可能一无所获而过于兴奋。当你得到好消息时，好好享受吧。这个行业很少有高潮，你应该抓住机会。然而，不要开始告诉每个人你的好消息，除非它真的可靠。

This is a long and deeply rutted road. It doesn’t do to get too excited over what will likely turn out to be nothing. When you get good news, enjoy it. There are few highs in this business, and you should take the ones that come your way. However, don’t start telling everyone your good news, unless it’s really solid.

仅仅因为“大明星先生正在阅读它”并不意味着你会得到支票。你可以等几个月，然后才发现他们没有读过它就通过了。

Just because “Mr. Big Star is reading it” doesn’t mean you’re going to get a check. You can wait months on someone, and then realize they passed without ever reading it.

让你的想象力随心所欲并不是一个好主意。继续你的日常工作。继续考虑你的家人和重要的事情。如果好事会发生，那它就会发生，但不会很快发生。你越是因一点好消息而兴奋不已，当那点快乐变成糟粕时，你和你的家人就越要忍受失望。而且，很可能所有的快乐都会变成糟粕。欢迎来到失望之城。

It’s not a good idea to let your imagination run away with you. Keep your day job. Keep thinking about your family and what’s important. If something good is going to happen, it’s going to happen, but no time soon. The more you bounce off four walls, all revved up because of a tiny piece of good news, the more disappointment you and yours will have to endure when that bit of joy turns out to be dross. And, like as not, all joy will end as dross. Welcome to Disappointmentville.

 

制片人（激动）：我们离电影只有一步之遥了！

我（自言自语）：是的，我离摩纳哥公主卡洛琳的口交也只有一步之遥了。

Producer (excited): We’re one “yes” away from a movie!

Me (to myself): Yeah, and I’m one “yes” away from a blow job from Princess Caroline of Monaco.

这是令人失望的行业。这就是游戏的本质。接受它并意识到它，不要让自己太沉迷其中。如果发生了一些好事，准备好利用它，但请不要每天都兴奋不已，因为一些伟大的事情可能即将发生。只有当它真的发生时，你才允许发疯。

It’s a disappointing business. That’s the nature of the game. Embrace that and be aware of it and don’t let yourself get too wrapped up in it. If something swell happens, be ready to capitalize on it, but please don’t spend all day every day all thrilled because something great may be about to happen. Only when it REALLY DOES HAPPEN are you allowed to go nutso.

直到你获得批准，或第一天担任主要摄影，或获得艾美奖提名，请保持兴奋。这有点悲观，但从长远来看，这对你的灵魂和你周围人的理智都有好处。

Until you get a big green light, or a first day of principal photography, or an Emmy nomination, keep your excitement on simmer. It’s a bit pessimistic, but in the long run, it’s better for your soul and for the sanity of those around you.

保持冷静。有时候，这并不容易。

Be cool. Sometimes, it’s not easy.

100. 你把希望与否认混淆了！

100. You’re confusing hope with denial!

 

在某个时刻，你必须问自己是否应该放弃。

At some point, you must ask yourself if you should quit.

最后，在你一次又一次被拒绝之后，你必须意识到你不会写剧本。很多人都不会写剧本，这没什么可耻的。如果一个人是个好作家，他们很快就会写出来。娱乐业是一个残酷的行业龙会把你烧成灰烬，如果你允许的话。试图进来的人排成一条长队，门很小。如果你不能想办法缩小自己以适应那扇门，你就永远进不去。不幸的是，没有导游。这就像爱丽丝梦游仙境，但没有饼干叫你吃。早上早起，一周多起几天，都不能让你得到你想要的东西。最后，你必须决定这永远不会奏效。

Finally, after you’ve been rejected and rejected and rejected, you’re going to have to realize you can’t write a screenplay. A lot of people can’t; there is no shame in it. If someone is a good writer, they get it quickly. The entertainment business is a cruel dragon and will burn you to a crisp if you allow it to. The line of people trying to get in is endless; the doorway, tiny. If you can’t figure out a way to shrink yourself down to fit in that door, you’ll never get through. Unfortunately, there is no tour guide. It’s like Alice in Wonderland without the cookie asking you to eat it. Waking up earlier in the morning, more days a week, will not get you what you want. Finally, you have to decide this is not going to work, ever.

我无法回答你是怎么想出来的。你什么时候划清界限，什么时候意识到洛杉矶人的鼓励是在浪费你宝贵而无可替代的时间？

How you figure that out is something I can’t answer. When do you draw the line, when do you realize that encouragement from people in Los Angeles is a waste of your precious and irreplaceable time?

这是一门手艺；你可以做得更好，但有一天你必须问自己，“这有用吗？那些给我材料的人是在帮助我做些什么，还是他们只是拍拍我的头说，‘非常好，我很想看看你的下一个作品’？”

It is a craft; you can get better at it, but someday you must ask yourself, “Is this working or not? Are the people I am giving my material to helping me do something with it, or are they just patting me on the head saying, ‘Very nice, I’d love to see your next effort’?”

虽然不写剧本或不在好莱坞取得成功可能是难以想象的，但一次又一次的失败，或一次又一次的鼓励，最终意味着你不会取得任何成就。你应该坐下来认真看看人们对你的材料说了什么——或者，他们没有告诉你什么。

While it may be unimaginable to consider not writing screenplays or not being a success in Hollywood, failure after failure after failure, or encouragement after encouragement after encouragement, finally means you’re not going to get anywhere. You owe it to yourself to sit down and take a long hard look at what people are telling you about your material — or, what they are not telling you.

在某些时候，你可能必须放手。

At some point, you may have to let it go.

淡出

Fading Out

 

嗯，这很令人沮丧，不是吗？

Well, that was depressing, wasn’t it?

你花了那么多钱买了一本书，但最后那个人却告诉你放弃。

Pay all this money for a book, and right at the end the guy tells you to give up.

如果我能说服你戒烟，而且只收取这本书的费用，你就应该用我的名字给你的下一个儿子命名。

If I can convince you to quit, and only for the price of this book, you should name your next son after me.

你不想放弃？那就别放弃。但当周围的人都失去理智时，你要保持冷静。

You don’t want to quit? Then don’t. But keep your head when all about you are losing theirs.

 

“这里有数百万美元等着你去抢，而你唯一的竞争对手就是白痴。别让这事传出去。”编剧赫尔曼·J·曼凯维奇在 1926 年从好莱坞发给纽约本·赫克特的

电报中说道

“There are millions to be grabbed out here and your only competition is idiots. Don’t let this get around.”

screenwriter Herman J. Mankiewicz, in a 1926 cable

from Hollywood to Ben Hecht in New York

仅仅因为你在交易中看到有人以 50 万美元的价格出售他的第一部剧本，并不意味着你也会卖出你的第一部、第二部或第九部剧本。那可能是他的第九部剧本，但这是他试图出售的第一部剧本，他告诉所有人这是他的第一个剧本。也许这实际上是他的第一个剧本。我的第一个剧本已经制作完成了。这没什么大不了的，因为下一个剧本和接下来的五个剧本怎么办？你的主要工作是写一个剧本，然后写另一个剧本。之后再写一个。然后写更多。之后再写更多；在某个时候，你会学到你在做什么。

Just because you read in the trades about some guy selling his first script for $500,000 doesn’t mean you’re going to sell your first, or your second, or your ninth. That may have been his ninth screenplay, but the first he ever tried to sell and he’s telling everybody it’s the first script. Maybe it actually is his first script. My first script got made. Big deal, because what about the next one, and the next five? Your main job will be to write a script, and then write another script. And another after that. And then more. And then even more after that; and somewhere in there, you’re going to learn what you’re doing.

在你花费数千小时在打字机、笔记本和纸张、电脑上，或者向一位漂亮的秘书口述之后，你就会开始知道如何写剧本了。有些人一开始就知道如何写。他们很幸运。而有些人则需要时间。你可能是其中之一。但重要的是不要认为你的第一个剧本是天才，好莱坞是愚蠢的，因为他们不买它。写一个，然后写另一个。这是一个学习过程。我现在比刚开始的时候写得更好了。我提醒你：

After you put in thousands of hours at your typewriter, pad and paper, computer, or perhaps dictating to a comely secretary, you’re going to begin to know how to write a screenplay. Some people get it right off the bat. They’re lucky. With some people it takes time. You may be one of those people. But the important thing is to not think your first script is genius and that Hollywood is idiotic because they’re not buying it. Write one, and then write another one. It’s a learning process. I am a better writer now than I was when I started. I remind you:

 

“竞争太激烈了。”

Richard Sylbert

“The competition is grotesque.”

Richard Sylbert

最近，好莱坞变得困难多了。

Recently, Hollywood has gotten a lot more difficult.

制片厂不再像以前那样购买剧本。他们想要的是来自系列的电影。以前，他们会买一个剧本，然后围绕它制作一部电影。现在不行了。这个游戏风险太大。制片厂的业务完全由品牌知名度和营销驱动。

The studios don’t buy scripts like they used to. They want movies that come from franchises. Used to be, they’d buy a script and build a movie around it. No more. The game is too risky. The studio business is all driven by brand recognition and marketing.

剧本曾经是微电影的明星，但现在很少出现大卖。虽然有，但不像以前那样每个周末都有。此外，制片厂发现开发是一种糟糕的经济模式，因为作家即使没有报酬也会写作。现在，制片厂让制片人和作家完成工作并将作品交给他们，而无需花一分钱。

Screenplays used to be mini-movie stars, but big spec sales happen rarely now. It can happen, but not every weekend like before. Plus, the studios found out development was a bad economic model, as writers will write even if they’re not paid. Now, the studios let the producers and writers do the work and bring it to them, without spending a dime.

对于编剧来说，好处在于在制片厂体系之外还有一个独立的市场，你可以制作电影并在很多地方出售。

What’s good for writers is that there is an independent market outside the studio system, where you can make movies and sell them in lots of places.

对作家来说，糟糕的是制作人可以要求你免费工作。如果有人对你的想法感兴趣，并告诉你他们可能想制作它，如果你写了它，你会怎么做？

What’s bad for writers is that producers can get away with asking you to work for free. If someone’s interested in your idea and tells you that they may want to make it, if you write it, what will you do?

这是一个不可能的情况。

It’s an impossible situation.

但话说回来，这一直是不可能的，甚至比五年前达到的不可能程度还要不可能。“这比 20 年来的情况更糟！”“我很高兴现在没有试图闯入！”“哇哦，感谢上帝，我的妻子在钱中畅游！”每当喝得足够多时，你都会听到这样的话。

But, then again, it’s always been impossible, and is even more impossible than whatever previous level of impossibility it had managed to achieve five years ago. “It’s worse than it’s been in 20 years!” “I’m sure glad I’m not trying to break in now!” “Whooee, thank God my wife is swimming in money!” are lines you hear whenever enough alcohol has flowed.

因为这个过程非常残酷，所以如果你知道你为什么要进行这种愚蠢的写作，那将会大有帮助。当你完成“你的剧本糟透了！ ”清单并寄出剧本时，问问自己“我为什么要这样做？”你这样做是因为你被迫写作吗？你内心是否有故事想要写出来，却无法阻止自己写下来？还是你想发财并在好莱坞取得巨大成功？如果是后者，你的道路将更加艰难，因为即使你有天赋和好主意，也很难发财，也很难在好莱坞取得成功，因为你必须有运气。你必须在正确的停车场，在正确的时间遇到​​正确的人：

Because the process is so savage, it will help a lot if you know why you are pursuing this writing foolishness. As you finish the Your Screenplay Sucks! checklist and send your script off, ask yourself “Why am I doing this?” Are you doing it because you are compelled to write? Do you have stories in you bursting to get out and you can’t stop yourself from writing them down? Or are you trying to get rich and be a big success in Hollywood? If it’s the latter, you will have a more difficult road, because, even if you have talent and good ideas, it’s difficult to get rich and it’s difficult to be a success in Hollywood, because you have to get lucky. You have to be in that right parking lot and bump into the right person at just the right time:

 

“所以你只需要问自己一个问题。你觉得自己很幸运吗？朋克。”

肮脏的哈利

“So you just have to ask yourself just one question. Do you feel lucky? Punk.”

Dirty Harry

在军队里，人们说：“即使要付出生命，也要坚守高地。”在写作时，要时刻记住你的读者，即使要付出生命。你必须记住谁在阅读你的剧本，并把他们的观点放在你面前，不管怎样。话虽如此，因为这是半艺术性的事业，你仍然必须为自己写作。你必须取悦自己。这个行业太难了，你写的东西被制作出来的机会太小了，所以你必须在写作中享受乐趣。

In the Army they say: “Keep to the high ground even if it kills you.” In writing, keep your reader in mind, even if it kills you. You’ve got to remember who’s reading your script and keep their point of view right in front of you, no matter what. That said, because this is a semi-artistic endeavor, you still have to write for yourself. You have to please yourself. This business is so difficult, the chances of what you’re writing getting made are so small, that you have to enjoy yourself in the writing.

 

“在 39 岁时取得成功并意识到在失败中你正在慢慢建立你想要的生活，这很奇怪。”

艾丽丝·西伯德

“It’s very weird to succeed at 39 years old and realize that in the midst of your failure, you were slowly building the life that you wanted.”

Alice Sebold

听起来可能有点奇怪，如果你身无分文时觉得很有趣，那么兑现支票时也会觉得很有趣。如果你不喜欢没人喜欢你的东西，那么当一线明星答应出演你的电影时，你也不会感觉更好。

As odd as it may seem, if it’s fun when you’re broke, it’ll be fun when you’re cashing checks. If you don’t enjoy it when no one likes your stuff, you won’t feel any better when A-List Talent is committing to be in your movie.

然而，如果你写作是因为你必须写作，如果你写作是因为你是一名作家，那么创作剧本的行为可能就足够了。你很可能必须在你知道自己在做什么之前，写四五篇。也许多达十篇。但如果你享受这个过程，而不为最终的结果而烦恼：财富、名声，或者嫁给查理兹·塞隆，那么这对你来说可能是一件好事。

However; if you are writing because you have to write, if you are writing because you’re a writer, then the act of creating your screenplay may be enough. Chances are you’re going to have to write four or five of them before you know what you’re doing. Maybe as many as ten. But if you enjoy the process and don’t sweat the end result: riches, fame, or marrying Charlize Theron, then this could be a good thing for you.

最后再考虑一下：

Consider this for the last time:

 

“写一个能改变你生活的剧本。即使你卖不出去，至少你也改变了你的生活。”

约翰·特鲁比

“Write a screenplay that will change your life. If you don’t sell it, at least you will have changed your life.”

John Truby

所有写作老师和书籍都说“重要的是旅程”，这完全是真的。忽视这句名言会让你自食其果。写作是如此痛苦、如此令人心碎，而且需要很长时间，如果你在失败时没有过得开心，那么在成功时你也不会有任何乐趣。

All the stuff all your writing teachers and all the books say about “it’s the journey that matters” is totally true. Disregard that bon mot at your peril. Writing is so painful and so heartbreaking and takes so long, that if you aren’t having a wonderful time while you’re a failure, you won’t have any fun when you’re a success.

你需要享受写作。享受写作的每一个方面。抱怨写作有多难对你没有好处，只会让那些可能能够帮助你的人望而却步。没有人愿意和一个爱抱怨的人在一起。假设每个人都很艰难，然后继续努力。

You need to enjoy writing. Every aspect of it. Complaining about how tough it is does you no good and only puts off people who might be in a position to help you. No one wants to be around a whiner. Assume everybody’s got it tough and press on.

有一条看不见的线。线的一边是所有不从事电影行业的人。这可能包括你。有时，我也在那里。线的另一边是所有靠写作赚钱的人，他们与导演会面，获得素材选择权，让演员参与到他们的剧本中——其中一些人实际上在赚钱。

There is an invisible line out there. On one side is everyone NOT in the movie business. This probably includes you. From time to time, I’m there too. On the other side of the line, are all the people who are getting paid to write, having meetings with directors, getting material optioned, having actors attach to their screenplays — and some of those people are actually making money.

但是，你不必担心，他们和你一样不快乐、痛苦和有自杀倾向。与业内人士站在同一阵线并不会让你更快乐。毫无疑问，获得工作报酬是令人满意的，但它对你的心理的影响比你想象的要小。

But, never you fear, they are just as unhappy and miserable and suicidal as you are. Being on the side of the line with the people who are IN the business does not make you happier. Getting a paycheck for your work is satisfying, make no mistake about it, but it has less effect than you’d think on your psyche.

跨过界限进入电影行业并不会改变你与作品之间的根本关系。获得报酬并不会让你成为更好的作家。它不会让你更快乐。让一位著名导演参与你的剧本创作并不会让你的剧本比一周前更好在他读它之前。它会让其他人认为它更好，但这和你的灵魂有什么关系？

Stepping across the line INTO the movie business does not change the fundamental relationship you have with your work. Getting paid does not make you a better writer. It will not make you happier. Having a famous director attach himself to your screenplay does not make the script any better than it was a week before he read it. It makes other people think it’s better, but what has that got to do with your soul?

 

“你怎么知道一个剧本好不好？当汤姆·克鲁斯把它交给你并说，‘这是一个非常好的剧本。’”

匿名

“How do you know when a script is good? When Tom Cruise hands it to you and says, ‘This is a really good script.’ ”

Anonymous

如果汤姆·克鲁斯从未对你的剧本说过那些神奇的话语，你仍然需要想办法让自己感到满足。

If Tom Cruise never says those magic words about your script, you still have to figure out a way to be content.

 

“努力坚持下去。”

丹·乔治酋长在《逃亡者乔西·威尔士》中说道

“Endeavor to persevere.”

Chief Dan George in The Outlaw Josey Wales

无论你是否得到报酬，你都必须开心地坐在办公桌前、咖啡店里的笔记本电脑前或汽车前座上写作。否则，写作就毫无乐趣可言。得到报酬不应该影响你想做的事情。

You have to be happy at your desk, at that laptop in the coffee shop, or in the front seat of your car, doing your writing, whether you ever get paid or not. Otherwise, it is no fun. Getting paid should not affect what you want to do.

因为，如果这不是你想做的事，你为什么要做呢？

Because, if it’s not what you want to do, why are you doing it?

淡出。

FADE OUT.

 

结束 ​

THE END

 

请访问www.yourscreenplaysucks.com。书中有很多我找不到的有用内容！

Visit www.yourscreenplaysucks.com. Lots of useful stuff I couldn’t find room for in the book!

发送建议，我会将它们放在网上或书的第二版中。假设有的话。

Send suggestions and I’ll put them online or in the book’s second edition. Assuming there is one.

再次，我希望这本书能够对你有所帮助。

Again, I hope the book proves helpful.

关于

作者

About the

Author

 

威廉·M·埃克斯是美国编剧协会终身会员，他的剧本已被制作成三部故事片。埃克斯曾为米高梅、迪士尼和环球影业以及福克斯、NBC 和 ABC 电视网写过剧本。目前，他关于西贡沦陷的剧本正在由导演乔恩·阿米尔执导，由 Overture Studios 出品。他在范德堡大学教授编剧和电影制作。

A Lifetime Member of the Writers Guild of America, William M. Akers has had three feature films produced from his screenplays. Akers has written for MGM, Disney, and Universal Studios as well as Fox, NBC, and ABC networks. Currently, his script about the fall of Saigon is under option to Overture Studios with director Jon Amiel. He teaches screenwriting and filmmaking at Vanderbilt University.

埃克斯的法语还算不错，有两只乖巧的狗，还参加过《危险边缘！》的比赛。但他没有获胜。

Akers speaks reasonably decent French, has two well-behaved dogs, and was a Jeopardy! contestant. He didn’t win.

www.yourscreenplaysucks.com

www.yourscreenplaysucks.com
